Now that Yugoslavia is about to reopen to foreign trade with the lifting of sanctions, the country's economy should start to grow. A lot of money will be made, and the strike committee wants to be sure that the new rulers from Dos do not just reproduce the old system by imposing so-called democrats on factories. They have suffered too much from opportunism in the past. The same Mr Covic, who has become Dos's troubleshooter in urging workers to end the factory seizures, was the Socialist mayor of Belgrade and the third most senior man in Mr Milosevic's party until he switched sides in 1996. Yet during these past four years of "opposition" he has been able to remain managing director of a profitable company making tin cans. To prevent another round of musical chairs, the strike committee at Trudbenik wants a proper system of accountability in the company, credible financial public accounts and no further role for party politics in factory appointments. It will not just blindly put its faith in Dos. Mr Jelic was finishing his explanation when the door burst open and a red-faced man stormed in. "It's Dusan Djuraskovic, the managing director. He told us yesterday he would be on a business trip today," Mr Jelic explained while we watched in astonishment as he made his way to the head of the table, shouting all the way. He was too worked up to notice or mind the presence of foreign reporters. "No provocations, please. I'm here and I want peace and dignity," he bellowed, his anger undermining his presumably prepared opening words of conciliation. Then he launched a tirade of promises and threats, constantly pounding the table. "I don't recognise your crisis committee. But I'll sign your request for my resignation. Call the police. Call whomever you like. I'm ready to go because I want peace and quiet, and for the sake of my family. "We're so close to killing each other here. It needs just a little thing to set if off. You can see all the company's papers. There's nothing to hide. Sue me if you want to. But if I leave here, the company will lose. I'm running it well." He took a blank piece of paper, and signed it. "Fill in whatever you like," he shouted. As the tirade went on, workers started to whisper. "He must be drunk. He had to work up his courage somehow," one surmised. "Excuse me, who invited you here?" a worker shouted. That piece of lip set off a new torrent of words ending with the managing director's final threat: "I'll go off and see Covic tomorrow, and the other Dos leaders." "All right," someone shouted. "We'll be here in the building all night and we'll have reinforcements tomorrow from all the rest of the company's sections." webTitle: Smith defied advice on dome payout

fields.headline: Smith defied advice on dome payout
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Chris Smith, the culture secretary, and eight members of the millennium commission ordered a senior civil servant to pay £76m to keep the dome afloat after he had told them it was a waste of public money, the national audit office investigation into the £1bn fiasco will reveal next month.
fields.body:
Chris Smith, the culture secretary, and eight members of the millennium commission ordered a senior civil servant to pay £76m to keep the dome afloat after he had told them it was a waste of public money, the national audit office investigation into the £1bn fiasco will reveal next month.

The damning report will say that Mr Smith has twice had to issue a ministerial direction order forcing Mike O'Connor, director of the commission, to hand out cash to the "near bankrupt" attraction and raid national lottery programmes for the disadvantaged to prevent the dome going bust.

The disclosure is a fresh blow to Mr Smith's Whitehall image as "Teflon man", coming straight after the chaos over the handling by the lottery commission of the two rival bids to run the lottery.

The first order was made last May when Mr Smith, in his capacity as chairman of the commission, ordered £29m to be given to keep the dome going. The letter ordering the decision has been placed in the Commons library by David Davis, Tory chairman of the Commons public accounts committee.

The second - and until now secret - order for another £47m was made last month after Mr O'Connor made a second objection to spending the cash on the dome. The letter, sent in Mr Smith's name while he was in Australia, was to keep the dome afloat and pay new unexpected bills to "wind up" the attraction in December.

The draft report reveals that Mr Smith received unanimous support from his fellow commissioners to demand the money after they had examined whether to close down the dome. But they were told that millions of pounds of more cash would be needed to compensate donors, pay out redundancy to staff and meet creditors' bills.

They had also received a desperate appeal to pay the money from Lord Falconer, the dome minister, who was facing repeated calls for his resignation from the Tories.

The disclosure will put Mr Smith and his fellow commissioners in the firing line on November 20 when the public accounts committee summons the top civil servants responsible for the dome. Mr Smith will launch a strong defence of his decision - which he will emphasise was backed by every other member of the commission - should the Tories attack him for wasting public money. It is understood he will argue that he saved public money by not closing the dome because of the huge costs that would have entailed.

The other commissioners who will have to justify their actions include Michael Heseltine; Mo Mowlam; the former Times editor Simon Jenkins; Lord Dalkeith, a landowner; Lord Glentoran, chairman of Redland Tile; the TV presenter Floella Benjamin; Judith Donovan, the founder of a marketing company; and the broadcaster and writer Heather Couper.

webTitle: Xerox takes the axe to jobs

fields.headline: Xerox takes the axe to jobs
fields.trailText: Xerox, the photocopying group, succumbed to investor pressure yesterday and announced a drastic restructuring after a series of profits warnings.
fields.body:
Xerox, the photocopying group, succumbed to investor pressure yesterday and announced a drastic restructuring after a series of profits warnings.

Shares in the company fell 9% to $10.25, a 52-week low, in spite of a rally on Wall Street, after Xerox contradicted speculation that it was on the verge of filing for bankruptcy protection.

The group's stock market value has fallen by two-thirds since June after a flood of bad news. A profits warning last week was the company's fourth in little more than a year, prompting rumours that it was struggling under an unmanageable debt burden.

In a statement yesterday designed to ease concerns about its liquidity, Xerox revealed that it had negotiated a $7bn (£4.7bn) revolving credit facility which was available until 2002. Jeff Simek, a company spokesman, said Xerox was considering a significant restructuring exercise. Xerox employs 94,000 people around the world.

David Giroux, fund manager at T Rowe Price, one of the company's shareholders, said he expected significant job cuts to be announced as well as disposals to reduce costs. Analysts have suggested that as many as 20,000 jobs could be outsourced as a result of the shake-up, likely to be announced later this month with the group's third-quarter results.

Mr Giroux said investor patience was wearing thin and called for the company to sell parts of its business to reduce debt. "The most important thing they need to do is to get rid of the debt finance business," he said.

The company has been hit by fierce competition in the growing market for digital copying, a bodged sales reorganisation and a weak euro.

MyPoints, an online payments company, also upset the market with a surprise profits warning yesterday. Shares in the fledgling business more than halved to just over $2 yesterday after it warned that earnings would be almost 75 per cent below expectations.

Lauren Fine, analyst at Merrill Lynch, called the disappointment of "shocking magnitude" and accused the management of "delinquency" in failing to determine the extent of the shortfall.

fields.headline: Orange float delayed to 2001
fields.trailText: France Telecom yesterday said the €100bn (£59bn) flotation of the enlarged Orange mobile phone group will take place early next year.
fields.body:
France Telecom yesterday said the €100bn (£59bn) flotation of the enlarged Orange mobile phone group will take place early next year.

The timetable for the relisting of Orange in London and Paris confounded market expectations that it would happen by the end of this year.

Insiders said the decision to wait was simply because of the complexity of combining 15 companies, some of which are joint ventures, into one entity.

France Telecom will also be hoping that the swing in investor sentiment against mobile phone businesses has subsided by the new year.

The enlarged group, dubbed New Orange, will include the assets of the original company including its 8.3m strong customer base in Britain.

It will also take in the mobile phone businesses owned by France Telecom including its domestic network Itineris and interests across mainland Europe. It will be Europe's second largest mobile phone group, with 30m subscribers.

The marketing launch of the share issue is expected to take place in January, with the flotation likely in February. The aim is to put up to 15% of the shares in free float.

Michel Bon, France Telecom chairman, said: "The process of combining the mobile assets of France Telecom with Orange to create a leading global wire-free business is now well advanced."

Hans Snook, Orange's chief executive, added that he was "looking forward enormously" to the listing of the enlarged group.

It emerged last week that Mr Snook is to give up day-to-day running of the business to concentrate on broader issues as executive chairman of Orange.

Jean-François Pontal, a France Telecom director close to Mr Bon, will assume the role of chief executive.

fields.headline: We lock them up and then expect thanks
fields.standfirst:
Just how long is a refugee supposed to bow and scrape?
Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Last Friday, the law firm Bhatt Murphy was rung by the Mail on Sunday, who said they were writing a piece about detention of refugees and were interested in featuring one of their clients. This is like being rung by the British National party and asked to give your address so they can send you their autumn catalogue.
fields.body:
Last Friday, the law firm Bhatt Murphy was rung by the Mail on Sunday, who said they were writing a piece about detention of refugees and were interested in featuring one of their clients. This is like being rung by the British National party and asked to give your address so they can send you their autumn catalogue. If the Mail were ever to question the justice of jailing refugees, it would be to promote sterilisation as the alternative.

The reason for the sudden interest in the client, whose asylum claim was upheld by the appeals tribunal and who is therefore legally resident, was that he is suing the Home Office. He claims that the last three months of his detention were unlawful because the Home Office was in possession of all the information that led to his asylum claim being upheld. Part of his complaint is that, after complaining about conditions in the notorious Campsfield House, he was handcuffed and moved to prison.

Bhatt Murphy asked the Mail to guarantee their client's anonymity, for his safety and that of his family still in Algeria. The Mail's position is that, given that he is bringing a civil action, his identity is public. This raises the question that if the whole world is talking about it already, why does the Mail think it's such a scoop? If the British public and the Algerian government spend their days at the Royal Courts of Justice, scouring the daily listings and sitting in on civil suits, the story is redundant. Actually, there are people who do that, but most are homeless, few look Algerian and I doubt whether any are Mail readers. Mail readers haven't sat in on trials since the death penalty was abolished.

Nevertheless, the newspaper refused to accept that the man or his family might suffer as a result of the story. Bhatt Murphy found themselves explaining that fear of persecution is what being a refugee is all about. It's not a legal status the Home Office confers with gladness of heart. Moreover, not all regimes are above taking out their frustration with exiles on friends and family.

To spell it out for the Mail, the solicitors referred the paper to guidelines from the United Nations high commissioner for refugees. But the paper was determined, feeling best placed to make judgments about the safety of political dissidents abroad. Perhaps the Mail should start an advice page in its international edition with hints on evading arrest and torture. But I suppose the suggestion "Stay calm and don't move, especially here" would become repetitive.

On Saturday Bhatt Murphy won a court ruling against the Mail, and on Sunday the paper grumpily informed readers that it wasn't allowed to put the man's family at risk. However the paper was able to give us illuminating quotes from Ann Widdecombe and Robin Corbett, who is a Labour MP and chair of the home affairs committee.

Widdecombe told us, "It is perfectly proper for asylum seekers to be detained, particularly where there is good reason to fear they may disappear before their case is decided." Well, under her proposals, there would be no "particularly"; she wants to put them all in camps, which she calls "reception centres". I have spoken to many a receptionist; they are usually charming and none has ever held me in a headlock, smashed my belongings or said, "Go home if you don't like it."

But Labour's reign has scarcely been more humane than Widdecombe's notion of what it is to meet and greet. Despite the perpetual blather about the fear of refugees absconding, most of those in detention are awaiting decisions, cannot be deported and have no reason to go on the run. About one in seven refugees are detained the second they arrive, and one in 10 are still in jail three months later. The man in the Mail story endured 19 months of detention. The fact that he is suing over only three months of it shows considerable forbearance in my view.

At present more than 1,000 refugees are in camps and prisons, with Jack Straw hoping to build on that success by jailing another 1,700. So it is not surprising that the loyal minion Robin Corbett gave the Mail this piece of wisdom: "It seems a very churlish way to show gratitude to a country which has given him sanctuary."

In the first place, the man is not suing the country; he is suing the Home Office. In the second place, just how long is a refugee supposed to bow and scrape? Must his children also feel grateful that the government conceded something to their father that was his by right? Can the government do what it likes to people if they weren't born here, and should they be jolly thankful if they're not tortured?

webTitle: Maverick who sparked the new intifada

fields.headline: Maverick who sparked the new intifada
fields.standfirst:
Hawk may ally with Barak - at a price

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Hawk may ally with Barak - at a price
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon, poised to bulldoze his way back into power in Israel, has long been associated with some of the bloodiest chapters in his country's 50-year conflict with the Arabs.

Last night Mr Sharon, leader of the opposition Likud party, was still considering the request from the prime minister, Ehud Barak, to join an emergency national unity coalition following the violent collapse of the peace process.

So far the 72-year-old maverick has made no formal response, but sources close to him were quoted as saying he would take up the offer - but on his own terms.

As so often before in his long and rocky career, many people believe this larger-than-life hawkish figure is more of a problem than a solution.

It was his visit to the mosques of Jerusalem's Temple Mount (Haram al-Sharif) last month that triggered the present crisis. It was widely seen as a deliberate provocation.

Yet even if it was a little disingenuous for Mr Sharon to claim that he was only another Jew visiting a holy site, his move was more the pretext for than the cause of the explosion of Palestinian anger that followed.

Israeli observers believe the Likud leader had his own motives: highlighting objections to Mr Barak's readiness to make concessions over Jerusalem; and vying to keep his own party position in the face of a possible challenge from his predecessor, the former prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu.

Mr Barak's call to Mr Sharon to join a unity government seems to be another large nail in the coffin of the peace process, a clear lurch to the right after the mortal blows of recent weeks.

Palestinians and many Israelis remember him most for being the architect of the disastrous 1982 invasion of Lebanon, when as defence minister he tried to destroy the PLO militarily so he would not have to deal with it politically.

In what turned out to be the most unpopular and divisive war in the country's history he was accused of misleading his own prime minister and was forced to step down after being found indirectly responsible for the Sabra and Shatila massacres of Palestinians by Israel's Lebanese Christian allies.

He has been wreathed in controversy ever since he was a young army officer, commanding a unit that launched punitive raids against Jordan and Egypt in the 1950s. In one of them, at Qibya, scores of civilians were massacred.

Much decorated for his brilliant exploits and élan - though his heroism has often been questioned and mocked by his many critics - he led the Israeli counter-attack across the Suez Canal in 1973.

In the early 1970s, as head of the army's southern command he was responsible for a brutal crackdown on Palestinian resistance activities in the Gaza Strip.

Later, like many Israeli generals, he went into politics, using his position as agriculture minister under Menachem Begin to patronise and expand Jewish settlements all over the West Bank, delighting in showing journalists the detailed maps and the spade he carried in his car boot.

Running a succession of ministries he made no secret of his goal his of "creating facts" on the ground to make it impossible to compromise on territory with the Palestinians.

Subterfuge was always part of his strategy. Unsurprisingly, he opposed the 1993 Oslo peace agreement from the start, insisting that Yasser Arafat, the PLO leader, could never be trusted.

On that point, he is consistent: "Every time Arafat wants to put some more pressure on Israel, he turns to violence," he protested after the Temple Mount incident on September 28. "For him, terror is a tool in the negotiating process."

Sharon has had personal tragedies, losing a son and recently his wife Lily, who shared his rambling Negev ranch and their heavily-guarded home in the Muslim quarter of Jerusalem's Old City.

With a controversial past and a central role in an uncertain future, he still casts a giant shadow over his own people - and their enemies.

"This man is connected with catastrophes for the Palestinians," said Yasser Abed-Rabbo, minister of culture in the Palestinian Authority. Many Israelis feel the same.

fields.headline: EU agrees £118m winter aid
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: European Union leaders meeting in Biarritz have agreed on an emergency aid package for Serbia worth some £118m. The money, to be spent on drugs, heating oil, schools and possibly food, is supposed to help the Serbs get through the coming winter.
fields.body:
European Union leaders meeting in Biarritz have agreed on an emergency aid package for Serbia worth some £118m. The money, to be spent on drugs, heating oil, schools and possibly food, is supposed to help the Serbs get through the coming winter.

EU officials claimed the cash would be disbursed "in a matter of weeks" and made it clear that the aid was unconditional.

The new Serbian leader, Vojislav Kostunica, is expected to fly to Biarritz today.

fields.headline: Colombia rebels deny kidnap
fields.trailText: Colombia's biggest guerilla group has denied kidnapping foreigners from an Ecuadorean oilfield in the Amazon jungle.
fields.body:
Colombia's biggest guerilla group has denied kidnapping foreigners from an Ecuadorean oilfield in the Amazon jungle.

The captives - thought to include five or six Americans, two Frenchmen, a Chilean and an Argentinian - were abducted by six masked gunmen and flown by helicopter to neighbouring Colombia by a group claiming to be Colombian rebels, said military officials in the Ecuadorean capital, Quito.

Ecuador's vice-president, Pedro Pinto, said the leftwing Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc) had claimed that the kidnapping was in reprisal for Plan Colombia, an anti-drug trafficking initiative backed by $1.3bn (£885m) in US aid.

But rebel spokesman Carlos Antonio Lozada said: "I can assure you with total security that the Farc has nothing to do with this incident."

Farc rebels, whose field commanders operate with substantial autonomy, have had to backpedal on similar denials in the past.

Last month, a guerrilla hijacked a commuter plane and forced it down at a Farc-held southern airport. The group initially denied the rebel was one of theirs, but later conceded that he was.

There were conflicting details about the latest kidnapping. Mr Pinto said there were only nine hostages, and that one of them was believed to be an Ecuadorean.

In Washington, a state department official said that at least 10 but probably as many as 25 people were believed to have been seized, including five Americans.

He said about 15 heavily armed men were thought to have been involved.

At least three of the five Americans were pilots and one of them was ordered by the kidnappers to fly the captives out, said the official.

Other reports said one of the victims was from New Zealand.

The oilfield, operated by the Spanish energy giant, Repsol, lies in Ecuador's northern territory, which borders Colombia's southern state of Putumayo, the heart of the cocaine-producing region. AP

webTitle: Man held after three are found battered to death

fields.headline: Man held after three are found battered to death
fields.trailText: A man suspected of bludgeoning to death two middle aged sisters and their elderly father was arrested on the doorstep of the family's gas-filled home in Coventry after making a 999 call.
fields.body:
A man suspected of bludgeoning to death two middle aged sisters and their elderly father was arrested on the doorstep of the family's gas-filled home in Coventry after making a 999 call.

Police responding to the call had to wait until gas workers cut the supply before entering. They found the body of Clifford Hall, 74, on the landing of the house and the bodies of his daughters Linda, 46, and Susan, 43, in downstairs rooms.

All three had suffered serious head injuries. Officers described the scene as "horrific", but said there were no obvious signs of a struggle.

A 24-year-old man was arrested at the scene on Thursday night and was yesterday being treated at a Coventry hospital for reasons police refused to specify.

Police said the motive for the attack was still unclear.

The suspect, who was not well enough to be interviewed yesterday, is not thought to have a history of mental illness.

Police had never previously visited the address or had reason to contact the family.

Police confirmed that the arrested man had made the 999 call. A spokesman said it was possible that the gas had been allowed to leak deliberately.

Neighbours, who first raised the alarm with the gas company Transco after smelling fumes, expressed shock at the deaths of a "model family" who played an active role in the community life of Potters Green.

Linda Hall, who had a disability, stayed at home caring for her father, while her sister worked as a clerical officer at Coventry and Warwickshire hospital. Susan had an unemployed son, Stuart.

Clifford Hall, who had worked for an electrical company before his retirement, was described as a public spirited man who volunteered his time to tend his neighbours' gardens.

Margaret Gair, 68, said: "After my husband died 13 years ago, Cliff went out of his way to help me. He did my flowers for me and made the garden look beautiful. I'm so devastated that he could die in such an horrific way."

Another neighbour, Louise Cooper, 36, said: "Cliff was a very friendly man and he loved gardening. He had just laid a new lawn at his home.

"He used to help me with my garden, he didn't do it for the money - he just liked to help people. He has been through lots of heart surgery and had a pacemaker. He did lots of little jobs for me. He was very kind."

Grieving neighbours laid bunches of flowers outside the house.

fields.headline: Jihad called then bombers attack
fields.standfirst:
TV footage leads to call for revenge attack

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: TV footage leads to call for revenge attack
fields.byline: David Hirst  in Beirut, and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Television footage of Israeli attack helicopters bombing the West Bank and Gaza on Thursday prompted fierce reaction yesterday across the Muslim world, with crowds from Egypt to Afghanistan calling for a holy war to revenge their Palestinian brothers.

About 10,000 worshippers poured on to the streets after Friday prayers at Cairo's al-Azhar mosque demanding war with Israel and shouting: "There is no god but God, and the Jews are the enemies of God."

The worshippers had been listening to Sheikh Mohammed Sayyid Tantawy. He is reported to have urged Muslims to cut off all ties with Israel and rally to the Palestinian cause, noting that Egypt had already "waged four wars for the sake of Palestine".

Chanting slogans would not be enough, he said. "Only being firm would help".

In Kabul, preachers invoked a holy war at Friday prayers, while the ruling Taliban called for instant revenge. "We strongly condemn Israel's oppressions against defenceless Palestinians and support the righteous cause of Palestine," a Taliban spokesman said.

The leaders of Egypt, Jordan, Syria and Saudi Arabia are expected to meet this weekend in Riyadh to prepare for a plenary Arab summit conference, due on October 21, which will draw up a collective Arab policy on the Israeli-Palestinian crisis.

Their task will have been rendered all the more difficult by moves by the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, to form an emergency government that includes the rightwing extremist opposition leader General Ariel Sharon.

Since General Sharon triggered the Israeli-Palestinian upheaval with his visit to the al-Aqsa compound two weeks ago, Arabs have been rallying to the Palestinian cause with a vigour not seen for years.

A similar note of renewed anger was struck by Palestinian refugees in Lebanon and Jordan yesterday. About 7,000 marched through the largest of Lebanon's refugee camps, Ein el-Hilweh, condemning Thursday's "massacre" and calling on Egypt and Jordan to sever relations with the state of Israel.

They set fire to an effigy of Mr Barak which had been daubed with the words "specialised in murdering children". A model of the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, suffered a similar fate.

Thousands of demonstrators staged angry demonstrations in Jordan, Bahrain and Turkey.

Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, the secretary general of Hizbullah, appealed to Arab leaders to follow the wishes of their people. "Those whose countries have with ties with Israel should sever them. This is the least we can expect from the Egyptian president."

Oman, which, along with Qatar, is one of two Gulf countries to have engaged in diplomatic "normalization" with Israel, ordered the closure of its trade mission in Tel Aviv, and Israel's in Muscat, following rare pro-Palestinian demonstrations there.

Last week Jordan announced that it was delaying the departure of its new ambassador to Tel Aviv.

The Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, who has strongly criticized two other Arab leaders, Colonel Gadafy of Libya and president Ali Abdullah Salih of Yemen, for their militant rhetoric, has shown no sign of heeding calls for ties to be cut.

The US and Britain are monitoring a tank division of Saddam Hussein's Republican Guards, which moved west from Baghdad on Thursday. Satellite pictures showed no significant movement yesterday.

Outside the Middle East, anger exploded in Indonesia when thousands of Muslims marched to the parliament in Jakarta to protest against the Israeli forces' actions. Students also threw rocks at the US embassy and clashed with police protecting the building.

webTitle: Both sides agree on one thing: peace is dead

fields.headline: Both sides agree on one thing: peace is dead
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: It was nearly noon and the young men were engaged in a shoving match with the cordon of Israeli riot police blocking the gates of the mosque.
fields.body:
It was nearly noon and the young men were engaged in a shoving match with the cordon of Israeli riot police blocking the gates of the mosque.

Yesterday, on the third Friday since two peoples began their descent into an unholy war, it all came home to the heart of the matter: the sacred ground of the Haram al-Sharif in Jerusalem.

In the tangle of lanes around the mosque, thousands of Israeli riot police were deployed in the greatest show of force since the onset of violence. Only middle-aged men, and women, were allowed inside for afternoon prayers, and the crowds were seething with frustration.

On the other side of Jerusalem's old walled city, meanwhile, the most sacred shrine of the Jews was almost deserted. Despite the approach of the Sukkot festival, few worshippers dared visit the Wailing Wall.

As the hearts of two peoples returned to their faith, there could hardly have been a greater divide. One nation was angry and defiant. The other, Israel, was bracing for more horrors to come.

In scuffles on al-Mojahedin Street, named for holy warriors, Israeli riot police used canes and forcefully applied fists to chests to turn back young men from the mosque.

"This is the ultimate humiliation, preventing me from going to pray," said Mazen Sublaba, aged 25.

Mercifully, there was no real violence, and the massive police deployment broke the pattern of earlier Fridays when youths have stormed out of mosques throwing stones and petrol bombs.

At Damascus Gate, one of the main entrances to the walled city, mounted policemen loomed over the crowds before driving them back with tear gas. Some men rolled out their prayer mats and knelt where they were. Others stood their ground.

"Saddam, Saddam, the conqueror. Go back to bombing Tel Aviv. If you want us to wear a commando uniform, we are ready," they screamed.

After Yasser Arafat freed 350 militants from Palestinian jails, including the top bomber of the Hamas movement, that is precisely Israel's fear. Yesterday there was intense security around shopping malls and other public places, and the army issued warnings of a renewal of terror.

"We understand that they understand that they have a green light for terrorist attacks," said Major Yarden Vatikay, an Israeli army spokesman. "These are people who do not plan sporadic fire. These are people who plan to demolish buildings, hit buses and kill women and children."

In the afternoon a few dozen Israeli activists stood outside a square in west Jerusalem with placards pleading: "Don't kill the peace". But the streets were unusually quiet, even for the eve of the Jewish sabbath.

Twenty four hours after all of Israel seems to have watched and recoiled in horror from the uncut television footage of the killing of their soldiers, a consensus seemed to be forming that peace was dead, and that the Israeli left had been fools to even think of negotiating with the Palestinians.

"The psychological and cultural split yawned open yesterday into a deep and perhaps total rift. The Palestinian people are mobilising for a war of independence, the Israeli public is united, at least at the moment, in a battle of survival," Ma'ariv newspaper said.

In Petah Tikva, the hometown of one of the dead soldiers, they were even more unforgiving. "It is not just this murder, but the behaviour of the Arabs inside and outside the country," said Dr Yehuda Finkelstein.

"This is not a peace process. this is part of a Palestinian project on how to destroy us and to throw us away from the Mediterranean area."

In Ramallah, where worshippers went straight from afternoon prayers to throw stones at an army checkpoint on the edge of town, they agreed with the Israelis on one point, at least. Peace was dead. However, they said it had never amounted to much anyway. "What is peace?" said one teenager with a Tommy Hilfiger t-shirt wrapped around his head. "I can't even get out of this shithole unless the Israelis say so."

On the roads leading out of town, which Israel has blocked with concrete barricades, a handful of children were snapping at their catapults, testing them for future confrontations.

Outside the police station where the Israeli soldiers met their deaths on Thursday, a few policemen in black uniforms struggled to maintain their dignity, standing guard over what was reduced to a heap of rubble by Israel's rocket attack.

Otherwise, the streets were eerily quiet.

Nobody here is expressing contrition at the deaths of the soldiers. Instead their outrage is focused at Israel's deployment of its war machinery to avenge those deaths. "This is not an intifada any more. This is war," said Yusuf Ali, who runs a cafe that is the fuelling point for young Palestinians in between bouts of stone-throwing.

In the distance a machine-gun mounted on an Israeli tank was aiming its fire on a small hut where a Palestinian sniper had been hiding. Down the road the barricade was burning as usual.

"No matter what happens, sooner or later, even if it takes 100 years, Jerusalem is going to be back with all the Muslim people, not just the Palestinians. And this is only the beginning," said Mr Ali.

fields.headline: How foolish virgins grow wise
fields.standfirst: Why you're not a real stockbroker until after a crash
fields.trailText: Why you're not a real stockbroker until after a crash
fields.body:
The crash, when it came, was terrifying. I'd waited for what seemed like an eternity, hoping throughout that it might by some miracle be averted. In the event, anticipation proved to have been no preparation for the reality. Thirteen years on I still bear the mental scars.

The great storm of October 1987 brought a tree down on to the roof of my south London bedroom. The great financial storm that blew in with it almost brought down the roof on my career as a stockbroker. On the wall of the kids' playroom now hangs a print of fallen trees in Kew Gardens dated October 21, 1987 as a reminder of the disasters that dog our lives.

This week's weather has reminded many of the storm that effectively closed the London exchange on the Friday before Black Monday, October 19, 1987. The pathetic fallacy has always seemed to me to be the cheapest trick in the novelist's bag, but even the gods aren't above using it when it suits. The rain has fallen in stair rods and, by coincidence, investors' spirits have taken a drenching.

When I began working life as a wet behind the ears investment manager, older hands told bar-room tales of the crash of 1974. Of careers destroyed, of lives ruined, and of grinding months of boredom playing interminable hands of poker awaiting the establishment's rescue of the system. It seemed to me that the investment community divided neatly into those who had lost their crash virginity and those who had to undergo this trauma.

Now I find myself to be one of the experienced, spinning yarns of '87 to those the right side of their early thirties. They give me the same look of reluctant indulgence that I no doubt returned to the class of '74 as they sought to prepare me for trials ahead that I couldn't even imagine.

Black Monday itself found me on holiday in Egypt, having left roof repairs back home to others. A Reuters tickertape in a Cairo hotel lobby made it clear that much greater devastation was now being handled by colleagues back on the trading floor. I thought briefly of cutting short my vacation, but reasoned that I was too junior to be missed and, if things were that serious, I wouldn't have a job to go back to.

When I did return, the trail of devastation wreaked by the financial hurricane was, literally, breathtaking. The arbitrage trading book I managed had lost all of its gains of the year, and then added losses of equal magnitude. My trading positions had not been touched by superiors too preoccupied with problems of their own.

It did indeed feel difficult to breathe. Suddenly, also, I had a whole new perspective on those above me in the pecking order. I'd always known that somewhere, deep down, they were human. Now their human frailty was laid bare for all to see and one or two soon disappeared, returning only for former colleagues' leaving parties.

The collapse sorted out the genuinely tough from the self-deluded and revives memories of one individual, a senior fund manager, an inveterate office bully, and a market punter on a colossal scale. Former colleagues told me with great relish of his breakdown in the office under the weight of the losses on his personal portfolio.

The self-appointed hero of the markets had suddenly discovered the downside of leverage in the futures market. He completely lost it. Client portfolios were forgotten. As were his juniors. Calls from his wife to discuss the designs for their new hand-crafted kitchen can't have helped. Result? Next plane to Asia and a lengthy period of career rehabilitation.

Leverage and a pervasive culture of personal punting among the broking community were an explosive combination. One salesman at a leading bank was grateful for his employer's paternalistic approach. It transferred him to the back office and took a cut of his salary for a couple of years to recoup his losses in the derivatives markets. To my knowledge he never reappeared in a front-line role.

A stricter compliance regime has curtailed the personal dealing activities in most leading investment banks over the subsequent years. But thoughts of a crash still bring with them fears of disappearing bonuses and then fears of job cuts.

Aftershock

This week Morgan Stanley Dean Witter announced $90m of losses in their high yield bond portfolios. Apparently they only made the announcement to quash rumours of $500m of losses. Closer to home, one leading London investment bank has given up all of its year-to-date market-making profits and more in the past fortnight. The maths is bound to work its way through the system in the time-honoured fashion.

In 1987 a combination of natural forces and positive action from the financial authorities eventually turned the tide of negative sentiment. Interest rates were cut. Corporates took the view that the real world would be unaffected and took the opportunity afforded by depressed share prices to launch takeover bids. In the UK, the government and the Kuwaitis stepped in to "rescue" the BP issue that threatened to blow holes in banks' balance sheets.

Subsequent threatened crashes have been averted by a mixture of luck, intervention and - perhaps most importantly - the collective memory of October 1987. Equity valuations have never been quite so stretched as at that point when viewed in the context of the underlying economic situation. Perhaps, deep down in the market's psyche, the aftershock from the last crash has kept investors an inch back from the cliff edge.

The exception, however, has been the technology stocks in 2000. Very few of the investors - private and professional - who took hold of these shares and drove their valuations up into the stratosphere have any investment memory 13 years old.

The Nasdaq index of US tech stocks is now 40% below its peak. This is a crash all of its own. It has created a whole new generation of old farts who will in time bore the next generation of over-confident young crash virgins.

Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities. edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

They give me the same look of reluctant indulgence that I no doubt returned to the class of '74 as they sought to prepare me for trials ahead that I couldn't even imagine. Black Monday itself found me on holiday in Egypt, having left roof repairs back home to others. A Reuters tickertape in a Cairo hotel lobby made it clear that much greater devastation was now being handled by colleagues back on the trading floor. I thought briefly of cutting short my vacation, but reasoned that I was too junior to be missed and, if things were that serious, I wouldn't have a job to go back to. When I did return, the trail of devastation wreaked by the financial hurricane was, literally, breathtaking. The arbitrage trading book I managed had lost all of its gains of the year, and then added losses of equal magnitude. My trading positions had not been touched by superiors too preoccupied with problems of their own. It did indeed feel difficult to breathe. Suddenly, also, I had a whole new perspective on those above me in the pecking order. I'd always known that somewhere, deep down, they were human. Now their human frailty was laid bare for all to see and one or two soon disappeared, returning only for former colleagues' leaving parties. The collapse sorted out the genuinely tough from the self-deluded and revives memories of one individual, a senior fund manager, an inveterate office bully, and a market punter on a colossal scale. Former colleagues told me with great relish of his breakdown in the office under the weight of the losses on his personal portfolio. The self-appointed hero of the markets had suddenly discovered the downside of leverage in the futures market. He completely lost it. Client portfolios were forgotten. As were his juniors. Calls from his wife to discuss the designs for their new hand-crafted kitchen can't have helped. Result? Next plane to Asia and a lengthy period of career rehabilitation. Leverage and a pervasive culture of personal punting among the broking community were an explosive combination. One salesman at a leading bank was grateful for his employer's paternalistic approach. It transferred him to the back office and took a cut of his salary for a couple of years to recoup his losses in the derivatives markets. To my knowledge he never reappeared in a front-line role. A stricter compliance regime has curtailed the personal dealing activities in most leading investment banks over the subsequent years. But thoughts of a crash still bring with them fears of disappearing bonuses and then fears of job cuts. Aftershock This week Morgan Stanley Dean Witter announced $90m of losses in their high yield bond portfolios. Apparently they only made the announcement to quash rumours of $500m of losses. Closer to home, one leading London investment bank has given up all of its year-to-date market-making profits and more in the past fortnight. The maths is bound to work its way through the system in the time-honoured fashion. In 1987 a combination of natural forces and positive action from the financial authorities eventually turned the tide of negative sentiment. Interest rates were cut. Corporates took the view that the real world would be unaffected and took the opportunity afforded by depressed share prices to launch takeover bids. In the UK, the government and the Kuwaitis stepped in to "rescue" the BP issue that threatened to blow holes in banks' balance sheets. Subsequent threatened crashes have been averted by a mixture of luck, intervention and - perhaps most importantly - the collective memory of October 1987. Equity valuations have never been quite so stretched as at that point when viewed in the context of the underlying economic situation. Perhaps, deep down in the market's psyche, the aftershock from the last crash has kept investors an inch back from the cliff edge. The exception, however, has been the technology stocks in 2000. Very few of the investors - private and professional - who took hold of these shares and drove their valuations up into the stratosphere have any investment memory 13 years old. The Nasdaq index of US tech stocks is now 40% below its peak. This is a crash all of its own. It has created a whole new generation of old farts who will in time bore the next generation of over-confident young crash virgins. Edmond Warner is chief executive of Old Mutual Securities. edmondw@omsecurities.co.uk

fields.headline: After the revolution
fields.standfirst:
Paddy Ashdown, who has spent the past week in the Balkans, charts the way ahead
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The west seems incapable of thinking of more than one Balkan thing at a time. But in the Balkans, it is the interconnection of things which matters. By thinking only of Croatia in 1992, we blew up Bosnia.
fields.body:
The west seems incapable of thinking of more than one Balkan thing at a time. But in the Balkans, it is the interconnection of things which matters. By thinking only of Croatia in 1992, we blew up Bosnia. When we ended the Bosnia war at Dayton, we forgot about Kosovo. And now there is a real danger that in the rush of relief and euphoria to welcome President Vojislav Kostunica in Serbia, we will destabilise the peace we have created in Bosnia and Kosovo and undermine the fragile government in Croatia.

This is not to underestimate the remarkable transformation taking place in Belgrade; or the potential of the moment. It is merely to caution that there are now many ways to waste the opportunity that Mr Kostunica and the forces of democracy in Serbia have presented to us. One is for the west to judge Mr Kostunica by what he has said and done in the past. Mr Kostunica says he is a nationalist (I think he means a patriot, but there is no such distinction in Serbo-Croat). His past statements, and even some of his actions, do give cause for concern. But if it had not been so, I doubt that he would have rid us of Milosevic. So the right policy is to judge him, not by the past, but by what he does in the weeks and months ahead. And so far the things he has done have been good, even brave.

Mr Kostunica is a legalist and has, to some, acted too slowly to rid Serbia of the malevolent forces of Milosevic. But it is a good thing to have, as president of ex-Yugoslavia, a man who is scrupulous about the law. No one should under- estimate the poison which Milosevic can infiltrate into the Serb body politic as long as he is around. But I think that the revolution that unseated him is now irreversible. If Mr Kostunica has achieved this without the lawlessness which would have resulted from more extensive use of popular force on the streets, and so strengthened the legal foundations of his government for the future, then that should be a matter for welcome, not regret.

But if a too sceptical approach is one danger which the west should avoid, a too euphoric one is another. My hunch is that Mr Kostunica's instincts are those of cooperation and good relations with neighbours. But there is a long way to go before he establishes a stable and effective government which can put these qualities into action. Too early a western commitment of full support, before the transformation has been completed, could be dangerous. We must not relax for Serbia the standards of internal democracy and the acceptance of the rule of international law which we have demanded of other Balkan nations. The first priority should be for President Kostunica to stabilise his government. But in the end, there can be no compromise on the necessity to bring to justice in the Hague those indicted for war crimes in ex-Yugoslavia. Anything less would risk destabilising the fragile government of President Stipe Mesic in Croatia, who has taken great risks to send the Tudjman-era war criminals to the Hague.

So the west's policy should be to offer goodwill and help for Mr Kostunica at the start, to judge him by what he now does and to be patient about progress, but firm about the conditions which must, ultimately, be fulfilled.

What then can Mr Kostunica do to capitalise on the wider opportunities in the Balkans which his velvet revolution has created? Here the picture is mixed. There is now a real opportunity to resolve the Montenegro question which has held the Balkans on a hair-trigger for war in recent months. There seems a willingness in Belgrade to renegotiate the constitutional relationship with Montenegro, within a confederal "commonwealth" based on the principle of equality. This would leave all powers with the two constituent nations, except for those relating to foreign affairs, the army and the management of a single convertible currency which they hope will lead to the euro. There even seems to be agreement between the two countries to abandon the old name of Yugoslavia in favour of a new name, "Serbia-Montenegro" - a name whose undoubted inelegance seems a small price to pay for the removal of one of the Balkans' most explosive flash points.

For Bosnia, too, the change in Belgrade is good news. Mr Kostunica has said (and made me promise to repeat) that he accepts the Dayton borders and wishes to establish diplomatic relations with Bosnia-Herzegovina. This should increase the votes of the moderates, at the expense of the pro-Milosevic Serbs, in the forthcoming Bosnia-wide election early next month. Freed from threats to its existence from both Croatia to its west and now Serbia to its east, Bosnia should be able to get down to the business of building itself as a state and making the changes necessary to become a candidate for Europe.

In Kosovo the picture is more mixed. Though they will not admit it publicly, the presence of Milosevic gave legitimacy and strength to the Kosovan Albanian claim for independence. These are neuralgic times for Kosovan Albanians. They know that the removal of the dictator who so violated and brutalised their community has weakened their claim for total independence. And they fear that, just as the west's caravan moved on from Bosnia to Kosovo, now all the political will, influence and aid is about to move north to Belgrade.

Some say that we will see played out in Kosovo the same phenomenon that I witnessed as a soldier in Belfast in 1970. The troops arrive as heroes to the oppressed, but soon become the enemy who keeps them from their political ambitions. I don't think this is likely in Kosovo. But it will need a great deal of political maturity and wisdom from Kosovo's inexperienced politicians to understand that the right response to Kostunica is not to retreat into suspicious gloominess and introspection, but to accept that Kosovo is now in an economic and democratic race with Belgrade, which they intend to win. The west will not abandon Kosovo. But we are now playing a larger game of regional reconstruction, and Kosovo will better serve itself by being part of this than by retreating into a small island of Balkan refuseniks.

Kostunica, if he is wise, should help this process. He needs to understand that security for his fellow Serbs in Kosovo does not come out of the barrel of a K-For gun, but out of a new political relationship between the two communities, which, on the Serb side, he can help lead from Belgrade. No doubt his own nationalist elements will want him to strike muscular positions on Kosovo. That would set the province alight, cause even more suffering to the Serbs, increase the votes of the Albanian extremists in next week's Kosovo elections and make sure that K-For troops have to stay longer. His best course of action is to say he wants to work constructively with the UN in Kosovo, advise Kosovan Serbs to do the same and leave the status of Kosovo to later when things have quietened down.

One final step we should now consider. The end of Milosevic has left a number of interconnected southern Balkan issues still to be resolved: the status of Kosovo, the relationship between Montenegro and Serbia, the stability of Macedonia and, now that we have removed the danger of a greater Serbia, the question of a greater Albania. There is now a case for looking at these regionally - for a kind of "southern Balkans Dayton". As I said, in the Balkans it is the interconnection of things which matters.

Paddy Ashdown's diaries, which include previous trips to the Balkans, will be published on November 1

fields.headline: Nobel prize goes to 'Seoul's Mandela'
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: This year's Nobel Peace Prize will be awarded to South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, for promoting democracy and reconciliation on a peninsula still divided by the cold war.
fields.body:
This year's Nobel Peace Prize will be awarded to South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, for promoting democracy and reconciliation on a peninsula still divided by the cold war.

Mr Kim, often referred to as "Asia's Mandela", was chosen by the Norwegian Nobel committee yesterday ahead of a record 150 nominees, including the US president, Bill Clinton, and the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, and the former US senator who tried to broker peace in Ulster, George Mitchell.

A long-time dissident who was tortured, exiled and sentenced to death before gaining power in 1997, Mr Kim has been nominated every year since 1987.

His historic visit in June to Pyongyang - for the first North-South summit since the Korean war of 1950-53 - did the trick: "There may now be hope that the cold war will also come to an end in Korea," the Nobel citation said.

As in previous years, the committee has used the prize to boost the key figure in a fragile peace process. The risks of this are seen now in the Middle East, in flames just six years after the Palestinian president, Yasser Arafat, and Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres, respectively Israel's prime minister and foreign minister of the day, became Nobel laureates.

Since being elected president in 1997 in the first democratic transfer of power in South Korea, Mr Kim has ordered amnesties for thousands of political prisoners. His "sunshine policy" of diplomatic and economic engagement with the north has seen hundreds of separated families meet.

The Nobel award comes just as Mr Kim's popularity was starting to flag amid growing doubts about the north's intentions and the economic costs of engagement with such an impoverished neighbour.

webTitle: OM's improved offer for exchange wins few friends in London

fields.headline: OM's improved offer for exchange wins few friends in London
fields.trailText: Swedish group OM yesterday raised its hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange but met rejection from its target and a cool response from many in the City.
fields.body:
Swedish group OM yesterday raised its hostile bid for the London Stock Exchange but met rejection from its target and a cool response from many in the City.

The new bid, an all-paper offer with a cash and shares alternative, values the exchange at just over £1bn, some £300m more than the first approach, but the gloss was immediately knocked off the offer by yesterday's 6% fall in OM's share price.

Brian Winterflood, one of the most vocal opponents of the London exchange's now abandoned plan to merge with its German rival, said he was not interested in selling his shares. "We are of the opinion that the LSE should be owned by users and shareholders. We are not in the business of selling our shares," Mr Winterflood, chief executive of Winterflood Securities, said. "These are founder shares and may be worth many hundreds of millions one day."

UBS Warburg, the exchange's largest shareholder, was also understood to be unswayed by the higher price.

Angela Knight, chief executive of the Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers, argued that OM's offer "missed the point".

"It will be of interest only to shareholders who are looking at price alone. The majority are wanting a strategy which brings lower trading, clearing and settlement costs."

OM's approach had impressed many in the financial community she said, but "the basic proposition is not quite there".

However, OM urged shareholders not to be complacent. "The stock exchange has not delivered in the past and won't do so in the future," said Peter Cox, who runs OM's London operation. "Shareholders can't hope it's going to be OK in the end. It has not been a successful strategy over the last 10 years."

Don Cruickshank, chairman of the exchange, urged shareholders to reject the bid. "The revised OM offer provides London Stock Exchange shareholders with a choice between two unattractive alternatives: either even more shares of uncertain value or cash and even less influence."

OM's new offer requires shareholders either to swap all their shares for OM's, which are listed in Stockholm, valuing an LSE share at £35.83, or take £20 in cash and some OM shares, giving a unit value of £32.79.

The LSE's share price yesterday failed to reach the level of the higher offer, closing at £28.15 - up from £26.50 on the day - while OM's fell sharply.

Mr Cox put the share price fall down to the general malaise facing hi-tech stocks. He said the new bid addressed concerns shareholders had raised, offering to appoint new directors to its board and promising clear dialogue with LSE members, customers and end users in an attempt to placate the smaller private client stockbrokers who have accused the London exchange's management of failing to consult them over strategy.

fields.headline: PO wants £130m for universal bank
fields.trailText: The Post Office is trying to coerce the major banks to inject a £130m annual subsidy into the universal bank by warning them their branches will become clogged up with social security claimants if the controversial project fails.
fields.body:
The Post Office is trying to coerce the major banks to inject a £130m annual subsidy into the universal bank by warning them their branches will become clogged up with social security claimants if the controversial project fails.

More than 16m people receive their benefits in cash over 18,000 post office counters but will need to have bank accounts by 2003 when the government intends to automate the payments system.

Many of the major banks remain opposed to the universal bank as it will lose as much as £300m a year. But the PO warns that unless they support it, they will have to offer accounts through their own branches. The PO said last night that it had begun a further round of talks with the banks about getting the project off the ground.

The government is understood to be prepared to inject £130m annually but wants the banks to stump up the same amount. The major clearing banks, Barclays, Lloyds TSB, HSBC and NatWest/Royal Bank of Scotland, are being asked to bear 10% of the cost each, approximately £13m a year.

Halifax and Abbey National are being asked to inject between £10m and £8m a year each and some of the major building societies are being asked to give £6m each, with another, unspecified, group being asked to provide the remainder. The banks are also being asked to spend an additional £50m to set up the bank.

The universal bank is at the heart of the government's plan to throw a lifeline to the PO after social security payments are automated when it will lose £400m a year revenue. The banks are already setting up basic accounts for some 3m people who do not have them.

The Treasury demanded that these accounts, unlikely to make any money for the banks, be set up separate to the universal bank. Without the universal bank, these are the accounts into which social security payments may be made.

webTitle: Next forges ahead with expansion plans

fields.headline: Next forges ahead with expansion plans
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer's problems look set to escalate as Next starts an expansion programme taking over up to 13 former C&A outlets writes Julia Finch .
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer's problems look set to escalate as Next starts an expansion programme taking over up to 13 former C&A outlets writes Julia Finch .

The large stores - bigger than supermarkets - will put Next head to head with M&S with the amount and range of merchandise on display in some of the country's main retail centres.

It is understood that Next has already agreed terms to take over nine C&A stores, and eventually hopes to move into 12 or 13 sites.

Three of the large new Next outlets will be open for business before Christmas.

These are in Inverness, Middlesborough and the Bluewater shopping centre in Kent.

While M&S has been struggling, Next has been thriving at its expense, especially popular among younger shoppers. M&S has been forced to announce a series of poor sales figures and lower profits.

Next, on the other hand, is proving to be one of the most buoyant names on the high street.

fields.headline: Victor Cross
fields.trailText: The keyboard player Victor Cross, who has died in a road accident aged 40, was one of a handful of musicians who sculpted lovers' rock in the mid-1980s. He was also a singer and musical arranger, equally proficient on bass, guitar and drums.
fields.body:
The keyboard player Victor Cross, who has died in a road accident aged 40, was one of a handful of musicians who sculpted lovers' rock in the mid-1980s. He was also a singer and musical arranger, equally proficient on bass, guitar and drums.

The fourth of eight children, born in London to Jamaican immigrant parents, Cross worked as a car mechanic after leaving school. In 1981, his younger brother Garnett "Sergeant Pepper" Cross, himself a singer and keyboard player, took him to Ariwa Sounds, the south London recording studio established by the sound engineer and producer Neil Fraser, better known as the "Mad Professor". Victor played every instrument, and provided backing vocals. His style and ability to cover complex American soul material impressed Fraser, who gave him session work.

In 1985, Victor became Ariwa's chief keyboard player and with Black Steel, another multi-instrumentalist, formed the core of the Robotics house band, so named because of the pair's robot-like ability to interpret Fraser's ideas. While a member of the Robotics, Victor played on some of the biggest hits by Kofi and John McLean, and on those of his sister, Sandra Cross. He was also featured on early work by political toaster Macka B.

When Ariwa work tapered off, he joined roots singer Norman Grant's Twinkle Brothers band, and regularly supported live performances by sound system stalwart and religious vocalist Jah Shaka. Victor's talent as a live performer led to work with Bob Andy, Earl 16 and Horace Andy. He was one of the first to play keyboards with Scratch Perry in Britain, and, more recently, supported Michael Rose, of Black Uhuru. Last year, he became a featured member of Aswad's touring band. For Fraser, he played bass and keyboards on Nolan Irie's second album, and contributed to an upcoming release by Love Clinic.

It was while returning from a French festival, with veteran reggae singer Max Romeo, that Victor's tour bus went off the road near Orleans.

In 1990, he married Michelle Josephs, another Ariwa backing vocalist. She survives him, as do their daughter Viquichele Victoria, and his two other children from earlier relationships, Charmaine and Leon. He was a talented and big-hearted man.

 Victor Cross, reggae musician, born June 21 1960; died September 9 2000

webTitle: The Middle East: In search of a new map

fields.headline: In search of a new map
fields.standfirst:
The Middle East is in peril but not yet lost
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Is there now a threat to the regional order in the Middle East? It is a question that has naturally been raised as the violence in Israel and the territories continues, especially since it has been accompanied by demonstrations across the Arab world, by the attack on the USS Cole and the bombing of the British embassy in Yemen.
fields.body:
Is there now a threat to the regional order in the Middle East? It is a question that has naturally been raised as the violence in Israel and the territories continues, especially since it has been accompanied not only by demonstrations across the Arab world but by the attack on the USS Cole and the bombing of the British embassy in Yemen. Nervous markets, as is their way, have already decided to act as if there were such a danger. It would be foolish to be too sanguine, particularly about the possibility of terrorist action. But it is plainly not true that the region is trembling on the brink of the kind of revolutionary change that would bring down existing governments and install radicals and fundamentalists in their place. There is no outside power, as there was in the past in the shape of the Soviet Union, to sponsor such changes.

As for the prospect of wider war, neither Syria nor Israel would gain anything by it. Nor does it seem likely that the one other state that could cause military trouble, Iraq, will do so at a moment when it has been successfully working its way back into international life in spite of United Nations resolutions and American and British hostility. Middle Eastern governments are certainly frightened and perplexed. Critical though some were of the peace process and of Israel, the slow working out of a settlement between Israelis and Palestinians formed a core activity to which everybody related, as they did to the larger American management of the region. That management was there to be used when necessary, to be resisted on occasion, to be influenced when possible. But it provided a map on which leaders, governments and political movements could orientate themselves. Now the map is suddenly indecipherable and all are having to cope with the resulting uncertainty. There is also the problem undemocratic or quasi-democratic regimes face when their peoples take to the streets in the knowledge that the legitimacy of their protests cannot be questioned. When real politics is so constrained, popular anger that may have many causes other than the one proclaimed jets through the few allowed channels with greater force. Probably all Middle Eastern governments want the situation, as the phrase goes, brought under control. But none wants to be associated with a failed effort to do so, hence the caution with which Egypt, for instance, is treating the idea of a summit- meeting on its soil.

In the place of functional activity, Arab diplomats are rushing about in the search for instant condemnation. They are, for example, pursuing a resolution accusing Israel of genocide, at the UN Human Rights Commission in Geneva - a course of action as unfair as it is useless. A hundred dead is a terrible thing, but it is not genocide. The United States, meanwhile, is "working the phones" and President Clinton is available for a summit. There will be one, it may be hazarded, as long as there is not another Ramallah.

The Middle East is a region that resists change, and when change comes it never comes in a uniform way to all its countries. There is no part of the world over which western governments are more prone to sudden panic. But, while it is true that events in Israel and the territories do not augur some immediate upheaval across the region, it would be a different matter if Israelis and Palestinians go into permanent political regression. That is why all must hope that "working the phones" will lead at least to a halt to that process.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Stelios defends brand name
fields.body:
Stelios defends brand name

Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the owner of easyGroup, has called in lawyers in an attempt to protect the "easy" brand name.

The recently launched website easytohire.co.uk, which gives people access to companies that hire products, ranging from dresses to cars, has been contacted by easyGroup lawyers.

Keely Mumbray, managing director of easytohire, said: "We don't think that anyone should have a monopoly on any word in the English language."

Rolls-Royce in £1.1bn order

Singapore Airlines has given aero-engine firm Rolls-Royce a £1.1bn order to fit Trent 900 powerplants in Airbus's new superjumbo plane.

The far east carrier is likely to take up to 25 of the new A3XX aircraft, whose wings are made by UK company BAE Systems.

Singapore Airlines is the launch airline for the 550-seat A3XX. The first of the new planes will join its fleet in 2006.

Rolls-Royce will build more than 100 engines, which will be delivered over a five-year period from 2006.

Axa faces high court order

The Consumers' Association is to seek a high court order against Axa to force it to fund a legal challenge by 500 policyholders over the insurer's plans to distribute £1.7bn in orphan assets.

The association believes that potential payouts are biased in favour of shareholders.

It decided to file an application for costs against Axa after it refused to fund a legal challenge earlier this week.

"We have been inundated with thousands of letters of concern over Axa's plans. The fact that 500 people have asked us to represent them in court is symbolic of the extent of policyholder concern on this issue," said the association.

Hornby shows positive signs

Hornby said it was no longer in talks with parties regarding a possible takeover of the company.

The model train manufacturer said its current trading was ahead of where it was at the same time last year, adding that its programme to reduce stock was progressing well. Although it was too early to predict sales at the critical Christmas period, the signs were "positive".

The company said that if all went well it could return a significant amount of cash to shareholders early in 2001.

Bus operators' offices raided

Office of fair trading officials investigating bus operations in the Leeds area have raided the offices of two of the country's largest bus operators, FirstGroup and Arriva.

Officials confirmed that they visited FirstGroup's business in Leeds and Arriva's Yorkshire operations in Wakefield. They took documents away for investigation.

The OFT team also visited the groups' head offices in Aberdeen and Sunderland.

A spokeswoman said that they were gathering information and would not decide whether there had been an infringement of competition law by the two operators until they had all the facts.

OFT adds Boys to team

The office of fair trading said Penny Boys has been appointed as deputy director general.

Ms Boys is presently secretary to the competition commission. The timing of her move to her new post will depend on arrangements for her replacement at the commission, the OFT said.

fields.headline: Africa's new dreams
fields.trailText: Christopher Hope's article contained some valid criticism of the new South Africa, but the headline did his case a disservice. Any suggestion that the new South Africa is "a lot like the old one" is outrageous.
fields.body:
Christopher Hope's article (Just like old times, G2, October 11) contained some valid criticism of the new South Africa, but the headline did his case a disservice. Any suggestion that the new South Africa is "a lot like the old one" is outrageous.

Graeme Bloch's reply (I cannot recognise the picture you paint, G2, October 13) spoke eloquently for many of us who went through worse punishments under the old apartheid regime than merely having our words banned, and made, with categorical examples, the case that the new democratic South Africa is in fact gloriously different from the old in its entire approach to dissidence.

To suggest otherwise on the basis of such marginal criticisms as were made, compared with the days when critics were arrested, prosecuted, banned, exiled, banished and murdered, is to insult the great achievements of those South African heroes who have achieved such a great transformation of what was deservedly such a pariah state.
Donald Woods
London

webTitle: Bush pulls ahead after tarring Gore as lover of big government

fields.headline: Bush pulls ahead after tarring Gore as lover of big government
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush has recovered his lead in the American presidential election opinion polls in part because more voters have come to see Al Gore as a traditional liberal advocate of big government, advisers to both White House candidates believe.
fields.body:
George W Bush has recovered his lead in the American presidential election opinion polls in part because more voters have come to see Al Gore as a traditional liberal advocate of big government, advisers to both White House candidates believe.

Republican strategists urged Mr Bush to put the "big government" issue at the centre of his case against Mr Gore during the second presidential debate earlier this week in North Carolina.

Mr Bush, as usual, carried out his advisers' wishes to the full.

President Clinton is believed to be among the Democratic moderates who counselled Mr Gore to place more emphasis on the government's role as a promoter of opportunity rather than as a provider of solutions, an approach that Mr Gore tried to follow with limited success in the debate.

While recent US campaign headlines have focused on aspects of the candidates' characters, Mr Bush's current surge has been accompanied by the emergence of strong public support for a smaller and less activist government than Mr Gore proposes.

Results of a Washington Post survey of public opinion this week showed that Americans prefer a less interventionist government by a margin of nearly two to one, a finding which could make it very hard for Mr Gore to capture centre-ground voters, who are particularly sceptical about government activism.

According to the Post poll, 58% of voters say that they would favour "smaller government with fewer services", as against 32% of Americans who prefer "larger government with many services". When asked which of the two candidates would do a better job "holding down the size of government", 54% chose Mr Bush, while only 33% chose Mr Gore.

Mr Gore's dilemma is that almost all of the individual programmes he supports are very popular; he revived his flagging candidacy this summer by pledging to use government spending to help "working families" and the poor.

Yet, as the election nears, those promises seem not to hold such attraction for the affluent minority of Americans who are expected to vote on November 7.

"Gore's reliance on government solutions has been very successful in rallying the Democratic base, but it does not play well with the independent voters whose support he also now needs," a leading Democratic moderate said this week.

Mr Bush, who has placed a $1,300bn (£885bn) tax cut over 10 years at the centre of his programme, relentlessly painted Mr Gore as a supporter of big government during their debate.

"I don't believe, like the vice-president does, in huge government," Mr Bush said Wednesday during his closing remarks."I believe in limited government. And by having a limited government and a focused government we can send some of the money back to the people that pay the bills."

On several occasions during the debate, Mr Gore tried to stress his credentials as a limited-government man. "I'm for shrinking the size of government. I want a smaller and smarter government," he said.

"I'm not for command and control techniques," he said later in the debate.

At times, however, Mr Gore also seemed an enthusiast for government intervention at home and abroad; responding to Mr Bush's calls for limited US foreign engagement, Mr Gore said that the US should "provide the leadership on the environment, leadership to make sure the world economy keeps moving in the right direction".

And when he talked about subjects such as healthcare, hate crimes and education, Mr Gore seemed to embrace government activism very willingly.

In 1992 and 1996, Mr Clinton successfully finessed the issue with his "third way" strategy, in which he reinvented the Democrats as the party of more limited government activism.

Mr Gore has not been able to follow through on that approach in the way that hardcore moderates - such as his running mate, Senator Joseph Lieberman, and President Clinton - would normally favour.

As he saw his support languishing throughout the first half of this year, Mr Gore was compelled to move to the left, trying to inspire traditional Democratic voters with promises of big spending programmes - especially on pensions and prescription drug benefits for the elderly - made possible by the surplus in the federal budget.

That strategy restored Mr Gore's candidacy to health in August and for much of September. But in the past three weeks the vice-president has lost ground as Mr Bush regained it with promises of tax cuts.

Win or lose, the issue is certain to be at the heart of the election post-mortems after November 7.

fields.headline: Many frogs, few princes
fields.trailText: Have I lost my sense of "fun", or does it say something utterly desperate about our society that when a middle-aged woman exposes her bra for a few seconds during one of these interminable "award" ceremonies, it actually becomes part of the national news?
fields.body:
Have I lost my sense of "fun", or does it say something utterly desperate about our society that when a middle-aged woman exposes her bra for a few seconds during one of these interminable "award" ceremonies (Richard takes blame as Judy comes undone, October 11), it actually becomes part of the national news? But as the Indian proverb so aptly puts it, "The frog who lives at the bottom of a well doesn't know what the ocean is like, because it doesn't know there is an ocean."
Jacques Legars
London

 Writing about Judy Finnigan (One of us, October 12), Gareth McLean says: "It might sound sexist to reduce a woman to her bosom but it isn't." Isn't it? Funny, sounds pretty sexist to me. Mind you, perhaps that's because this little gem was nestling in the midst of two pages of patronising banality. Surely you have something more edifying with which to fill pages than this misogynist drivel?
Rebecca Lee
London

 I have never heard of Judy Finnigan, yet I have heard of "Richard and Judy", without ever having seen their show. Teaching a group of bright sixth-formers yesterday, I discovered that none of them had heard of Arthur Scargill, the Tolpuddle martyrs or Buddy Holly. They all had mobile phones, though, one of which went off. I wonder if these facts are related in any way?
Tony Rowlands
Bristol

fields.headline: Glamour, girls
fields.trailText: Thank you so much for your headline today telling us all that Paris fashion week is "more edgy than New York, not as harsh as London or as over-enthusiastic as Milan". I have to confess that this still leaves me sartorially challenged.

Is it all right if I go out today in my turquoise tracksuit with oatmeal knitted waistcoat and dark blue suede loafers, or should I dress up a bit more with my tartan trousers, off-white blouse and the green cardigan with gold buttons?
