Chester

 Adoring babychild turns into stroppy, self-obsessed pre-adolescent (He's a big boy now, October 11). Way to go son, with a mother who thinks it reasonable to write about this crucial stage in your life in a national newspaper, you sound reassuringly normal to me.

London

The Beastie Boys managed it with Girls, on their seminal debut album, Licensed to Ill, from 1987(ish). Although the lyrics are repugnant, sexist, hilarious claptrap, the kids can come up with some of their own, making it an English lesson too. Simply set the drums to a rocky/funky beat, select a bass-heavy instrument for the keyboard (although it won't be used much), and have the xylophones leading. London

London

Bournemouth

fields.headline: Baronesses bite back
fields.trailText: So Catherine Bennett prefers Ann Widdecombe to Margaret Jay? I must say that I am no more impressed by her preference than I am by her flippant - and patronising - approach to the real needs of women.
fields.body:
So Catherine Bennett prefers Ann Widdecombe to Margaret Jay (Distant voices, G2, October 12)? I must say that I am no more impressed by her preference than I am by her flippant - and patronising - approach to the real needs of women.

Margaret Jay stands for the Labour record on women's issues: more than a million women benefiting from the minimum wage; millions of families better off thanks to the working families tax credit; new childcare places for more than a million children; helping women to balance home and family commitments; not to mention giving women working part-time the right to be treated the same as their full-time, often male, counterparts.

In contrast, Ann Widdecombe stands for the Tories' neglect of women's issues during their 18 years in power, and the backward steps they would take if they returned. Despite having a female prime minister, the Tories ignored the concerns of women and the pay gap, and failed to provide decent, affordable childcare. If they ever came back to power they would abolish the working families tax credit and provide tax breaks only to those women who are lucky enough to live in Miss Widdecombe's "preferred model" of marriage. This would transfer money from some of the poorest women, such as single parents and their children.

Think again, Ms Bennett. Do you really prefer a woman who would deny you the choice to live your life how you wish, or a woman who is committed to helping those women who need it most?
Baroness Lockwood

 As women Labour peers, we know Margaret Jay both as a woman and as a minister. She is nothing like the malicious portrait painted by Catherine Bennett.

If Ms Bennett wants to indulge in this pernicious and inaccurate rubbish, that is a matter for her. But Guardian readers deserve better.
Baroness Blackstone, Baroness Gould of Potternewton, and 14 others

webTitle: Letters: Words that precede the bombs

fields.headline: Words that precede the bombs
fields.trailText: Amos Oz attacks Arafat and pleads for a Palestinian right to nationhood and sovereignty. Mr Oz's tone is temperate and rational. This contrasts with Edward Said's article, which makes a similar demand for Palestinian rights, but uses the language of anger and hate.
fields.body:
Amos Oz (Why Arafat must take the blame, October 13) attacks Arafat and pleads for a Palestinian right to nationhood and sovereignty. Mr Oz's tone is temperate and rational. This contrasts with Edward Said's article (Double standards, October 12), which makes a similar demand for Palestinian rights, but uses the language of anger and hate.

Mr Said calls Ariel Sharon a "paunchy old war criminal", Yasser Arafat "an ageing and discredited leader" of a "corrupt and stupidly oppressive regime", and Hosni Mubarak an "isolated and unpopular Arab chief... compelled humiliatingly to toe the American line". When a respected academic such as Mr Said resorts to inflammatory vilification, attacking people because they are overweight and old, he discredits his own argument, and lets down the Palestinians, for whom he has acted as a spokesperson. He certainly would not make it easy for Mr Oz to persuade his fellow Israelis to put away their guns and begin delicate negotiations.
Fred Lowe
Dublin

 Do I detect double standards in the media's reporting of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict? Israeli soldiers were "murdered", but 12-year-old Mohammed al-Durrah was "killed".
Dr Andrew Strouthous
London
andystrouthous@hotmail.com

 In all the news about the repugnant beating to death of the Israeli soldiers, few journalists seem to have considered the possibility that the victims may have been on an undercover assignment targeting Palestinian radicals. Just such an operation led to the killing of a Palestinian activist a few weeks ago. Even if they were "reservists" who got "lost" (though Ramallah is surrounded by Israeli roadblocks), the anger and fear of Palestinians over these undercover operations explains the brutality of the killings. Does no one remember the killing of German pilots by British civilians during the war?
Paul Cheney
Department of international relations, San Francisco State University
pacheney@sfsu.edu

 Those of us who gladly took part in the war against territorial aggression and racial madness 60 years ago, those who found great satisfaction in liberating Belsen, must view the present conflict in the Holy Land with great sadness.

The images are the same. A young boy shot dead cowering with his father behind a rock. The people held to be responsible brutally beaten to death.

We are all to blame, insofar as the UN failed to impose international law after the 1967 war and has allowed illegal occupation ever since. The madness of the Suez operation diminished Britain's moral position. The foreign policy of the US is flawed with political considerations. Surely now is the time for the UN to show real strength and resolve at last. Or is it already too late?
H Smith
Felixstowe

 The Arab-Israeli peace initiative nurtured by the Clinton administration now looks irremediably damaged. Had it been successful, not only would it have been a triumph for President Clinton, but the Democratic party would also have benefited, with the increased possibility of the election of Al Gore as the next president of the United States. As it is, an absence of a peace settlement will benefit presidential candidate Bush.

An exactly similar situation occurred in 1968 when the out-going President Johnson tried to arrange a peace settlement of the Vietnam war.

The Paris talks failed when the South Vietnamese withdrew from the negotiations. We now know that Richard Nixon was directly responsible for the withdrawal of the South Vietnamese, who were promised better terms if Nixon were elected. The result was that Johnson's initiative failed, Nixon narrowly beat Democrat candidate Hubert Humphrey in the November election and the war continued until the final humiliation of the Americans in 1973.

Am I justified in being cynical about US involvement in the Middle East?
Chris Weeks
Beaworthy, Devon

 As long as mankind remains in thrall to outdated beliefs in "gods", there is no chance of peace on earth. All religions profess peace and love - yet they have been responsible for most of the bloodshed throughout the ages. Can anyone really believe an all-loving God would wish the men who tore those Israeli soldiers to pieces to be with him in paradise? Religions are relics of the dark ages. They foster hatred, enmity and bigotry and have no place in a modern, civilised society.
Robert Readman
Boscombe, Dorset

fields.headline: The Maxwell files
fields.standfirst: Hoover bounced the Czech
fields.trailText: FBI agents detailed to keep an eye on the bouncing Czech wondered why Robert Maxwell was keeping his (female) staff up late. Evidently disappointed, they concluded it was only to get more work out of them.
fields.body:
Given what we now know about J Edgar Hoover's private life and proclivities, to turn up in FBI files might be a testimony to moral fitness rather than the opposite. Pandering to the boss's prurience, agents detailed to keep an eye on the bouncing Czech wondered why Robert Maxwell was keeping his (female) staff up late. Evidently disappointed, they concluded it was only to get more work out of them.

So Maxwell was no threat to the American way of life. Minor self-reinvention (claiming to come from Scotland rather than central Europe) was and remains the American way. What these releases from Washington show, in spite of their deadpan style, is how much larger than life Maxwell was, how energetic - he did not just aspire to be prime minister but to write the antidote to Das Kapital. That "pathological ambition" recorded by an FBI informant makes it easier to explain how he managed to steamroller his way through so many industries and reputations, let alone pension funds.

The bureau disclosed reports on Maxwell to third parties, which was probably illegal. Unscrupulous he was (at that stage in his career - worse followed) but he doubtless shared an interest in making a fast buck with many members of the American College of Physicians which was being warned against him.

The files, in other words, say as much about Hoover's FBI as about the would-be political and intellectual hero it was investigating. But does the release of the files impede the bureau's present-day law enforcement activities? Of course not. We know Maxwell had extensive dealings with the Secret Intelligence Service, MI6; it may even have "invented" him. His Security Service file must be pretty thick too. When the Americans can be as free with information as they are, there can be no UK national interest in retaining files here. The Blair government's constipated passage of freedom of information legislation will do little to help.

fields.headline: Memorable responses
fields.trailText: In 1994 I wrote to Labour parliamentarians asking if they could send me a short definition of "socialism". Three-quarters did not reply.
fields.body:
In 1994 I wrote to Labour parliamentarians asking if they could send me a short definition of "socialism". Three-quarters did not reply. One Labour peer (a former minister in the Callaghan government) telephoned me to say how insulted he felt by the request. The response I received from Donald Dewar was very different. He wrote: "Thank you for your letter. I thought it would be discourteous not to reply, but I must confess that I am not very practised at definitions.

"For me socialism is very much a matter of my general approach to political problems. I have never seen the Labour party as being narrowly bound by one definition or one particular approved ideological form. Politics and the Labour party are about redressing the balance in favour of ordinary people and the constant fight against poverty and lack of opportunity. It is a matter of justice and common sense in practical approach which carries confidence and so leads to power. I am afraid none of that amounts to a definition, but for that I make no apology."

It says something about the quality of the man.
Ivor Morgan
Lincoln

 Donald Dewar is quoted as saying that "cynicism, together with unrealistic expectations, are the two greatest bugbears of polities". I would suggest that facing up to this important point would be the most worthwhile tribute to a truly great man.

A change in attitudes would be a valuable memorial to a fine man.
Anthony Garrett
Falkland

fields.headline: Sentencing politics
fields.standfirst: Let justice decide Hindley's release
fields.trailText: Why is Myra Hindley still in prison? For one simple reason: because politicians have been left in charge of her release.
fields.body:
Why is Myra Hindley still in prison? For one simple reason: because politicians have been left in charge of her release. Successive home secretaries have refused to take on the tabloids, who have turned her into a focal point of evil. She also provides a useful foil. The last three home secretaries - Straw, Howard and Waddington - have sought to bolster their "tough" images with declarations that Hindley would spend the rest of her life behind bars. Mr Straw leaked his reaffirmation of this decision in 1997, as a cover for a liberal move under which several thousand short-term prisoners were offered early release through electronic tags. Now the lord chief justice, in an interview in this week's New Statesman, has reaffirmed his view that under the new Human Rights Act, home secretaries are likely to lose their power to decide how long murderers serve in prison. Good for him.

There is a proper role for politicians in sentencing, which includes establishing a proper legal framework and broad policy. But in a democracy, they should play no part in determining sentence lengths of individuals. Mature democracies are supposed to have risen above such tinpot dictatorial procedures. Slowly, but inex orably, the home secretary's powers over the release of convicted killers has been cut back. The European Court of Human Rights has already ruled that once the two boys who killed James Bulger have served their "tariff" (the fixed term for retribution and deterrence), the final indeterminate period which depends on risks posed by the offenders can no longer be set by home secretaries. Earlier, home secretaries lost the power of release over discretionary lifers. But they still, for the moment, hold on to their power after a mandatory life sentence. Hindley's case is likely to be one of the first under the new Human Rights Act.

No one would want to deny the gravity of Hindley's crimes, nor ignore her refusal over 20 years to accept culpability for all five children murdered. But all this is a long time ago. She has now served 35 years, more than twice the average life sentence. The lord chief justice at the time of her trial, no softie, only recommended 25 years. The parole board, which scrutinised her case minutely, has already recommended an open prison - a pre-step to release. All that is keeping her inside is public opinion. But justice systems, set up to be above lynch law, are expected to rise above public opinion.

webTitle: Four arrested on allegations of fraud over Dome contract

fields.headline: Four arrested on allegations of fraud over contract
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Four people have been arrested by police in connection with allegations of fraud involving a Millennium Dome contract, Scotland Yard said yesterday.
fields.body:
Four people have been arrested by police in connection with allegations of fraud involving a Millennium Dome contract, Scotland Yard said yesterday.

Two people - a man in his 30s and a woman in her 60s -were detained on Thursday morning at addresses in London and West Yorkshire.

The pair were bailed to return to a London police station in February.

A man in his 30s and a woman in her 20s were arrested by Merseyside police in the Wavertree district of Liverpool on Thursday afternoon.

They will be taken to a London police station "in due course", a spokesman at Scotland Yard said.

A number of addresses have been searched during the operation by officers from the Metropolitan police fraud squad's public sector team in London, and a "quantity of material has been removed", the spokesman said.

But a spokeswoman for the New Millennium Experience Company, which operates the dome, said the attraction itself, on the bank of the Thames in south-east London, was not searched.

A company spokesman said: "It is a matter for the police and the courts. That is all we can say at the moment."

Details of the fraud squad's investigation of the "inappropriate" contract first emerged almost a month ago.

The allegations were brought to the attention of fraud squad officers by the dome's operators, who spotted the alleged irregularity during an internal audit.

A company spokesman said in September that the con tractor in question was responsible for services within the dome building itself rather than the actual structure or the attractions.

The fraud squad inquiry centres on an allegation of illegal procurement of a contract by a firm working for the NMEC.

The claims of irregularities are believed to be related to an alleged failure, involving a south-east London firm, to follow guidelines.

fields.headline: Radio 1 axeman quits key post
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The BBC lost one of its most senior executives yesterday when Matthew Bannister, the axeman of Radio 1's ageing disc jockeys, quit the corporation after 22 years.
fields.body:
The BBC lost one of its most senior executives yesterday when Matthew Bannister, the axeman of Radio 1's ageing disc jockeys, quit the corporation after 22 years.

He will step down as director of marketing and communications at the end of the year, a role he was given in a BBC restructuring led by Greg Dyke, the director general.

Mr Bannister was credited with the transformation of Radio 1, which has led to its current success. But his plans to restructure the marketing department have met with resistance. Many staff could not conceal their delight at his departure.

Staff were informed via an email from Mr Dyke, which read: "I am very sorry he is leaving but he has decided it is time for a change in the direction of his career.

"He has done some of the most interesting jobs around, and BBC Radio's current success is in no short measure down to the work he did as the controller of Radio 1 and as director of radio."

Mr Bannister had intended to leave after he lost out to Mr Dyke in the race for the post of director general, but friends say the pair "gelled" as soon as they met. Mr Dyke persuaded him to stay, but Mr Bannister hinted yesterday that he had not enjoyed his latest post. "When you have worked for the BBC for a long time, as I have, it can get a bit much for you," he said.

As Radio 1 controller, Mr Bannister was responsible for clearing out the old guard of "smashie and nicey" DJs and repositioning the station for younger listeners. He recruited Chris Evans to the station. Ratings fell drastically during his reign, but have increased since. Observers put its current success down to the Bannister revolution.

Others, however, say he was out of his depth in senior positions. As director of radio, he had a difficult relationship with the controller of Radio 3, Nicholas Kenyon. His position as the BBC's director of production was short-lived.

Mr Bannister, 43, began at BBC local radio as a reporter 22 years ago, later rising through the ranks at Capital Radio, in London. In 1988 he became managing editor of BBC Greater London Radio and went on to become Radio 1 controller in 1993.

A number of people have been tipped to succeed him: Richard Peel, a long-serving BBC press spokesman who is now at the Independent Television Commission is one possibility, as is the BBC press chief, Sally Osman. Both, however, have little experience of marketing. An outsider is Mr Bannister's predecessor, Sue Farr, who left the corporation after her role was reduced.

Mr Bannister said he had no immediate plans. He will stay at the BBC until December.

webTitle: Glastonbury festival organiser faces prosecution over safety

fields.headline: Glastonbury festival organiser faces prosecution over safety
fields.trailText: Glastonbury festival's organiser Michael Eavis is facing prosecution for allegedly letting twice the permitted number of revellers into this year's event.
fields.body:
Glastonbury festival's organiser Michael Eavis is facing prosecution for allegedly letting twice the permitted number of revellers into this year's event.

Police believe an estimated 100,000 fans jumped the fence or otherwise avoided paying, vastly swelling crowds and jeopardising public safety. Mendip district council, which licenses the Somerset festival, voted at the end of a three-hour meeting on Thursday to recommend that the farmer be prosecuted for breaching his licence.

Superintendent John Buckley, who led the police operation at the festival, told the council that Mr Eavis had failed adequately to control access to the site, failed to ensure the integrity of the perimeter fence and failed to provide adequate security.

"We view the issues we have raised as being extremely serious. This is not the first time that concerns have been expressed regarding the festival," said Mr Buckley.

"Regrettably, other large public events have suffered tragedies, and the priority for all of us must be public safety."

Mr Eavis claimed to have been victimised following the deaths of nine people at the Roskilde rock festival in Denmark earlier this year.

"There has been Roskilde, Notting Hill and Hillsborough and they think we're going to be next," he said.

"It is rubbish. We didn't get one person hurt as a result of crushing or overcrowding this year. This is the best organised festival in the world. I've put my heart, life, soul and body into it to make it work."

The farmer, who has been running the festival at his Pilton farm since 1972, recently unveiled a section of a new "super fence" aimed at deterring fence-jumpers.

However, Mr Buckley said he did not agree that the "super fence" would be an adequate deterrent to anyone wanting to get in without a ticket.

A final decision on prosecution will be taken by the council's chief executive.

It is now possible that an application for a licence to host next year's festival could be refused.

webTitle: Stripping away shyness US soprano comes down to earth at Lakes master class

fields.headline: Stripping away shyness US soprano comes down to earth at Lakes master class
fields.trailText: The American soprano Barbara Bonney, famous for the sensitivity of her singing and the breadth of her repertoire, has performed in all the world's great opera houses and venues.
fields.body:
The American soprano Barbara Bonney, famous for the sensitivity of her singing and the breadth of her repertoire, has performed in all the world's great opera houses and venues.

But tonight she makes her first appearance at a less well known arts venue - the Methodist church in Wordsworth Street, Penrith, Cumbria.

She will be teaching, not singing. The audience will watch a masterclass in which she will guide six young singers, three of them British, through songs, arias and other big numbers from the concert repertoire.

The six were selected from 56 students at music colleges around Britain under a scheme promoted by the Samling Foundation, established in 1996 to develop the talents of young visual and performing artists.

For two days, the international star has worked with her students in the sanctu ary of a country house on the shores of Ullswater in the Lake District.

Yesterday she asked tenor Paul Robinson why he felt tense and nervous as he launched into Richard Strauss's Zueignung. "Because you're naked," he replied in a metaphorical kind of way.

"But stripping naked is probably the most wonderful thing a human being can do in front of other people," replied Ms Bonney, whose meaning appeared much more literal: she urged the six to strip off (in the privacy of their own homes) in front of a mirror, the better to know themselves.

In a baronial room (oak beams, chandelier, crossed brass trumpets) she kept her own clothes on but fell to her knees, taking Mr Robinson with her, much to his surprise. And there on the carpet they duetted like penitents. "Don't sing with such a big voice," she urged. "When you are nervous, pick someone in the audience to sing to. They will be so giving that they will help you to overcome your nervousness."

Fiona Duncan, a soprano, tried one of Strauss's Four Last Songs and was encouraged to leave out the words and to go back to find her "eight-year-old voice". Ms Duncan described the session as nerve wracking but fabulous. "I've found another voice," she beamed. "When I did the song a second time, I felt I was floating, with the sound coming out of the top of my head. It's amazing to have been able to achieve that in just one session."

Ms Bonney, meanwhile, took in the view of the fells and considered the years to come. "I'm thinking about how much longer I will be able to stand this schedule of travelling and singing so much," she said.

"It's a gruelling life. I've been thinking about what I am going to do after that. And now I know. It's something to look forward to.It gives me huge gratification to pass something on in this way."

webTitle: Forecast on visitors doomed the dome

fields.headline: Forecast on visitors doomed the dome
fields.standfirst:
National audit office report spectacular over-optimism meant disaster was inevitable from day one, says watchdog
Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: National audit office report spectacular over-optimism meant disaster was inevitable from day one, says watchdog.
fields.body:
A devastating, blow by blow account that leaves few people connected with the £1bn Millennium Dome fiasco unscathed will be revealed by parliament's financial watchdog, the national audit office, next month.

The report describes how the misconceived project - already over budget before it opened - applied for four separate tranches of cash this year, totalling £179m, to avoid bankruptcy.

The report records a story of how directors and senior staff of the New Millennium Experience Company lost control of the dome's finances, accepted without question over optimistic visitor projections, and had no clue of who owned what and how many contracts they had let.

The only way disaster could have been avoided was if the dome had never been opened in the first place.

The one year contracts signed before the end of last year were based on 12m visitors including 1m guests coming to the dome.

The dramatic failure to predict accurately the correct number of visitors is the main reason the auditors give for the financial catastrophe that followed.

The national audit office predicts that the final figure for visitors will be 4.5m, including cut price tickets and 1m guests.

As a result of the shortfall in visitors, money was haemorrhaging from the dome each month, the report points out.

The auditors blame the original directors of the company, who include Michael Grade, Channel 4's former chief executive, Sir Brian Jenkins, chairman of the Woolwich Bank, and Bob Ayling, former chief executive of British Airways, for not taking a grip on the project.

They also reveal that the nine millennium commissioners initially failed to question the visitor projections until things started going wrong.

The first alarm bell rang when the dome company took up a £50m tranche held in reserve.

The second came in February - only two months after the dome had opened - when the company won a "final" £60m to tide it over.

The money was handed over only after the millennium commission sent its own finance officers into the com pany to check the facts. They came back saying the cash was essential. The dome immediately gobbled up £30m to stave off debts - and then drew on the remaining £30m over the next two months.

By May there was a demand for another £38.4m. This time the commission's director, Mike O' Connor, refused to sign the cheque.

Accountants Deloitte and Touche had already been sent in to the dome, and uncovered more financial disasters.

But Chris Smith, the culture secretary, and the nine commissioners agreed to give the dome another £29m.

Then in August the dome company demanded another £43m as part of the deal to sell it as an going concern to the Japanese company, Nomura, at the end of the year. The money was granted on the grounds it would be returned after Nomura paid £105m to take over the dome. Then came the devastating report from PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accountantcy firm, revealing the dome was technically insolvent and could not meet its bills.

Nomura pulled out and the company's letter -put in the House of Lords library by the government - lists a catalogue of failings, all covered in the auditors' report.

The final blow came last month when the commissioners had to overrule its own director for the second time in four months, after he refused to pay out another £47m to keep the dome afloat and provide for the "winding up" process. Once again the money had to be paid by diktat.

webTitle: State fights tribe's bid to ban alcohol on Indian land

fields.headline: State fights tribe's bid to ban alcohol on Indian land
fields.trailText: Two hundred years ago, white hunters and traders in the United States believed that the best way to cheat native Americans was to get them drunk.
fields.body:
Two hundred years ago, white hunters and traders in the United States believed that the best way to cheat native Americans was to get them drunk.

To this day, alcoholism is one of the main problems on the reservations. Now a fight is brewing over a historic decision by one tribe to ban alcohol sales on its reservation, a decision being challenged in the courts by the state's attorney general.

The Yakama tribe in Toppenish, Washington state, has been deeply affected like almost every other tribe by alcoholism among its members. Three weeks ago, it decided to ban the sale of alcohol at the stores and taverns on its 2,000 sq mile ( 5,000 sq km) reservation: possibly the first time a "wet" reserve has voted to go dry.

But the ban has prompted protests from some among the 20,000 non-Indians living in the three small towns on the reservation; they want to continue buying alcohol there.

The dispute highlights the Indians' struggle to deal with the debilitating effects of alcohol - and the issue of just how much power they can wield inside what are supposedly autonomous areas.

The attorney general of Washington state, Christine Gregoire, plans to sue the Yakama for trying to impose a local law that they have no authority to enforce. The Yakama claim that under the federal laws of the 1830s, intoxicants should not be sold on Indian land.

Jack Fiander, a lawyer and tribal council member leading what he believes is the first attempt by a US tribe to ban liquor sales, said: "It's symbolic when you enact something that excludes alcohol from the reservation. It's like you're casting it out."

Mr Fiander cites statistics showing how much alcohol has damaged the tribe. Alcohol figures in twice the number of traffic accidents involving native Americans on the reservation as against the rest of the state. Mr Fiander has complained that many of the grocery stores are effectively liquor stores, taking around 80% of their profits from liquor.

Ms Gregoire's office stresses that the state appreciates the Yakama's desire to deal with a serious problem, and is challenging only the tribe's methods. "We're very understanding about the desire of the tribe to address the serious problems of alcohol," said a spokesman, adding that the action was being brought to find out if the Yakama had the right to impose the rules on non-Yakama.

Indian Health Service data show that native Americans are three times more likely than other Americans to die of cirrhosis of the liver. Between 5% and 25% of their babies are likely to be born with mental or physical damage because the mothers are alcoholic. The average national rate is 0.2%.

Michael Dorris, in his study of foetal alcohol syndrome entitled The Broken Cord, wrote: "Tribe after tribe learned... how to drink from Europeans whose bad manners, determination to get drunk and lack of restraint were notorious."

Mr Dorris argued that, over time, Indian communities incorporated this "trapper style".

In Killing the White Man's Indian, Fergus Bordewich wrote: "White traders well knew that a drunk Indian was easier to exploit than a sober one, and many an Indian was tricked out of the fruits of his hunt when he was offered a 'free dram'. "

Now the courts will have to decide if there was ever really such a thing as a free dram.

webTitle: Facing a vista of rack and ruin

fields.headline: Facing a vista of rack and ruin
fields.standfirst:
Residents awaken to scenes of devastation
Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: At 3 am yesterday the centre of the small Sussex town of Uckfield was under several feet of water. After the drama of the flood 24 hours earlier there was an eerie calm, even a surreal beauty as the waves rippled in the moonlight against the walls of McDonald's, the bank and supermarkets.
fields.body:
At 3 am yesterday the centre of the small Sussex town of Uckfield was under several feet of water. After the drama of the flood 24 hours earlier there was an eerie calm, even a surreal beauty as the waves rippled in the moonlight against the walls of McDonald's, the bank and supermarkets.

Five hours later, the deep brown scummy waters had gurgled off towards the sea, leaving a grim reality.

Uckfield residents woke yesterday to find their town devastated. A vile smell of rotting carpets and floor tiles hung in the air. Tarmac and pavement had been ripped up. The foundations of houses had been exposed. Litter and packaging had spread itself all over the industrial estate and back a half mile on to the main roads.

The floor of Boots the chemist was a foot deep in shampoos and medicines, glass and shelving. Estate agents, health food shops and interior decorators were counting the cost of the worst floods in memory.

For Martin Stenning, a Sussex University ecologist who lives in the town, it was all predictable. "There has been increasing development in the town and all over the flood plain," he said. "The water is running off the new estates and fields faster than ever. This is an awful warning for people who want to build in inappropriate places."

If Uckfield was trying to get back to normal, for other towns the worst was by no means over yesterday. As the waters receded in some places they were mounting elsewhere downstream.

Emergency services spent all night evacuating the village of Yalding, near Tonbridge, only to find the waters still rising all yesterday and yet more people to be evacuated by boat or helicopter. "We've picked up 30 people so far ," said a Kent fire brigade spokesman yesterday morning. " We've been up all night and there seems no end to it."

"We went to bed at 10pm and the water was just a few inches high," said Steve Boone, who lives near the village. "This morning it was five feet up the stairs. We got really worried when we saw the speed and force of the current. Thank God for the brigade, they were brilliant."

The hundred or more people in the nearby Hampstead Fields caravan park were evacuated through the night. "We lost absolutely everything. We've had two floods already this year but this was the big one," said Susan Pullen.

Her husband Mick had been out on a borrowed boat to see if he could find anything. He returned crestfallen: "We are still alive, girl, but it's start again time now. The fish is gone, the photographs too, but I've got the financial papers. I can hardly believe it. The waters are six feet deep now. Everybody's stuff is floating around, even the dustbins."

Yalding and many other Kent and Sussex villages were yesterday, in effect, islands in wide seas of floodwater. In Lewes, where hundreds of people spent the night in churches or community halls, the waters rose steadily until high tide at 1am. By morning ambulances, goalposts and telephone boxes and several hundred houses were still under five feet of water in the north and west of the town.

James French was keeping guard on his brother-in-law's house where water reached ceiling height, but by lunch time yesterday was only four feet deep. "They are on holiday. I don't dare tell them what's happened," he said.

"Lewes is a great big mess," said Jan Parker, a resident. "There are barrels of beer bobbing down the river, factories near the river have gone under, and part of the shopping centre is devastated."

The scale of the floods and intensity of the rainfall has shocked people as streams have turned into rivers, puddles into lakes and lakes into small seas in just a few hours.

With the floods have come traffic gridlock and eccentric driving. Yesterday the emergency services were infuriated by cars stuck while trying to turn round in deep puddles and many motorists ignoring warning signs.

"It's only October, the start of the rains and bad weather," said Jane Marsham, shopping yesterday in Lewes. "This isn't normal. We need to know what is happening."

"It's like after a hurricane here," says Martin Pebburt who farms organically between Lewes and Uckfield. "We've lost all our potatoes and some carrots but others have lost cattle and poultry. It will be the last straw for some. I am devastated."

Ten miles away in the village of Five Oak Green, the clear-up was starting for the third time in 10 months and recriminations were flying. Many residents believe that the floods have considerably wors ened since an estate of houses was built on the old village pond. "They've mucked around rotten with the drainage here," said one woman. "If we'd had some gelignite we'd blow the whole lot up. I don't know how much more of this we can take."

By lunchtime, Tonbridge was under threat with the river Medway reaching within 15 centimetres of the top of the bank. The pressure was relieved only by the water board releasing some of the floods through a main sluice. Nevertheless school playing fields were under a metre of water, Sainsbury's supermarket car park was also flooded, and the shopping centre was best approached with wellington boots.

fields.bodyText: At 3 am yesterday the centre of the small Sussex town of Uckfield was under several feet of water. After the drama of the flood 24 hours earlier there was an eerie calm, even a surreal beauty as the waves rippled in the moonlight against the walls of McDonald's, the bank and supermarkets. Five hours later, the deep brown scummy waters had gurgled off towards the sea, leaving a grim reality. Uckfield residents woke yesterday to find their town devastated. A vile smell of rotting carpets and floor tiles hung in the air. Tarmac and pavement had been ripped up. The foundations of houses had been exposed. Litter and packaging had spread itself all over the industrial estate and back a half mile on to the main roads. The floor of Boots the chemist was a foot deep in shampoos and medicines, glass and shelving. Estate agents, health food shops and interior decorators were counting the cost of the worst floods in memory. For Martin Stenning, a Sussex University ecologist who lives in the town, it was all predictable. "There has been increasing development in the town and all over the flood plain," he said. "The water is running off the new estates and fields faster than ever. This is an awful warning for people who want to build in inappropriate places." If Uckfield was trying to get back to normal, for other towns the worst was by no means over yesterday. As the waters receded in some places they were mounting elsewhere downstream. Emergency services spent all night evacuating the village of Yalding, near Tonbridge, only to find the waters still rising all yesterday and yet more people to be evacuated by boat or helicopter. "We've picked up 30 people so far ," said a Kent fire brigade spokesman yesterday morning. " We've been up all night and there seems no end to it." "We went to bed at 10pm and the water was just a few inches high," said Steve Boone, who lives near the village. "This morning it was five feet up the stairs. We got really worried when we saw the speed and force of the current. Thank God for the brigade, they were brilliant." The hundred or more people in the nearby Hampstead Fields caravan park were evacuated through the night. "We lost absolutely everything. We've had two floods already this year but this was the big one," said Susan Pullen. Her husband Mick had been out on a borrowed boat to see if he could find anything. He returned crestfallen: "We are still alive, girl, but it's start again time now. The fish is gone, the photographs too, but I've got the financial papers. I can hardly believe it. The waters are six feet deep now. Everybody's stuff is floating around, even the dustbins." Yalding and many other Kent and Sussex villages were yesterday, in effect, islands in wide seas of floodwater. In Lewes, where hundreds of people spent the night in churches or community halls, the waters rose steadily until high tide at 1am. By morning ambulances, goalposts and telephone boxes and several hundred houses were still under five feet of water in the north and west of the town. James French was keeping guard on his brother-in-law's house where water reached ceiling height, but by lunch time yesterday was only four feet deep. "They are on holiday. I don't dare tell them what's happened," he said. "Lewes is a great big mess," said Jan Parker, a resident. "There are barrels of beer bobbing down the river, factories near the river have gone under, and part of the shopping centre is devastated." The scale of the floods and intensity of the rainfall has shocked people as streams have turned into rivers, puddles into lakes and lakes into small seas in just a few hours. With the floods have come traffic gridlock and eccentric driving. Yesterday the emergency services were infuriated by cars stuck while trying to turn round in deep puddles and many motorists ignoring warning signs. "It's only October, the start of the rains and bad weather," said Jane Marsham, shopping yesterday in Lewes. "This isn't normal. We need to know what is happening." "It's like after a hurricane here," says Martin Pebburt who farms organically between Lewes and Uckfield. "We've lost all our potatoes and some carrots but others have lost cattle and poultry. It will be the last straw for some. I am devastated." Ten miles away in the village of Five Oak Green, the clear-up was starting for the third time in 10 months and recriminations were flying. Many residents believe that the floods have considerably wors ened since an estate of houses was built on the old village pond. "They've mucked around rotten with the drainage here," said one woman. "If we'd had some gelignite we'd blow the whole lot up. I don't know how much more of this we can take." By lunchtime, Tonbridge was under threat with the river Medway reaching within 15 centimetres of the top of the bank. The pressure was relieved only by the water board releasing some of the floods through a main sluice. Nevertheless school playing fields were under a metre of water, Sainsbury's supermarket car park was also flooded, and the shopping centre was best approached with wellington boots. "Six inches of rain in 72 hours. That's more than we get in months. It makes you think," said one policeman, drafted in without so much as a raincoat.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Father accused of child's murder | Three held over carnival death | Students oust ex-soap star
fields.body:
Father accused of child's murder
Leonard Hurst, 33, of Bracebridge Heath, Lincolnshire, was remanded in custody until October 20 by Lincoln magistrates yesterday on a charge of murdering his daughter, Daniella, 2. Hurst, who is separated, was arrested on Tuesday after he was found by police in his car with Daniella's lifeless body in the passenger seat. A postmortem examination revealed carbon monoxide poisoning.

Three held over carnival death
Three men have been arrested in connection with the murder of Abdul Bhatti, 28, at the Notting Hill carnival, police said yesterday. The three, in their teens and 20s, were bailed. Two teenagers held in September are also on police bail.

Students oust ex-soap star
Ex-EastEnders star Ross Kemp was yesterday asked to resign as rector of Glasgow University after failing to attend campus engagements. A vote of no confidence was passed by the students' representative council.

Secret of Cliff's youthful looks
On the eve of his 60th birthday Sir Cliff Richard has revealed that his boyish looks are not all down to clean living. He admitted to OK! magazine that he had his forehead injected with a toxin to banish wrinkles.

Legionnaire's kills priests
Canon Harold Parker, 73, from Ripon, North Yorkshire, and Fr Tony Foulkes, 71, from Blackpool, have died of legionnaire's disease contracted during a millennium reunion at the English College in Rome last month.

webTitle: BBC gets six months to 'prove' 10pm news

fields.headline: BBC gets six months to 'prove' 10pm news
fields.standfirst:
Culture secretary gives warning that ITV is over-regulated, after struggle over programming
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Ministers have given BBC governors six months to review their decision to shift the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.
fields.body:
Ministers have given BBC governors six months to review their decision to shift the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, wants the governors to look at the decision again early next year: if ratings fall, the BBC will be in breach of its royal charter, he said.

Addressing executives from the regional ITV news companies earlier this week, he said ITV's struggle with the Independent Television Commission over News at Ten showed that the commercial network was over-regulated. By contrast, the BBC, a public service broadcaster funded by a universal tax, was able to shift its main evening news bulletin within weeks.

Mr Smith's comments are the first indication that the government intends to curtail the powers of BBC governors in a forthcoming white paper on broadcasting. All broadcasters are likely to be placed under one regulator, with the BBC governors' powers reduced to those of a board of management.

Mr Smith told the ITV bosses it was "no secret" he opposed the move of the BBC news to 10pm.

Questioned by Steve Anderson, ITV's controller of news, about the BBC move, Mr Smith replied: "The governors have specific responsibilities under the charter. If it becomes clear that the decision to move the news from 9pm to 10pm and in the process go head-to-head with ITN does result in a diminishing audience then that seems to me to be a clear breach of the purposes laid down in the charter. It will be incumbent on the board of governors to exercise their responsibilities under the charter."

Asked how long it would take to assess the success of the BBC's move, Mr Smith said: "Six months would give us a good indication."

Sir Christopher Bland, who chairs the BBC board of governors, has indicated that it will review the situation only after a year. The Tories had called for a review after six months.

Mr Smith acknowledged that ITV, a commercial broadcaster, should not have had such a protracted struggle with its regulator over news scheduling. "The difference in the way ITV has had to handle its news move and the way the BBC has gone about it has indeed been noticed. We are looking as part of the white paper process at the way that the BBC and the rest of broadcasting are regulated. There is a very clear case at the moment that ITV is over-regulated."

The last edition of the Nine O'Clock News, which has run on the BBC for more than 30 years but now makes way for ratings-winning drama and entertainment, was presented by Peter Sissons last night. There was no emotional send-off; Sissons simply reminded viewers to tune in at 10pm from Monday.

Sissons said last night that staff had a "sneaking admiration" for the swift move by Greg Dyke, the director general, and Sir Christopher. "You have to trust the judgment of people who were such big hitters in ITV," he said. There were no plans for a big party, but the production team would "crack open a few bottles of champagne."

The Ten O'Clock News would have the same agenda and team as the Nine, he stressed. But regional headlines will be included at the start and an extended regional news bulletin will be incorporated into the end, before the national headlines.

webTitle: Inventor wins ban on rival cleaner Dyson

fields.headline: Inventor wins ban on rival cleaner Dyson
fields.trailText: James Dyson, inventor and manufacturer of the bagless vacuum cleaner, last night won a high court injunction banning Hoover from selling its Triple Vortex cleaner.
fields.body:
James Dyson, inventor and manufacturer of the bagless vacuum cleaner, last night won a high court injunction banning Hoover from selling its Triple Vortex cleaner.

It was the second court victory for Mr Dyson in 10 days. On October 3 deputy judge Michael Fysh QC ruled that Hoover, once the dominant player in the cleaner market, had infringed Mr Dyson's patent by copying parts of his "dual cyclone" cleaner in their new appliance.

Last night the same judge ruled that Hoover may not sell or manufacture any more of its Triple Vortex cleaners within the UK with immediate effect.

But the judge triggered a renewed vacuum cleaner war by reserving judgment on whether to bar Hoover from using the trade mark Vortex.

The group, owned by Italian white goods maker Candy, said it would go ahead with the launch on Monday of a new cleaner, Vortex Power, which relies on a single cyclone mechanism - and does not infringe Mr Dyson's copyright.

Mr Fysh also made clear his ban holds only until Mr Dyson's patent runs out in June next year, and reserved judgment on whether to extend it for a further 12 months after that.

Mr Dyson, 53, a man with a mission to rebuild UK industrial inventiveness, is seeking millions of pounds in damages from Hoover. These will be assessed at a later date by the court, although it last night ordered Hoover to pay an advance £200,000 towards Dyson's costs.

At stake in the 18-month battle is a European market for cleaners worth around £1bn a year. Mr Dyson, who claims more than half the UK market, wants to conquer the continent but says he is held back by the surging pound and UK exclusion from the euro.

Hoover, bought by Candy five years ago after it ran into severe problems with a "free" holiday offer, plans a renewed assault on UK and European markets via its new bagless cleaner, Vortex Power.

Christopher Floyd QC, representing the group, which has seen its share of the UK market plummet to 10%, told the court that Hoover was no longer selling the Triple Vortex and was recalling the model from dealers. Recalled models would have the offending mechanisms taken out and replaced with the new system.

Peter Prescott QC, for Dyson, claimed Hoover had been given at least a 12-month advantage in developing its bagless cleaners by infringing a patent and it should not be allowed to benefit from it. He claimed Hoover had spent £5m promoting the name Vortex and, while its new machine did not infringe the patent, it cashed in on the reputation of the now banned Triple Vortex.

Mr Dyson, who suffered a series of rebuffs from other manufacturers before launching his own cleaners in 1993, sells 98,000 cleaners a month from his Malmesbury base in Wiltshire, which employs 1,900.

Hoover is building its new cleaner at Cambuslang, Glasgow, and last night won leave to take its case that "bagless" technology was well known within the industry to the court of appeal.

webTitle: The man who would be PM - and the new Marx

fields.headline: The man who would be PM - and the new Marx
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Robert Maxwell wanted to become prime minister and write a landmark philosophy book which would have the same enduring influence as the works of Karl Marx, his FBI file reveals.
fields.body:
Robert Maxwell wanted to become prime minister and write a landmark philosophy book which would have the same enduring influence as the works of Karl Marx, his FBI file reveals.

Maxwell confided his ambitions to an associate, who quickly reported back to the FBI that he appeared to be "sincere and nuts".

Over drinks in his apartment in New York in 1956, Maxwell appears to have relaxed and told the informant "freely and confidentially" that his business activities were just a means to achieving his ambitions.

The first was to become prime minister. He had sought nomination as an MP the previous year, but he had been very ill. Maxwell served without much distinction as a Labour MP between 1964 and 1970.

He had already started on his second ambition - a "monumental work on economic philosophy" which was "anti-Marx, but will have the same lasting influence as the works of Marx".

Maxwell was recorded as saying: "The world needs a new philosophy, now that Marx and other isms have proved a failure."

The informant "remarked that he is not a psychiatrist, but to him, it seems that Maxwell is 'sincere and nuts'."

He believed Maxwell had "a pathological amount of ambition".

Maxwell had recently established Pergamon Press which published scientific journals. The associate "pointed out the fear that Pergamon Press... might go bankrupt because of too rapid growth and Maxwell's other fantastic enterprises".

He added that scientists were critical of Maxwell because he was competing in a small market against established firms and non-profit-making societies.

Three days after this conversation, Maxwell dined with an unnamed woman, and again the FBI received a full report. "The informant stated that Maxwell tried to impress her with his importance and his wealth."

According to the report, Maxwell wished to give the impression of being powerful while hoping to make an ally of the informant since she could be of use to him because of her position in the UN atomic organisation.

fields.headline: The ripe stuff
fields.standfirst: Autumn can be a bit depressing, says Laura Barton, but at least we can always cheer ourselves up with the best in British fruit. Jeremy Lee, for one, swears by it
fields.trailText: Autumn can be a bit depressing, says Laura Barton, but at least we can always cheer ourselves up with the best in British fruit. Jeremy Lee, for one, swears by it
fields.body:
Four miles or so from Reading station - just go left at the Pack Saddle pub and follow the signs - lies Cross Lanes Fruit Farm (0118 9723167; email, apples@crosslanesfruitfarm.co.uk), all 25 acres of it filled with 60 varieties of fruit: pears, apples, quince, plums and damsons, available from late August until Christmas. Gill Franklin is standing in her driveway, looking like a sprightly girl with her silvery hair and astonishingly blue eyes. It barely seems possible that she has two grown-up children.

We sit in the kitchen, drinking tea; a pair of black, furry bear slippers has been kicked off in a corner, a bowl of eight pears sits in the middle of the table. Intermittently, Gill leaps up to see to customers, speak to her husband, her son or the gas man. Each time, she climbs into a pair of wellington boots and trots outside. The thin stripe around each leg of her jeans shows where the tops of the wellies have rubbed them pale.

Gill and her husband, Dennis, left London in 1977, substituting the bustle of city life for the hedgerows of Mapledurham. At the time, it was a place where you couldn't buy a red pepper for love nor money, and the restaurants shut on a Tuesday night. Friends thought they were barmy. But the Franklins had a plan: they were hoping to start a family, and also wanted some land that would be an investment. They considered an art gallery and a fishery before deciding on the orchard.

Being novices to the fruit-growing business, they relied at the beginning on two local women who had worked on the farm under its previous owner. Back then, the ministry of agriculture doled out advice free of charge, which was a huge help in the early days. They still get the ministry's weekly notes, though they now have to pay for them.

And that's not the only change: 23 years ago, the district boasted many independent, family-run fruit farms and shops; now, there are virtually none. That's a waste, says Gill, as the land around the Chilterns is ideal for fruit - it's clay patches on top of chalk, she explains, which gives the fruit the water it needs. The rise of the supermarket put paid to all that, while the success of the Le Crunch Bunch ad campaign for Golden Delicious ("They should have been prosecuted under the trade descriptions act. They're not delicious at all.") sounded the death-knell for many British varieties.

As a result, the Franklins decided to specialise more, to bring in damsons and medlars, and to revel in their fruit's seasonality. This may well be the only way to compete with the big chains, but it requires constant work, 365 days a year, planting and grafting and pruning, not to mention lugging 15lb picking-bags and 52lb bushels during the harvesting months. There is no end to it, but "every little bit more you do improves things for next year," says Gill.

Gill is not just a grower, however; she's an aficionado. She eats eight to 10 apples a day, a different variety for different times of day. In the morning, she'll have something robust, a James Grieve or a Russet. Come teatime, she'll choose something more aromatic: a Spartan, say. Her favourite, though, is the Egremont Russet, that mottled, almost-pear of an apple. As for pears, she likes Beurr Hardys the best, for their smooth flesh and scented flavour.

She shows me the pears in the bowl on the kitchen table - the Comice, the Concorde, the Conference (named after the 1885 National British Pear Conference), the pretty little Glou Morceau, the Beth, the Williams, the Packham's Triumph and the Onward - and says that they grow their pears on quince roots, to keep the trees small. It makes the fruit easier to pick, she explains, and also means that the sun can reach all of the branches.

The Comice, which is increasingly popular, faintly blushes with soft, creamy flesh, and is famed for being very sweet and juicy. This juiciness may make it inappropriate for cooking, but it's the perfect partner for cheese. Slurpiness in a pear has never been a bad thing: in The Anatomy Of Dessert, Edward Bunyard wrote, "It is, in my view, the duty of an apple to be crisp and crunchable, but a pear should have such a texture as leads to silent consumption." This is one reason why the Franklins hand out slips of paper with their pears, explaining how to tell when the fruit is ripe and how to store it.

Next, it's on to a tour of the orchard. First stop is the quince, which stands alone, a beautiful, plump tree, its fruit hanging heavy and golden among rather sad-looking leaves. It used to grow in a friend's garden, says, Gill, but three years ago they dug it up and transported it to Cross Lanes in the back of the car. Despite the rough treatment, it has thrived. The blossom is the size of a 20p piece, explains Gill, and white with a pink inside - like water lilies, she says. The fruit comes in two varieties: the perfumed, which is shaped like a mini football, and the pineapple, which resembles a pear - the Franklins grow the latter.

Quince may have fallen from favour somewhat - when was the last time you saw it in your local hypermarket - but not for nothing was it the original fruit used in marmalades (indeed, the Portuguese call it "marmelo"). And this is still the best way to use this marvellous fruit - in jams, jellies, marmalades and syrups.

Then it's to the barn, in which are piled boxes of apples and pears. The air here is heavy with the scent of autumn fruit, all honeyish, sweet and musty; it's the kind of smell you crave when you've been too long in the city. Gill slices off some pear for me to try. It is delicious and nutty, tasting, somehow, of the last flicker of summer. All recipes serve six.

Quince jelly
One of my all-time favourite things. This recipe is from Mrs CF Leyel, a long-standing reference. Sorry to all you decimal lovers out there, but with jelly and jam I still work in pints and pounds. It just comes out better that way.

Ripe quinces
Water
Sugar

Pare and core the quinces, cut them up, weigh them and pop into a pot. Pour in a pint of water to each pound of fruit, and bring to a simmer: be careful here, as if you cook them too long the colour changes to red; you want it to remain quite pale. Strain through a jelly bag and set aside. The next day, weigh out the juice, put it into a preserving pan and boil for 15 minutes. Remove from the heat and stir in 12 ounces of sugar for each pound of juice. Boil for 15-20 minutes, until cooked, stirring all the time and removing any scum that rises to the surface. Bottle in scrupulously cleaned, dried and warmed jars.

Quails with Quince
An idea of Jane Grigson's that is a curious delight. It also works well with pheasant or guinea fowl.

2 large, ripe quinces
12 quail
6 tbsp Calvados
225g quince jelly (recipe above, or buy membrillo - quince cheese - from a good deli)
Butter
100ml well-flavoured stock
Salt and pepper

Wipe any fluff off the quinces, then peel, core and thinly slice the fruit. Place in a single layer on the base of a suitably-sized pot, and pop the quails on top. Pour over the Calvados, seal the pot with clingfilm and a lid, and refrigerate for a couple of days. Remove the quails from the pot, and keep refrigerated. Transfer the fruit to another pot, cover with enough water to come halfway up the sides of the pot, and add the jelly. Simmer gently until the quince becomes very tender.

Pre-heat the oven to 200C/400F/ gas mark 6. Butter an earthenware dish and lay half the cooked quince inside. Butter the birds and place atop the fruit. Pour over any juice remaining in the the original pot. Lightly salt and pepper the birds, then cook in the oven for 15-20 minutes, basting once or twice. Put the birds to one side to rest in a warm spot, add the stock to the roasting dish, and return to the hot oven for a further 10 minutes.

If the quince is still too liquid, then simply carry on cooking in the oven until reduced sufficiently. Return the quails to the dish and transfer to the table. Serve with roast or boiled potatoes, and a salad of bitter leaves.

100ml white wine
210ml water
220g caster sugar
1 vanilla pod
1 bayleaf
6 Williams pears
The juice of 1 lemon
120g best-quality ricotta
6 dssp delicate honey
30g flaked almonds, roasted golden-brown

Put the wine, water, sugar, vanilla pod and bayleaf in a big pot. Make a disc out of greaseproof paper that is slightly larger than the pot, and keep to one side. Bring the contents of the pot to a boil and simmer for five minutes or so. Peel the pears and cut them in half lengthways. Toss in lemon juice, to prevent discolouring, then remove the core. Slip the pears into the simmering syrup and bring the pot to a boil for 30 seconds or so. Turn down to a simmer, cover with the disc of paper and then a plate, and cook for 20-25 minutes, until they offer no resistance to a knife. Remove from the heat and leave to cool.

Place two halves of pear on each serving plate. Divide the ricotta between the pears, then spoon over the honey and a liberal sprinkling of flaked almonds. Add a couple of spoonfuls of syrup to the plate, and the dish is done.

Normandy Tart
For the pastry
130g unsalted butter
250g plain flour, sifted
1 tbsp icing sugar, sifted
1 egg
1 egg yolk
1 pinch salt
For the filling
500g good Williams pears
Lemon juice
50g sugar
º tsp ground cinnamon

For the cream
1 egg
60g caster sugar
30g plain flour
145ml double cream
3 tbsp Calvados
Icing sugar, for dusting

Place the butter, flour and icing sugar in a bowl and manipulate with your fingers until the mixture is the texture of fine crumbs. Add the salt, egg and yolk, and bring together into a smooth dough. Knead as lightly as possible, then mould into a fat, round disc, cover and refrigerate.

Pre-heat the oven to 150C/300F/ gas mark 2. Roll out the pastry thinly, and line a 22cm-diameter tart case. Peel and halve the pears, then toss them in lemon juice. Remove the core and any fibre, then slice thinly and toss with sugar and cinnamon. Scatter the slices randomly in the tart shell, and bake for 20 minutes or so, until tender and coloured golden.

Beat the egg with the sugar, until thick and pale, then beat in the flour. Add the cream and Calvados, and mix until smooth. Pour this over the cooked pears, and cook gently for another 10 minutes or so. Dredge the top with icing sugar, and baking for a further 15-20 minutes, until lightly puffed, golden and just set. Serve warm with lightly whipped double cream

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.
fields.bodyText: Four miles or so from Reading station - just go left at the Pack Saddle pub and follow the signs - lies Cross Lanes Fruit Farm (0118 9723167; email, apples@crosslanesfruitfarm.co.uk), all 25 acres of it filled with 60 varieties of fruit: pears, apples, quince, plums and damsons, available from late August until Christmas. Gill Franklin is standing in her driveway, looking like a sprightly girl with her silvery hair and astonishingly blue eyes. It barely seems possible that she has two grown-up children. We sit in the kitchen, drinking tea; a pair of black, furry bear slippers has been kicked off in a corner, a bowl of eight pears sits in the middle of the table. Intermittently, Gill leaps up to see to customers, speak to her husband, her son or the gas man. Each time, she climbs into a pair of wellington boots and trots outside. The thin stripe around each leg of her jeans shows where the tops of the wellies have rubbed them pale. Gill and her husband, Dennis, left London in 1977, substituting the bustle of city life for the hedgerows of Mapledurham. At the time, it was a place where you couldn't buy a red pepper for love nor money, and the restaurants shut on a Tuesday night. Friends thought they were barmy. But the Franklins had a plan: they were hoping to start a family, and also wanted some land that would be an investment. They considered an art gallery and a fishery before deciding on the orchard. Being novices to the fruit-growing business, they relied at the beginning on two local women who had worked on the farm under its previous owner. Back then, the ministry of agriculture doled out advice free of charge, which was a huge help in the early days. They still get the ministry's weekly notes, though they now have to pay for them. And that's not the only change: 23 years ago, the district boasted many independent, family-run fruit farms and shops; now, there are virtually none. That's a waste, says Gill, as the land around the Chilterns is ideal for fruit - it's clay patches on top of chalk, she explains, which gives the fruit the water it needs. The rise of the supermarket put paid to all that, while the success of the Le Crunch Bunch ad campaign for Golden Delicious ("They should have been prosecuted under the trade descriptions act. They're not delicious at all.") sounded the death-knell for many British varieties. As a result, the Franklins decided to specialise more, to bring in damsons and medlars, and to revel in their fruit's seasonality. This may well be the only way to compete with the big chains, but it requires constant work, 365 days a year, planting and grafting and pruning, not to mention lugging 15lb picking-bags and 52lb bushels during the harvesting months. There is no end to it, but "every little bit more you do improves things for next year," says Gill. Gill is not just a grower, however; she's an aficionado. She eats eight to 10 apples a day, a different variety for different times of day. In the morning, she'll have something robust, a James Grieve or a Russet. Come teatime, she'll choose something more aromatic: a Spartan, say. Her favourite, though, is the Egremont Russet, that mottled, almost-pear of an apple. As for pears, she likes Beurr Hardys the best, for their smooth flesh and scented flavour. She shows me the pears in the bowl on the kitchen table - the Comice, the Concorde, the Conference (named after the 1885 National British Pear Conference), the pretty little Glou Morceau, the Beth, the Williams, the Packham's Triumph and the Onward - and says that they grow their pears on quince roots, to keep the trees small. It makes the fruit easier to pick, she explains, and also means that the sun can reach all of the branches. The Comice, which is increasingly popular, faintly blushes with soft, creamy flesh, and is famed for being very sweet and juicy. This juiciness may make it inappropriate for cooking, but it's the perfect partner for cheese. Slurpiness in a pear has never been a bad thing: in The Anatomy Of Dessert, Edward Bunyard wrote, "It is, in my view, the duty of an apple to be crisp and crunchable, but a pear should have such a texture as leads to silent consumption." This is one reason why the Franklins hand out slips of paper with their pears, explaining how to tell when the fruit is ripe and how to store it. Next, it's on to a tour of the orchard. First stop is the quince, which stands alone, a beautiful, plump tree, its fruit hanging heavy and golden among rather sad-looking leaves. It used to grow in a friend's garden, says, Gill, but three years ago they dug it up and transported it to Cross Lanes in the back of the car. Despite the rough treatment, it has thrived. The blossom is the size of a 20p piece, explains Gill, and white with a pink inside - like water lilies, she says. The fruit comes in two varieties: the perfumed, which is shaped like a mini football, and the pineapple, which resembles a pear - the Franklins grow the latter. Quince may have fallen from favour somewhat - when was the last time you saw it in your local hypermarket - but not for nothing was it the original fruit used in marmalades (indeed, the Portuguese call it "marmelo"). And this is still the best way to use this marvellous fruit - in jams, jellies, marmalades and syrups. Then it's to the barn, in which are piled boxes of apples and pears. The air here is heavy with the scent of autumn fruit, all honeyish, sweet and musty; it's the kind of smell you crave when you've been too long in the city. Gill slices off some pear for me to try. It is delicious and nutty, tasting, somehow, of the last flicker of summer. All recipes serve six. Quince jelly One of my all-time favourite things. This recipe is from Mrs CF Leyel, a long-standing reference. Sorry to all you decimal lovers out there, but with jelly and jam I still work in pints and pounds. It just comes out better that way. Ripe quinces Water Sugar Pare and core the quinces, cut them up, weigh them and pop into a pot. Pour in a pint of water to each pound of fruit, and bring to a simmer: be careful here, as if you cook them too long the colour changes to red; you want it to remain quite pale. Strain through a jelly bag and set aside. The next day, weigh out the juice, put it into a preserving pan and boil for 15 minutes. Remove from the heat and stir in 12 ounces of sugar for each pound of juice. Boil for 15-20 minutes, until cooked, stirring all the time and removing any scum that rises to the surface. fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Crunch time: apples, part 1
fields.trailText: Crunch time: apples, part 1
fields.body:
The subject Malus pumila. Enduring symbol of temptation: ask Adam, Atalanta or Aphrodite. Enduring associate of virtue, order and rectitude: think apple pie, apple-cheeked, apple of my eye. 'The hardiest, most resilient, and most diverse fruit on earth' (Apples, by Frank Browning, Penguin).

The basics All year round, we eat apples. Apples from Italy, South Africa, the US, France, New Zealand, blah blah. Controlled-atmosphere storage and lots of fossil fuels used in transport mean that they reach us in pretty good nick, but only at this time of year do we get the pomologist's premier pick at the peak of perfection. If the alliteration hasn't knocked you off your stride, you probably guessed that we are talking about English apples.

The details English apples in autumn are the best we get: fresh from the tree and potentially of explosive flavour. Just remember that the apple as a perfect globe is a creation of agribusiness. In non-industrial apples, imperfections can easily coexist with great flavour. For instance, russetting - patches of rough skin. Alfred Wodehouse, of Stonehill Orchards in North Collins, New York, says it's caused by 'trivial trauma' such as a leaf rubbing or bad weather. For instance: a peculiar shape, such as being smaller on one side. Explanation: incomplete pollination. For instance: dented fruit. Possible explanation: a bug bite. Effect on flavour: zilcho. Flavour matters, not looks. Where to learn more: the October Apple Celebration at Brogdale Horticultural Trust, Faversham, Kent (October 20-22) - 300 varieties on display, 'apple doctor' on call, guided tours, etc. Ring 01795 535286 or email info@brogdale.org.uk. Essential reading: Frank Browning.

Where to buy Most supermarkets make some effort to support the local industry. Fruit 'n' veg stalls should be groaning with Cox's, Worcesters, Russets etc. Closer than North Collins.

The easy way out Read on next week for further ideas.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck
fields.body:
Arithmetic is not my strong suit but, try as hard as I can, I cannot divide 225 million by 2,600 and get any other answer than 86,538.46, even though I am baffled at this result. For if we place pound signs in front of the first and last figures and the word 'branches' after the middle figure we achieve an astonishing result: the average sum paid by the Japanese bank Nomura for each one of Thresher's and Victoria Wine's wine businesses.

Eighty-six grand for an off-licence, fixtures and fittings, accommodation, plus all the stock? Sounds like a 20-point bargain to me. The head office and the delivery vans get thrown in for free, presumably, so what we have here is a killing. No wonder Mr Guy Hands, who runs the department of Nomura that did the deal, has been said to knock up an annual bonus worth tens of millions.

What is neglected in all of this, of course, is the human being who manages each one of those wine shops and the people s(he) employs. Am I courting a flood of readers' complaints if I write enthusiastically - as I intend to do - of VW's and Thresher's wines? Will there be anyone behind those counters to serve you? Or will each branch be turned into a massage parlour or a betting shop or whatever it strikes Mr Hands' fancy to do with his new sprawling empire?

I shall take a chance. I shall write about the first eight wines that follow in the reasonable hope that the means to purvey them still exist. At Thresher and Victoria Wine shops then (but not Wine Rack) there is, for openers, Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi Verbacco 1999 (15.5 points out of 20, £3.99), which is a truly scrumptious Italian classic of some class and precision. It has a nervous edge typical of the breed, and lovely nutty undertones. Veramonte Cabernet Sauvignon 1997 (16 points, £6.99, also at Oddbins), from Chile, is by far the most concentrated and convincing of the Veramonte wines, showing, as it does, rich dark chocolate fruit with humour and weight.

Anubis Malbec 1999 (16 points, £5.99), from Argentina, is juicy with a wonderfully polished turn of speed, and it has tremendous texture. Norton Semillon Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £4.99), also from Argentina, has hugely engaging plumpness and richness of purpose. There is wonderful baked melon fruit, soft textured acids and a gorgeous finish here.

At Wine Rack and Bottoms Up only, there is Falerio Pilastri Saladini 1999 (15.5 points, £4.49), from Italy, which has a lovely chewy edge and remarkably effective if subtle, crisp fruit. At Thresher wine shops (and Oddbins also), there is the invigorating Dashwood Sauvignon Blanc 1999 (16 points, £6.99), from New Zealand, which parades ripe gooseberries, lemon and a faraway echo of ogen melon, all beautifully textured. At Wine Rack and Bottoms Up, there are two stunning 17-point Italian reds: Valpolicella Ripassa Superiore Zenato 1997 (£7.99) and Amarone della Valpolicella Zenato 1995 (£17.99).

The first shows the seemingly casual brilliance of Zenato's winemaking, where effortlessly integrated fruit and acid with textured, delicately tannined complexity deliciously combine. The second red costs more, but also offers more. It flaunts licorice, figs, ripe cherries, damsons and beguiling tannins. Even so, I'd still cellar it for five or six years and see it reach, possibly, perfection at 20 points.

Tesco has some impressive reds as well. Picajuan Peak Bonarda 1999 (15.5 points, £3.79), from Argentina, has a wonderful rich and invigorating jammy richness that manages to stay dry and characterful. Picajuan Peak Sangiovese 1998 (16 points, £3.79) is rivetingly fruity, well-organised and engaging, exhibiting savoury touches to the tannins, firm touches of plum and blackcurrant to the dry fruit. It is certainly a contender for the £3.80-and-under Wine of the Year.

Montana Reserve Merlot 1998 (16.5 points, £8.99, also at Thresher and Victoria Wine), from New Zealand, is a stylish conglomerate of opulent fruit with gorgeous woody undertones - the fruit, though, is firmly in command. This wine has a fine texture, providing a tightly woven finish of substance and stylish moreishness. Mr Hands should try it. He patently likes bargains, even when they cost.

fields.headline: Net addict
fields.trailText: Eventually I found a yoga retreat in Scandinavia that accepted my credit card's reward points (I have to be a bit careful after my extravagant holiday).
fields.body:
Eventually I found a yoga retreat in Scandinavia that accepted my credit card's reward points (I have to be a bit careful after my extravagant holiday). Thanks to my natural grace and peak physical condition, I made lightning progress, from 'ananda' yoga to 'astanga' and 'bikram' (hot, hot, hot, according to www.yogasite.com).

The evenings were certainly hot; Igor, one of several Russians there, seemed madly keen on me, and I found myself responding. He had a Rasputin-like magnetism, and his story was intriguing: at 18 he had been the youngest party commissar in the USSR; now he owns a huge software empire (everything manufactured under licence, he assured me).

On the third day, the evening activity was a communal sauna. Igor was at the other end of the log cabin, but I pretended to ignore him. Eventually, the heat was unbearable; I fled from the steamy inferno and ran towards the icy lake. He appeared out of nowhere and blocked my way, brandishing a handful of birch twigs.

'You need this first, Tanya,' he said in his enchantingly accented English.

I looked at him - he had the physique of a sculpted socialist hero combined with the eyes of a capitalist tiger. Software was the last thing on my mind. Teasingly, he caressed my skin with the leaves... Instantly, I broke out in multicoloured blisters the size of £2 coins. Igor muttered harsh-sounding, incomprehensible words and ran back to the sauna cabin; I fled to my lodge and switched on my laptop.

Thanks to www.4allergies.4anything.com, I recognised my symptoms; I left for home without delay. A marvellous specialist in Harley Street (www.harleystreetmedical. com) confirmed my suspicions: I'm allergic to birch leaves. My skin is like satin once more, but will I ever find Igor again?

tanya@gorgeoustanya.co.uk
