fields.headline: Abstract painter's great escape
fields.standfirst:
Terry Frost
Royal Academy, London
***
fields.trailText:
Terry Frost
Royal Academy, London
***
fields.body:
It's Upstairs, Downstairs at the Royal Academy. Downstairs is the shock-horror of Apocalypse, while upstairs the Sackler gallery has the far more respectable retrospective of Terry Frost RA. It suggests a neat, cynical division of the RA's public into two. But the result is a surprise. Frost began painting in a German prisoner-of-war camp where he spent four years of the second world war, and today lives in Newlyn, Cornwall. His paintings bounce, breathe, make you feel you have been transported to a salty, sunny utopia somewhere between Land's End and Long Island.

This exhibition makes the best case I've seen for the rather implausible claim that the abstract painters who worked in St Ives after the war were Britain's answer to the New York School. That's not true: British abstract painting was mostly too modest, too dry, too English. But Frost's paintings have some great qualities.

There's a freedom to the way he slaps on the paint that must surely have something to do with his desire to escape imaginatively from that PoW camp. He throws together a circle, a spiralling squiggle, a series of slanty straight lines. He likes these dollops and blobs and streaks of colour, and his palette - at its most intense in 1950s paintings such as the Tate Gallery's Yellow Triptych (1957-59) - is never confined. What Frost does best is allow dull English colours - the creamy grey of a cloudy morning, the rust and smoke browns of heavy industry in Leeds Painting II (1954-56) - burst into unlikely life, so that Leeds burns gold and bronze.

Frost is also an artist of nature. He's in a British tradition of landscape that has observation of the world as its beginning and end. With Frost, the observation leads into liberating abstract territory; but his painting has a roughness of texture and underlying realism of colour that ground it in the world. That's where the toughness of his early paintings comes from.

Frost never had the massive originality of his American contemporaries. You can see that in the 1960s he started to jump on the latest bandwagons: he puts words in a painting, like the young David Hockney; he has a go at painting like Ellsworth Kelly. In 1974 he moved back to Cornwall and his painting since has been more lightly decorative, without the bite of his early work. But even today, in his 85th year, Frost can do it: Exclamation Mark (2000) rocks off the wall.

Painting is a sensualist's art with little use for irony. Leaving the RA you pass Richard Prince's pictures in the Apoca lypse show. He does mock-1950s abstract paintings over which he prints terrible jokes: "I was up there in the prison talking to Charlie Manson and he says to me he says 'Is it hot in here or am I crazy?' " Frost's paintings from the 1950s, the core of his achievement, are abstraction without the irony, and they make Prince's jokes look sad, sad, sad.

 Until November 12. Details: 020-7300 5959. This show is being personally supported by Paul and Alison Myners. Mr Myners is chairman of the Guardian Media Group.

webTitle: Time is right for community banks

fields.headline: Time is right for community banks
fields.trailText: Banks are failing to support deprived areas despite booming profits that would allow them to keep local branches open, according to a report out this week.
fields.body:
Banks are failing to support deprived areas despite booming profits that would allow them to keep local branches open, according to a report out this week.

The New Economic Foundation says banks would only need to spend 0.2% of their profits - £40m - on a network of 1,500 community banks. It could encourage large numbers of people without bank accounts to benefit from services like direct debits that can save them money. Most utilities offer discounts to customers who pay via direct debit.

The Case for Community Banking, by Derek French, argues that community banks in pubs, churches, schools and village halls, could regenerate areas. "Siting banks in such places could prove an effective solution to community decline by underpinning other vulnerable areas of community life," he says.

He says the banks, run locally but acting as a shared agency through which all clearing banks could offer services, could be "a powerful aid to to local economic and social regeneration". In the US banks are required by law to operate in poor neighbourhoods. More than $1trillion has been committed by US banks to deprived areas, and "such lending can be profitable".

The major high street banks have resisted the idea of clubbing together to help deprived areas. Concerns about the loss of brand identity and who would pay for the the scheme have been raised with ministers.

Mr French says he recognises that bank directors are trapped between "conflicting economic and social imperatives". But he says some comunities have been devastated by the loss of their last remaining bank.

 Contact www.neweconomics.org or tel: 020-7407-7447.

webTitle: House prices may be boiling again

fields.headline: House prices may be boiling again
fields.standfirst: After a summer in the doldrums the signs point to a growing number of property hot spots. Liz Stuart surveys the scene nationwide and looks at tactics for buyers and sellers
fields.trailText: After a summer in the doldrums the signs point to a growing number of property hot spots. Liz Stuart surveys the scene nationwide and looks at tactics for buyers and sellers.
fields.body:
The housing market is on a knife-edge. After several months of gloom and falling prices, particularly in London, both the Halifax and Nationwide indices showed last week that prices had ticked up during the month. Nationwide even stuck its neck out with a bullish forecast of rising prices in 2001.

Adding fuel to the argument that the market may have turned are figures this week from Bradford & Bingley Estate Agents, which show that the number of buyers in the market far exceeds the number of sellers, particularly for higher-priced homes.

Bradford & Bingley says that if you have the right property which has been put on to the market at the right price, then you can still sell quickly.

The most speedy transactions - with homes going in less than one week - have been taking place in Yarm and Stokesley in the north east and Bramhall in the West Midlands, while homes in Burgess Hill in West Sussex, Alton and Liss in Hampshire, Sidcup in Kent, Redditch in Worcestershire, Maldon in Essex and Ivybridge in Dartmoor have all sold within a fortnight. It shows that looking at the house market from a north/south perspective is becoming increasingly outdated.

There have been large upswings in demand for houses in the north and Scotland which shows up on the Bradford & Bingley survey under the "ratio of buyers registering to properties available". Back in January this was 4:1 in Scotland and 3:1 in the north, whereas now that has rocketed to 10:1 and 5:1 respectively.

However, the south and south east remain the markets where properties sell most quickly - in contrast to reports that the market has slowed down. The average detached property in these areas is selling in eight weeks, with the average flat being snapped up in six weeks and bungalows taking seven to sell. This compares with a nationwide average of nine weeks.

The average number of viewings before a sale is agreed ranges from five for a terraced property in Scotland to 16 for a detached house in the same region.

Ian Davies, regional business director for B&B estate agents in the south east, says: "In the south if you have a property to sell in the majority of cases if you price it realistically you will find a buyer, although the market is more competitive."

The percentage of the asking price eventually paid by a buyer is another good indication of market strength; any house can sell quickly if the owner is prepared to heavily mark down the price. But again the B&B figures show that this is not happening. The national average for the percentage of the asking price compared to the price paid is 97%. This is slightly lower in the North (96%) and much higher in Scotland (105%), but the latter is due to differences in the system of house purchase north of the border, where it is quite usual to ask for "offers in excess of" a certain amount.

So, how can buyers increase their chances of getting the property they want? Jim Jamison, chief operating officer at B&B estate agents, says: "Since our last report was issued, we have seen a growing trend towards tactical selling.

"When the market was at a peak earlier in the year, people were finding a property before putting their own on the market. Fortunately we are now seeing evidence of people selling their own property at the same time or even before looking to buy the home of their dreams.

"With good quality and realistically priced homes continuing selling quickly, our advice is to put your house on the market before you start looking to buy."

Nationwide argues that buyers have time on their side - but not much. It is forecasting a relatively quiet market over the next few months and then an upward surge in prices next spring.

"An upward trend in house price inflation is likely to recur, although it may not be until next spring. By this time first-time buyers will be more confident that the housing market is running at a sustainable rate and this, combined with higher real take-home pay should lead to a resurgence in the market," says a spokesman.

fields.headline: NatWest takes Step
fields.trailText: NatWest, part of the Royal Bank of Scotland, confirmed this week that it will meet the government deadline for banks to offer a basic current account to customers on low incomes.
fields.body:
NatWest, part of the Royal Bank of Scotland, confirmed this week that it will meet the government deadline for banks to offer a basic current account to customers on low incomes.

The banks's Step Account is fee-free and offers access to cash machines and branches, where they exist. But it has no overdraft facilities.

Lloyds TSB is expected to follow the initiative in the the next three weeks after a successful pilot scheme in Scotland.

The Bank of Scotland has offered a basic account for some time, but the likelihood of other banks, namely HSBC and Barclays following suit is unknown.

Barclays is the only bank, however, that has signalled its approval for the government's proposed Universal Bank, to be run by Post Offices.

The Treasury has told the banks that they must come up with a basic account by the end of the month and take part in the Universal Bank as part of wider initiatives to regenerate poor areas of the country.

fields.headline: Technology funds short-circuit
fields.trailText: Technology stocks took fright yet again this week, but this time it wasn't just dot.coms but the telecom stocks that make up the major holdings of many technology funds.
fields.body:
Technology stocks took fright yet again this week, but this time it wasn't just dot.coms but the telecom stocks that make up the major holdings of many technology funds.

Motorola sent shockwaves through the market with a warning that worldwide growth in demand for mobile phones has slowed.

It predicts that handset sales will be around 410m-425m this year, compared to earlier forecasts of up to 450m. Its shares promptly fell 19%. The fall-out from the Motorola announcement soon hit other telecom stocks, with Ericsson and Nokia, Europe's biggest manufacturers of mobile phones, seeing their shares slide 6%. Other telecoms equipment manufacturers also saw their shares go into freefall.

But the major technology funds say they have yet to suffer a wave of selling, despite sagging performance. A survey this week from fund analysts Lipper showed that all but one of the 26 technology funds in the UK saw their returns fall during September. It said that the average drop during the month was 7.49%.

However, there are signs the fashion for technology funds is fading. In August sales of technology funds were £104m, a fraction of the £701m peak in March, when the dot.com boom coincided with the traditional end-of-tax year rush into Isas.

But global marketing director Steve Lipper believes investors should not be overly concerned. He says: "This is a volatile market and these ups and downs are to be expected. The message stays the same - this is a potentially rewarding sector but expect a bumpy ride on the way."

webTitle: Lloyds TSB 'has broken its branch closures pledge'

fields.headline: Lloyds TSB 'has broken its branch closures pledge'
fields.standfirst: When the bank said it would not reopen in Bell Green, one of the most deprived areas of the West Midlands, many residents were furious, says Phillip Inman
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB was accused this week of abandoning one of the most deprived parts of the West Midlands, despite making a pledge that it would never be the last bank to leave an area.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB was accused this week of abandoning one of the most deprived parts of the West Midlands, despite making a pledge that it would never be the last bank to leave an area.

Local residents and traders in the Bell Green district of Coventry reacted angrily to the news that the local Lloyds TSB branch had shut without notice leaving them, in some cases, to travel several miles to the nearest bank branch.

The bank says a series of armed raids on the branch had left staff "traumatised" and it could not guarantee their safety if the branch had re-opened. Three raids on the branch had taken place in the last four months and five in the last year. CCTV cameras were installed inside the branch and outside in the Riley Square shopping centre, but had failed to act as a deterrent or gain a conviction.

A spokeswoman for the bank says the decision was made in the interests of branch staff. "It is never a decision we take lightly, but in this instance the safety of our staff was paramount."

The Bell Green branch in the north of the city serves four large housing estates. Residents say they make up the most deprived section of Coventry.

An application for regeneration funding under the gov ernment's New Deal for Communities initiative is currently being put together that should bring £50m to the estates for a range of employment, welfare and education projects.

Nerissa Jones, a local vicar and head of the partnership board preparing the funding bid, says that the decision to close the Lloyds TSB branch could end any hope of regenerating the area.

"It is a very serious predicament, not just for local shops and traders that use the bank's facilities, but the whole community. One of my parishioners, an elderly and infirm lady, needed to spend £13.50 on taxis to get to a branch. She can't use buses. She can't walk that far. It was all she could do. Most people with children, the elderly and many other groups will need to get a bus, which costs a lot."

She scoffs at the notice sent out by the bank encouraging customers to use its telephone banking and internet facilities. She says many people on the estates can't afford phones, let alone afford extra bills from phoning their bank. She says few people in her congregation have computers connected to the internet.

"Residents have every sympathy with the bank's staff. In fact, we think they have been very hard done by. They don't seem to have been given much protection by the bank. But closing the branch has placed a heavy burden on the local community."

Ms Jones says a £100,000 CCTV system covering the whole shopping centre is about to be installed by the city council and a new police station is soon to be located near the branch. "Why shut down when the first steps of regeneration are going ahead?"

Lloyds TSB director Dennis Holt refutes claims that the bank was the last to quit the area - a pledge made last year to MPs on the Treasury Select Committee. He says five other branches are located "nearby". Two further branches can be found in the city centre. He says there are several post offices that customers can use for cashing cheques and withdrawing money. There is also a Coventry Building Society branch near to the closed branch.

"Bell Green by any definition is a suburb of a much larger community. We believe we are still well represented in that community," says Mr Holt.

fields.headline: Halifax in big switch
fields.standfirst: Now the bank is offering to change all the direct debits if rivals' customers defect to one of its accounts
fields.trailText: Halifax this week launched its biggest challenge yet to its high street banking rivals with the launch of a new range of aggressively priced credit cards and pledges on deposit and overdraft rates - all part of a big charm offensive to woo trade.
fields.body:
Halifax this week launched its biggest challenge yet to its high street banking rivals with the launch of a new range of aggressively priced credit cards and pledges on deposit and overdraft rates - all part of a big charm offensive to woo trade.

On Tuesday it pledged to set a 100-strong "crack switching team" on the customers of Lloyds TSB, Barclays, HSBC and NatWest. Chief executive James Crosby said: "The battle for customers starts today. The perception about inertia (among customers) is very strong. It will become a myth very quickly."

To combat the switching inertia - whereby customers do not bother to move providers for a better rate because they think it will be too complex to transfer their direct debit arrangements - the bank says it will handle the direct debits itself.

It also promised to pay 4% interest rate on deposits and charge only 10% on authorised overdrafts, beating the rest of the high street hands down - the other four all pay just 0.1% interest on deposits and both Lloyds and Barclays charge as much as 18.8% on overdrafts which have been previously agreed.

On Wednesday came the next announcement. It unveiled a new range of credit cards with low introductory rates, particularly if you are transferring your business to Halifax from a rival.

The Platinum card, which is aimed at customers with a household income of more than £25,000 who need a credit limit in excess of £3,500, has a rate of 2.9% for the first five months for balance transfers, rising to 16.9% at the end of that period. If you take out a card without transferring a balance the rate is 16.9% from day one.

The Gold card rate is 3.9% for five months and then 16.9%, again for transferring balances. It is aimed at people whose household income is more than £20,000. The credit limit on this card is £3,000.

The bank is also relaunching its Classic Visa card with an introductory rate of 3.9%, rising to 17.9%, both for transferring balances and new transactions. Halifax says the launches are part of its strategy to double its 1.5m base of credit card customers within the next three years. "Customers taking out a Halifax Platinum card and transferring £1,200 from their Barclaycard, for example, would save more than £100 in the first year," says James Corcoran, managing director of Halifax Card Services.

However, although the introductory rates are rated the best on the high street, and the standard rates are among the lowest (the HSBC Gold and Platinum card are cheaper than their Halifax equivalents, for instance), there are better rates available from non-high street providers. Capital One charges 0% for six months, reverting to 12.9% and Egg charges 2.5% initially on debt transfers, which then reverts to 10.9% after six months.

But Abbey National says that research it has conducted among 4,000 people shows that just 5% switch credit card provider in search of a better rate. It also showed that while 77% of people have considered moving to another card issuer, 42% say the process is too much hassle.

fields.headline: Bad behaviour from Badly Drawn Boy
fields.standfirst:
Badly Drawn Boy
Leeds Metropolitan University
***
fields.trailText:
Badly Drawn Boy
Leeds Metropolitan University
***
fields.body:
It's difficult to decide exactly which bit of Damon Gough's two-hour car crash of a pop set is the highlight. It could be the bit where he remembers the Who's Live at Leeds, impersonates Roger Daltrey's twirling microphone technique, hits himself and falls headlong off the stage. Or the moment where somebody shouts "Boring!" and the outraged singer hurls himself into the crowd, ending up biting the end off his microphone. It could be the hilarious anecdote about attempting to sing on Later with Jools Holland (tonight on BBC2) while being forced to stare at the En Vogue singer's "52DDD cleavage". Or the time when he suddenly starts wailing about winning the Mercury music prize while his unrehearsed band sound like a dustbin falling down a flight of stairs.

Never mind the Mercury, this should win a Bafta award for comedy. Except that Badly Drawn Boy obviously does mind winning the Mercury. By all accounts he was so shocked he spent the next day in the pub. By the look of things he's been there ever since.

A bottle of Jack Daniel's perches precariously on his keyboard. He makes speeches of variable hilarity and sobriety which involve the words "fuck", "press" and "tits". Badly Drawn Boy has made his name on shambolic performances, but with tuneless guitars, mauled Bruce Springsteen anthems, collapsing songs, audience abuse, unlistenable 10-minute jams and the occasional flight of utter genius, this really takes the biscuit.

Imagine - if you dare - a cross between Ray Davies playing Haight Ashbury, Les Dawson's Terrible Pianist and Ollie Reed on After Dark. It's that bad. And that good. And, often, somewhere bewildering in between. Weirder still, it's suspiciously like an act. The Jack Daniel's is rarely troubled, and some songs/witticisms are delivered so impeccably that this man could simply not be that drunk (either way, he's almost as good an actor as Ollie). So is this "performance" myth-making, or marketing, or both? Gough professes to hate the music industry, but his shenanigans are no less a gimmick than Britney Spears's school uniform.

Equally, BDB rightly champions the cause of live spontaneity, but when even the prearranged slide show proclaims "Sham Bollock", you know that you're in the realms of at least semi-scripted chaos.

After two hours, six premature slurs of "Goodnight" and a genuinely terrifying moment where he makes as if to take his clothes off, Damon finally delivers the gorgeous bittersweet anthems people have paid for. Pissing in the Wind, Disillusion and The Shining are worthy of any prize you care to name, but Gough doubly plays with fire.

Just as Hendrix came to hate the way people remembered him setting fire to his guitar more than his music, Townshend rued the guitarsmashing. At the moment, Badly Drawn Boy is on an obvious post-ceremonial roll, but he should beware the long fall from mercurial talent to debauched circus freak. Nice beer belly, though.

 At L2, Liverpool (0151-707 9977), tonight and Queen Margaret University, Glasgow (0141-339 8383), tomorrow, then touring.

webTitle: Theatre review: The labours of Peepolykus

fields.headline: The labours of Peepolykus
fields.standfirst:
Goose Nights
Lyric Studio, Hammersmith
***
fields.trailText:
Goose Nights
Lyric Studio, Hammersmith
***
fields.body:
It is time we nailed the lie that young people don't go to the theatre. The Lyric Hammersmith was teeming with them on Thursday both for the main house White Devil and for this studio show by Peepolykus, a three-man comedy team. Judging by Goose Nights, they have an avid young fan club that laughs at everything they do; seeing them for the first time, I found them intermittently hilarious but far stronger on visual than verbal invention.

In this show they send up the conventions of classical Greek drama with an updated version of the labours of Hercules. They strike a chord instantly as they form a sombre, black-hatted chorus that advances on the audience to ask: "Is man good or is man evil?" That hits exactly the right note of primal portentousness. Thereafter the show develops the promising idea of a modern Greek waiter plucked from the obscurity of a northern caff to undertake Herculean labours to save mankind. He finds himself wrestling snakes, encountering a mysterious jungle woman and journeying to Hades to meet a rabid Cerberus.

Physically, the trio are enormously inventive. At one point they evoke a funfair ghost-train, complete with robotic axeman, with dazzling economy, and they hurl themselves vigorously into numerous slapstick routines. Clearly the rubber-limbed David Sant, who plays Cerberus, is of the school of Norman Wisdom that believes the more often you fall down the funnier you are. But the show would be an even bigger hit if it stuck more closely to the Greek myth and if the actors didn't keep beating their fragile puns into the ground. The Marx Brothers, who are clearly role models, had SJ Perelman to write their material and anchor their anarchy; here the actors and director Darren Tunstall have devised the script themselves. The difference shows.

For all my caveats, the young audience roared and howled. And there is no denying that the saucer-eyed Sant, the buck-toothed John Nicholson and the laid-back Javier Marzan combine genuine physical dexterity with a sense of comic tradition. Given a first-rate script, who knows what they might achieve?

 Until October 28. Box office: 020-8741 2311.

webTitle: A credit to all Ireland is McCarthy's band

fields.headline: A credit to all Ireland is McCarthy's band
fields.trailText: Republic of Ireland manager Mick McCarthy will be happy to wallow in told-you-so bliss for a while yet as the country gears up for a return to the good old days after Wednesday night's victory.
fields.body:
The Republic of Ireland, according to the match-day programme for their midweek World Cup qualifier against Estonia, are "the team that play football like Mozart writes music". Heady praise indeed for a side that until recently were being written off as more karaoke than classical.

Mick McCarthy is not likely to be offered the Freedom of Dublin just yet but his side's remarkable progress over the past two months has given Ireland's craggy manager enough ammunition to wallow in told-you-so bliss for some time yet.

McCarthy was so irritated by what he saw as negative press coverage in Ireland that he took it upon himself to phone the editor of a Dublin paper last week over an article making mischievous claims that he and Roy Keane were barely on speaking terms.

For the time being, at least, the knives have been put away in Group Two. Impressive away draws with Portugal and Holland and Wednesdays's 2-0 defeat of Estonia have sparked the sort of heady expectation that has not been experienced since the giddy days of Jack Charlton.

The only matter of concern among the Irish is that they must wait so long before the next qualifiers. They have until March before facing two away games in the space of four days, against Cyprus and Andorra. If the Irish win both they would be ideally placed going into their last five games, four of which are at Lansdowne Road.

In the meantime they host Finland next month and Denmark in February, matches to experiment, even if there seems no need for tinkering. "If it ain't broke, don't fix it," says McCarthy. And that will be music to Irish ears.

 Ryan Giggs returned from Wales's gritty Group Five 0-0 draw in Poland confirming that he hopes to sign his new Manchester United contract "fairly soon - hopefully before Christmas". It is believed the new deal is for five years and and, in tying the 26-year-old to Old Trafford effectively for the rest of his career, will make him one of the country's highest earners.

fields.headline: Brown sweats on touchline ban
fields.trailText: Craig Brown must until next week to learn if he will face punishment following his expulsion from the dugout during Wednesday's 1-1 draw against Croatia.
fields.body:
Craig Brown must sweat on next week's meeting of a three-man Fifa panel to learn if he will be banned from the touchline for Scotland's next World Cup Group Six qualifier, following his expulsion from the dugout during Wednesday's 1-1 draw here against Croatia.

It is thought Scotland's manager could fall back on video evidence to appeal against any sanction the disciplinary committee may impose, perhaps allied to the referee's assessor's report on the officials' overall performance.

Brown had a running battle with the referee, Gilles Veissière, throughout the match. He insists he did not swear at the Frenchman though on more than one occasion, according to Brown, the referee virtually sprinted the length of the pitch to shout at him: "Shut up!"

What made the spectacle doubly bizarre for Scots was that Brown is well known as a man of enormous natural courtesy.

It was the first such caution for Brown in 13 years with the national squad, initially as assistant to Andy Roxburgh and then as manager. Back in the 80s, though, there was one notorious scrap in his time as manager of Clyde when he staged a one-man pitch invasion during a game at Forfar - a sortie that was ended, according to one version, only by police intervention.

As far as Zagreb is concerned, though, he was forcefully pleading innocence yesterday. "I thought there were some strange decisions going on in the game, not just against us but against the Croats as well, though I still don't know what I've done," Brown said.

He did admit to jumping up in anger at one rough challenge on Paul Dickov - a confession borne out by pictures in one Scottish tabloid of an irate Brown pumping his fist like a schoolboy whose conkers had just been stolen.

The Scots, now top of their group after three away games, have a friendly against Australia next month before Belgium arrive for their next qualifier in March.

One of Brown's concerns is the uncertainty over his captain. Colin Hendry, who turns 35 in December, has been an anchor for the Scots but, according to Brown, he urgently needs to reclaim his place at Coventry.

"Everyone knows I am a Hendry fan but he can't keep going just playing one international game a month," he said.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Hamed ready to fight for Wednesday

fields.headline: Hamed ready to fight for Wednesday
fields.trailText: Former world featherweight champion Prince Naseem Hamed has indicated he is keen to take over his stricken home-town club Sheffield Wednesday.
fields.body:
Prince Naseem Hamed, the former world featherweight champion, has plans to take over his stricken home-town club Sheffield Wednesday.

Hamed, who relinquished his world title this week, has let it be known he is willing to invest in Wednesday by buying out Charterhouse's 36% stake to become their major shareholder. He would need to find at least £4.5m.

"We know Prince is a Wednesday supporter and he has the money," said the club's spokesman Steve Chu. "But it's one thing buying out Charterhouse; we need someone who can invest money beyond that." Wednesday are believed to be around £16m in debt.

webTitle: Ragbag army in need of field marshal

fields.headline: Ragbag army in need of field marshal
fields.standfirst:
Richard Williams: Bring on the next generation

Ron Atkinson: This is no hard luck story
fields.trailText: Never mind the demeaning excuses for an abysmal performance, the reality is a humiliating five-month wait hoping that the mighty Albanians have not hit a winning streak.
fields.body:
The result of the worst crisis to hit an England football team since Bobby Moore and the bracelet is that the nation which gave the game to the world will spend the next 5 months hoping that Albania have not hit a winning streak.

As if it was not bad enough for England to be bottom of their 2002 World Cup qualifying group, with one point from two matches, they are two points behind the Albanians and Greece while at the top of the table Finland prepare to slog it out with Germany.

The qualifiers resume in March next year when England play the return game against the Finns at Anfield before meeting Albania in Tirana four days later. Unless, by then, the present farcical situation has seriously given way to a sharp attack of common sense by management and players alike, England can forget about competing in the first World Cup of the new millennium.

In the space of five days English football's cock-eyed conceit has given way to despair and endless self-criticism. Just as things were never that good, nor need they be that bad, even now. But Saturday's 1-0 defeat by Germany, which left the old Wembley to a pauper's grave and Kevin Keegan to walk out as England coach, was barely redeemed by Wednesday night's ragbag of a scoreless draw in Helsinki.

Only the day before the Finland match Adam Crozier, the Football Association's chief executive, had spoken of a golden future for English football which would end the need to keep harking back to the World Cup triumph of 1966. Even allowing for the fact the Scots, of which Crozier is one, were fed up with hearing about this by 1967, it was a forward-looking view.

Within 24 hours, however, memories of '66 came flooding back as England were denied a late winner in Helsinki which was a convincing action replay of the goal Geoff Hurst was allowed, on the nod of the Soviet linesman, after his shot had struck the underside of the crossbar and bounced down behind the West German line. This, at least, is what England have claimed ever since and, 34 years on, a wider variety of television camera angles suggested that in Ray Parlour's case the goal should also have stood. On this occasion, however, a French linesman was not convinced.

If England accepted a linesman's word in 1966, they have to accept it in 2000. And Howard Wilkinson's grumbles about Antti Niemi, the Finland and Hearts goalkeeper, staying on the pitch after up-ending Teddy Sheringham early in the game, followed by moans about a bumpy pitch and the high wind were demeaning.

Before Wednesday night England sides had managed to beat Finland eight times out of nine without the opposition having men sent off. The pitch in the Olympic Stadium, moreover, has always been bumpy, yet somehow England had managed to win there on six of their previous seven visits.

It was strange, too, that whenever Jari Litmanen had the ball the wind seemed to drop and the pitch became a bowling green. The reality is that an uneven surface will exaggerate technique, both good and bad. As Chris Waddle noted: "With Litmanen in our team we'd have won 3-0 but we didn't have anyone of his quality."

Quite so. Wilkinson has been condemned for his selection and tactics but he had only three days to sort a winning team out of a job lot of journeymen. The England side that took the field in Helsinki was always going to owe more to Frankenstein than Einstein, in that it had been assembled out of isolated spare parts rather than any theories of relativity.

England's substitutions were a reminder that, if Keegan was the bringer of jollity, Wilkinson is the mystic. His explanations as to why Sheringham, average but persistent, was taken off rather than Andy Cole, who was comically bad, and why Michael Owen did not get on at all should have been accompanied by diagrams from Pythagoras or sketches by Dali. "I tried to give the team a shape and a plan and we needed to stick to it," the caretaker explained. "Some players didn't do as well as they would have liked."

Nevertheless, Wilkinson refused to be downhearted. "Maybe this result is the start of clawing our way back," he hoped. "After all, God got seven days, we got three." The Almighty, however, was not playing Finland ...

"We want a new England coach for the long term who will think long term," Wilkinson added. "He's got to decide how to do things."

For the moment England's next Mr Wonderful appears to be everyone and no one. Crozier wants the speculation all over by Christmas but the job of running the national team is not even what it was at 3pm last Saturday. When a Messiah gives up, what hope is there for a mere mortal?

fields.headline: Bring on the next generation
fields.standfirst:
David Lacey: Ragbag army in need of field marshal

Ron Atkinson: This is no hard luck story
fields.trailText: Thanks, but no thanks. It's time to do what's right and let them go. All those over 22, bar Beckham, McManaman and Martyn. Bring in the youngsters en masse and build a new England from scratch.
fields.body:
Let's look at the whole thing another way. You know what the psychotherapists say: when you have a bad experience, try to take the good out of it. And the good that can be taken from the experience of England's performances against Germany and Finland is the knowledge that an era is over. All that is required now is a commitment to accept the new reality and to act on it.

So thank you David Seaman, for the service represented by your 62 caps. At least you can say you went out with a clean sheet to your name. Thank you Tony Adams and Martin Keown, with more than a hundred caps between you, for your wholehearted efforts.

Thank you Paul Ince, for a handful of heroic performances, although you never quite realised that a truly great player's commitment to his squad is not conditional on the fluctuations of his own personal fortunes. Thank you Dennis Wise and Gareth Southgate and David Batty and Sol Campbell and Paul Scholes and Graeme le Saux and Philip and Gary Neville, proven Premier League professionals who never quite convinced the jury of an ability to make the transition to international football. Thank you Nick Barmby and Ray Parlour and all the other middle-to-late twentysomethings whose chances were comparatively few but who, if they were ever going to make authentic international footballers, would have done so by now. And thank you to Andrew Cole, a much better footballer than your international record might suggest, although 10 England appearances without a goal is enough of a chance for anyone. Thank you one and all. And goodnight.

Five-and-a-half months in the future lies the next Group Nine fixture, the return leg against Finland. By that time England will have a new head coach. And we shall know that the appointment has failed if the next incumbent finds himself scratching his head over the choice between Parlour and Ince, Le Saux and Phil Neville, Keown and Southgate. For that way lies nothing more than a repetition of the past.

Kevin Keegan took the rap for the failure against Germany. Coaches are important to the success of a football team, but players also have some say in the conduct of a match. And through their performances on Saturday and Wednesday, the majority of this bunch indicated that they are just not up to it. Hence the necessity for a mass valediction.

Who or what comes in to fill the vacuum? It can only be one thing: a commitment to the crop of outstanding young players it is England's good fortune to possess. They may have appeared merely by coincidence, or their arrival may have been the result of the now-abandoned Lilleshall experiment, but they certainly exist. And under Peter Taylor those players coalesced into a group, in the guise of the Under-21 squad. So now they know each other well, having played together in qualifying groups and tournaments. With England in such disarray, here is an asset which must not be overlooked.

The answer is to promote them now, virtually en bloc. To make way, anybody in the existing squad over the age of 22, with three exceptions: Nigel Martyn, at 34 the only short-term selection (with Richard Wright at his eventual replacement), to add stability to the defence; David Beckham, a certifiably world-class player; and Steve McManaman. No, McManaman is not getting a game for Real Madrid at the moment. But the best player on the pitch in Helsinki was Jari Litmanen, who is being similarly ignored at Barcelona. The Finns know Litmanen's value, even if the Catalan's coach Lorenzo Serra Ferrer has forgotten it, and McManaman would benefit from a similar show of faith.

Martyn, Beckham and McManaman would be joined by the Under-23s from the present squad - Michael Owen, Rio Ferdinand, Kieron Dyer, Wes Brown, Gareth Barry and Steven Gerrard - and by the cream of the recent Under-21 squad, such as Joe Cole, Jon Harley, Michael Carrick and Carl Cort. If some of them were having trouble holding a place in the first teams of their overmanned clubs, thanks to pressure from foreign players, then the coach would have to back his own judgment against that of a Claudio Ranieri or an Arsène Wenger, and to transmit that confidence to the players.

Howard Wilkinson, too cautious by far, is emphatically not the man to take charge of them. The poor showing of his Under-21s in the European championship finals last May proved that much. Let him go back to organising the national coaching schemes, where his admiration of the French system can do most good. The only possible choice is Peter Taylor, whose Under-21 side won games by playing in a progressive style which had less to do with national stereotypes than with world trends.

Earlier this week Taylor honourably said that he would not be prepared to leave Leicester City in the short term, having recently persuaded several players to extend their contracts. In that case the Football Association ought to be prepared to wait for him until the end of the season, having agreed a substantial amount of compensation with his club. Meanwhile, Taylor would look after the England team on a part-time basis, with the help, if necessary, of Bobby Robson.

This means that the next round of World Cup qualifying matches, and the friendlies which precede them, would be undertaken without a full-time coach, and with a fledgling squad. If that were to mean forfeiting qualification for 2002, so be it. The priorities are elsewhere. Imagine how much they would learn together from the experience, and how much stronger they would be when, as a mature squad, they faced their next challenge - qualification for Euro 2004, itself viewed as a stepping stone to the 2006 World Cup.

Yesterday Glenn Hoddle and Howard Wilkinson separately stressed the importance, in England's present position, of placing long-term planning ahead of short-term results. The FA have an opportunity now to get it right, and to take the public along with them. No one wants to see any more performances like those witnessed twice in the past week. For once, the bold step is likely to win more approval than the quick fix. The chance is there, and they had better not let it slip.

webTitle: There's no point looking for a hard luck story

fields.headline: There's no point looking for a hard luck story
fields.trailText: Forget about "if only". Focus is the key and we're not out yet. In any case, playing away from Wembley could work in our favour, as might the leadership of Sven-Goran Eriksson.
fields.body:
It would be easy to look at what happened to England in Finland and moan about bad luck, bad refereeing and how football has a nasty habit of kicking you when you are down. Forget the lot of it.

Every struggling side will insist they have been decimated by injuries or are not getting the breaks. But excuses and self-pity are a waste of time. The bottom line is that teams win matches, titles or qualify for tournaments because they deserve to.

In any case, these things cut both ways. Yes, you can look at the Ray Parlour "goal" or the foul on Teddy Sheringham and wonder what might have been. But then what about the Euro 2000 qualifier against Sweden at Wembley when Paul Scholes could have been sent off in the first minute?

I tried never to go down that road of "if only". It gives the players a get-out-of-jail card and I don't think you should ever do that. If you look back you'll find I made very few after-match comments about referees.

That is where Martin O'Neill did so well last season when there was all that boardroom trouble at Leicester. It would have been easy for him or the players to lose focus and say "How do you expect us to pull together?" But Martin used events off the field to bring his team even closer.

That mentality of taking responsibility is important. I tried to convey to my players that what we do is decisive; that, if we do it right enough times, we will win and, if we don't, it is our fault and nobody else's.

Of course there are times when someone scores with a deflection against you and you think "I don't need that". But, when the ball runs for you, you don't tend to turn round and say "We were jammy there," do you? And the incidents you moan about when you are down you generally shrug off when you're flying.

That's why I love players who are strong-minded and don't think in terms of hard-luck stories. Paul McGrath and Mark Hughes were like that. Martin Keown, who I think has emerged as England's best defender, also has that quality in abundance. That mental strength is something you see in all top sports people, be it Steve Redgrave or Tiger Woods.

In any case, it's by no means curtains for England's hopes of reaching the 2002 World Cup. I expected us to have four points by now and, if we had beaten Germany, people might have said it was quite a professional performance to go to Finland and get a point on a poor pitch in windy conditions.

Instead we went there looking down the barrel and that changes the perception. I know the performance was far from brilliant but there are enough games to rectify the situation and the break until Finland visit Anfield in March offers a chance to bring in a new coach and create a feeling that we are starting the campaign again.

As Howard Wilkinson said, England may not be good enough to win the World Cup but we are a lot better than we have looked in recent competitive matches. And I think playing at league grounds while Wembley is rebuilt could work in our favour.

Foreign teams definitely get a lift from coming to Wembley. Whatever anyone says, it was the Cathedral of Football and sides felt it was a privilege to play there. I remember being on the pitch before the Arsenal-Fiorentina Champions League game there last season. Gabriel Batistuta, Paulo Sousa and others were looking around clearly thinking, "This looks the business, we'll have a bit of this." And of course Fiorentina went on to win that match.

League grounds are an environment our players are more familiar with and that might bring performances which are less inhibited. Also the fans can provide extra adrenalin in those tighter stadiums.

Kevin Keegan wanted to play international matches at Newcastle United and I can understand that. You are guaranteed not only a big crowd at St James' Park but a very fervent one.

But finding the right man to replace Keegan is still the No1 issue. I wonder whether the most suitable candidate might be Sven-Goran Eriksson, the Lazio coach. He's got a northern European mentality but has spent a lot of time in Mediterranean Europe, speaks good English and knows our game well.

I wouldn't leave Lazio if I were him but he'll know that in Italy you are always on shaky ground. You can be top of the league, have a bad team photo and be sacked. And, if Eriksson wanted to stay to the end of the season, to try to win another Serie A title and the Champions League, and then take over the England job it would be worth the wait. Let's face it, we have hit a rocky patch and bad luck is not the reason.

I tried to convey to my players that what we do is decisive; that, if we do it right enough times, we will win and, if we don't, it is our fault and nobody else's. Of course there are times when someone scores with a deflection against you and you think "I don't need that". But, when the ball runs for you, you don't tend to turn round and say "We were jammy there," do you? And the incidents you moan about when you are down you generally shrug off when you're flying. That's why I love players who are strong-minded and don't think in terms of hard-luck stories. Paul McGrath and Mark Hughes were like that. Martin Keown, who I think has emerged as England's best defender, also has that quality in abundance. That mental strength is something you see in all top sports people, be it Steve Redgrave or Tiger Woods. In any case, it's by no means curtains for England's hopes of reaching the 2002 World Cup. I expected us to have four points by now and, if we had beaten Germany, people might have said it was quite a professional performance to go to Finland and get a point on a poor pitch in windy conditions. Instead we went there looking down the barrel and that changes the perception. I know the performance was far from brilliant but there are enough games to rectify the situation and the break until Finland visit Anfield in March offers a chance to bring in a new coach and create a feeling that we are starting the campaign again. As Howard Wilkinson said, England may not be good enough to win the World Cup but we are a lot better than we have looked in recent competitive matches. And I think playing at league grounds while Wembley is rebuilt could work in our favour. Foreign teams definitely get a lift from coming to Wembley. Whatever anyone says, it was the Cathedral of Football and sides felt it was a privilege to play there. I remember being on the pitch before the Arsenal-Fiorentina Champions League game there last season. Gabriel Batistuta, Paulo Sousa and others were looking around clearly thinking, "This looks the business, we'll have a bit of this." And of course Fiorentina went on to win that match. League grounds are an environment our players are more familiar with and that might bring performances which are less inhibited. Also the fans can provide extra adrenalin in those tighter stadiums. Kevin Keegan wanted to play international matches at Newcastle United and I can understand that. You are guaranteed not only a big crowd at St James' Park but a very fervent one. But finding the right man to replace Keegan is still the No1 issue. I wonder whether the most suitable candidate might be Sven-Goran Eriksson, the Lazio coach. He's got a northern European mentality but has spent a lot of time in Mediterranean Europe, speaks good English and knows our game well. I wouldn't leave Lazio if I were him but he'll know that in Italy you are always on shaky ground. You can be top of the league, have a bad team photo and be sacked. And, if Eriksson wanted to stay to the end of the season, to try to win another Serie A title and the Champions League, and then take over the England job it would be worth the wait. Let's face it, we have hit a rocky patch and bad luck is not the reason.  You've read the piece, now have your say. fields.headline: FA demands a broader cast
fields.trailText: Following u>direct's problems with pay-per-view on Wednesday, the FA is to seek a guarantee from Fifa and Uefa that more viewers can see England away games.
fields.body:
The Football Association is to seek a guarantee from Fifa and Uefa that more viewers can see England away games after problems with the pay-per-view coverage of the Finland-England match on Wednesday.

The FA's director of marketing Paul Barber says: "We want to talk to Fifa and Uefa about how, in future, we can maintain some control over the rights to England's competitive away games while recognising that for someone like Finland the money they secured will help develop Finnish football.

"But I want England fans to be able to see England matches. And we should be allowed to have some control over how our brand is represented in our own country."

The Finnish FA, as the home federation, sold the rights to u>direct for a massive £2.5m, and they in turn asked subscribers to pay between £6-£10. The company broadcast the match via Sky, various cable companies and ONdigital, and though there were few problems on Sky, other viewers reported technical problems such as frozen screens.

Among the complainants was the brewer Whitbread, which claimed that u>direct failed to provide the match to at least 50 pubs who had paid £140 each for the service.

Chris Emmel, a Whitbread pubs director, was scathing. "U>direct priced this match out of the reach of many fans, so they could only see it at their local pub," he said. "Yet despite the huge fees being charged, they let England supporters down in a big way."

Roger Hall, u>direct's managing director, admitted there were difficulties with a flurry of late calls to register but refused to take the blame for the technical problems.

Of England's remaining away World Cup qualifiers, the game in Albania is live on Channel 5 and the game in Germany on Sky. Only the game in Greece could be on pay-per-view, with the live rights still up for grabs.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Wasim faces ban from series
fields.trailText: Wasim Akram, along with several leading Pakistan players, who could receive further punishment next week after being implicated in the worldwide match-fixing controversy
fields.body:
Wasim Akram is one of several leading Pakistan players who could receive further punishment next week after being implicated in the worldwide match-fixing controversy.

The International Cricket Council, at its executive board meeting here on Monday and Tuesday, will discuss whether to impose further penalties to those already set by the Qayyum Report, which was published in May.

The ICC code of conduct commission, headed by Lord Hugh Griffiths, has studied Justice Qayyum's findings and has the power to issue stronger sanctions, even bans.

It is conceivable that Wasim, Mushtaq Ahmed, Waqar Younis, Inzamam-ul-Haq and Saeed Anwar could be suspended from the forthcoming one-day and Test series against England.

But the ICC does not want to anger the Pakistanis and run the risk of the tour not taking place. It is likely to do nothing or diplomatically to suggest that the Pakistan Cricket Board rethinks the punishments.

Following the Qayyum Report the former Pakistan captain Wasim was fined £5,000 and severely censured. Qayyum also said his finances should be investigated.

A row has broken out over whether Hansie Cronje will be allowed to become a television commentator. On Wednesday the former South African captain was given a life ban by the United Cricket Board of South Africa for match-fixing.

The board says the ban extends to playing, coaching, marketing and administering the game and would like it to extend to commentating.

The pay-per view TV station M-Net has reportedly paid a six-figure sum for a lengthy interview with Cronje for broadcast on its Supersport channel and is keen to use him as a summariser.

fields.headline: Shakoor renews attack on Gatting
fields.standfirst:
Controversial umpire:
• Repeats allegation he made 13 years ago
• Claims that Hussain's team have no idea how to play spin bowling
• Says England have no chance of victory in series against Pakistan
fields.trailText: Controversial former umpire Shakoor Rana, he of the notorious Faisalabad Test between Pakistan and England in 1987, has launched a renewed attack on Mike Gatting and slammed England's chances of success this winter.
fields.body:
Shakoor Rana says Mike Gatting is his favourite cricketer and that he is welcome to stay with him in Lahore. But after 13 years the umpire still persists with the outlandish claim that the England captain was cheating when Anglo-Pakistani tensions exploded at Faisalabad.

A gloriously unrepentant Shakoor, 63 and now an assistant sports officer with Pakistan Railways, also says England "cannot win" in Pakistan this winter and has attacked the decision not to tour the country in the past 13 years.

"I do not know why England does not come," he said. "It is not my fault. But it is England's bad luck. If they came to Pakistan they might have learned to play spin bowling, which they can't.

"I do not regret what happened. England should regret it. They lost a day's play from a match they were winning. How can I regret? It made me the most famous umpire. People don't recognise me now, but when I introduce myself everyone says: 'Ah, yes, the famous umpire.' "

Infamous might be more appropriate. It was the awful umpiring in 1987-88, most notably by Shakoor and Shakeel Khan, that paved the way for neutral officials and helped dissuade England from touring the country. Next week they return for the first time for an official tour.

"Mike Gatting is a good person," said Shakoor, who even before the England series 13 years ago kept a proudly thumbed cuttings book in which he was described as "The World's Worst Umpire". "He is my favourite cricketer. He can play spin bowling. If he comes here I would like him to be a guest in my house.

"He is not a cheat. But that day in Faisalabad he cheated. I don't know why. I think he lost his temper after losing the Test in Lahore. And after cheating he started abusing me. My code of honour allows me to kill a man who insults me.

"But he wrote me a note of apology. I used to keep it under my pillow. Now I have it in a drawer. But it is a closed chapter.

"I came to England a few years ago to see my son, Mansoor, who was playing in the Bradford League. I saw Gatting sitting in a car. I went over because I wanted to talk to him and shake his hand. But he said 'Oh God, not you again' and drove off."

Even by the Byzantine standards of Pakistani cricket the tour of 1987-88 was something else. It was probably the most acrimonious series played since Bodyline. And even that schism of 1932-33 was followed by another England tour to Australia four years later.

The furious, finger-pointing exchange between Shakoor and Gatting was more than a mere cricket row. They stuck the picture on front pages all over the world, even in Germany. There were colonial overtones. And the image of an angry England captain at odds with a foreign umpire was symbolically represented as another sign of a once great nation's terminal decline.

The flashpoint came at the end of the second day of the second Test in Faisalabad, when Gatting signalled David Capel to come up from deep square-leg to save a single. He had, he said later, informed the batsman, Salim Malik, of the field change, though this had increasingly become the job of the non-striker.

Then, as Eddie Hemmings came in to bowl, Gatting put his hand up to tell Capel he had come in enough. Shakoor, standing at square-leg, stopped play to tell the batsman about the fielder's position and then accused Gatting of cheating.

An ugly row followed and the following day Shakoor said he would not play unless he received an apology from Gatting. A mutual apology was brokered before the Pakistan captain, Javed Miandad, persuaded Shakoor to stand firm.

Gatting eventually issued an unreciprocated, scribbled apology on the understanding that he could tell everyone he had been made to do it by the England management. The third day's play was lost.

Shakoor contradicts this version. "I would never have agreed to apologise," he said. "Why? I was 100% right." The Pakistan tour 13 years ago was the most taxing leg of an arduous winter that also included a Test series against New Zealand, a World Cup and the Bicentennial Test against Australia in Sydney.

Those of us who were in Pakistan soon realised that England would not be allowed to win the series. Pakistan, it seemed, had decided to exact revenge for the previous summer when they toured England and vainly requested that David Constant and Ken Palmer should be removed from the panel of Test umpires.

In the first Test of 1987-88, in Lahore, England were convinced that they were cheated out of the match. The tone was set when Gatting, playing a sharp leg-break that pitched on off-stump, was given out lbw by Shakeel Khan.

According to the England players, this was one of nine bad decisions that went against them. They lost by an innings and 87 runs. "We weren't allowed to perform," Gatting said. "We were cut short by blatant umpiring."

Worse was to follow. Shakoor was appointed to stand in the second Test. "England asked me not to select Shakeel Khan," said Pakistan's unofficial manager, Hasib Ahsan. "Let's see how they like Shakoor Rana."

Shakoor already had a reputation as the world's most obstinate umpire. In 1978-79, in Faisalabad's first Test match, he held up play for 13 minutes while he argued with India's Sunil Gavaskar. And in 1984-85 he provoked the New Zealand captain Jeremy Coney to lead his players off the field in protest.

Shakoor dismayed Gatting's players by wearing a Pakistan sweater and when Mudassar Nazar handed him his cap prior to bowling he promptly put it on.

But Shakoor's actions backfired. He officiated in only two Test matches after the Faisalabad affair. "I don't even go to cricket matches now. But I watch them on TV with my grandson.

And I will watch England. It will be win at all costs for both sides. It always is.

"It is sad what happened before. Today the match referee would sort it out."

webTitle: South Korean president wins Nobel Peace Prize

fields.headline: South Korean president wins Nobel Peace Prize
fields.standfirst: Audio with Jonathan Watts
fields.trailText: The South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, won the Nobel Peace Prize today for his  work towards peace and reconciliation with North Korea.
fields.body:
The South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, won the Nobel Peace Prize today for his work towards peace and reconciliation with North Korea.

"In the course of South Korea's decades of authoritarian rule, despite repeated threats on his life and long periods in exile, Kim Dae-jung gradually emerged as his country's leading spokesman for democracy," according to the Nobel citation.

South and North Korea, foes on the battlefield a half-century ago, have warmed to each other more in the last few months than in more than a generation. Their armies remain locked in a standoff across a sealed border, but the mood on the peninsula is considerably lighter.

After patiently pursuing contacts with North Korea during the first two years of his presidency, Kim held a groundbreaking summit in June with his northern counterpart, Kim Jong Il. The two countries then stopped propaganda broadcasts, held a reunion of separated families, opened border liaison offices and agreed to reconnect a cross-border railway.

"His visit to North Korea gave impetus to a process which has reduced tension between the two countries," the Norwegian Nobel Institute said. "There may now be hope that the cold war will also come to an end in Korea."

The announcement was a cliffhanger to the last minute as the speculation was more muted than usual. Last year's winner, the humanitarian group Doctors Without Borders, figured heavily in guesses ahead of the announcement.

The five-member committee and its non-voting secretary Geir Lundestad stake their pride on keeping the secret.

The Nobel committee never reveals the nominees, only their number, which this year was a record 150. But those making nominations for the 9m Swedish kronor prize (about £600,000) often announce them. The peace prize capped a week of Nobel announcements - the latest, the literature prize, was awarded Thursday to Chinese dissident writer Gao Xingjian, now a French citizen.

Americans James J Heckman and Daniel L McFadden won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics on Wednesday for developing theories on how people work and live, research that contributed greatly to employment training, public transportation, communication systems and other areas.

The physics prize was shared by Americans Jack Kilby, who co-invented the integrated circuit at Texas Instruments in 1958, and Herbert Kroemer; and Russian Zhores Alferov.

This year's chemistry prize went to Alan Heeger and Alan MacDiarmid of the United States and Hideki Shirakawa of Japan for their discoveries in the use of plastics to conduct electricity.

The medicine prize recognised Swede Arvid Carlsson and US-based researchers Paul Greengard and Eric Kandel for discoveries about how messages are transmitted between brain cells, leading to treatments of Parkinson's disease and depression.

The prizes are presented on December 10, the date the prize's founder, Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, died in 1896. The peace prize is the only one presented in Oslo.

webTitle: Miller gives lukewarm backing to Gore

fields.headline: Miller gives lukewarm backing to Gore
fields.trailText: American playwright Arthur Miller last night declared his voting intentions to a sell-out audience at London's Lyric theatre where he was appearing as part of The Word literary festival.
fields.body:
American playwright Arthur Miller last night declared his voting intentions to a sell-out audience at London's Lyric theatre where he was appearing as part of The Word literary festival.

"I'll probably vote for Gore," he remarked, before adding "...I'm less unenthusiastic about him than the others".

A jovial Miller was on good form as he spoke for 40 minutes with National Theatre director Richard Eyre, and then answered questions for a further 15.

On his 85th birthday, he indulged in an evening of memoirs and anecdotes as he returned to the beginnings of his long career.

He described how, growing up in 1930s America, he came to be involved with the theatre and explained the impact that his depression-era upbringing had on his development as a playwright.

"During the depression, the theatre was alive with anger and excitement. It was at the centre of protests and there was a real social atmosphere," he said. "The depression had destroyed the American Dream - whereas before life had been limitless, suddenly you couldn't do anything. Education meant nothing - there were no longer any givens. The depression showed that everything could be changed and the essence of life is nothingness. I wanted to reflect this in the forms of my plays. I chose to write rather than act because writing a play is like being an actor without the embarrassment. Besides, I have no memory for lines."

Miller said that All My Sons, his first acclaimed play which premiered in 1947, was his bid to avoid becoming a "failed playwright": "I had written five or six 'experimental' plays - although no such word existed then; they were simply 'not good' - so I decided to write a play that I knew would really work. Again, it arose out of the depression - the idea that man is a social animal and society can also strike him down".

Miller said that he feels strangely divorced from what is possibly his best-known play, despite living less than quarter of a mile from the hut in which he wrote it, but added that: "I have clear memories of that time. I would occasionally go and see it and regretted that I had made it so sad. I decided to make a play in which nobody cried... that was The Crucible..."

He touched briefly on the McCarthyism associated with the play: "It was like living in insanity - the political system and whole grip on reality was in danger. The Crucible was an attempt to focus on that on stage, and demystify it", and brought his political concerns up to the present day when he voiced his familiar complaint of the lack of subsidy in American theatre compared with Britain.

webTitle: Ex-Treasury man called in to end lottery chaos

fields.headline: Ex-Treasury man called in to end lottery chaos
fields.trailText: The former Treasury mandarin Lord Burns was named chairman of the national lottery commission, an appointment the government hopes will quell growing controversy surrounding the award of the next licence to run the game.
fields.body:
The former Treasury mandarin Lord Burns was yesterday named chairman of the national lottery commission, an appointment the government hopes will quell growing controversy surrounding the award of the next licence to run the game.

Choosing Lord Burns, one of Whitehall's most experienced figures, sends a signal that the culture secretary, Chris Smith, wants to restore some credibility to the commission, which has seen its name ravaged in recent weeks.

Lord Burns, 56, comes with a down to earth reputation and was thought adept enough at handling emotive issues to chair the government's hunting inquiry.

Mr Smith will now want the two rival bidders, Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery and Camelot, to end their verbal warfare and resume negotiations with the commission.

The Conservatives immediately dubbed the appointment Tony Blair's "revenge" on Gordon Brown because of the history of ill will between the chancellor and his then-permanent secretary, which resulted in Lord Burns' enforced "retirement" from the Treasury in 1998 - clutching a peerage.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, also renewed his calls for the remaining four lottery commissioners to step down. "We welcome the appointment of Lord Burns, who is clearly a very able man," he said. "But question marks still hang over other members."

Lord Burns is stepping into a job many would regard as a poisoned chalice. He replaces Dame Helena Shovelton, who quit last week amid claims she mishandled the process for picking a group to run the lottery from next October. Lord Burns said he appreciated how difficult the task was. "It is clearly not an easy job but I believe it can be done otherwise I wouldn't have taken it on. The important thing is to look forward."

A decision to pursue exclusive negotiations with the People's Lottery was overturned in the high court in a judgment which suggested the commission had abused its power. In a letter to Lord Burns confirming his appointment Mr Smith acknowledged he was taking over at a "challenging time".

Mr Smith said: "He is someone of unimpeachable integrity and very high public stature."

Both Camelot and the People's Lottery were happy with the appointment. "We welcome a fresh pair of eyes and hope he can allay our concerns," said a Camelot spokeswoman. The People's Lottery said it hoped the process could move to a swift conclusion.

Lord Burns will receive an annual salary of £48,000 during his three-year tenure. A respected figure, his offences in the Treasury included his monetarist past as a Thatcher appointee and the suspicion that he was Downing Street's "fifth column" as Mr Brown and his inner entourage - Ed Balls, Geoffrey Robinson and Charlie Whelan - took control in 1997.

What clinched the exclusion, according to Andrew Rawnsley's book, Servants of the People, was that Lord Burns refused to help Mr Robinson out of political difficulty by saying he had been told about the then paymaster general's Channel Islands trust. Lord Burns believed he had only been told it was a "family trust" - with no tax implications.

That should reassure MPs and voters that Lord Burns is a genuinely independent figure, not a "crony".

fields.headline: People's peers attract 191 applications
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Parliament
Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Nearly 5,000 members of the public have expressed interest in becoming people's peers, according to Lady Jay, leader of the House of Lords.
fields.body:
Nearly 5,000 members of the public have expressed interest in becoming people's peers, according to Lady Jay, leader of the House of Lords.

She said yesterday that 191 people have already been formally nominated or completed application forms since adverts for people's peers were placed in mid-September. The deadline for applications is November 17.

An appointments commission is touring cities trying to drum up applications from voluntary groups, businessmen and public sector employees. The new source of crossbenchers is designed to produce up to 10 peers early next year. Lady Jay said stringent criteria would ensure the new peers added to the quality of debate in the second chamber. She has set great store by the new procedure to justify the continuation of an interim chamber before the government introduces a semi-elected system.

Lord Carter, government chief whip in the Lords, in sisted yesterday he would not lose any bills despite pressure to complete legislation in time for a Queen's speech in late November. Bills still requiring further scrutiny include the police (Northern Ireland) bill, the freedom of information bill, the countryside bill, the sexual offences bill, and the political parties, elections and referendums bill.

webTitle: People claims victory over MI5 after court ruling

fields.headline: People claims victory over MI5 after court ruling
fields.trailText: Friday 6.15pm The Sunday People is claiming victory over MI5 after a judge overturned an injunction to prevent it publishing information about Army activities in Northern Ireland, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Sunday People is claiming victory over MI5 after a judge overturned an injunction to prevent it publishing information about an Army unit alleged to have been involved in sectarian murders.

The paper is claiming the first major victory for press freedom under the new Human Rights Act, which came into force last week.

After the story, written by the People's Northern Ireland editor, Greg Harkin, appeared in the paper two weeks ago, the paper claimed it was banned from making any further reference to the activities of the the unit.

As a result of the injunction, the People said Mr Harkin was ordered to hand over to the MoD all notes and information relating to the story. The People said it was also ordered to hand over all information relating to the unit and to submit any further articles to the MoD for approval.

As part of the latest court ruling, however, the paper has agreed not to identify any agent, member or informant of the unit.

A spokesman for the MoD said: "An order was made by the court, the contents of which were agreed between the Ministry of Defence and Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd."

He would not comment on the specifics of the case, but added: "If [the Sunday People] do something which we feel would be prejudicial to national security, we will not rule out further action."

webTitle: The Way You See It: Richard Williams and the England cull

fields.headline: The Way You See It: Richard Williams and the England cull
fields.trailText: In his column today, Richard Williams suggests that England should cull Keown, Adams, Ince, Wise, Scholes, Andy Cole and Campbell and give youth a chance. Your reaction has been fierce: many of you reckon the piece should form the blueprint for England's future, while others have questioned Mr Williams' sanity and - rather harshly, surely? - suggested he was on mind-altering substances while writing it.
fields.body:
In his column today, Richard Williams suggests that England should cull Keown, Adams, Ince, Wise, Scholes, Andy Cole and Campbell and give youth a chance. Your reaction has been fierce: many of you reckon the piece should form the blueprint for England's future, while others have questioned Mr Williams' sanity and - rather harshly, surely? - suggested he was on mind-altering substances while writing it.

Neil Butler is one advocate of the former view. "It is the most sense anybody has ever expressed on the depressing subject that is the English football squad," he says, while Glen Crisp "couldn't agree more" with the article. Meanwhile, Peter Flint "can only applaud" Mr Williams for his "vision and clarity", adding: "As has been said often before, even by Ron Atkinson; 'If you're good enough, you're old enough. Our youngsters are good enough."

Martyn Hartley has a slight modification to Mr Williams' suggestions, however. "Having just read the best and most enlightened piece on the state of English football written for some time, I must say that I almost completely agree with your conclusions," he says. "However, history shows us that you cannot build a team solely on youthful skill and energy without adding a pinch of experience. As such, I would be inclined to hold onto a spine of experienced players to help bring on the youngsters."

That view is supported by Kirsteen Haxton, who while agreeing that Mr Williams makes some valid points, points out that: "France didn't become World and European champions by playing a team of youth players. They had a good blend of youth and players with tremendous experience - Laurent Blanc was no spring chicken."

But there have been plenty of strident criticisms of Mr Williams' article. "What class-A drug is Richard Williams on?" asks Ray Ansbro. "His insane and inane demand that Paul Scholes and Sol Campbell never play for England again is barmy beyond belief. Scholes, despite being played out of position, has scored more goals than any current England player, and Campbell is the best centre half in Britain.

"Two words sum up Williams' deluded drivel: Carl Cort. The man cannot be serious."

Ray's view is supported by Jeremy Gostick, who opines: "There's nothing like an England crisis to bring out every nutter with a half-baked theory about what to do next (and I don't mean Howard Wilkinson). So step forward Richard Williams, whose inspired solution is to drop Paul Scholes on the grounds that he's past it in his mid twenties (?!?) and replace him with the likes of err...Carl Cort. Christ, where do you get these people?"

However, the consensus seems to be that while Richard is right to suggest change, getting rid of Campbell and Scholes is a bit harsh. As David McGuiness puts it: "I agree totally with the overall views of Richard Williams although surely it would be stupid to confine two potential world class players like Scholes and Campbell to the international scrap heap - especially when you consider that Scholes has probably been England's most consistent goalscorer in the past twelve months."
