fields.headline: Anger,  Disillusionment, and  Despair
fields.trailText: ARSENE'S IN CHARGE
fields.body:
ARSENE'S IN CHARGE

Arsene Wenger certainly knows how to deal with the FA. Scarcely minutes after ruling himself out of the running for the vacant England job - "the England job is an attractive one, but someone else will be taking it, not me" - the no-nonsense Arsenal manager announced his intention to take the hapless footballing body through the courts.

A serene Wenger explained today that he is not best pleased with his recent 12-match ban for physically threatening behaviour. "Maybe I went to the meeting expecting some kind of small punishment, perhaps a fine," he mused, "but this is far, far too much, and I will certainly consult a lawyer. It is not only harsh, it is an injustice. I feel like I have killed somebody."

But just for the record, Arsene doesn't hate David Davies's very guts. That's because, although Arsene is hard (and he is), he's also fair. Showing a willingness to forgive and forget, Wenger today conceded that he may be prepared to coach England. When he is good and ready. "I wouldn't say no to the manager's job if I was completely free," he said, "but at the moment I give my all to Arsenal. Maybe in two or three years I will change my mind." This sounds fine to the Fiver - any major lawsuits should have been dealt with by then.

A LOVELY TALE

The Fiver spent most of Wednesday evening hurling a thesaurus's worth of profanities at u>direct's u>seless coverage. And when the TV wasn't incurring our wrath, French referee Alain Sars took up the slack. "Off, off, off!" we cried when Teddy Sheringham was tripped - only to see Monsieur Sars furiously shake his Gallic head. "Go-aaalllllllllll!" we cheered, as Romford Ray's rocket crashed off the bar and in - only for Sars to deny us again. Never mind, we thought - when Sars talks to the press, he wouldn't deny us our justice for a third time, would he?

"I don't feel responsible for England's defeat at all and anyway they had only one real opportunity to score," Mr Sars said today, knocking the Fiver's socks off. What about the sending off? "In such a case a referee wonders if that player really had a chance to score," Sars pondered. "I saw two Finnish defenders who could have intercepted the ball if Sheringham had shot. I assessed the striker had been tripped and that the keeper deserved a yellow card."

"Alright then, what about Romford Ray's wonder-goal?" we seethed - but even that was not Sar's fault. "How do you think an assistant can see where the ball bounced," he said, "when it's just hit the crossbar at 150 kilometres-per-hour and comes out straight away?" By using his eyes perhaps?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It looks like a classic case of a bandwagon effect snowballing out of control" - A classic case of mixed metaphors as William Hill spokesman Graham Sharpe explains why odds on Lazio's Sven Goran Eriksson for next England manager tumbled from 33/1 to 3/1.

SOMETIMES YOU HAVE TO GO BACKWARDS TO MOVE FORWARDS

Gerard Houllier today took a step closer to realising his dream. By agreeing a £7m deal with Dynamo Zagreb for Croatian international Igor Biscan, the Liverpool boss will soon be able to field a team consisting solely of defensive midfielders, thus unleashing his epochal 0-10-0 formation on a stunned footballing world. Biscan won't arrive until the mid-winter break in the Croatian season, mind you, so we'll have to put up with the tired old goal-seeking formation for a while yet.

"We will be delighted to have him, especially as so many other top European clubs were interested," babbled an over-excited Houllier as he imagined Biscan trapping a searching three-yard sideways pass from Jamie Carragher. "He is an international player and a class player. We've been watching him for a long time," he chattered, picturing his new charge racing down the wing to stop a Dietmar Hamann back-pass going out for a corner.

Of course, Biscan is a talented man - you don't get in the Croatian side at 22 years of age if you're no good. "He is a versatile footballer as he showed against Scotland when he played on the right of midfield," explained his new boss, showing worrying cavalier tendencies. Luckily for Liverpool fans however, Houllier was quick to clear up any confusion: "I see him as a defensive midfielder." So good luck with the new plan, Gerard, and remember: sideways pass and move, it's the Liverpool groove!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Both Newcastle and Celtic are lining up a bid for £3m-rated Everton defender Richard Dunne, according to reports.

West Ham have enquired about taking Torino defender Fabio Galante and midfielder Djibril Diawara on loan.

Sunderland are interested in taking Sporting Lisbon striker Kwame Ayew on trial, reports Planet Football. The 26-year-old Ghanian international is also interesting Rangers, Fenerbahce and several Bundesliga clubs.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Rangers have finally agreed a deal for Espanyol's £11m-rated striker Raul Tamudo. "Rangers and Espanol have agreed terms subject to changes in the transfer system, which is currently under review," said a club statement.

Ryan Giggs is close to agreeing a new five-year contract at Manchester United. "We are still in talks at the moment, I have 18 months of my current contract left and I would like to get things all sorted out," he admitted. "And I believe that will be done fairly soon, hopefully before Christmas time."

Sheffield Wednesday have given a cautious welcome to the Hamed brothers' interest in the club. Chairman Howard Culley admitted: "If Prince Naseem and the Hamed family are seriously interested in the future of Sheffield Wednesday, then I would be available to meet with them to explore their ideas."

Israeli winger Idan Tal has been granted a work permit and is expected to sign for Everton at the start of next week. Hearts defender Gary Naysmith should also complete a £1.75m move to Goodison later today.

BBC Scotland will screen both legs of Celtic's Euro-Vase tie with Bordeaux live, on October 26 and November 9.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)
Pah! As though we need to take tips on how to play football from other nations!

Live International Schoolboy Football (7pm, 12midnight)
A chance to take a long, lingering, possibly furtive look at fit young boys running around in their shorts.

Premier League Preview (11.30pm)
Tape this half-hour programme and, when Soccer AM is on tomorrow morning, watch it eight times in a row. That way, you won't have to put up with that preening ponce Lovejoy on your day off.

Sky Sports 3: Hold The Back Page (10pm, 4.30am SS1)
Now the nights are drawing in, wouldn't you like to hibernate in Brian's luxurious bouffant?

webTitle: TV chiefs promise broader cultural picture

fields.headline: TV chiefs promise broader cultural picture
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Television broadcasters yesterday launched a new drive to increase the number of ethnic minority faces on screen and behind the cameras.
fields.body:
Television broadcasters yesterday launched a new drive to increase the number of ethnic minority faces on screen and behind the cameras.

TV chiefs, concerned that black and Asian viewers are deserting them quicker than others, admitted that not enough has been done to reflect the changing culture of Britain.

All promised to stop “endless meetings” and take action to promote talent from ethnic minority backgrounds. The BBC, Channel 4 and Channel 5 set specific targets for increasing staff diversity. Chris Smith, the culture secretary, said he would monitor progress.

Launching the Cultural Diversity Network, its first chairman, Carlton TV’s chief executive Clive Jones, said broadcasters will lose even more viewers if change is not made now. “This country is facing a demographic revolution which means that this industry has to get its act together. Either we adapt, or what we do will become increasingly irrelevant for a vital part of the audience.” After years of attending meetings and commissioning reports, the time had come to act. “The status quo simply cannot be allowed to continue.”

The network is a joint initiative involving the BBC, ITV, Carlton Television, Granada Media, GMTV, ITN, Channel 4, Channel 5 and BSkyB. Each company has produced an action plan, with employment targets and commitments to increase the number of black and Asian screen actors and broadcasters.

Greg Dyke, director general of the BBC, repeated his stated commitment to increase the number of ethnic minority staff at the corporation from 8% now to 10% in 2003. The number of managers from minority backgrounds must double from a “pathetic” 2% to 4%. “We have to question why we haven’t made enough progress,” he said. The BBC was still “very white”, he added.

Although the BBC was not driven by advertising revenue, its licence fee obligations mean it must produce programmes of wide appeal.

ITV said it would order programme makers to consider how they portray cultural diversity in their programmes. Its revived soap, Crossroads, will have a strong multicultural theme. Channel 4 said it would increase its ethnic minority staff from 9% of its payroll to 11% by 2003, and Channel 5 said it aimed to reach 13%. BSkyB pledged to introduce a mentoring system.

Sir Herman Ouseley, chairman of the equal opportunities commission, said he detected a change in mood. “I’m hopeful that today is a watershed because the high-level executives have come here and pledged themselves to commitments, along with the secretary of state.”

Research has shown that black and Asian people are abandoning terrestrial television channels quicker than any other section of the community. Yet ethnic minorities constitute 7% of the UK population, and in London it is estimated the level will reach 30% next year.

Mr Smith said: “This initiative is not about political correctness, but about the plain realities of life.”


***

‘Black and Asian faces are on screen, but they need to be on the board’

Krishnan Guru-Murthy

At the launch of the Cultural Diversity Network yesterday, I kept thinking “Thank God for Lord Alli”. As one by one the middle-class, middle-aged, white men who run British television promised better portrayal and new targets for minority representation, at least Waheed was there from Carlton to show that there is one non-white face in a position of power. He is about the only one.

It is embarrassing - no, appalling - that there is nobody from an ethnic minority in top-level management at the BBC, ITV Network Centre, BSkyB or C5. Even at Channel 4 the two most senior black people are in charge of multicultural programmes. And it is not because there are no suitably qualified people from ethnic minorities.

On screen, things are not so bad. There are now quite a few non-white faces around, though some channels are better than others. Would anybody but Channel 4 have two black presenters fronting the main news together, as happens when I present the programme with Samira Ahmed or Daljit Dhaliwal? I do not think you would see it on the BBC, and certainly not on ITV. What is really great is that it does not happen here by design; it is just the way the rota works out.

Since I started in 1988 things have improved: for a start, there are many more of us. But getting black and Asian people into the production offices and on screen is not enough. They need to be in the boardrooms and chief executives’ offices if British television can achieve the “step change” the men at the top say they want.

Once, it was fashionable to have seminars; now, it is fashionable to say: “We’re fed up with seminars, let’s do things.” But I am optimistic because I think that for the first time the bosses are actually scared of what will happen if they do not stop talking and start doing something. They have set targets we can all judge them by and they know that if they fail, huge parts of the TV audience will simply desert them.

• Krishnan Guru-Murthy is a presenter of Channel 4 News

fields.headline: Families mourn lynch-mob victims
fields.standfirst: Wives prepare to bury husbands killed by an angry crowd of Palestinians
fields.trailText: Wives prepare to bury husbands killed by an angry crowd of Palestinians.
fields.body:
Hani Avrahami was alerted to the brutal killing of two Israeli soldiers via the internet. She immediately called her husband, a reserve soldier. His mobile phone rang and rang and a strange voice answered.

"I just killed your husband," the gruff voice said.

Israeli media reports of the last, desperate phone calls of the two widows to their husbands gripped Israelis today. Many were horrified by the television footage of Palestinians cheering as one of the soldier's bodies was thrown out a second-story window and attacked by the furious Palestinian mob.

Yossi Avrahami, 38, a toy salesman and father of three, was stabbed and beaten to death with another soldier in his reserve unit after they took a wrong turn and ended up in the middle of a funeral in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

A Palestinian crowd, angry over two weeks of fighting with Israelis that has left more than 90 people dead, attacked them after they were taken to a police station.

The second soldier who was killed, Vadim Norjitz, was a Russian immigrant who married his wife Irina only last week.

Mrs Norjitz had "called the cellular phone number a few times and no one answered and in the afternoon [the military] called to say he hadn't reached the point," Anna Norjitz said of her sister-in-law's efforts to reach her husband. "And then the police came and she understood Vadim was dead."

Irina Norjitz is three months pregnant, relatives told the Haaretz newspaper. Norjitz was buried today and Avrahami will to be buried on Sunday, the army said.

The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, has launched an investigation into the lynch mob killings.

fields.headline: RIP Urbanfetch
fields.standfirst: As Urbanfetch closes its virtual shop, Amy Vickers wonders if its dot.com competitors will learn that posting low profits against high losses is unsustainable in the long term.
fields.trailText: Urbanfetch was a dot.com disaster waiting to happen, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
It was always a dot.com disaster waiting to happen. From the moment that online delivery service Urbanfetch unveiled international expansion plans four months ago, everyone said it wouldn't last.

"A great idea and a fantastic service for consumers, but it's just not going to sustain itself" was always the general market opinion, so it came as no surprise whatsoever when Urbanfetch waved the white flag on its consumer operation last night.

Signs posted on the company websites today declare "It was a pleasure to serve you" and "It is with great regret that we will be closing our doors. We've enjoyed serving you, London." The firm is wrapping up by having a farewell sale and knocking off up to 50% on its products to clear its stock and close up shop in about a week's time.

Why did Urbanfetch fail? Simple mathematics really. The company offered free delivery on all items that had practically no mark-up - the idea being to develop consumer demand, build market share and then fingers crossed, it would become a thriving operation. While the minimum order value is now said to be £20, when the operation first launched in London customers found that they could order anything at any value, and it would be delivered.

One punter recalls ordering a solitary packet of cheese crisps costing £2.50 at the end of August, and others said they ordered tubs of Ben and Jerry's ice cream that came to little much more than £5. Perhaps Urbanfetch's eagerness to please and bend over backwards to get customers on side was the main contributor to its downfall, particularly since the actual cost of providing a one-hour delivery service is around £6 per order.

The spotlight has now fallen on competitors in this field, namely Kozmo.com, which had been mooted as a potential merger partner for Urbanfetch until talks finally fell through earlier this week. As an example of what a loss-leader this type of service is, Kozmo.com revenues for the whole of 1999 were just $3.5m against losses of $26.4m. Having already cancelled its IPO earlier this year and laid off staff, Kozmo.com is now looking increasingly unsteady in the light of the Urbanfetch closure.

Above, what the failure of Urbanfetch shows is that loss-leading business-to-consumer sites are not going to work. As the prolonged summer of dot.com discontent draws to a close and autumn/winter sets in, it is inevitable that more b2c businesses will fall by the wayside.

In fact, less than a few hours after Urbanfetch announced its closure, seven-month old BagsOfTime.com, which has a similar business model, said it would stop taking orders at 5pm on Friday October 13.

In an explanation on its website, BagsOfTime.com said it had "failed to distinguish our same-day workplace delivery model clearly enough from others in the 'rapid delivery' market that require a significantly larger investment to concentrate on 60-minute delivery to individual consumers at home."

The name Urbanfetch will remain and be morphed into Urbanfetch Express, a client-serving courier business operating solely in New York.

fields.headline: Lentils, lingerie and laziness
fields.standfirst:
Marks & Spencer directionless
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Another day, another desperate downward plunge for Marks & Spencer shares. Last night the price closed at 171p, equal to the once-proud store chain's net asset value. In other words, in the eyes of the market Marks & Spencer's 11% share of the clothing market is now worth absolutely zero.
fields.body:
Another day, another desperate downward plunge for Marks & Spencer shares. Last night the price closed at 171p, equal to the once-proud store chain's net asset value. In other words, in the eyes of the market Marks & Spencer's 11% share of the clothing market is now worth absolutely zero.

In the last two weeks the share price decline has gathered momentum. The shares have fallen nearly 25%, wiping £1.6bn off the value of the company.

The latest damage has been inflicted by a series of broker downgrades, culminating in one influential analyst suggesting that 165p was a more appropriate target price, and a few paragraphs hidden away in the small print of the competition commission's supermarkets report which revealed that M&S's food profits took a hammering between 1996 and 1999.

The Baker Street mob have always chosen not to divulge the bottom line performance of their foodhalls, but the consensus of opinion had always been that it was performing well, compared with the rest of the business.

M&S insist that the figures were distorted, unrepresentative, etc, on the grounds of extra costs associated with this, that and the other. But no one is listening to the flannel any more.

The sad truth is that M&S is unlikely to ever be returned to its previous pole position in British retailing, no matter what wheezes the company can come up with (and they would have to be a lot better than the uninspired bare-bottom ad campaign and its dreary Exclusively for Everyone slogan).

The science of shopping has changed. No one would now invent a store that sells lingerie alongside lentil soup.

The Great British shopper does not want vast stores full of endless racks of clothes, unless they come cheap in a discount warehouse. Our love affair with labels does not extend to the rather dull little white one in the back of M&S clothes.

The group needs surgery to prune back its store numbers - probably making many loyal staff redundant. But that is a bitter pill and M&S will probably only do half the job. Certainly there is still no sign of its new retail chief Roger Holmes beaming down to do the dirty deeds required.

Terminal decline beckons, and there is no reason why M&S shares should not slide even further south. Certainly, the heat-seeking value investment funds are showing no sign of locking on to M&S.

Plenty of stores trade at a discount to their net asset value - take House of Fraser shares, which change hands at about 50% of NAV. If Marks & Spencer traded on the same price/earnings ratio as Boots its shares would be just 120p.

And there is no reason to think that at some stage a bidder is bound to emerge. There hasn't been one for Arcadia, or Boots, or Oasis - and they are all much cheaper than M&S.

Not floating

Spare a moment, if you will, for those in the Square Mile counting on big bonus payments this year.

Behind the headlines of spiking oil prices and billions wiped on and off shares, there is a growing realisation that, whatever the macro-economic consequences of tension in the middle east, the damage may already have been done to many of the huge, fee-earning deals coming down the market slipway.

Jessops, the photographic chain, has already iced its flotation plans, having found that fund managers would rather keep their hands in their pockets for now. Other relatively small new issues insist they are battling onwards to market. But they should not be surprised if they find themselves facing a universally hostile reception in the City - any new company insistent on joining the quoted sector during a period of extreme uncertainty is automatically treated with high suspicion. They just look too desperate.

Of much more importance to the British market are issues such as Orange, due to be spun off by France Telecom, and Yell.com, ready to pop out of British Telecom. The big telcos are des perate to offload businesses as one way of reducing debt built up in the great race to be part of the next generation of mobile telephony.

Even if the window has not shut entirely after this week's market gyrations, there seems no real chance of achieving the ratings which were being assumed so casually, so recently.

And then there is Sky Global Networks, Rupert Murdoch's planned satellite holding company which will bring together his 37.5% stake in BSkyB and Asia's Star TV, along with interests in Italy, Latin America and Japan.

It has been billed as the biggest initial public offering of a media company - ever. And it promises a bonanza for every financial adviser involved, on both sides of the Atlantic - if it happens.

But the market is no longer so sure. Over the past week, shares in parent News Corporation have fallen by almost a quarter. It feels like a chilly autumn.

webTitle: Douglas and Zeta Jones in on art scam project

fields.headline: Douglas and Zeta Jones in on art scam project
fields.trailText: Michael Douglas and future wife Catherine Zeta Jones are set to star together in a film about a notorious British art forger
fields.body:
Michael Douglas and future wife Catherine Zeta Jones are set to star together in a film about a notorious British art forger.

Douglas has persuaded Zeta Jones to star alongside him in a biopic about John Myatt, jailed last year for making fakes of old and new masters and selling them on through collector John Drewe. The scam was exposed in 1995 and Myatt was given a six-year prison sentence.

Douglas and Zeta Jones, currently in the UK with their baby son Dylan, are planning to visit the Staffordshire-born Myatt (who only served four months of his sentence) before they return to Los Angeles, according to the Daily Express.

Douglas paid more than $1m to secure the film rights and plans to play Myatt himself, with Zeta Jones as the forger's estranged wife. Douglas's publicist last night said: "Michael is fascinated by Myatt and is a big fan of the art world. It is a fabulous storyline."

Described by experts as the greatest art forgery of the century, the swindle began when Myatt, a former teacher and frustrated artist, was abandoned by his wife and left with two children to bring up. He put an advert in Private Eye in 1987 offering "genuine fakes".

John Drewe, a professional conman, answered the advert and became a customer. He then offered Myatt a lot of money to produce fakes to order. The pair were only caught when Drewe's wife reported them to the police.

Ironically, renewed interest in Myatt has launched him as an artist in his own right. He has already sold several of his own paintings to New York and Californian clients.

The film, if it goes ahead, will be the second time the loved-up couple have appeared together on screen; they both recently finished filming Traffic for Steven Soderbergh.

Described by experts as the greatest art forgery of the century, the swindle began when Myatt, a former teacher and frustrated artist, was abandoned by his wife and left with two children to bring up. He put an advert in Private Eye in 1987 offering "genuine fakes". John Drewe, a professional conman, answered the advert and became a customer. He then offered Myatt a lot of money to produce fakes to order. The pair were only caught when Drewe's wife reported them to the police. Ironically, renewed interest in Myatt has launched him as an artist in his own right. He has already sold several of his own paintings to New York and Californian clients. The film, if it goes ahead, will be the second time the loved-up couple have appeared together on screen; they both recently finished filming Traffic for Steven Soderbergh.

fields.headline: Bannister weighs up his options
fields.standfirst:
Bannister told staff of revamp plans
Bannister quits BBC
Greg Dyke statement
Comment: wrong man in wrong job?
Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText:
4pm: Matthew Bannister, the BBC director of marketing who resigned today, has "no fixed ideas" about what he will do next. By Jason Deans.Bannister told staff of revamp plans
Bannister quits BBC
Greg Dyke statement
Comment: wrong man in wrong job?
Special report: The BBC
fields.body:
Matthew Bannister, the BBC director of marketing and communications who resigned today, has "no fixed ideas" about what he will do next, but is considering setting up his own business after working at the corporation for most of the past 22 years.

Mr Bannister this afternoon told MediaGuardian.co.uk that he was planning to take a complete break after leaving the BBC on December 15, but will be looking at "all sorts of options" after that.

"This is a fascinating and exciting time to be in the media industry," Mr Bannister said. "There's the convergence of TV and the internet, of radio and the internet."

He added that, after working at such a big public service broadcaster for so long, his next move "may be working for myself, maybe in more entrepreneurial areas".

Mr Bannister would not be drawn on suggestions of a possible move into talent management, but did not rule out working with talent in some capacity in his next job.

On the timing of his decision to leave the BBC, Mr Bannister said he had been "thinking about it for quite a bit - this is not about the BBC or Greg Dyke. I have done 22 years on and off at the BBC - now maybe the time has come to take my career in a different direction."

Responding to criticism that, as a broadcaster, he was not the best person to have taken the BBC marketing director role, Bannister quipped that he was "certainly aware of reading [such comments] in Campaign".

But he defended the move, saying Mr Dyke had wanted somebody for the role who could communicate effectively with the channel controllers, as well as think about consumers like a marketer. "You don't have to have a degree in marketing to be good at it - look at Richard Branson," he said.

"Also, there are not many people around who have dealt with the press in such a high-profile way as I have," he added, referring to his time as Radio 1 controller.

Mr Bannister said that he was "going to carry on full-tilt until December 15".

"I hope that when I go I will have left behind a marketing strategy, a budget for the next 18 months and plans for the first phase of cost savings [for the BBC marketing and communications division]."

fields.headline: Summit hopes grow despite shootings
fields.standfirst:
 Weekend talks hopes grow
 Shootings at Ramallah
 Clashes at mosque
 Cook ends diplomatic mission
Interactive map: what's going on, where?
Audio from Suzanne Goldenberg (2mins 40)
fields.trailText: Israel and the Palestinians were today close to arranging a weekend summit that would include the US, Egypt, Jordan and the United Nations in a high-level attempt to end more than two weeks of violence, Palestinian officials said.
fields.body:
Israel and the Palestinians were today close to arranging a weekend summit that would include the US, Egypt, Jordan and the United Nations in a high-level attempt to end more than two weeks of violence, Palestinian officials said.

Israeli officials confirmed that the terms of a summit were being negotiated, but said no agreement had been reached yet.

But as diplomatic moves gathered pace, a gun battle erupted between Israeli troops and Palestinian gunmen in the volatile West Bank town of Ramallah, the scene of a mob killing yesterday of two Israeli soldiers.

In Jerusalem, Israeli police beat back young Palestinians outside a revered mosque.

However, Israel and the Palestinians appeared to be moving toward a summit that would be held tomorrow or Sunday in Egypt, according to senior Palestinian officials. The Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak are both expected to attend the talks, the officials said.

The final details had not been worked out, and the Israelis and Palestinians were not dealing directly with each other, the officials added.

As a condition for attending the summit, the Palestinians are demanding that Israel withdraw its troops from the outskirts of Palestinian cities and lift its siege of their communities in the West Bank.

Mr Barak's spokesman, Gadi Baltiansky, confirmed that negotiations on a summit were under way, but nothing had been decided.

World leaders have sought to calm two weeks of fighting that escalated yesterday when the two Israeli soldiers were mutilated by a mob of enraged Palestinians. Israel responded with combat helicopters that fired rockets at key Palestinian targets, including Arafat's residential compound in the Gaza Strip.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, has been leading a group of diplomats trying to broker a truce to the Israeli-Palestinian bloodletting that has left at least 94 dead, the vast majority Palestinian. Mr Annan was meeting with both Israeli and Palestinian leaders today.

Earlier, Palestinians declared today a "day of rage."

In Ramallah, several gunmen fought with Israeli troops following a rock-throwing protest. Initial reports said Palestinians opened fire on Israeli troops with rifles and the Israeli's responded with "virtually everything they had" including automatic weapons firing live rounds. Up to 2,000 people were said to be involved, but there are no immediate details of casualties

In Jerusalem's Old City, clashes broke out between police and young Palestinian men as Muslims arrived for midday prayers at the Noble Sanctuary compound, the third holiest site in Islam.

Muslim men under 45 were turned back on the reasoning that they would be most likely to participate in rioting. Police with clubs hit young Palestinian men attempting to enter the compound, and Palestinians heaved stones and bottles. At least two Palestinians and one policeman were hurt.

"They won't allow me to go and pray," said Abu Abdullah Sahir, 29. "After everything else that has happened this makes me very angry."

The current round of violence, the worst in the area in decades, broke out on September 28 after a rightwing Israeli leader, the Likud party leader, Ariel Sharon, visited the mosque, which Jews call the Temple Mount and revere as the holiest site in Judaism.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, today ended his two days of shuttle diplomacy around the Middle East with a new plea for peace, saying "now is the time for the bloodshed to stop".

Mr Cook met with Mr Barak, who told him he was "interested" in attending a summit proposed by the Egyptians at the resort of Sharm El Sheikh.

But Mr Cook added: "I got the very clear message that if any meeting at Sharm El Sheikh is to be a success, it does not simply need to resolve the immediate crisis, it needs to provide perspective for getting back to business on the basis of what was agreed at Camp David.

"I got a clear statement from prime minister Barak that they are very interested in having a meeting but it must be a serious meeting, it must be a meeting with the prospect, not just of ending the current crisis, but of providing a path forward to resolve the issues that still divide the two sides in the peace process."

Timeline: how the region exploded
Steve Bell's view

fields.headline: 'More edgy than New York, not as harsh as London or over-enthusiastic as Milan'
fields.standfirst: Jess Cartner-Morley  reviews Paris fashion week
fields.trailText: Jess Cartner-Morley reviews Paris fashion week
fields.body:
This week's story is how Paris got its groove back. After the best part of a decade spent in the shadows of Milan, this week's catwalk shows proved that the French capital is firmly back in the frame. A city to which international designers have traditionally flocked, Paris is currently home to many of the most exciting design talents from America and Britain, Belgium and Holland. The fashion industry is reaping the rewards of a buoyant economy and even the perennial criticism of Paris, that it lacks what Stella McCartney calls "a vibe", is faltering in the face of a burgeoning music scene and a clutch of alternative style magazines.

One important element of the renaissance will come under the spotlight tonight, when Tom Ford unveils his first collection for Yves Saint Laurent. Ford's newly divided loyalties in his first season flitting between the vaunted Parisian house and Gucci are important both practically and symbolically: the Ford-led Gucci revival was, along with the success of Prada, the driving force behind the 90s coup in which Milan effectively dethroned Paris.

But whatever happens tonight, Paris has already proved itself this week. By striking a balance - more edgy than New York, not as harsh as London or as over-enthusiastic as Milan - Paris made sense of trends that have weaved through a month of shows. Designers grasped how to do edgy that wasn't ugly, desirable that wasn't flash. They also attempted to get to grips with two trends that look set to fox us next season: strange sleeve shapes and full skirts.

Sleeves as you or I know them were nowhere to be found on this season's catwalks. In their place were pieces of fabric flapping over the shoulder, as if the designer had been going to make sleeves but ran out of time. Or there were sleeves, but slit from shoulder to wrist. What vexed me most were the kimono and batwing sleeves, where the armhole starts almost at the waist.

Still, they do look nice. In Chloe's ladylike collection, they gave a modern slant to fitted, pleated skirts that might otherwise have looked a little Miss Marple; teamed with the house's signature sexy trousers, they formed a striking new silhouette. In Martine Sitbon's collection, they featured on dresses in distressed red silk and sequined black crepe. At Gaspard Yurkievich's hip show, they were part of an upturned triangular silhouette: black satin and rubber dresses had voluminous shoulders and a generous hood, and narrowed to skim the hips.

If the sleeve took some getting used to, the jury is still out on the full skirt. A circle skirt to the knee, given volume by pleats or folds, and accented with a wide belt or waistband, was a key item in many collections. Issey Miyake presented the most interesting take, with skirts given a puffball shape by feathers or paper flowers trapped in between net petticoats. At Louis Vuitton, full skirts came in rose-printed mosquito net fabric; at Givenchy, they were statuesque as wedding cakes in layers of piped organza, or scalloped leather over net.

Here and elsewhere they were worn with quiffs that gave a 50s flavour and an androgynous edge to the exaggerated womanly shape of the skirts. Androgyny was also in the air at Viktor & Rolf, where bobbed dancers wore buttermilk blazers with frilly shirts and ties - and the designers took to the floor for the final routine.

The problem with androgyny is that too often it boils down to women wearing things that look better on men. Drainpipe trousers, for instance. True, on the catwalk they look striking in contrast to voluminous blouses or 80s shoulder-padded jackets. But this look works only with the pipe cleaner-sized trousers catwalk models can get into: if your drainpipe-clad bottom half looks as wide as your batwing-clad top half, it's a recipe for disaster.

Print is another trend that will take some getting used to, but there were plenty of wearable versions in Paris: florals at Dries van Noten, Chinese-style pagoda prints at Cacharel. Chiffon - especially pleated, as at Valentino - looks likely to be unavoidable, too. Safari styling cropped up at Louis Vuitton and at Celine, where Michael Kors cited as his inspiration "Bowie and Iman take off with Bianca and Beard for the ultimate luxe safari".

Some designers avoided trends by being too outré, or not outré enough. Christian Dior came in the first category with a dizzying deconstructed version of a trailer-park beauty pageant. Galliano's prodigious talent is unarguable and only Jean Paul Gaultier could match his ebullience: his motorcycle leather shoulder shrugs and slashed tunics, with models swigging from beer cans, were Braveheart meets The Wild One.

At the other extreme, Colette Dinnigan would probably faint if faced with a slashed tunic. Her collection featured lashings of sequins, chiffon and lace on truly scrumptious dresses. For sheer beauty, it was pipped to the post only by Emanuel Ungaro, who have long been associated with a particular type of sugar-dusted super-femininity, but are moving on to fresher pastures. Appliqué petals stitched loosely on to fluid crepe dresses looked modern, while trouser suits with ribbon-wide chiffon trim looked phenomenal in neon zebra stripes on Alek Wek. In the real world, they'll sell like hot brioches in palest French manicure pink.

webTitle: She goes to the parties so you don't have to

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst: She goes to the parties so you don't have to
fields.trailText: She goes to the parties so you don't have to
fields.body:
Ahhh, romantic Paris at night. It was raining. Not the kind of grey drizzle you expect in London. This was real rain - fat ploppy drops that send your hair into ringlets and your mascara into dark, intriguing smudges. No cabs, no parapluie. I stood under a doorway watching embracing couples dashing from awning to awning. Occasionally they stopped and kissed. The man sheltering next to me smiled and nodded at the sky. "You need taxi?" I nodded. That was how I found myself skimming across Paris in the back of a cab with a (very) handsome Frenchman. Only turns out he was an Italian living in France. Signor Cornetto with a side dish of Gaul. The Paris fashion week after-show party season was under way. If London is pointless (any excuse for a bash) and Milan relies on a point (any excuse to earn a million or so), the Paris after-show party is pointedly sexual - any chance of a quickie? "I lurrrve you young fashion girrrls who are independent and trrravel all overrr the worrrld."

"Actually, I'm married."

"I lurrrve you marrrried fashion women who are dependent and trrravel only occasionally." Yawn.

First stop, some Brits abroad - four young designers had taken it upon themselves to hire a studio space and exhibit their wares in the heart of Europe's fashland. Eley Kishimoto (print-meisters - love the tights), Jessica Ogden (has a way with embroidery threads and print effects), Mulligan (top collection of asymmetric cuts and corsage details) and J Maskray (queen of stick-on sequins) had all been around at London but felt that exposure in Paris may bring extra international business. The party was low-key, conveniently so considering my dramatic trip at the entrance. Sliding around the exhibits, I found a video screening at the back and settled down to watch J Maskray's London presentation. Now, some people would flinch at an array of skin jewellery displayed on lap dancers. I, on the other hand, joined a group of French buyers who were clearly weaned off breast milk with soft porn. The glittering dragons' heads adhering to the writhing naked bodies were stunning. My pen flew across my notepad. Only after 10 minutes did I realise that, apart from the leech, I was alone in my viewing and the newly assembled crowd were watching me watching the show. Had anyone told them this was an alternative fashion show? I think not. "Oh look, there's an old pervert in the corner with a leery Italian watching a porn vid." Blushed?

Quick exit to wittily named Fur-midable - a cocktail party coutesy of Saga furs. Now, before you start, I don't approve of the use of fur in fashion either - but that shouldn't stop you attending. "Kate Adie doesn't approve of war," I told myself, "but that doesn't stop her going." Opinions suspended, I relinquished my handbag for an offensive weapons check and entered the fur-torn world of Saga. Champagne and hors d'oeuvres jostled for attention with electric blue mink-covered washbasin units and a bathroom mirror trimmed in bleached fox tails. Languorous models pawed at each other with all the "luxury-prop" realism of a Wallpaper magazine interiors shoot. Bad enough that those dear wee minkies have been turned into cuffs, muffs and collars. More terrible still, though, is the fact that their lives had been cut short to become... a tissue box cover or a classic novel binding. Need I say more? The only good thing: the assembled throng took not a blind bit of notice but remained adhered to the buffet table until the nibbles and champagne ran dry.

On to a photography exhibition (of which there are many this week) by... well, d'ya know, I don't remember, since my invite got washed clean by the rain and there wasn't a biog to hand (agent, take note). But it turned out to be yet another excuse to knock back champagne. There were lots of fashion celebs there, though, looking at photos of lots of fashion celebs. For them, in fact, it became a Question of Sport-style game, where you see a bit of someone and you have to guess who it is. "Look, there's me"; "Look, that's my leg next to Juergen Teller." This pastime, I assure you, may well be fun if it might be your leg. Not so great if it assuredly isn't.

For them, in fact, it became a Question of Sport-style game, where you see a bit of someone and you have to guess who it is. "Look, there's me"; "Look, that's my leg next to Juergen Teller." This pastime, I assure you, may well be fun if it might be your leg. Not so great if it assuredly isn't.

fields.headline: Take one Dior bag and a pot of paint
fields.standfirst: It's a mad idea... so now it's a trend!  Deborah Bee  on customising
fields.trailText: It's a mad idea... so now it's a trend! Deborah Bee on customising
fields.body:
The difference between looking fashionable and looking cool is all in the effort. You can wear top-to-toe Yves Saint Laurent till the cows come home but if you look as though you're "trying", you've immediately lost the cool ticket.

A complicated underground fashion trend leapt on to the catwalks in Paris this week. Although it is the polar opposite of "trying", it certainly isn't about "not trying". The "customised" look is rough around the edges (raw hems are everywhere), big on graffiti (see Louis Vuitton's great new bags) and loves a bit of tat in the form of dodgy keyrings and badges (Dior). The uninformed could be forgiven for thinking it is trying... to look absurd. Regardless, the Parisians are touting it as an official look for spring.

On the ultra-cool style scene this is not new. Young stylists and designers in London have been "personalising" for a while now - a snip here, a slash there, a badge or 10 anywhere else. Call it individualism, call it self-expression, call it not having the same stupid designer outfit as the next person - these style gurus are thumbing their noses at logo worship and doing to fashion what the Sex Pistols did to pop.

Trying to track a trend is a dangerous game. No one is ever really sure where mad ideas like this come from, though it could be traced to a backlash against the mid to late 90s American modern thing. As Donna and Calvin and Ralph deluged us with pared-down uniformity, someone, somewhere, must have thought: "I'm truly sick of concealed buttons - let's go down the flea market and get some real clothes."

Maybe it was Susanne Deeken, a young designer who was scooped out of St Martins to work for some of the top fashion houses. Her personal style betrays her love of contradictions: expensive jacket, secondhand jeans. "I go to the flea markets almost every week," she says. "It takes a real effort, but I've been doing it for years and have a 'library' of clothes now."

The trend for customising was born out of the trend for vintage, where alternative sizes, shapes and colours are not an option - if you really want the authentic 70s Saint Laurent top, you have to live with the size and the missing buttons. But wearing vintage is itself a form of customising because taking a modern garment and wearing it with something old sets the new in a different context.

Deeken is all for it. "If you do top-to-toe designer, you end up looking like a Christmas tree. It's more balanced to wear designer things with secondhand stuff or really old jeans. Fashion isn't meant to be so serious. It should be colourful, cheerful, funny."

The more recent spin on customising, though, is "personalising" designer clothes. French-born Camille Bidault-Waddington, a stylist who lives in London and works in Paris for Martine Sitbon, admits: "I take real pleasure in trashing something expensive. I bought one of the Dior saddle bags, took it home and painted it with scarlet acrylic paint." Then she attached cheap plastic keyrings to the handle and stuck badges to the sides.

The best bit, she says, is going back into the shops afterwards: "Just to see the assistants' faces. Personalising things this way shows you have no respect for logos but appreciate good design."

Deeken agrees. "I'd never buy anything with an obvious logo. Prada, Gucci, Louis Vuitton logos say: 'Look, I've spent a lot of money on this.' I don't like the message. It's too corporate, too fashion victim."

Truth is, though, some people are never going to like customising - or get it. "In Paris, I am treated like a funny little chicken because Frenchwomen are so sophisticated," Bidault-Waddington admits. "Customising is very much an English sensibility."

So will she buy into the graffiti prints at Louis Vuitton or Dior's pre-customised look? "Yes, I will buy it - but add my own graffiti, too."

Customising pre-customised clothes sounds like millennium maximalism gone mad - but Bidault-Waddington knows that nothing is more likely to halt the trend than its mass adoption. "If everyone else starts customising, I'll have to stop." She laughs. "Then I'll just have to wear a long black coat."

fields.headline: Across the great divide
fields.standfirst:
As the Middle East peace process teeters on the brink of collapse, Hélène Mulholland analyses how the Jewish and Palestinian communities in Britain view the process - and each other

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: As the Middle East peace process teeters on the brink of collapse, Hélène Mulholland analyses how the Jewish and Palestinian communities in Britain view the process - and each other
fields.body:
For Jewish and Palestinian people settled in Britain, the recent eruptions in the peace process makes for painful armchair viewing. The Jewish community in the UK has decided to tighten security amid fears the Middle East conflict could spread over here. But are their fears well founded?

"By and large, there has not been much feeling against Jews as Jews," says Ghada Kermi, chairman of the Palestinian Community Association of Britain. "The problem is with Israel."

But Simon Plosker, a spokesman for the Board of Deputies of British Jews, says: "Israel is extremely important to the British Jewish community," he says. "At the same time, it does not necessarily mean we have a problem with Palestinians or Arabs, in London or elsewhere."

There are an estimated 10,000 and 20,000 Palestinians living in Britain. Some came in the early 90s, after the Gulf war. Many others have been here since 1948.

Mejad Alzeer, the director of the Palestinian Return Centre in north-west London, which campaigns for the rights of Palestinians to return to their homeland, says that most Palestinians look forward to that day. "To the best of my knowledge, most of them want to go back and want somebody to recognise their right to do so," he said.

At least half of the Palestinian community lives in or around London. The rest are scattered around the country, working in a wide range of professions. "The culture is the same as Arab culture," Kermi explains. "There is nothing specific about it, though it is very informed by the Israeli background, and has much more of a political edge because of it."

Meanwhile, Plosker claims that the situation in the Middle East does not necessarily have a direct bearing on Jewish culture in Britain. "It is an entirely separate deal," he says. But he warns of fundamentalist and extremist groups actively trying to create tension in Britain between the Jewish and Arab communities.

Fewer than 300,000 Jewish people live in Britain, with numbers currently in decline. About 70% of the population of UK Jews are formally linked to a synagogue, but almost one third of that number is religiously unaffiliated. Like Palestinian Britons, they work in a wide range of occupations and can be found in all corners of the country.

One organisation trying to bridge the gap of extremism and hostility on both sides is the Maimonides Foundation, whose objective is to promote understanding, peaceful relations and cultural exchange between Jewish and Muslim groups, including Jews and Palestinians.

Its activities include the Daughters of Abraham forum, where women from both cultures meet to develop understanding, focussing on similarities and shared experience. An inter-faith football club for young people from both sides, assisted by Arsenal FC, is another example. Fun and collaboration to replace tensions and isolation.

Foundation spokesman David Krikler said: "We do make efforts to improve relations between Jews and Palestinians, and we try our best to ensure that the continuing improvements in relations in our community is not held hostage to the peace process. It is something achieved with great difficulty."

webTitle: Oct 13: Diary of a monitored social services department

fields.headline: Friday 13th, oh lucky day!
fields.standfirst: The department gets its league table results
fields.trailText: Another week, another taskforce - and no doubt another action plan. This week we were included in the government's hit list of authorities that have failing adoption services.
fields.body:
Another week, another taskforce - and no doubt another action plan. This week we were included in the government's hit list of authorities that have failing adoption services.

This was fair enough. Our reported figures have been poor and the lack of focus evidenced through external scrutiny. Having had warning of this from the social services chief inspector, Denise Platt, herself, (which was much appreciated) we had time to prepare for the inevitable media onslaught.

Now that has passed, we can put our energies back into implementing our plans for improvement, which have been in place since we carried out a best value review of our fostering and adoption services at the end of last year.

The results will, of course, take some time to show up in our figures. But I think when the taskforce arrives, its members will be able to engage with us as an authority that recognises the need to improve and has started the processes that will lead to far better performance in the future.

Looked forward with dread to Friday 13. No, I am not superstitious. It was the day of publication of the performance assessment figures or league tables, as we are not supposed to call them.

Bought my Guardian and was ecstatic to find no mention of Lambeth at all in the inevitable list of "poor performers". Considering we were acceptable/good or very good on 66% of indicators, this was only fair.

Working for an authority on special measures, I am all in favour of the increasing use of performance information (the "naming and shaming" aspect of it is unhelpful but probably unavoidable in a democratically accountable society). I want to be judged on fact rather than myth and history. We are still poor in much of our performance, but we are making progress in some key areas by focusing on the basics of safe practice and getting the organisation fit for its purposes.

I look forward to being able to answer members, staff and the public clearly when they ask what we have to do to get off special measures. It should be on the basis of evidence of improvement and facts about our comparative performance.

Formal clarification of the measures that are applied to judge authorities would be helpful and would go a long way to cementing a mature relationship between central and local government. Perhaps the performance assessment figures are a step towards this.

 Lisa Christensen is executive director, social services and health improvement, for the London borough of Lambeth

webTitle: Sharon the bull invited into china shop

fields.headline: Sharon the bull invited into china shop
fields.standfirst: If Ariel Sharon joins the Israeli government then war will be a reality, warns former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown
fields.trailText: If Ariel Sharon joins the Israeli government then war will be a reality, warns former Middle East correspondent Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The invitation to Ariel Sharon to join a new coalition government is a reflection of grimmest reality: Israel is on the brink of war, and in wartime the country always has a government of national unity.

Sharon, 72, has no shortage of admirers on the Israeli right, who see him as a hero, and no shortage of detractors, who see him as a dangerous rogue.

Palestinians generally have no such equivocation. They loathe the man. Arabs insist that it was Sharon's visit to the Haram al-Sharif mosque complex in Jerusalem on September 28 which sparked the latest bloodletting.

But their passionate dislike of the Likud leader goes back much, much further.

Nearly half a century ago, Sharon was winning a reputation in the Israeli army - and infamy among the Palestinians - as the young commander of Commando Unit 101, a shady outfit specialising in ruthless hit-and-run raids against suspected Palestinian guerrilla bases.

He served at ever-higher ranks in the 1956 Sinai war against Egypt, and in the six-day war of 1967. He resigned from the army in 1972 to begin an extraordinary political career, in which he has sought advancement in parties of the right, left and centre.

But on the main Israeli political issue, national security, Sharon has always been on the extreme right. In the late 1970s, when he at last gained ministerial office, he campaigned noisily for the occupied West Bank to be colonised by Jewish settlers, and promoted the strange concept, warmly embraced by the right that "Jordan is Palestine". We call it ethnic cleansing now.

In 1981 Sharon got the job he always wanted: minister of defence. He supervised the preparations for the following year's Operation Peace for Galilee, the invasion of south Lebanon which was supposed to protect Israel's northern border.

It was the start of a brutal little war, and an 18-year occupation. But the single act of brutality, still seared into the collective Arab memory, was the massacre of Palestinians in the Sabra and Shatilla refugee camps in Beirut, by the Christian Phalangist militia.

The militia, seeking revenge for the assassination of their leader, president-elect Bashir Gemayel, were allowed into the camps by Israeli army units, ostensibly on the pretext that they were looking for armed guerrillas. Instead, they fired indiscriminately, killing hundreds.

The Israeli left was outraged by the crime, which was apparently committed with their army's complicity. Sharon was only mildly criticised by the official inquiry, but was forced to resign.

In and out of office, Sharon has built a formidable following among those Israelis who believe their country has to use all means to defend itself against the surrounding hordes. His inclusion in government might protect the prime minister, Ehud Barak, from the tide of rightist criticism which threatens to engulf him.

But it will also bring new dangers to the crumbling peace process. Indeed, it is difficult to imagine any Arab leader who would be prepared to negotiate, let alone do a deal, with an administration including Sharon.

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN
fields.body:
THE GUARDIAN

Matt Wells reports on the new drive by broadcasters to increase the number of ethnic minorities both on screen and behind the cameras. Krishnan Guru-Murphy, the Asian presenter of Channel 4 News, gives his views. (p8)

The business pages carry a story about the reinvention of the Burberry brand. With sales up 30% it is, says the paper, fast becoming a textbook example of how to ramp a brand. (p28) The section also covers the closure of Urbanfetch's UK operation, with the loss of 100 jobs. (p28)

THE TIMES

The Times business pages carry a story about Pearson putting the remainder of its newsletters up for sale.(p28)
Doubts have been raised over Vivendi's commitment to British Sky Broadcasting after a company source said Vivendi did not want to continue to be a sleeping partner.(p28)
The Times also reports the closure of Urbanfetch's London and New York offices.(p28)
MEDIA PAGES
Giles Tremlett reports from Spain on how the armed Basque separatist group Eta has now included journalists on its list of targets for assassination.(p20)
Rick Sky says the affair between Peter Salmon, the BBC's head of sport, and actress Sarah Lancashire should not come as a surprise. The "beauty and the boss" phenomenon has, he says, been going on for years, with high profile examples including the marriage of Esther Rantzen and the late Desmond Wilcox.(p20)
There is also a full-page interview with John Ware, the Panorama reporter who named the Omagh suspects, (p21)
And a report by Ray Snoddy on how research has shown that radio advertising provides better value for money than television advertising. (p22)
Other articles look at the new financial spinoff of The Week and Liverpool FC's glossy new newsletter. (p25)

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

The FT reports that Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group is in advanced talks to buy Wave, a commercial radio station covering the Southampton area, for about £21m. (p27)
Other stories covered include the joint venture between Granada Media and Boots to create a digital television channel about health and beauty.(p27)
Channel 4 and BSkyB have formed a consortium with Arena Leisure, the publicly-quoted race course operator, to bid for the media rights to UK horseracing.(p38)
And the government has given the nod to BSkyB's takeover of British Interactive Broadcasting, which operates the interactive TV service, Open.(p28)
On the foreign pages, Vivendi is in last-minute talks with the European Commission to try to stave off a four-month antitrust inquiry into its proposed merger with Canal Plus and Seagram.(p36)
And the New York Times has dropped plans for an internet tracking stock because of difficult market condition.(p36)
The FT's marketing section is devoted to the fact that public health officials are waking up to advertising as a powerful tool in the battle to stop people from smoking.(p17)

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

The Telegraph carries a news item about a new Trading Standards Institute report that claims shopping on the internet is too expensive, too troublesome and too slow. According to the report, more than a third of internet shoppers experienced late deliveries, wrong orders and companies that disappeared with their money.(p15)
The Business section reports that pre-tax profits at Guardian Media, publishers of the Guardian newspaper, rose from £68.2m to 73.5m last year. (p35)
And Barclaycard, Britain's biggest credit card company, is planning a virtual shopping arcade on the internet for its 8m customers. (p34)

THE INDEPENDENT

The Indie writes that Marks & Spencer is following up its racy new ad campaign with a deal to sponsor a troupe of male strippers. In the latest and somewhat desperate attempt to boost flagging sales, M&S is in talks with The Dreamboys about backing a 30-day stripping tour across the UK.(p13)
In the business section, the paper reports that BSkyB has entered the battle for UK horse racing media rights by teaming up with Arena Leisure to stop rival Carlton Communications from gaining control.(p21)

THE SUN

The Sun carries an exclusive interview with actress Sarah Lancashire's dad, in which he springs to his daughter's defence following the revelation that she is having an affair with the BBC's married head of sport, Peter Salmon.(p14)
And the paper reports that England's dismal performance against Finland on Wednesday night was a massive telly flop, with just 3.4m viewers tuning in to BBC1's highlights. (p20)

THE MIRROR

The Mirror has a "showbiz exclusive" with the story that Mel C is being treated for depression. (p1)
A report on Michael Buerk's dummy run for the BBC's new Ten O'Clock News programme. And the BBC has clinched a deal to screen the snooker world championships until 2006. (p21)

DAILY MAIL

The Mail has bought the Guardian's G2 cover piece yesterday, canonising Judy Finnigan. (p32)

DAILY EXPRESS

The Express reports that actress Sarah Lancashire is "devastated" that her affair with Peter Salmon is out in the open. The actress is reported to be an "intensely private person". (p32)

And Finally

THE DAILY STAR features Wonderbra model Adriana Sklenarikova wearing the new "variable cleavage" Wonderbra, which allows the wearer to choose the depth and plunge of her cleavage by pulling two drawstrings, under the inevitable headline "Adriana's pulled". Ms Sklenarikova was promoting a new poster campaign, which carries the tagline (wait for it) "I pull the strings". (p1)
And the Star reports the fascinating statistic that drinkers watching football on the TV spill 20,000 pints of beer on carpets in homes and pubs every time there's a goal. (p5)

fields.headline: In brief: Catfish and Mandala by Andrew X Pham
fields.standfirst: Post your reviews and comments
fields.trailText: Every now and then a book comes along that defies categorisation. Catfish and Mandala is one of them, and - in UK newspapers at least - Pham was punished by being consigned to the travel round-up.
fields.body:
Every now and then a book comes along that defies categorisation. Catfish and Mandala is one of them, and - in UK newspapers at least - Pham was punished by being consigned to the travel round-up.

In fact, as every round-upper pointed out, this is far more than a bike-across-the Pacific-Rim-and-find-yourself book (though, in the course of it, Pham does just that). Peter Hughes in the Times described it as Jack Kerouac meets Wild Swans . Pham shares with Kerouac a belief that the road may hold answers - in Pham's case, his journey takes him back to the Vietnam his family escaped as boat people when he was 10 years old. "America fished us out of the ocean like downing cockroaches and fed us and clothed us," he writes. But if America saved the Phams in body, it left them flailing in soul, and here is where the Wild Swans comparison comes in. Only by going back, by staring in the face what happened to his family and their country, can Andrew Pham begin to understand what he now is, and what his transsexual sister, Chi, used to be, before she was driven to suicide.

The exquisite sense of mission, the pressure to understand through reliving, creates a writing style that, according to Lucy Gillmore of the Independent on Sunday, makes you "want to stick your tongue out and lick every last morsel of the page". Some of the prose proved a little too purple for Anthony Sattin in the Sunday Times, who nonetheless conceded that Pham had the outsider's gift of clear sight and had caught the mood and exposed the dilemmas of an emerging country.

The Times's Hughes saw it not as a book about Vietnam, but a fine addition to the growing American literature of the Vietnam war. The New Yorker, though, saw no need to classify it at all. "In his passionate telling, his travelogue acquires the universality of a bildungsroman."

But the most touching tributes are on amazon.com - many from other Vietnamese Americans, and one from a Vietnam vet. He'd often wondered, he said, how the "exfiltrated" Vietnamese had fared and what had happened to the ones who got left behind. Now, finally, he knew.

webTitle: Three more questioned over carnival murder

fields.headline: Three more questioned over carnival murder
fields.trailText: Three more people have been questioned in connection with the murder of a man at this year's Notting Hill Carnival, police said today.
fields.body:
Three more people have been questioned in connection with the murder of a man at this year's Notting Hill Carnival, police said today.

The men, in their late teens and early 20s, were arrested by police investigating the death of salesman Abdul Bhatti, a 28-year-old graduate from Hounslow, west London.

Scotland Yard said the three had been bailed to return to a police station at a future date.

Two teenagers who were arrested at the end of September are due to answer police bail in November.

Bhatti was beaten and kicked to death while attending the carnival with friends on August 28.

fields.headline: The House of Mirth
fields.standfirst: Gillian Anderson is Oscar-worthy in Terence Davies's brilliant adaptation of Edith Wharton, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This outstanding film shows how masterly is Davies's visual sense and what a light, adroit touch he has turned out to have with "period" furniture and detail
fields.body:
Terence Davies has characterised The House of Mirth by Edith Wharton as Jane Austen with the gloves off. That isn't quite true - Jane Austen is Jane Austen with the gloves off - but Davies has brought an unexpected intensity, a genuine passion, to his adaptation of Wharton's novel of love, cruelty and guile in America's high society of the early 20th century.

The story of Lily Bart (Gillian Anderson), the beautiful society princess who miscalculates in her search for an advantageous match, becomes a Rake's Progress of social shame.

The heroine heads into the unthinkable abyss of poverty with each calamitous romantic manoeuvre among the drawing-room Machiavels and country-house Clausewitzes - and Davies compels you to watch, horrified and fascinated, as Lily arrives at her self-willed, tragic fate.

This outstanding film shows how masterly is Davies's visual sense and what a light, adroit touch he has turned out to have with "period" furniture and detail. It is a revelation to see how he has transformed the novelistic conventions of place and character with such tact, and the kind of sobriety and discretion that allows the cast to give vivid, attractive performances. What a refreshing experience that is after the mess Martin Scorsese managed to make of Wharton's The Age of Innocence, obtusely fetishising the mahogany and bone china and unconvincingly affecting to find eroticism in Daniel Day-Lewis pantingly unbuttoning Michelle Pfeiffer's glove. Davies's film wears its history lightly.

In particular, Gillian Anderson is a revelation. Many was the jeer and jest that this casting had provoked here and there, I am sorry to say, with some wondering aloud if David Duchovny is to be cast in future as the lead in a biopic of Lord David Cecil.

But Anderson is excellent. Her jolie-laide face is capable of conveying an acutely calibrated, technically accomplished range including mischief, erotic rapture, despair, self-loathing. Sometimes she is sleek and pert, sometimes ill and puffy and bathed with cold sweat. Davies and his cinematographer, Remi Adefarasin, often have her face right in front of shot for what seems like minutes at a time and it is a challenge that she meets triumphantly as a screen actor. This is the kind of role that might have gone to Glenn Close 10 or 20 years ago, but I wonder if Close would have carried it off with this much style. In particular: her appearance in a tableau - Summer by Watteau - is despatched with aplomb. This is an Oscar-credible performance.

The same, or almost the same, goes for Lily's suitors, Dan Aykroyd and Anthony LaPaglia: respectively, Gus Treynor, the married man whose attentions are the beginning of Lily's downfall, and Sim Rosedale, the wealthy bachelor whose offer of marriage Lily first spurns, and then, in dire financial straits, humiliatingly wishes to accept. These are big, rangy, well-fed actors who look their age. But both Aykroyd and LaPaglia have an appropriately leonine presence, conveying genial and cynical exuberance which thrillingly turns ugly when the subject of their own wealth and status is at issue. In some ways their gamey, rackety performances are more successful than the primped and upright Eric Stoltz as Lawrence Selden, Lily's one true friend.

Money is always the raw and unavoidable fact of this movie: money promised, money withheld, money deployed and money displayed. And although it is not precisely true that Wharton is more frank than Henry James on the question of money - it will be interesting to compare The House of Mirth with the forthcoming Merchant Ivory account of The Golden Bowl - she and Davies are certainly more candid about the catastrophic effects of its sudden removal.

The gravitational pull of poverty and social shame is what guides this movie's narrative, skilfully formed by Davies, particularly in the pleasing transposition from the chill of the American eastern seaboard to the sunlit fleshpots of the Mediterranean where Lily's treacherous circle of friends have arrived in a yacht. There, Lily is to be seen lounging on deck with the brilliant blue water rippling behind her, evidently shot on a sound stage with a back-projection. A pleasingly Hitchcockian moment of camp.

How extraordinary that this is Terence Davies's first film in six years, and only his fifth in a career of 25 years. His signature visual touches are all there: the languorous, unhurried takes on the still-life interiors. But this has been opened out into a substantial, well-upholstered picture with more sinew and power than almost any other period drama of recent times. It gripped me like a thriller throughout: a brilliant new film from a great British director.

webTitle: Republican shot dead in west Belfast

fields.headline: Republican shot dead in west Belfast
fields.trailText: A man was today shot dead in a gun attack in a republican area of west Belfast.
fields.body:
A man was today shot dead in a gun attack in a republican area of west Belfast.

He was killed as he sat in a parked car in Whitecliff Parade in the Ballymurphy area.

Police said he was sitting in the front passenger seat of the white Peugeot when two hooded men approached on foot and shot him at close range.

The driver was uninjured, police said.

RUC officers sealed off the area. A spokesman said detectives had not yet established a motive.

The victim is believed to have connections with a dissident republican group. He had just left his mother's house in Whitecliff Parade and got into the passenger seat of the car when the gunmen approached and shot him several times in the head at point blank range.

fields.headline: ITV weighs in with Fat Friends
fields.trailText: 2pm overnights: The ITV 9pm hit drama factory cranked into action again last night, with the Kay Mellor-scripted series Fat Friends enjoying a successful first outing. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The ITV 9pm hit drama factory cranked into action again last night, with the Kay Mellor-scripted series Fat Friends enjoying a successful first outing.

Fat Friends, which boasts a strong ensemble cast including Alison Steadman and Josie Lawrence - and last night an appearance by Countdown legend Richard Whiteley playing himself - averaged 9.7m and a 41% share from 9-10pm.

On BBC1 from 9.30pm, Lenny Henry school drama Hope & Glory managed just 4.2m/19%. For the second week running, the show suffered the indignity of being less popular than factual fare running at the same time on supposedly minority interest channel BBC2.

This week the BBC2 culprit was a new run of the science strand, Horizon, which opened at 9.30pm with a crowd-pleasing look at mega-tsunami tidal waves (4.6m/21%).

Earlier in the evening, ITV paid BBC1 medical drama Holby City the back-handed compliment of scheduling a Coronation Street special and Who Wants to be a Millionaire? against it from 8pm, with predictable results.

Holby City (5.3m/22%) got a good going over from the two ratings bruisers, with Coronation Street (13.1m/56%) handing the cosh over to Millionaire (11.9m/50%) at 8.30pm.

Last week Holby City's series opener - which faced a 60-minute Millionaire - had already posted the show's lowest ever rating, a 7.2m/31% share.

The critics' choice, US hood opera the Sopranos, returned for a second UK airing on Channel 4 at 10.30pm with a very respectable 1.4m/11%. It was followed at 11.30pm by the 11 O'Clock Show (0.6m/10%).

From 9pm last night Channel 5 boosted its ratings with the film Batman and Robin (2.1m/11%), G String Divas (1.2m/15%, 11.20-11.55pm) and 100% Sex (0.5m/11%, 11.55-12.25pm).

At 10pm, that rare beast - a peak time ITV documentary series - was sighted, with Dynasties (4.6m/27%) opening with a look at the Getty family.

Overall, ITV recorded its third night on the trot with a peak time share over 40%.

fields.headline: Bannister told staff of plans to overhaul department earlier this week
fields.standfirst:
Bannister quits BBC
Special report: The BBC
Dyke statement on Bannister
Matthew Bannister: the wrong man in the wrong job?
fields.trailText: 1.30pm update: Matthew Bannister told staff of plans to overhaul the department only days before today's surprise resignation, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Matthew Bannister, who has today resigned as the BBC's marketing chief, circulated a memo among PR and marketing staff only this week, outlining his strategy for the overhaul of the department.

In the memo, Mr Bannister is understood to have said he plans to "strengthen" the BBC's core press office, beefing up the corporation's central "reactive" press office and scaling down resources in the genre-based press departments.

The memo is thought to have detailed plans to develop specialist marketing teams for programme and channel publicity, focusing more on channels and types of viewers and less on genres and departments.

Speaking to MediaGuardian.co.uk, Mr Bannister declined to comment on the contents of the memo. But he indicated that he was keen to emphasise the distinction between the "reaction" function of a core press office and marketing for programmes.

"There are two parts to the [press and publicity] operation," he said. "There's the day-to-day business of publicising our programmes. Then there's the high-profile stuff that comes along and we have to respond to, such as this week's Panorama on the Omagh bombing."

Mr Bannister added that he hoped to have in place a strategy for the BBC's marketing and publicity services over the next 18 months by the time he leaves at the end of the year. The BBC is expected to make an announcement in the next three to four weeks.

Meanwhile, as the BBC begins to search for his replacement, Richard Peel, currently the ITC's director of public affairs and regions and a former long-serving BBC spokesman, has been linked as a potential successor.

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week nine
fields.standfirst: Betting site Blue Square gave three Football Unlimited writers £100 each to bet with. Here are the latest desperate punts
fields.trailText: Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £120.87, Sean Ingle = £101.77, Football Unlimited punters collective = £73.15, Paul MacInnes = £70.00
fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties): Scott Murray = £120.87, Sean Ingle = £101.77, Football Unlimited punters collective = £73.15, Paul MacInnes = £70.00

Scott Murray

Arsenal v Aston Villa: Villa to win £5 @ 5/1

OK, so Arsenal are a better side than Villa. And they've won every game played so far this season at Highbury. But don't forget: they've rode their luck at home on a couple of occasions, and that's against so-called lesser opposition like Charlton and Shakhtar as well.

This is also the first season Arsene Wenger's men look like making a serious fist of their European Cup campaign, and with an important trip to Lazio coming up only three days later, you could forgive them for easing up in the Premiership.

Villa, meanwhile, are on no mean roll themselves - so surely fives is too good a price to turn down.

Sean Ingle

£2 Trixie (three doubles and one accumulator = £8 in total) on Sunderland v Chelsea: number of goals 0 or 1 @ 13/5; Leicester v Manchester United; number of goals 0 or 1 @ 14/5; Southampton to beat Everton @ 3/1

After Deng Xiaoping replaced Mao Zedong as supreme Chinese leader he instituted a policy called 'Socialism with Chinese characteristics', transforming China from a backward, beat-up country into the economic powerhouse we see today. Like Deng, I am hoping that by tweaking the master's formula - in my case Blue Square's Patrick Murray - my bank balance, like China's GNP, will soar.
