fields.headline: Boo's back
fields.standfirst: Fashionmall.com is relaunching Boo.com as a style portal in the hope that a clever commercial makeover will ensure its success this time round.
fields.trailText: Dotcom failures have been rife of late, but one company is bucking the trend by relaunching one - the infamous Boo.com, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
First Boxman, now Urbanfetch - dot.com failures have been coming in thick and fast of late. But one company is bucking the trend by taking the rather unusual step of reopening rather than shutting down a failed dot.com. Fashionmall.com, a Nasdaq-listed online fashion retailer and a company that is surely old and wise enough to know better, is to relaunch Boo.com.

The brand name that has become almost a byword for failure in the dot.com industry is to relaunch at the end of this month with the tagline, "Boo.com - because style never dies".

Fashionmall.com will next week launch a guerrilla marketing campaign that it describes as "very accepting of both the good and the bad in what we have bought". And of course the one good thing about guerrilla marketing is that it's cheap. Given that the online retailer is famous for having spent a whopping $44m worldwide on marketing the first time round, that's probably a good thing. Boo's extravagant marketing budget was seen as one of the many reasons for its eventual collapse.

This time round, financial caution seems to be the order of the day. Fashionmall plans eventually to have a small European office, but for now the new operation will be run by a 10-strong team in the US compared with the hundreds who worked for the old company.

And the new Boo will not suffer from the technical problems that dogged its more ambitious predecessor because all that Fashionmall bought was the brand name. The relaunched Boo will not be an e-commerce site selling goods of its own, but rather a style portal that will tell users what's trendy and what's not and refer them to the trendiest products and sites on the net.

"The new Boo will basically be an editor for the best of the internet," says Kate Buggeln, president of Boo.com. "We will find the best products that different stores have to offer and provide that information to users." They will also use a team of so-called "style scouts" to contribute obscure fashion finds from around the world.

Examples of this include Skin, a new range of clothing customised to carry the wearer's e-mail address. The company is also developing private label merchandise and has deals in place with a variety of partners including the style magazine, Dazed & Confused, and US publication Fashionwear Daily.

But if it's all going to be so different, why call it Boo.com? "Wherever I go I am asked why we are reviving a tarnished brand," says Ms Buggeln. "And the answer is that people are interested. Everyone's heard of Boo.com and everyone wants to know about us."

fields.headline: Matthew Bannister: the wrong man in the wrong job?
fields.standfirst:
Matthew Bannister's appointment as BBC marketing chief was always regarded as an odd choice. So today's resignation will come as little surprise.
Bannister quits BBC
Outgoing Bannister outlines his strategic plans
Special report: The BBC
Dyke statement on Bannister
fields.trailText: Matthew Bannister's appointment as BBC marketing chief was always regarded as an odd choice. So today's resignation will come as little surprise, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Matthew Bannister's move to become BBC director of marketing was always viewed by insiders as a slightly odd, but at the same time a very BBC kind of appointment, and his sudden departure will come as no surprise to many.

Odd because Mr Bannister's background was in broadcasting, not marketing. Yet also very BBC because the corporation has a long history of putting people regarded as good managers and loyal servants into positions for which they have apparently little relevant experience.

There have certainly been mutterings from within the ranks of the BBC's marketers about this BBC suit being parachuted in over their heads, to run the newly formed marketing and communications "petal" in the corporate structure announced by Greg Dyke in April.

The BBC's marketing operation was swelled considerably during the later years of Sir John Birt's reign as the corporation went out into the commercial world and hired some of the brightest and best around.

Former BBC Broadcast marketing head Sue Farr left shortly afterwards. Maureen Duffy, brought in from the commercial sector to raise BBC1's marketing game, went to run ITV daytime. Meanwhile, Jane Frost, who was Birt's corporate marketing chief and regarded as the architect of the BBC's award-winning Perfect Day promo, was believed to be less than impressed with Mr Bannister's appointment but decided to stick it out.

Mr Bannister himself is said to have been reluctant to take the job, but was persuaded to do it by Greg Dyke, with whom he reportedly got on very well. He is understood to have been considering leaving the BBC altogether, after failing to get the director general's job himself last summer, and move into talent management. It is thought that after having a complete break, he may still go in this direction.

He was regarded as one of the Birtists - the group of BBC execs who helped implement the former director general's management consultancy-inspired cost-cutting regime in the 1990s. He first made his name by relaunching Radio London as the hip and trendy GLR, before moving on to oversee the creation of the crucial Birtist tract, Extending Choice, in the early 1990s.

In 1993 Bannister was rewarded for his efforts with the controllership of Radio 1. He famously threw out the station's Smashy and Nicey image, bidding farewell to the likes of Simon Bates, Dave Lee Travis and several million listeners in the process, and introduced a more cutting edge indie/dance playlist just as the mid-1990s Britpop scene took off.

But perhaps his most famous Radio 1 coup was signing Chris Evans to present the breakfast show - a moment caught for posterity courtesy of a supposedly clandestine "secret meeting" between the two, an event actually staged for the benefit of a News of the World cameraman.

In 1996 Mr Bannister moved further up the BBC corporate ladder, taking over as director of radio in the Birt restructuring that split broadcasting and production. At the beginning of last year he was promoted again, to chief executive of BBC Production. Six months later he made the shortlist to replace Birt as director general, but lost out to Dyke.

fields.standfirst:

Matthew Bannister: the wrong man in the wrong job?

fields.trailText: Statement from Greg Dyke, director general of the BBC, on Matthew Bannister's departure
fields.body:
Statement from Greg Dyke, director general of the BBC, on Matthew Bannister's decision to leave the BBC:

"I'm sorry to announce that Matthew Bannister has decided to leave the BBC. He will be stepping down as director of marketing & communications at the end of the year to pursue opportunities outside the Corporation.

"Matthew has been a great colleague in the short time we've been working together and the ideas he has contributed to the One BBC restructuring and the future direction of the organisation have been stimulating and productive.

"I'm very sorry he is leaving but he has decided it's time for a change in the direction of his career.

"He's done some of the most interesting jobs around, and BBC Radio's current success is in no short measure down to the work he did, firstly - and famously - as the Controller of Radio 1 and subsequently as Director of Radio.

"We wish him success in the future."

fields.headline: Insurers face £2bn payout after floods
fields.trailText: Insurers were today facing a multi-billion-pound payout as the worst floods to hit south-east England for decades finally began to recede.
fields.body:
Insurers were today facing a multi-billion-pound payout as the worst floods to hit south-east England for decades finally began to recede.

Dozens of homes and businesses across the region have been left devastated - and insurers fear the floods may turn out to be the UK's costliest natural disaster.

Jeffrey Salmon, managing director of Salmon Assessors, said it was likely to cost insurers more than £2bn, more than double the cost of the hurricane that hit the same region in 1987.

The flooding in Kent and East Sussex led to hundreds of people being evacuated from their homes and dozens of rescues by emergency services.

Daybreak brought a glimmer of hope this morning for thousands of people whose homes and businesses were inundated. After a dry night, rivers which yesterday overflowed were beginning to recede.

The lower levels of the ancient castle town of Lewes, East Sussex, still resembled a huge lake, but the watermark on buildings showed that the floodwaters had fallen by at least 18ins.

People in Maidstone, Tonbridge and Yalding and were still on alert as high tides were due this afternoon on rivers in the area.

The Environment Agency said the south-east of England had two and a half times the normal monthly rainfall for October falling by yesterday evening.

Kent fire brigade said it received more than 390 calls for help during the last 24 hours.

Up to 200 soldiers are on standby to assist the emergency services in the event of further flooding.

Firefighters today rescued a married couple and their 73-year-old neighbour after a river flooded their homes. Crews used a lifeboat to get to the homes in Yalding, Kent, after the River Belt burst its banks and flooded properties with up to 4ft of water.

A Kent fire service spokesman said some people had refused to leave their homes and had barricaded themselves in, and were now becoming trapped by the rising water levels.

Angela Shave and her husband Stephen, both 45, were rescued this morning in the centre of Yalding. The couple then returned with firefighters and paramedics to save their neighbour, Cecil Robins.

Mrs Shave said: "The water started coming in at 3am, first in the kitchen and then in the lounge. We moved what we could upstairs, but then the water started rising up the stairs. We were trapped upstairs with the water level still rising. We were going to try to wade out for help, but we were terrified we would be swept away.

"There is about 4ft of water on the ground floor and the sofa is floating around my front room The emergency services said we might be able to get back to our home on Monday."

fields.trailText: 10.15am update: Matthew Bannister, the BBC's director of marketing, has unexpectedly resigned from the corporation, writes Janine Gibson.
fields.body:
Matthew Bannister, the BBC's director of marketing, has unexpectedly resigned from the corporation this morning, the BBC has confirmed.

Neither the BBC nor Mr Bannister will comment at this stage on why he is leaving now. He has not revealed a new job and is said by friends and colleagues to be planning to take a break to decide what to do next.

A BBC spokeswoman said that headhunters would be appointed to find a replacement to fill the post of director of marketing after Mr Bannister leaves at the end of the year.

Mr Bannister, whose career in the BBC has taken in high-profile jobs including controller of Radio 1, director of radio and chief executive of BBC production, has held the job since Greg Dyke's last senior management shake-up in April.

His appointment to the marketing brief was made controversial by the swift departure of the BBC's senior marketeer, Sue Farr.

One of the several unsuccessful internal candidates to replace John Birt as director-general of the BBC, he was seen by many inside the corporation as his anointed successor.

Sources this morning said that Mr Bannister had resigned with no job to go to. One colleague said: "He is in the process of deciding what he wants to do with his life."

Mr Bannister and Mr Dyke informed staff of his departure this morning. Mr Bannister said: "I first joined the BBC 22 years ago and I've decided now is a good time to move my career in a different direction."

webTitle: New FTSE index will focus on hi-tech shares

fields.headline: New FTSE index will focus on hi-tech shares
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Net news
fields.trailText: A new stock market index containing the fashionable technology, media and telecommunications shares is to be launched next week by FTSE International, the company which runs the FTSE 100 index.
fields.body:
A new stock market index containing the fashionable technology, media and telecommunications shares is to be launched next week by FTSE International, the company which runs the FTSE 100 index.

The new index, which will be known as FTSE TMT, is to be constructed in such a way that leading telecoms shares such as Vodafone will not be able to dominate it in the same way that they can influence the main FTSE 100 index. Vodafone has accounted for as much as 12% of the FTSE 100.

Mark Makepeace, managing director of FTSE International, said the index had been designed to make it easier for unit trusts and other investment products to be launched against it.

It is expected that 36 stocks will be contained in the index when it is calculated for the first time on Monday. Unlike other indices, which always contain the same number of stocks, the TMT will contain as many as fit the classification of technology, media or telecoms within the FTSE 350 index.

They will also need to be traded via SETS, the London Stock Exchange's main trading platform for the largest shares.

The dominance of any single stock will be limited by a system under which the largest 10 stocks will each be given a 4% weighing in the index, the next 10 a 3%, and the rest a 2% weighting.

The first products set up to make it easier for investors to get exposure to the TMT sector will be the so-called iShares launched by Barclays.

fields.trailText: Gao Xingjian, a veteran exiled Chinese dissident novelist and playwright whose work has so far been chiefly known to specialists, said "It's a miracle" yesterday when told he had won the £615,000 Nobel prize for literature.
fields.body:
Gao Xingjian, a veteran exiled Chinese dissident novelist and playwright whose work has so far been chiefly known to specialists, said "It's a miracle" yesterday when told he had won the £615,000 Nobel prize for literature.

The news prompted almost equal surprise in much of the world and in Britain. A Leeds professor of Chinese studies said: "There are half a dozen British dramatists who have a stronger claim". But a London scholar said: "He is a worthy choice."

He beat a field of candidates said in pre-prize speculation to include William Trevor, Salman Rushdie, VS Naipaul, Mario Vargas Llosa, JM Coetzee, Margaret Atwood, Ben Okri, Philip Roth and Norman Mailer.

Though Gao is classed as an unperson in China, which did not react officially yesterday, the award was forecast to cause widespread private joy there as the literary equivalent of the country winning the World Cup.

But it also highlighted earlier feminist attacks on him for misogyny in his work, his interest in Chinese peasants' bottoms, and his obsessive theme of lust.

His acquaintance for 20 years, the Australian critic Linda Jaivin, wrote in a review of Soul Mountain, the novel the Nobel judges praised most: "When Gao meets an 'ugly' woman of middle age, he can barely disguise his contempt. The women he encounters are of interest to him only so far as they are nubile."

However, the judges' citation in Stockholm called it "a great novel, one of those singular literary creations that seem impossible to compare with anything but themselves".

They gave him the prize "for an oeuvre of universal validity, bitter insights and linguistic ingenuity".

Horace Engdahl, the Swedish Academy's permanent secretary, told journalists: "I think it is safe to say that Soul Mountain is one of the most remarkable creations of modern literature".

During the Chinese cultural revolution of the 1960s, Gao, now 60, had to burn manuscripts and was sent to a re-education camp. In the 1980s he was allowed to publish and have plays performed widely.

But in 1983, hearing he would be sent to a prison farm, he fled Beijing and spent 10 months wandering over 15,000 kilometres in Sichuan. Soul Mountain is based on this. In 1987 he left China. He currently supports himself mostly by painting in a working class Paris suburb.

Yesterday he said: "I'm very, very surprised. It is a great honour and a sign of recognition for my work. It is really something, especially for a Chinese man, because the Nobel is a very heated issue in China. If I have chosen to live in exile, it is to be able to express myself freely without constraints."

Gao's novels and plays have been praised in France and Australia but are little known in Britain.

Michael Hockx, lecturer in modern Chinese literature at the London School of Oriental and African Studies, said: "He has been known to specialists at least since the 1980s.

"He is extremely influential as an experimental theatre writer. He caused something of a revolution in Chinese drama - mixing the western influences of Brecht and the theatre of the absurd with conventional Chinese practices.

"I would agree with the award. He is a worthy choice. He is writing in rich directions".

But Bill Jenner, head of Chinese studies at Leeds University, said: "It is an extraordinary choice. Very few people in China will have heard his name before the announcement.

"He made a bit of a name about 15 years ago for very sub-Beckett kind of stuff. He was a leading name of a short-lived literary flowering, copying western experimental theatre.

"I wouldn't have thought anyone would have thought him a runner for the Nobel prize. He's a perfectly good writer - but, if you're looking for someone special, half a dozen British dramatists spring to mind as having a stronger claim."

 Collected works

Bus Stop A play in the style of Samuel Beckett in which the cast waits for a bus which never comes. Variously described as a brilliant satire on Chinese inefficiency and "a poor undergraduate copy of Waiting for Godot". Carla Kirkwood, a Californian professor who has directed it on stage, said: "The issues of procrastination and lack of self-initiative are universal".

Soul Mountain His first novel, about his flight from Beijing in 1983 after being warned he was to be sent to a prison farm, and his 10 months of wanderings in Sichuan. Described by professor Mabel Lee, of Sydney University, as "the story of one man's quest for inner peace and freedom".

One Man's Bible, his second novel. The Nobel citation says: "The core of the book involves settling the score with the terrifying insanity usually referred to as China's cultural revolution".

Preliminary Exploration into the Techniques of Modern Fiction Prose work said to have caused intense debate in China by challenging the social realism that was the hallmark of literature and art under Mao.
Globe-trawling Academy baffle again

webTitle: Chips are down for EU expansion at casino summit

fields.headline: Chips are down for EU expansion at casino summit
fields.trailText: European Union leaders flew into Biarritz last night to get down to the nitty-gritty of trying to reform their club before new members join in the coming years.
fields.body:
European Union leaders flew into Biarritz last night to get down to the nitty-gritty of trying to reform their club before new members join in the coming years.

Two days in the fashionable French Pyrenees coastal resort of Biarritz will do much to determine the future shape of a body whose institutions will seize up unless they change.

Despite distractions over the Middle East crisis and the future of Yugoslavia, Tony Blair and his fellow summiteers are expected finally to put their cards on the table - appropriately enough, in the city's belle époque casino.

What happens here will have a big impact on the Treaty of Nice, the document due to crown France's term holding the EU presidency in early December, just seven weeks away.

"If you're looking at the new treaty, Biarritz is the meeting that tells what the market can and can't bear," said one key official.

Tough issues are on the agenda, including the extent to which majority voting prevails in EU decisions, the relative weight of the 15 member states, the size of the European Commission and the possibility of formalising a "two-speed Europe" in which states that want faster integration go ahead themselves on that basis.

Leaders are also likely to adopt the draft EU charter of fundamental rights.

No formal decisions will be taken, but by tomorrow night, the endgame that will lead to the EU's most important treaty since Maastricht launched the euro in 1992 will have begun.

The summit opens, however, with many gaps unbridged, despite months of talks.

Reform is urgently needed to prevent the decision-making structures - created in 1957 for the six original members of what was the European Economic Community - breaking down when the EU expands to 25 or more. Poland and Hungary are leading the field for entry by the middle of the decade, but Romania, Bulgaria, Malta and Lithuania are all queueing up too.

France's president, Jacques Chirac, set the pace last summer when he called for a "pioneer group" of integrationist-minded countries that could forge ahead without being held back by laggards.

Britain's nightmare is that this could mean a formal role for the 12 members of euroland, marginalising EU finance ministers and paving the way for economic integration that would leave Britain in the slow lane.

Denmark's rejection of the single currency last month, and the knock-on effects in Sweden and Britain, mean that this is now a long-term problem.

Speaking in Warsaw last week, Tony Blair signalled that he was prepared to countenance two speeds, but not two tiers, implying concessions on the final treaty terms.

British officials say Mr Blair will resist pressure to surrender the national veto in key areas such as taxation and defence. He can count on the support of like-minded countries, including Sweden, Ireland and Luxembourg.

Contrary to claims by eurosceptics, Britain does not stand alone on any single EU issue of importance.

The EU's big four - Germany, France, Italy, Britain - are united over two sets of crucially linked issues. All are prepared to sacrifice one of their two commissioners in Brussels in exchange for a reweighting of votes in the council of ministers, where EU governments cooperate.

In recent years the big guys have lost out to the little players - so there is now a real problem of democratic legitimacy with the 400,000 people of Luxembourg having two votes as against 10 for 85m Germans.

Germany seems to have accepted that the parity among the big four should not change, but Spain is pressing hard for recognition as a medium-sized member. The tradeoffs and alliances of the coming weeks will be decided in Biarritz.

Smaller countries have been irritated by attempts by the bigger ones to set a limit of 20 commissioners, an issue that seems likely to be settled by staying with one per country and creating deputy commissioners.

Mr Blair is ahead of the curve in calling for increased cooperation among member states - the main theme of his Warsaw speech - while paying lip service to the importance of the commission as the guardian of the treaties and the vast single market.

Romano Prodi, the commission's beleaguered president, is in danger of looking even more marginal than usual.

fields.trailText: "I love you Portia," sighed the utterly perfect Ned Maddstone. "I love you, too," swooned the equally utterly perfect Portia. "Yuk," chorused the envious Ashley, Rufus and Gordon
fields.body:
"I love you Portia," sighed the utterly perfect Ned Maddstone. "I love you, too," swooned the equally utterly perfect Portia. "Yuk," chorused the envious Ashley, Rufus and Gordon.

"Please deliver this letter, Maddstone," gasped Paddy Leclare, on an outward bound trip, before dying of cancer.

"I've missed you awfully, Portia," gulped Ned. "I've missed you, too," moued Portia.

"Yuk-ee," sniggered Ashley, Rufus and Gordon. "Let's fuck things up for Ned by getting him busted."

"All right sonny, you're nicked."

"G-gosh," stammered Ned. "I d-don't know how it got there."

Oliver Delft from MI6 barged into the station. "Maddstone," he barked. "Where did you get this IRA communique?"

"I was given it by one of my beaks before he died," Ned squealed. "I was to give it to a Mr Phillip R Blackrow."
Delft blanched.

Later he pressed a bell marked "Phillippa Blackrow".

"Mummy," he shouted. "Just because you're an Irish terrorist, I've had to torture an innocent lad and send him to a top secret mental hospital on a Swedish island."

"Who are you?" said the evil Dr Mallo, six years later.

"I'm Tom," replied Ned.

"I'm not really," whispered Ned to another inmate, Babe, two years later.

"I know," said Babe. "I'm going to teach you 12 languages, make you chess grandmaster and very, very brainy."

"Thanks," replied Ned in an obscure Lapp dialect six years later.

"I'm dying," said Babe. "Escape in my coffin, with this spoon and chewing gum. Go to Geneva and use my bank account."

Ned gasped. "Wow, £324m. That's a lot. Time for revenge. But first I'm going to become Simon Cotter, the world's most famous internet entrepreneur."

"I'm not Cotter after all," said Ned to Rufus. "And you're about to be killed by some Turkish drug dealers."

"I'm not Cotter after all," said Ned to Ashley as he prepared to commit suicide after being exposed as a pornographer.

"I'm not Cotter after all," said Ned to Oliver, as he forced him to eat hot coals from the Aga.

"I'm not Cotter after all," said Ned to Gordon as he suffered a fatal heart attack after his unethical business practices were exposed.

"I know you're not Cotter and I'm going away," said Portia, as Ned booked himself a ticket back to Sweden.

fields.trailText: Thanks to my babies, Victoria and Brooklyn. Thanks, dad. It's all really hard but I love it. I'm shy and I can't reveal too much but I hope this is an insight. Thanks
fields.body:
I love football. I guess that's due to my dad. Dad didn't push me, but he probably programmed me. I used to play keepy-uppy until bed time.

I didn't like school but I think it's important to get a good education, so we read Brooklyn books. I think Victoria and I are the perfect couple. We don't kiss and hold hands for show - we even do it when we have a cup of tea.

Some people say I've got a temper. I am competitive. I probably get it from my dad. I've always respected the manager, Alex Ferguson, but I've never been to his house. We've had rows but he keeps things private, not like Glenn Hoddle, who didn't earn trust. Kevin Keegan is nice, though.

The red card against Argentina was harsh and I cried but Tony Adams was nice to me and he's been through a lot. I write down the names of people who upset me. I'll get them back. Winning the treble was the best. The fans who wished my son dead are the worst.

I've always wanted tattoos, probably because my dad had them. I wouldn't push Victoria to have one because it might not go with a certain dress and then she'd regret it. The wedding was great. I love Christmas. They made a Buddha image of me in Thailand. I was honoured, but you have to laugh.

There are cameras everywhere.

I love clothes and so does Victoria. We can spend all Saturday on clothes. Sometimes we wear the same stuff by accident. We have a really close connection like that.

I'm in touch with my feminine side. I get the male side out playing football. Maybe that's the modern equivalent of hunting. That and my love of cars.

I was honoured to win second-best player in the world. If I won best player the first person I would tell would be Victoria, and then my dad.

I want to keep working hard, like Victoria does at her singing. Health and happiness - that's it.

And if you really are pressed: The digested autobiography, digested

fields.headline: Days of reckoning
fields.standfirst: This tight presidential election campaign has been marked by an obsession with numbers - specifically, the candidates' wildly fluctuating margins in the national polls. Martin Kettle, however, has his eye firmly on a more important figure
fields.trailText: This tight presidential election campaign has been marked by an obsession with numbers - specifically, the candidates' wildly fluctuating margins in the national polls. Martin Kettle, however, has his eye firmly on a more important figure
fields.body:
In an American presidential election there is one number that matters more than any other. That number is 270, the total of electoral college votes that either Al Gore or George W Bush must amass in order to capture the White House on November 7.

At a time when all who are involved in this tight presidential election campaign are obsessed with national polls showing one or the other man ahead - often by tiny margins - it is worthwhile to remember that the presidency is decided not by the popular vote but by the electoral college. In theory - and even, on three past occasions, in practice - the winner in the popular vote does not necessarily become president.

This hasn't happened for more than a century, but it is not an impossibility this November. Indeed this is precisely what the latest state-based polls are indicating. Bush may have a narrow lead in the national match-ups - this week's Pew poll put him ahead by the narrowest of margins, 45% to 44%, for example - but the accumulated picture from the states is different. Out there, it is Gore, not Bush, who is in the lead. And on election day, it's the states that each candidate wins that will determine the outcome.

A brief reminder of how the electoral college works. Each state has votes equal to its members in the US House of Representatives and in the US Senate combined. Since a state's representation in the House is based on its population, while each state has two senators, populous California has the most electoral college votes with 54, while seven small states and the District of Columbia each have just three. There are 538 members of the electoral college, and therefore 270 electoral college votes are required to win the presidency.

It has to be admitted that, at this stage, the composite picture from the states can only be put together by local polls taken on different dates and of differing levels of reliability. Nevertheless, the latest calculations suggest that Gore currently has 281 electoral college votes leaning his way, while Bush has only 249. One state, the normally Republican Arizona, is too close to call, but even if Arizona is added to the Bush total, it isn't enough to overtake Gore at present.

Gore's states currently consist of California, Connecticut, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Hawaii, Illinois, Iowa, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nevada, Hew Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont, Washington and Wisconsin.

Bush's current list comprises the rest: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona (perhaps), Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, West Virginia and Wyoming.

The electoral map after November 7 will inevitably look different to the map as it appears today. Nevertheless, a few features stand out. Gore's strength is concentrated wholly in the four westernmost states, the mid-west and the north-east. Bush controls almost everything else to the west of the Missouri river, plus the South and a significant salient in the mid-west. Bush country covers more acres than Gore country, which is concentrated in the most densely populated states.

If Gore wins on this basis in November, he will be the first presidential candidate not to carry his own state since George McGovern in 1972. But the similarity ends there for, whereas McGovern was obliterated, Gore would win the White House. The really striking thing about this match-up is that it would make Gore the first Democratic president in history to be elected without the support of a single Southern state.

Talking to a Gore aide the other day, we compared notes on the battle for the individual states. His list for a narrow Gore win was rather different from the line-ups just discussed. It didn't include Oregon, Nevada, Iowa, Missouri or Maine. It did, however, include Tennessee and West Virginia. Even that list gives a pretty amazing picture of Gore's America. The only Southern state in the Democratic camp was Tennessee. It foresaw Republican victories in Missouri and Florida, two states where Gore has strong hopes of winning.

But the most significant thing was the underlying and unspoken assumption. A Gore aide predicts his man will win by 274 to 264, losing some of the most important battleground states of the election. If that doesn't tell you that November 7 will be one of the closest elections in American history, then nothing will.

Gore's states currently consist of California, Connecticut, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Hawaii, Illinois, Iowa, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nevada, Hew Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Vermont, Washington and Wisconsin. Bush's current list comprises the rest: Alabama, Alaska, Arizona (perhaps), Colorado, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, Montana, Nebraska, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, West Virginia and Wyoming. The electoral map after November 7 will inevitably look different to the map as it appears today. Nevertheless, a few features stand out. Gore's strength is concentrated wholly in the four westernmost states, the mid-west and the north-east. Bush controls almost everything else to the west of the Missouri river, plus the South and a significant salient in the mid-west. Bush country covers more acres than Gore country, which is concentrated in the most densely populated states. If Gore wins on this basis in November, he will be the first presidential candidate not to carry his own state since George McGovern in 1972. But the similarity ends there for, whereas McGovern was obliterated, Gore would win the White House. The really striking thing about this match-up is that it would make Gore the first Democratic president in history to be elected without the support of a single Southern state. Talking to a Gore aide the other day, we compared notes on the battle for the individual states. His list for a narrow Gore win was rather different from the line-ups just discussed. It didn't include Oregon, Nevada, Iowa, Missouri or Maine. It did, however, include Tennessee and West Virginia. Even that list gives a pretty amazing picture of Gore's America. The only Southern state in the Democratic camp was Tennessee. It foresaw Republican victories in Missouri and Florida, two states where Gore has strong hopes of winning. But the most significant thing was the underlying and unspoken assumption. A Gore aide predicts his man will win by 274 to 264, losing some of the most important battleground states of the election. If that doesn't tell you that November 7 will be one of the closest elections in American history, then nothing will.

webTitle: Jean-Marie Messier poised to sell BSkyB stake

fields.headline: Jean-Marie Messier poised to sell BSkyB stake
fields.standfirst: BSkyB shares rocked by Vivendi sale rumour
fields.trailText:
12pm: Vivendi's Jean-Marie Messier has dealt a blow to BSkyB by reportedly telling analysts he is willing to dump his stake, says Dan Milmo.
BSkyB shares rocked by Vivendi sale rumour
Messier outlines global vision for Vivendi
Deal faces EC scrutiny
Special report: Merger mania
fields.body:
Vivendi chairman Jean-Marie Messier this morning dealt a blow to BSkyB by reportedly telling analysts he is willing to dump his stake in the satellite broadcaster.

Mr Messier was speaking at an analysts' meeting, where he gave details of the French media company's proposed merger with Seagram of Canada - owner of Universal Studios.

EC regulators meet today to give their verdict on the merger, and it is understood that Mr Messier made the last-gasp offer to get the deal through and avoid an indepth, four-month investigation.

Vivendi's 22.7% stake in BSkyB, which has Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation as its key shareholder, has been the subject of constant speculation over the past few months.

Mr Messier wants to move his BSkyB stake into Mr Murdoch's Sky Global Networks, which contains all of News Corp's satellite TV operations. Analysts said today that Mr Messier's comments could represent sabre-rattling in an attempt to secure a deal with Mr Murdoch.

BSkyB's shares fell 3.4%, or 31p, to 869p on the news.

Analysts said the market is unlikely to give a warm reception to a 22% offering in the current climate, with TMT stocks under pressure from an unsteady Nasdaq and the Middle East crisis.

Both BSkyB and Vivendi declined to comment on the reports.

webTitle: In brief: How rude! George downsizes Jar Jar

fields.headline: How rude! George downsizes Jar Jar
fields.trailText: Plus: Tavernier to tackle Occupational hazards in the film industry, Bond may hit the bogs, minor Middle East tiff casts doubts over Redford-Pitt movie, Liam boards Harrison's sub and Will Smith bouncy as Men in Black 2 gets going
fields.body:
 Star Wars director George Lucas is reported to have been "shocked and surprised" by the adult reaction to his brash amphibian jester Jar Jar Binks. Though kids loved the character, grown-ups found him irritating and felt he dominated far too much of the film, reports Ain't it Cool news. Lucas has apparently responded by reducing Jar Jar's part in Episode 2 and making the character more serious and wised-up in the years since the last outing. An early assessment of the co-written script reckons it's a huge improvement on the Phantom Menace, not that that represents any great achievement.

 Director Bertrand Tavernier's next project will focus on the French film industry during the Nazi occupation according to Yahoo news The $13.3m film will be based around two real-life figures: screenwriter Jean Aurenche and assistant director Jean Devaivre, who reluctantly continued making films during the 1940-1944 Nazi occupation. Producer Frederic Bourboulon said 'Laissez Passer would be "a tribute to French cinema of the period, from which [today's filmmakers] come." Filming begins on November 6.

 Pierce Brosnan has pleaded with the 007 producers to set the next James Bond film in his native Ireland. The Irish Screen Commission's Roger Green, who spent last week with Brosnan, says: "Pierce has faced them and said, 'I'd like to do a scene or three scenes in Ireland'. We're ready to supply him with all the proof we can to handle such a large production. They usually use four major locations, and we are asking them to consider Ireland for one of those scenes. It could be Pierce's last Bond - because his contract is up after this movie."

 Brad Pitt and Robert Redford are apparently considering whether to shoot their current film in the war-torn Middle East, reports today's Daily Mail. Both stars were in London last night rehearsing for The Spy Game, a tale about international espionage, and were unsure whether to stick to the original plan and shoot in Israel. Film executives are apparently unhappy with the idea, one insider told the Mail: "We are worried not only about the guerilla attacks, but also the threat of kidnapping." The film's producer, Iain Smith, last night met with Israeli officials to determine whether or not it would be safe to film in the country.

 Liam Neeson looks like he has made a full recovery from his motorcycle accident last year and signed up to star alongside Harrison Ford in the submarine drama K-19. According to Mr Showbiz Neeson will play Ford's second-in-command aboard the crippled Russian nuclear submarine.

 The ever-chirpy Will Smith wass positively beside himself confirming that 1997's alien-comedy blockbuster Men in Black is to return with all personnel present and correct: he'll be back, as will Tommy Lee Jones and director Barry Sonnenfeld. "The whole gang is back! And they bring Tommy's character back. I can't let it out, but it's so brilliant!" gushed Smith. He did let on that Sonnenfeld is currently penning the script though, chirruping: "It's great when a sequel can have a better script because it is so rare that the second film is better than the first one. But this one is ridiculous!"

fields.headline: Is  Marco Pierre White really the chef of the decade?
fields.standfirst: Well, yes, according to a poll of 1,800 chefs. But the Guardian's food editor,  Matthew Fort,  isn't so sure that MPW deserves the title
fields.trailText: Well, yes, according to a poll of 1,800 chefs. But the Guardian's food editor, Matthew Fort, isn't so sure that MPW deserves the title
fields.body:
On Monday the AA announced its chef of the decade, based on a poll of 1,800 chefs. It came as no great surprise to anyone that it was Marco Pierre White, quondam enfant terrible of the kitchen, terror of the dining room, flayer of critics, who officially retired from the stoves last year to concentrate on building up his chain of restaurants and his already considerable wealth.

The truth is that the real chef of the past decade, indeed of the century, died in 1935. His name was Auguste Escoffier. Escoffier transformed the place of the chef in the restaurant hierarchy, the working conditions for all kitchen staff, formalised the way in which kitchens worked, established the kitchen hierarchy and the place of the chef within it, and laid down the basis for much of what passes for modern cooking.

There is scarcely a chef worth his salt who hasn't turned to Escoffier's La Guide Culinaire in their hour of need (and there are a great many chefs whose salt would be greatly improved if they did). Escoffier's groundwork prepared the way for the celebrity chef of today, and there is no chef in the UK who has greater celebrity than Marco Pierre White. (There is a distinction between being a celebrity and merely being famous, like Jamie Oliver or Gary Rhodes.) However, celebrity does not necessarily equate to importance or influence.

If you study the menus in any of the restaurants in which Marco Pierre White has an interest, you will find a homage to classical French cooking. It may be titivated, reworked, reorganised, relabelled, but the origins are unmistakable. It is the French food that earlier generations fell in love with, told us about, and which we came to expect when we first went to France. This is one aspect of Marco's talent - he has an instinctive understanding of the kind of food many people like to eat and of the environment in which they like to eat it.

That is why Granada, with whom he has a close business involvement, have asked him to bring his skills to bear on what has hitherto been one of the most distinctive, and direst, of British eating experiences, the food in old Trust House hotels.

But you don't look to a Marco menu for the influences of Italian, Indian, Japanese, Chinese or fusion cooking. His food is rooted firmly in the past. Even when he was at the height of his cooking powers, when he made Harvey's in Wandsworth a place of pilgrimage, his food was French in all essentials. In spite of the much publicised fact that he has never been to France, he showed an uncanny awareness of the latest dishes and developments in the great kitchens there.

This is not to diminish his brilliance. He has won his Michelin stars. He was, at the time, the youngest chef ever to be awarded three of them. He was probably the greatest kitchen technician this country has ever seen. He understood how to create great sauces, cook meat or fish precisely, to assemble dishes so that each part of them was perfect, like an engineer understands stress or a chemist the reaction between various chemicals. He can impart this knowledge to the large number of chefs he now has working for him, and this is why his restaurants, by and large, turn out food to an astonishing level of consistency and excellence. But does that make him the chef of the decade? Has he really changed the way in which we eat or think about food? Has he done more for us than other contenders such as Pierre Koffman, Raymond Blanc or even Nico Ladenis?

Pierre Koffman is the hero of most chefs in the industry. He published two remarkable books, Memories of Gascony and La Tante Claire, and these have been his sole contributions to the media factory. In the celebrity stakes, Pierre Koffman hasn't even made it to the starting line. Not for Koffman, Ready, Steady, Cook, chatshow appearances or gossip columns.

Koffman keeps to his kitchen. Mr Koffman cooks. As a professional and as a creative chef, Koffman is an exemplar, but his very reticence probably disqualifies him from the accolade.

Nico Ladenis was, until his retirement from the kitchen last year, the most individual figure, as famous for his abuse of customers and the media as he was for the exquisite passion of his cooking. But his stance, at the height of his powers, was unashamedly elitist. He never became part of the culinary establishment. He eschewed the pulpit that TV or the press might have offered him, and so he had less impact he might otherwise have had.

Raymond Blanc is another matter. No one can accuse Raymond Blanc of being a shrinking violet. Books have poured from him. He has charmed from the pulpit of TV. He demonstrates, instructs, talks, broadcasts and, of course, cooks. His is a naturally restless nature, and a curious one, too. He has had a Japanese period. He has dabbled in Indian spicing. He has sought to harness techniques from other culinary cultures and explore technology. He has been a fervent spokesman on behalf of organic food, and has practised what he preached in the gardens of Le Manoir aux Quat' Saisons. He has reinvented his cooking at regular intervals, not always to good effect it has to be said, but he always returns to his French roots. Mère Blanc is never far away from her son's culinary invention. This inventive energy has been as marked during the last 10 years as it was during his first 10.

Perhaps most importantly he has been a great missionary for good food outside his own restaurant. The Le Petit Blanc chain of brasserie-effect eateries, which he is rolling out across the country with the backing of the Virgin Group, is making a contribution to the quality of eating out at the democratic end of the market.

And, of course, he has also been a phenomenal teacher of chefs. Paul Heathcote, Richard Neat, Bruno Loubet, Aaron Paterson, Michael Caines, John Burton-Race, Michael Wormersly, not to mention MPW himself, have all passed through his kitchens. All these chefs have gone on to run Michelin-starred kitchens of their own.

However, there is little generic similarity between their cooking styles. Raymond Blanc seems to have the gift of inspiring and instilling principles in his chefs without forcing them to conform to a Blancian template. In this he differs greatly from Marco. It isn't that the chefs who have passed through Marco's kitchens lack creativity, but the style of food they go on to produce is very much in the master's image. None the worse for that, you may say, given the excellence of the master. True, but it doesn't take cooking in this country any further forward. It immures it in history. It takes its principles from an outmoded past. It's as if painting or architecture still subscribed to the taste of classical Greece or Rome.

Marco bestrode the London restaurant scene like a colossus in the 90s. He embodied the zeitgeist of the capital's gastronomic aspirations. Nothing he said or did was ever less than interesting. He was the source of immense excitement. He cooked and he made money, and he knew when to stop.

The notion of a chef of the decade is, frankly, risible, but if you had to choose one it would be as well to remember that London doesn't represent the rest of Britain, and French cooking is not the future or even the present of food in this country.

webTitle: Sixteen feared dead in attack on US destroyer

fields.headline: Sixteen feared dead in attack on US destroyer
fields.standfirst: Terrorists blamed for 'despicable act'
fields.trailText: An explosion that devastated one of the US navy's most sophisticated destroyers in Aden yesterday was caused by an elaborately planned terrorist suicide mission, Pentagon officials alleged last night.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle in Washington and Brian Whitaker in Yemen
fields.body:
An explosion that devastated one of the US navy's most sophisticated destroyers in Aden yesterday was caused by an elaborately planned terrorist suicide mission, Pentagon officials alleged last night.

Officials said two men were seen standing to attention in military style on the deck of a small boat that came alongside the USS Cole moments before a massive explosion which tore a 600sq ft hole in the destroyer, killing four US sailors and injuring more than 36. Another 12 US sailors were missing, feared dead.

The Cole, a Burke class destroyer which is part of the US Fifth Fleet, was paying an unannounced visit to Aden for a refuelling stop scheduled to last between four and six hours. The fact that the Cole's arrival was not widely known points equally to a high level of security intelligence and terrorist preparedness.

The Cole was travelling from the Suez canal to the Persian Gulf to take part in the US oil blockade against Iraq. That fact immediately raised suspicions of Iraqi involvement in the incident, though with anti-American tensions so high across the Arab world at present, no one in Washington was ruling out any possibility.

The Pentagon ordered all US ships docked in the region to put to sea last night as a precaution against any further attacks.

Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh denied terrorists were behind the explosion. "I don't think it's a terrorist attack," he told CNN, insisting his country harboured no "terrorist elements."

But Yemen has been plagued by generally low-level terrorism for many years. Following the Afghan war, many Muslim fighters took refuge there, taking advantage of lax security, the ready availability of weapons and the rugged terrain to use it as a base for training and activities in other countries.

The vessel which caused the explosion was described as a small, rubber boat which was assisting the Cole with its mooring lines as it docked. Some early reports suggested that the vessel rammed the Cole.

The Cole was said to be under control and to have the use of its own engines on reduced power last night. The ship remained listing to its port side in Aden harbour.

Yemeni television showed pictures of some of the wounded sailors in hospital in Aden. President Saleh visited the wounded.

President Clinton was notified of the incident at his home in New York state yesterday morning. He later called it "a despicable and cowardly act".

fields.headline: Overexposed...
fields.standfirst: ...dogs in baby carriages
fields.trailText: ..dogs in baby carriages
fields.body:
A little terrier carried insouciantly under a slim arm, wrapped up ever so casually in a pastel pashmina, was last season's Fendi baguette. True, it wasn't much cop at carrying your mobile, Marlboro Lights and flat keys, but it was much cuter and a guaranteed conversation starter.

On the boulevards of Paris, though, you need to go one step further. After all, once you've spent the odd 1000F sorting out the chic chien's pedicure and blow-dry, you want to show him off, not smother him in cashmere. And heaven forfend he should get too close to the pavement, chipping his beautifully manicured claws, or risk dirtying his clean fur by getting too close to the elements.

The only solution, of course, is to sport him about in a fetching baby carriage. You can now wheel him up and down the Left Bank without breaking your stilettoed stride. With Paris fashion week in full swing, dogs in baby carriages have been more prominent than Jade Jagger. You can't expect caring fashionistas to leave petit Milou home alone while they're off sipping champagne with John Galliano, can you? You heard it here first. The mobile dog is the new mobile phone.

You can't expect caring fashionistas to leave petit Milou home alone while they're off sipping champagne with John Galliano, can you? You heard it here first. The mobile dog is the new mobile phone.

fields.headline: Oversubscribed...
fields.standfirst: ...Jeremy Scott's phone pouch
fields.trailText: ...Jeremy Scott's phone pouch
fields.body:
And speaking of mobile phones, don't you think it's about time you jazzed yours up a bit? Everyone and their dog (especially the dog) has a signature ring, customised cover and internet access on their precious portable. So how can the fash pack (who owned a mobile, like, so long before you did) make theirs stand out from the crowd?

Good ol' Nokia know a gap in the market when they see one and have gone straight for the fashion jugular. At Paris fashion week, they unveiled (no sniggering at the back, please) a spring collection for the supermodel 8210, replete with accessories, by desirable designers such as Jeremy "Mate of Karl Lagerfeld" Scott. His sequined case with embedded paste jewels is totally fab. No longer will you have unattractive pocket bulges (so inconvenient when one is wearing one's new Balenciaga jeans), but now your phone will dangle ever so elegantly down your side.

Or it would do. Sadly, this little baby is a one-off. One can only hope it will be available for those of us with phone fetishes some time soon. And for the sneerers out there, wouldn't you prefer us to sport one of these than have one more person programme Westlife into their phone?

webTitle: BSkyB shares rocked by Vivendi sale rumour

fields.headline: BSkyB shares rocked by Vivendi sale rumour
fields.standfirst: Messier outlines global vision for Vivendi
fields.trailText:
9.45am: BSkyB shares have tumbled amid rumours that Vivendi will be forced to sell its stake to secure EC approval for its Seagram merger, says Dan Milmo.
Messier outlines global vision for Vivendi
Deal faces EC scrutiny
Special report: Merger mania
fields.body:
BSkyB shares tumbled this morning amid rumours that Vivendi will be forced to sell its stake in the satellite broadcaster to secure EC approval for its merger with Seagram.

The stock fell 3.8%, or 34p, to 866p in early trading as reports emerged that French media company Vivendi may sell its 20% stake.

EC regulators will today announce if they are to approve the merger with Seagram, owner of Universal Studios and Universal Music, or subject it to an in-depth, four-month probe.

However, analysts this morning poured cold water on the rumours, pointing out that Vivendi's chairman, Jean-Marie Messier, has in any case been threatening to sell his stake.

The ambitious chairman is at loggerheads with BSkyB's key shareholder and News Corporation chief, Rupert Murdoch. Mr Messier wants to convert his BSkyB interests into a holding in Sky Global Networks - the company that groups together Mr Murdoch's satellite TV companies.

Mr Messier is understood to be willing to sell his stake in BSkyB if Vivendi does not secure an interest in Sky Global, which is set to float at the end of the year.

webTitle: Grease lightning to strike third time

fields.headline: Grease lightning to strike third time
fields.trailText: The Thunderbirds and Pink Ladies look set to return to the big screen, after it was confirmed yesterday that Grease 3 will go ahead
fields.body:
The Thunderbirds and Pink Ladies look set to return to the big screen, after it was confirmed yesterday that Grease 3 will go ahead.

American boy band 'N Sync have commissioned a script for the project and look set to star as tough high school gang the T Birds, reports Yahoo news.

Details of the plot are still sketchy, but rumour has it that current queen of pop Britney Spears (who is dating 'N Sync member Justin Timberlake) will also star in the film as the leader of the Pink Ladies.

Though neither camp will confirm the rumour, 'N Sync have hinted at the possibility of Ms Spears hopping on board: "It's gonna be a huge, huge movie, and we've got some major, major people in it We're the five stars of it with another person that you're gonna know very well."

The original Grease starred John Travolta and Olivia Newton John as a mismatched high school couple. A huge international success, it sang and danced its way to box office millions in 1978. However sequel Grease 2, starring a young Michelle Pfeiffer and British actor Maxwell Caulfield, did little to continue the magic and was a critical and box office flop.

Filming for Grease 3 will begin in spring next year.

webTitle: 70% of children in care achieve no exam passes

fields.headline: 70% of children in care achieve no exam passes
fields.standfirst:
Social services flunk government target as minister terms new figures 'grim', but says standards are on the way up
Education Unlimited
Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Less than a third of children in the care of local authorities achieve any qualifications when they leave school at 16, according to social services statistics published by the government for the first time yesterday.
fields.body:
Less than a third of children in the care of local authorities achieve any qualifications when they leave school at 16, according to social services statistics published by the government for the first time yesterday.

Ministers set a target for at least 50% of children to gain one or more GCSE passes at grade G or above, rising to 75% by 2002/3. But last year the average for England was 30% and only 13 of 150 authorities reached the 50% goal.

Social services performance indicators for 1999/2000 showed figuresranging from 4% in Milton Keynes to 73% in Bracknell Forest. Other low performers with a pass rate of 10% or below included Oldham, Greenwich, Kirklees, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough and Peterborough. The national pass rate for those getting at least one grade G is 95.4%.

John Hutton, the health minister responsible for social care, said the figures were grim. "Councils must help looked after children to succeed in school so that more opportunities are available to them as adults.

"None of us would accept those standards for our own kids. We should absolutely not accept them for children in care because we have a collective responsibility for them."

The educational statistics were a blot on a pattern of fast improvement in most services. A year ago Mr Hutton warned 17 authorities to get their house in order or risk other authorities being ordered to take over their role. Yesterday he said: "There is now clear evidence that standards are on the way up."

Of the 150 authorities, 122 were improving on at least half the measures of performance. And there was good progress on three of the government's priority areas. The proportion of "looked after" children be ing adopted increased from 4.0% to 4.7%. As a result an extra 500 children were being offered the opportunity of a secure family.

After a poor showing last year, nearly all councils were fulfilling their statutory inspection obligations.

But the government is concerned that not enough councils are reviewing the cases of children under their protection at the proper time. Only 29 authorities had a 100% record last year and 59 had a record of less than 85%.

"It is not acceptable that one in six children deemed sufficiently at risk to be included on the child protection register have not had their cases reviewed when they should have been. This puts children at risk and must be addressed urgently," Mr Hutton said.

The authority with the worst record was Liverpool, with 22% of case reviews held on time. Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services, said she was confident that a new chief executive and director of social services were tackling the problem.

In contrast to last year's attempt by ministers to shame poor performers, Ms Platt said: "We are not about beating up individual authorities." However, under pressure from the media, officials named eight authorities offering an unacceptable service on more than half the 37 measures of performance. They were Calderdale, Knowsley, Hull, Berkshire, Windsor and Maidenhead, Isles of Scilly, City of London and the London borough of Islington.

Three authorities were "acceptable or better" on at least 30 of the 37 indicators: Derby, Derbyshire and Redbridge. The fastest improvers were Leicester, Peterborough and South Gloucestershire.

Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said the councils were pleased with clear improvement across the country on many of the services. "We share the government's and the public's ambition to ensure ever improving social services to meet the needs of vulnerable members of our society."

Rita Stringfellow, chair of the Local Government Association's social affairs executive, said: "I am delighted that over 50% of local authorities are at maximum performance or have improved on last year."

fields.headline: Liverpool finally sign £7m Biscan
fields.trailText: Liverpool have finally agreed a £7m deal with Dynamo Zagreb for Croatian international Igor Biscan. The 22-year-old midfielder will arrive at Anfield in December, during the mid-winter break in the Croatian season.
fields.body:
Liverpool have finally agreed a £7m deal with Dynamo Zagreb for Croatian international Igor Biscan. The 22-year-old midfielder will arrive at Anfield in December, during the mid-winter break in the Croatian season.

Despite the wait, Gerald Houllier was more than happy to have beaten off competition from several top European clubs to sign the highly-rated Biscan. He told the club's official website: "I am delighted to say things have now moved on significantly. We've reached an agreement with his club. We now hope he will join us at the end of his current season with Zagreb which is in December.

"We will be delighted to have him, especially as so many other top European clubs were interested. He is an international player and a class player. We've been watching him for a long time.

"He is a versatile footballer as he showed against Scotland when he played on the right of midfield. But I see him as a defensive midfielder."

webTitle: 'Israel's measured military response was, if anything, mild'

fields.headline: 'Israel's measured military response was, if anything, mild'
fields.trailText: What the Middle East papers say
fields.body:
Palestinian news outlets in English, which are sketchy at the best of times, now seem paralysed by the general fear gripping the region.

Even the Palestinian National Authority website has collapsed, and the ministry of information pages are unavailable for the second successive day.

The mood of Arab anger against Israel is, however, well captured by the Arabia.com site, which features comprehensive coverage of ongoing events. It carries a chilling opinion poll in which 53% of respondents, asked how Yasser Arafat should respond, opt for a declaration of war.

Belligerence is also the prevailing tone in the Israeli papers, which shrug off any suggestion that Israel itself may bear some responsibility for the crisis.

The Jerusalem Post is adamant: "Arafat cannot escape responsibility for the unspeakably brutal lynching of two Israeli soldiers in Ramallah, even if, as Palestinians claim, his police tried to prevent the mob from removing them from police custody. No known steps have been taken to arrest the perpetrators.

"Most importantly, the lynching was the product of relentless PA (Palestinian Authority) incitement to violence. It was this incitement that produced the violence of the last two weeks, and has only accelerated with every Palestinian casualty. Israel's measured military response was, if anything, mild or, in the IDF's (Israeli Defence Forces) own description, 'symbolic.' The frenzied cries of Palestinian spokesmen that Israel has 'escalated' and is perpetrating 'massacres' of Palestinians are absurd."

The more liberal daily Ha'aretz also clearly believes that Israel has behaved reasonably, in the face of great provocation. It devotes its editorial not to the escalating conflict with the Palestinians, but to the ugly outbreak of violence between Jews and Arabs within Israel. It notes with approval that the disturbances have died down, and that there are signs of reconciliation.

"Apparently, both sides were horrified by the violent events and realised that for the sake of normal life together and for the sake of preserving the rule of law, an effort must be made to restrain emotions and impulses and to find a common denominator for coexistence."

fields.trailText: 11am: Endemol is to act as global distributor for F*cking Famous, an interactive docu-soap created by Swedish oufit Kamera, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Endemol Entertainment will act as global distributor for F*cking Famous, an interactive docu-soap created by the Swedish streaming media specialist, Kamera.

The programme focuses on the lives of a group of young people seeking fame by interacting with their web audience. An Endemol spokesman said no details were yet available on the production of the series and the format it would take.

It is understood that the format for F*cking Famous will be designed with the web in mind first, and will be adapted separately for television.

webTitle: Floods chaos - and more rain on way

fields.headline: Floods chaos - and more rain on way
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The worst flooding in decades brought chaos to much of southern England yesterday, causing millions of pounds in damage as homes and businesses became waterlogged, thousands of people stranded and main roads blocked.
fields.body:
The worst flooding in decades brought chaos to much of southern England yesterday, causing millions of pounds in damage as homes and businesses became waterlogged, thousands of people stranded and main roads blocked.

Rivers swollen by a night of unceasing rain burst their banks, sending torrents of water rushing through town centres in Sussex, Kent and Hampshire.

More than 150 flood alerts were issued across the country yesterday as meteorologists predicted more rain to come.

Uckfield in East Sussex was worst hit after five inches of rain in 12 hours left the town almost completely submerged.

Lifeboat crews were drafted in to rescue stranded residents and workers and one man was swept away by the fast-flowing floods as he tried to open his shop. He was spotted 20 minutes later clinging on to the banks of the river Uck. He was airlifted to safety by a coastguard helicopter which was scrambled from Eastbourne, 18 miles away.

A teenage looter was caught by a quick-thinking police officer who borrowed a JCB to chase and arrest the youth as he waded through the flooded high street with a trolleyfull of stolen goods.

In Lewes, six lifeboat crew narrowly escaped with their lives when their rescue boat was dragged underneath a bridge that had been almost submerged by the water.

Residents were last night evacuated from the town as the waters rose and the Ouse threatened to burst its banks.

The environment agency described the situation across the south as "dire", warning that conditions were likely to get worse before they got better as the Met Office warned that there would be more rain in south-east England.

By last night the agency had issued 40 flood warnings, advising that flooding was expected to spread to other areas of the country, including Devon, Yorkshire and Shropshire.

Severe flood warnings, alerting people to an imminent threat to life and property, were issued for 16 rivers in Sussex and Kent.

Sussex police urged drivers to stay at home as main roads were flooded.

webTitle: Mobile phone bullies drove teenager to suicide

fields.headline: Mobile phone bullies drove teenager to suicide
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: School bullies are turning to mobile phones and the internet, campaigners warned yesterday, after a 15-year-old killed herself following anonymous calls to her mobile.
fields.body:
School bullies are turning to mobile phones and the internet, campaigners warned yesterday, after a 15-year-old killed herself following anonymous calls to her mobile.

Gail Jones, from Tranmere, Merseyside, took an overdose on May 4 after being bombarded with silent calls, sometimes receiving up to 20 in half an hour. An inquest heard that the teenager left a suicide text message on her phone the night before she died.

"She tells us how she feels towards us and hints that it was the nuisance calls which drove her to do what she did," said Glyn Jones, the girl's father. "It really got to her and she could not take it any more."

Campaigners said bullying via mobile phone calls, text messages and email was escalating at a worrying rate.

Liz Carnell, founder of the internet support group Bullying Online, said the problem was almost unknown before last Christmas, when many children received prepaid mobile phones as gifts. A quarter of teenagers now own one.

Ms Carnell said her organisation receives about two calls a week from children receiving nuisance calls. She knew of one pupil who had received death threats via text messages.

fields.headline: Dennis Interactive to set up London base
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Dennis Interactive, the US digital agency, is to open a London office, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Dennis Interactive, the US digital agency whose clients include Cosmopolitan and Maxim magazines, is to open a London office.

The new agency will be headed by Andy Watson, the former operations manager of Netfulfillment, and Imogen Edwards from Handbag.com. They will report to Tom Livaccari, the agency's vice-president of business development.

Mr Livaccari pledged that the new European operation would not simply be a satellite office of the New York agency.

He said: "Dennis Interactive is in a position to offer its UK and European clients integrated digital services at a time when our competitors in London are either purely design-oriented or satellite offices of large US agencies."

fields.headline: Band & Brown Group moves to corner sports sponsorship
fields.trailText: 10.15am: The Band & Brown Group has launched a specialist sports agency called Playmaker, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Band & Brown Group has launched a specialist sports agency called Playmaker to concentrate on the £390m UK sports sponsorship market.

Playmaker, which will provide sponsorship management as well as PR services, is to be run by Rowan Andrews and David Piper. It starts trading with two major accounts: the football sponsorship interests of both Nationwide Building Society and One2One.

As group account director at Band & Brown, Mr Andrews ran one of the agency's consumer PR divisions, which included a number of sports related accounts including AXA's FA Cup sponsorship. Mr Piper, a former footballer, headed Larkspur's sponsorship team and previously managed the Coca-Cola Cups in both England and Scotland.

Playmaker will be heavily tied into iJack, Band & Brown's specialist online division, to widen its offering.

Mr Piper said: "Sponsorship is now an important part of the marketing mix. Most sponsors are no longer interested in simple patronage, but instead are looking to involve themselves in mutually beneficial partnerships with rights holders. Playmaker's role will be to add significant value through the management of these partnerships and their subsequent sponsorship properties."

fields.headline: AMV unrolls Economist poster push
fields.trailText: 10am: Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO is launching the next phase of its poster campaign for The Economist next week. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO is launching the next phase of its national poster campaign for The Economist next week.

The ads will run on 96 and 48-sheet sites nation-wide and six-sheet executions posted at travel sites across London.

The campaign will continue the theme of promoting The Economist to occasional and non-readers by suggesting that the publication enables you to surpass yourself.

One execution will feature copy that reads, "A poster should contain no more than eight words, which is the maximum the average reader can take in at a single glance. This, however, is a poster for Economist readers".

Other new taglines will include, "Don't be a waste of space"; "Ever go blank at the crucial...thingy?" and "Is it me or is quantum phsyics easier these days?".

All media was bought by New PHD with a spend of £500,000.

fields.trailText: 10am: Digital agency Organic has appointed Nick Sparey as group director, media, in its London office, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Digital agency Organic has strengthened the management team in its London office with the appointment of Nick Sparey as group director, media.

Mr Sparey, who joins from Tempest Online Marketing where he was head of new business, has been charged with growing the company's marketing services, implement global media strategy and develop Organic's Wap, PDA and interactive TV credentials.

John Baker, managing director at Organic London, said: "In order to continue to grow the company in the UK we need talented media and marketing people with strong operational experience."

Mr Sparey has more than ten years of experience in various other companies including BMP DDB Needham and Mediapolis. He effectively replaces Jason Dooris, former media director at Organic, who left to head up Media.com, MediaCom TMB's online media arm.

fields.headline: Grey Advertising lands PCCW task
fields.trailText: 10am: Pacific Century CyberWorks, a leading Hong Kong internet company, has appointed Grey Advertising, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Pacific Century CyberWorks, a leading Hong Kong internet company, has appointed Grey Advertising.

The appointment came without a pitch but PCCW saw credential presentations from several unnamed agencies. There was no incumbent agency.

J Walter Thompson and McCann-Erickson Worldwide handle traditional advertising for PCCW, while Zenith Media is the media agency of record.

Beyond Interactive, the digital marketing division of Grey, will handle the business. Billings were undisclosed.

Beyond Interactive will provide campaign strategy, media buying and planning, creative, data solutions and other interactive marketing services for each of PCCW's business units, including Netvigator, Powerbase and HKT Mobile Services. PCCW recently completed the takeover of Cable & Wireless HKT, one of the territory's largest telecom companies.

PCCW is developing a full range of broadband internet capabilities and is aiming to become a premier provider of telecommunications, digital technology and new media services. Currently it has 25 offices across 18 countries and 15,000 employees worldwide.

webTitle: Ken Loach to make Channel 4 film

fields.headline: Ken Loach to make Channel 4 film
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Film director Ken Loach has signed a deal with Channel 4 to make his first TV work in years, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Ken Loach, the film director renowned for hard-hitting social realism films such as Riff Raff, Raining Stones and My Name is Joe, has signed a deal with Channel 4 to make his first TV work in years.

The film, which has the working title the Navigators and follows a group of Sheffield railway maintenance workers struggling to adapt to privatisation, is Channel 4's new head of drama Tessa Ross's first commission.

The broadcaster is stumping up 30% of the budget and will premiere the film in the UK on its terrestrial service. In the rest of the world, the Navigators is being lined up for a theatrical release.

The 100-minute movie, which has been scripted by Rob Dawber and is being made by Parallax Pictures, went into production earlier this week on location in Sheffield. It is expected to go out on Channel 4 next year.

Mr Loach started out working in British TV in the 1960s, collaborating with producer Tony Garnett on ground-breaking work such as Up the Junction and Cathy Come Home, before moving into feature films with Kes. His latest film, Bread and Roses, deals with a Los Angeles janitors' strike.

webTitle: Wireless Group snaps up Wave 105 FM

fields.headline: Wireless Group snaps up Wave 105 FM
fields.trailText: 9.30am: The Wireless Group is to buy the remaining 75.4% share in Wave 105 FM for £21.3m. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Wireless Group is to buy the remaining 75.4% share of Southampton's Wave 105 FM that it does not already own for £21.3m.

The deal, subject to approval by Wave shareholders, will boost the acquisitive radio group's presence in the south of England.

The Wireless Group, created in 1999 by former Sun editor Kelvin MacKenzie out of what was Talk Radio, has expanded significantly through buying the Radio Partnership and the Independent Radio Group. Last year it floated on the stock market.

Mr MacKenzie said the acquisition "represents an important addition to our regional radio portfolio and complements our successful stations in Scotland, the north of England and Wales. We were missing out in the south and now we have begun to fill that gap with a station covering a valuable urban area."

webTitle: Scoot.com links up with Vivendi's Ad2-one

fields.headline: Scoot.com teams up with Vivendi ad sales agency
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Scoot.com has moved closer to French media giant Vivendi by teaming up with the Ad2-one ad sales agency, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Scoot.com, the online directories service, has moved closer to French media giant Vivendi by teaming up with the Ad2-one ad sales agency.

Ad2-one is owned by VivendiNet, an internet subsidiary of Vivendi, which has a 22.4% stake in Scoot. The three-year sales agreement will see Ad2-one selling Scoot content across its WAP, interactive TV and internet channels in Scoot's markets in the UK, France, Belgium and the Netherlands.

Robert Bonnier, chief executive of Scoot, said: "Our growing European reach and ubiquitous multi-access platform is an increasingly attractive medium for corporate advertisers."

Scoot has been constantly linked with Vivendi takeover bids, resulting in massive leaps in its share price. The stock rose 53% on September 4 when a delay in issuing a statement to the Stock Exchange convinced dealers that a takeover bid was imminent. Today, shares in the company fell 2%, or 3p, to 98p, far below their year-high of 374p.

Meanwhile, Scoot also announced its subscriber base had increased to 30,069 in the fourth quarter, a rise of 29% on the previous quarter. The company said it expects the subscriber growth rate to be even higher in the current quarter.
