webTitle: Explosion rocks British embassy in Yemen

fields.headline: Explosion rocks British embassy in Yemen
fields.trailText: An explosion at the British embassy in Yemen's capital, Sana'a, shattered the windows and that of neighbouring buildings, but nobody was injured, witnesses and embassy officials said.
fields.body:
An explosion at the British embassy in Yemen's capital, Sana'a, shattered the windows and that of neighbouring buildings, but nobody was injured, witnesses and embassy officials said.

The blast just after dawn shattered windows at the three-floor embassy as well as a neighbouring school and the nearby Dutch embassy.

Only a Yemeni night guard was on duty at the time, a British embassy spokeswoman. Nobody was hurt, she said.

"The explosion was close to a generator," she said. "We sustained considerable damage to the building itself."

British Foreign Secretary Robin Cook, in an interview with Sky News, said foul play was suspected.

"We believe a bomb of some kind was flung over a wall," Cook said. "It was not a particularly professional attack, rather an opportunistic one, and it seems to have landed on a diesel generator and has caused quite a substantial explosion."

The explosion shook the entire district, said Hisham al-Qubati, a secretary at the nearby Yemen Times building.

"I heard a loud explosion at 6.05am (0305 GMT) and rushed over to the embassy. They wouldn't let us in, but I could see shattered windows and the damage to a school next to the embassy," Mr al-Qubati said.

A forensics team was trying to determine the cause of the blast, the embassy spokeswoman said.

The explosion comes a day after US officials say suicide bombers in a small boat blew a gaping hole in a US warship at a refuelling stop in the Aden harbour in Yemen. The blast killed six members of the crew, injured 35 and left 11 missing.

Sport First has appointed Walker Media to handle the £3m media account for its first major campaign.

The Times is copying The Observer by launching a monthly sports supplement.

Optimedia has won the UK account for Citizen Watches and the pan-European task for Intercitrus.

The Media Shop has picked new clients worth more than £3m.

webTitle: TiVo to link up with Omnicom

fields.headline: TiVo to link up with Omnicom
fields.trailText: 9.30am: TiVo Inc is expected to announce a deal with Omnicom, making it the first member of the TiVo ad agency partnership programme, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
TiVo is expected to announce today a deal with the Omnicom Group in New York making it the first member of what is known as the TiVo strategic advertising agency partnership programme.

The agreement will give Omnicom agencies the ability to test different methods of advertising that take advantage of the TiVo time-shifting technology and offer Omnicom clients potential discounts if they work with TiVo.

Omnicom agencies include BBDO Worldwide, DDB Worldwide and TBWA. Another shop owned by Omnicom, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, has been the TiVo consumer agency since February.

The development of advertising that differs from traditional commercials stems from a crucial feature of the systems sold by TiVo which enables viewers to pause, replay, rewind and fast-forward through television programmes and commercials as they are watched.

In an interview with the New York Times today, Stacy Jolna, chief programming officer and vice-president for advertising and media partnerships at TiVo in California, said: "Clearly, advertising will change in a dramatic way. Viewers have never been more central in half a century of watching TV.

"The point of this is for agencies to work with us, to experiment with and get a better understanding of the new advertising and marketing techniques we will develop."

webTitle: BBC may apply international licence fee

fields.headline: BBC seeks international licence fee for overseas online users
fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText: 8am: The BBC is considering issuing a licence fee to allow it to charge overseas visitors to view programming content on its websites, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC is considering launching an international licence fee that would allow it to charge overseas visitors to view programming content on its websites. Such a move would let the corporation expand its web streaming operations.

The initiative, which is to be funnelled through BBC.com and the recently secured domain name, BBCnews.com, has come to the forefront of BBC international online policy since the TV licensing authority was quoted as saying all users accessing the streamed broadcasts had to have a licence fee.

At present BBC.co.uk streams selected parts of its news programming and is planning to migrate library clips to the internet as part of its Project Irene initiative. However current narrowband technology is holding back faster development of streaming initiatives. This is not expected to change for several years.

According to Drew Kaza, managing director of BBC Internet & Interactive, the rights issue is under discussion although his priority is to launch BBC.com in the next few months, initially with just text and stills and some streaming.

He said: "We're making progress there, but we won't be able to do much initially. It could be a decent long-term business proposition for the BBC if it's not held back by those that think there is a huge pot of gold out there."

Mr Kaza added that the other key issue for the BBC's international commercial portals was using redirection technology that is able to determine where an internet user is coming from and direct them to the relevant site.

He said the system was "pretty much there" and was able to differentiate European users from the IP addresses and American users from the time clock settings on their PCs.

In terms of how the money will be collected, the BBC is considering two options: either developing a pay-per-view service or charging a set subscription, which would give access to an archive of BBC programming.

Mr Kaza, however, said it might be five years before consumers are willing to pay to watch programming via the internet.

webTitle: Bright Station in 'no bid' for Boxman

fields.headline: Bright Station in 'no bid' for Boxman
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Bright Station is unlikely to bid for failed internet venture Boxman, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Bright Station, the company being linked with Boxman, the dot.com world's latest high-profile failure, is unlikely to bid for the company, according to an observer close to both companies.

The internet incubator is being linked with online CD retailer Boxman, which applied for voluntary liquidation on Wednesday. Bright Station has gained a reputation for picking up the pieces from failed internet ventures after it bought the technology assets of online retailer boo.com earlier this year.

However, the source said: "Bright Station has looked at distressed dot.coms in the past and they might be expected to run the rule over this one, but I cannot see where it fits in with what they are trying to do."

Bright Station has folded the boo software into its Sparza subsidiary, which supplies e-commerce solutions, and gained boo's top technology staff in the process. The company also owns the WebTop search engine programme and SmartLogik, which provides knowledge management solutions.

Bright Station could not be reached for comment last night.

fields.headline: S&J drives away with £27m Smart car
fields.trailText: 8,15am: Springer & Jacoby has picked up the $40m (£27m) international marketing communications account for DaimlerChrysler's Smart car, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Springer & Jacoby has picked up the $40m (£27m) international marketing communications account for DaimlerChrysler's Smart car.

It's understood that Leagas Delaney, Scholz & Friends and Berlin-based KNSK Slagman also took part in the pitch.

fields.headline: Carlton Interactive seeks agency to spearhead £10m web drive
fields.trailText: 8am: Carlton Interactive is seeking an advertising agency to spearhead its portfolio of internet ventures, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Carlton Interactive has begun a search for an advertising agency to spearhead its portfolio of internet ventures.

The pitch, understood to be worth £10m, is being handled through the AAR. Duncan Eaton, marketing director of Carlton Interactive, is putting together a shortlist of agencies.

Mr Eaton is in charge of marketing Carlton Interactive's range of ventures, including consumer websites Popcorn, Jamba and Simplyfood, and Carlton's portal site, Carlton.com.

Mr Eaton's appointment in April this year followed a series of moves by Carlton to expand its new media presence. The company, which renamed its Carlton Online division Carlton Interactive last year, has bought stakes in several online ventures, including a £20m investment in the UK launch of US internet search engine Ask Jeeves.

Carlton has announced a wide-ranging deal with WH Smith to cross-promote each other's web activities. WH Smith will run Carlton's e-commerce offer, while Carlton will sell advertising space and provide content on both the whsmith.co.uk and carlton.com websites.

webTitle: Channel 4 back in bid for media rights

fields.headline: Channel 4 back in bid for media rights
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Arena Leisure has joined forces with BSkyB and Channel 4 to bid for the media rights to Britain's 59 racecourses. The joint-venture, named NewCo, will make its offer within the next fortnight, a move which signals Channel 4's return to negotiations following its withdrawal of a £225m bid in July.
fields.body:
Arena Leisure has joined forces with BSkyB and Channel 4 to bid for the media rights to Britain's 59 racecourses. The joint-venture, named NewCo, will make its offer within the next fortnight, a move which signals Channel 4's return to negotiations following its withdrawal of a £225m bid in July.

Ian Penrose, spokesman for Arena whose £320m bid, made in September, lapsed on Tuesday, said: "Our partnership with Channel 4 and BSkyB combines all the necessary expertise to develop UK racing as a truly global media and gaming product.

"We sincerely hope the racecourses will appreciate that this partnership is best placed to maximise enhanced revenue streams to racing."

Arena's previous bid was surpassed by a £400m offer over a 10-year period from media group Carlton, who have set a deadline of October 24 for beginning a period of exclusivity. NewCo are obviously in a position to better the Carlton bid by some way.

Stephen Atkin, chief executive of the Racecourse Association, welcomed the new development. "We look forward with interest to receiving their offer," he said. "We have been attempting to broker a 59-racecourse solution since the end of July and a great deal of work has been done."

Channel 4's proposed 10-year-deal, involving ntl subsidiary Premium TV and the BBC involving the "Super 12" racecourses, collapsed largely in the face of opposition from the remaining 47 tracks.

BSkyB had also been involved in negotiations with the Super 12 but pulled out in February. However, a spokesman for Channel 4 said: "I think there is a feeling that there is more common ground between the racecourses as a whole. It is not yet plain sailing, but the situation has moved on."

A spokesman for the BBC, who are not so far included in the new deal, said: "We still have a commitment to racing and are following the situation closely."

Aidan O'Brien will run Minardi, Mozart, Cashel Palace and Freud in tomorrow's Darley Dewhurst Stakes for which 11 have been declared. Speaking at Newmarket yesterday, he said: "Mick Kinane will tell me which one he wants to ride and I'll leave it to him, I shan't be advising him."

O'Brien works Giant's Causeway on the all-weather surface at Southwell this afternoon to try and gauge whether the colt should be aimed at the Breeders' Cup Classic on the dirt or the Mile on turf at Churchill Downs next month. "He'll gallop over a mile or maybe nine furlongs with Shoal Creek and one other and we'll see how he goes," explained the trainer. "He's bred to go on the dirt but you never know."

O'Brien's Ishiguru started hot-favourite to score first time out in the Snailwell Maiden Stakes yesterday but after leading a furlong out was caught in the last few strides by the more experienced Ajwaa, trained by Marcus Tregoning.

Ishiguru is a powerful, sprinting son of Danzig and this defeat should prove only a minor setback particularly when he gets some fast ground.

Members of the syndicates run by Peter Harris have been enjoying a great run this autumn and the Tring trainer landed a double with Katy Nowaitee and Idle Power.

Katy Nowaitee, owned by The Stable Maites, followed up her win in the Cambridgeshire in the Listed Grangewood Severals Stakes and will stay in training next season although she could have one more run in a Group 3 race at Bordeaux.

Idle Power is owned by a 12-strong syndicate called The Dreamers who were understandably overjoyed with their 20-1 winner. Harris has found that the natural enthusiasm of his owners means they back their horses regardless of what he says.

 Today's scheduled meetings at Brighton and Redcar were called off yesterday and the wet weather threatens tomorrow's Catterick card. An inspection will be held at 12.30 to determine prospects, but the course was unraceable yesterday.

webTitle: Nettar quits BBH to head PR  at Grey

fields.headline: Nettar quits BBH to head PR at Grey
fields.trailText: 8am: Lorette Nettar, the PR director and board member at Bartle Bogle Hegarty, has resigned to join Grey Advertising as head of PR. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Lorette Nettar, the public relations director and board member at Bartle Bogle Hegarty, has resigned from the agency to join Grey Advertising as its head of PR.

The move reunites her with Martin Smith, the deputy chairman and one of the founding partners of BBH who joined Grey as chief executive in April this year.

Ms Nettar will be replaced by Sarah Pollard, head of public relations at Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper, who joins the agency next week.

webTitle: Middle East turmoil overshadows EU summit

fields.headline: Middle East turmoil overshadows EU summit
fields.trailText: EU leaders are expected to issue a crisis statement on the situation in the Middle East, at the start of their two-day Biarritz summit in south-west France.
fields.body:
EU leaders are expected to issue a crisis statement on the situation in the Middle East, at the start of their two-day Biarritz summit in south-west France.

Intended to consider plans for the internal reform of the EU, the gathering has been overshadowed by the eruption of conflict between Israel and Palestine.

The Israeli regional co-operation minister, Shimon Peres, will attend the summit as the emissary of Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak, although it is uncertain what role he will play. The British foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has postponed his arrival to the summit to stay in the Middle East.

The EU has in the past played peace broker between Israel and Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat.

The main business of the gathering is to settle differences over how the EU develops in the next few years, in preparation for new members, mainly from eastern Europe. These include how far to go in scrapping national vetoes over European issues, limiting the size of the European Commission, and the re-weighting of votes in the decision-making European Council to make sure the introduction of a raft of smaller countries can't throw the EU off course.

Mr Blair arrived late last night to go straight to a dinner with fellow European socialist leaders, where the spiralling conflict dominated discussion.

Another war-torn region will also feature heavily at the summit, with the leaders tomorrow having a working lunch with new Yugoslav president Vojislav Kostunica, on his first visit outside Serbia since Slobodan Milosevic lost power.

Separately, Mr Blair met his Irish counterpart Bertie Ahern for 30 minutes last night, on his arrival at the summit. A spokesman for the prime minister said the two leaders had continued the discussions they had yesterday on the outstanding difficulties in the peace process and agreed they would probably have more discussions over the next two days.

Foreign affairs are likely to overshadow any prospect of a clash between Mr Blair and other leaders over the proposed EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the text of which has already been agreed.

fields.headline: A Nice mess
fields.standfirst:
The first wave of east European entrants to the EU will alter the balance of the European constitution. But how will the scales be reset?
Special report: the European commission
fields.trailText: No one expects this weekend's summit of EU leaders in Biarritz to rearrange the furniture to accommodate Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary among the dozen candidates knocking at the gate.
fields.body:
No one expects this weekend's summit of EU leaders in Biarritz to rearrange the furniture to accommodate Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary among the dozen candidates knocking at the gate.

There will be late nights in smoke-filled rooms at the next summit, in Nice, in December. So much for transparency in decision-making: Europe's prime ministers will stumble bleary-eyed into a Mediterranean dawn and announce that deals have been struck. And the public, increasingly edgy and suspicious (scepticism is not only a British prerogative), may feel yet more alienated. Where are the national debates on enlargement? In Germany the beginnings of one uncovered deep misgivings.

What has to be decided sounds numbingly technical but ultimately, says Michel Barnier, the commissioner responsible, it is a matter of political will. The Germans deserve more than the 10 votes that they now wield of the 87 allotted the 15 member states in the European Council. The council will sit in France this weekend - it is the regular forum of EU prime ministers, the place decisions are made (or deferred).

Tony Blair wants to beef the council up, to move away from the "supranational" commission to more government-to-government dealings. Its exact legal status may be cleared up if, as they threaten, the Netherlands sues it for blocking access to documents dealing with security and military affairs - necessary (say the UK and others) if the EU is to see data from Nato.

But the European Council is out of date. Germany gets seats in the European parliament pro rata to its population but not in the council, despite the huge German subsidy (see the chart) that keeps the EU going. There is also the vexed question of "qualified majority voting", the proportion of votes in the European Council that constitutes a veto.

At present a minimum of 71% of yes votes is needed to legislate. Till now the Mediterraneans have been able to muster the strength to stop the northern Europeans. But all bets are off once the east Europeans join - Poland's 39m would qualify it for a hefty share of votes and change for ever the equations on who can stop what.

Biarritz will pass on the future composition of the European commission, the Brussels executive body headed by Romano Prodi. The plan is to give the UK, France and other biggies a single commissioner, letting smaller fry have theirs on rotation. And then there is the size of the parliament in Strasbourg. Polish accession would, again, require radical revision. The total number of seats is capped at 700; Poland would be due 60. Who is going to give up space? And don't forget Luxemburg, less than a million people but one commissioner, two council votes and six members of the European parliament.

Enlargement requires the candidates to shape up. On present reckoning, Hungary, Estonia and Slovenia will shortly have absorbed the European rules and ordinances. President Pompidou ruled in 1969 that such prodigious digestion was a precondition of entry. (There is no reason, in principle, that transitional arrangements could be not be substituted.)

It is considered bad form to note that several existing members would not qualify for entry on that basis. One wag asks whether the candidates are meant, within a matter of months, to acquire a German economy, a British civil service, a Swedish welfare state and a French electoral system. Or how about a Greek economy, Belgian civil service, Austrian industrial relations and an Italian electoral system?

Polish agriculture cannot shrink in time for entry in 2004, the date they want and the one endorsed by Tony Blair in Warsaw last week. That either means Polish farmers will not get the Euro-supports paid to Bauern in Bavaria and paysans in Provence or there will be some giant reworking of the EU budget. Look at the chart again. Most scenarios, with or without Polish farmers, push the Irish and Spanish into the net payments column later this decade. Which explains why their politicians have begun to talk Eurosceptic.

There are 13 declared candidates for EU entry, including Malta and Cyprus (at least the Greek bit of the island, which itself raises problems). A premise of the stability pact offered the Balkan countries was that they too would soon join.

In a new book the former German chancellor Helmut Schmidt says it is time to draw the wagons round. Poland belongs to Europe, he says, but not Russia, except there is a bit of a problem with the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad, once Königsberg, sandwiched between Euro-aspirants Poland and Lithuania.

But stopping further expansion does not solve the immediate problem of reforming European gover nance. If agreement were reached this year, the treaty embodying the changes would have to be ratified by member states - another Danish referendum would be likely. Only after negotiations with the Poles and others were finalised and the putative treaty of Nice ratified would formal invitations be issued to the joiners, and, if that is not done before the end of 2003, the new kids on the block could not take part in the next parliamentary elections due in June 2004 - a very tight timetable.

The word on the chaussée is that the Nice summit will only be a stopgap. The great debate to which Mr Blair was contributing last week will have to result in further fundamental revisions of the European constitution, with or without the Poles.

david.walker@theguardian.com

 Charles Jenkins (ed) The Unification of Europe? (Centre for Reform, www.cfr.org.uk)

fields.headline: Martyrs, never victims
fields.standfirst: As the Middle East lurches toward war, the death toll rises apace - all but a handful of them Muslim Palestinians. Middle East editor Brian Whitaker looks at the myth-making that accompanies each death
fields.trailText: As the Middle East lurches toward war, the death toll rises apace - all but a handful of them Muslim Palestinians. Middle East editor Brian Whitaker looks at the myth-making that accompanies each death
fields.body:
The British have never had much of a taste for martyrdom. Perhaps it's because we have never had to fight off a foreign occupation, or perhaps because in our colonial past we were more in the business of making martyrs than becoming martyrs ourselves.

Christianity has its martyrs of course, but these days the possibility of martyrdom is not something that the average British churchgoer need contemplate. It therefore comes as a cultural shock, when travelling around the Middle East, to find how readily people talk about martyrs and how many people claim to have known at least one personally.

Anyone who has met a violent death in the service of country, religion or a cause is likely to be considered a martyr. Arabs often use the word 'martyr' where a British person would talk instead of 'victims' (unarmed Palestinians killed by the Israelis, for example), or 'heroes' (Kuwaitis who fought the Iraqi occupation despite overwhelming odds against them).

One obvious reason for this difference is that in Islam martyrdom brings special privileges. A martyr goes immediately to paradise, while others must wait for their final destination to be decided on the day of judgment.

Where martyrdom is involved, nobody tries to hide the gruesome details - in fact, everyone is encouraged to look. There's a building in Kuwait known as the Martyrs' House - a villa in a quiet suburb where a dozen resistance fighters were besieged and eventually killed by Iraqi forces. It has been preserved almost as the Iraqis left it, with holes in the walls and rubble on the carpets. Plaques mark the exact spot where each body was found. Alone in a glass showcase is a pair of jeans worn by one of the dead men - with a bloodstained bullet hole in the crotch.

Palestinians fighting Israeli occupation often display the bodies of martyrs to reveal the marks of bullets and beatings. Although westerners might regard this as intrusive almost to the point of disrespect for the dead, in Arab eyes it heightens respect by showing the extent of the person's suffering and sacrifice. Apart from its religious connotations, martyrdom is also linked to Arab concepts of honour, manliness and moral superiority. Some of the honour attaches to a martyr's surviving relatives, enhancing their respect in the community.

Similar attitudes apply to those who are not martyred but endure torture or imprisonment without betraying their cause. That is regarded as a sign of true manliness, and for many young Palestinians it has become a rite of passage. In a chapter in a new book*, American anthropologist Julie Peteet tells the story of Hussein, a 24-year-old Palestinian who was arrested during the intifada of the 80s for throwing stones and building barricades.

After a public beating in the alleyways, he was taken away for 18 days' interrogation by the Israelis. Stripped naked and without proper sanitation for the first three days, he was beaten with fists, pipes and rifle butts, then kept in prison for nine months.

On the day of his release, a succession of visitors came to the family's home to pay their respects, and among them was a neighbour who asked him to mediate in a dispute. In Arab society, mediation is normally the preserve of much older men, and it indicated the new esteem in which Hussein was held.

On later visits, Peteet found that seating arrangements in the household - which indicate the social hierarchy when receiving guests - had changed, with Hussein now occupying the senior position. In conversation, his father deferred to him, never interrupting as he described his experiences, except to mutter, "Prison is a university", or "Prison is for men".

It can be difficult for a foreigner not involved in the Palestinian cause to share the emotions at work here. But they become easier to understand when you meet someone from your own profession who has suffered. Earlier this week I was in Yemen to help with a training workshop for Yemeni journalists. During a coffee break one of them mentioned, quite casually, that he had been imprisoned three times.

It left me feeling that there was probably no way I could show him enough respect. And wondering whether, in his position, I might not be tempted to give up journalism and open a grocery store instead.

* Imagined Masculinities: Male Identity and Culture in the Modern Middle East. Edited by Mai Ghoussoub and Emma Sinclair-Webb. Published by Saqi Books. UK price: £14.95.

It has been preserved almost as the Iraqis left it, with holes in the walls and rubble on the carpets. Plaques mark the exact spot where each body was found. Alone in a glass showcase is a pair of jeans worn by one of the dead men - with a bloodstained bullet hole in the crotch. Palestinians fighting Israeli occupation often display the bodies of martyrs to reveal the marks of bullets and beatings. Although westerners might regard this as intrusive almost to the point of disrespect for the dead, in Arab eyes it heightens respect by showing the extent of the person's suffering and sacrifice. Apart from its religious connotations, martyrdom is also linked to Arab concepts of honour, manliness and moral superiority. Some of the honour attaches to a martyr's surviving relatives, enhancing their respect in the community. Similar attitudes apply to those who are not martyred but endure torture or imprisonment without betraying their cause. That is regarded as a sign of true manliness, and for many young Palestinians it has become a rite of passage. In a chapter in a new book*, American anthropologist Julie Peteet tells the story of Hussein, a 24-year-old Palestinian who was arrested during the intifada of the 80s for throwing stones and building barricades. After a public beating in the alleyways, he was taken away for 18 days' interrogation by the Israelis. Stripped naked and without proper sanitation for the first three days, he was beaten with fists, pipes and rifle butts, then kept in prison for nine months. On the day of his release, a succession of visitors came to the family's home to pay their respects, and among them was a neighbour who asked him to mediate in a dispute. In Arab society, mediation is normally the preserve of much older men, and it indicated the new esteem in which Hussein was held. On later visits, Peteet found that seating arrangements in the household - which indicate the social hierarchy when receiving guests - had changed, with Hussein now occupying the senior position. In conversation, his father deferred to him, never interrupting as he described his experiences, except to mutter, "Prison is a university", or "Prison is for men". It can be difficult for a foreigner not involved in the Palestinian cause to share the emotions at work here. But they become easier to understand when you meet someone from your own profession who has suffered. Earlier this week I was in Yemen to help with a training workshop for Yemeni journalists. During a coffee break one of them mentioned, quite casually, that he had been imprisoned three times. It left me feeling that there was probably no way I could show him enough respect. And wondering whether, in his position, I might not be tempted to give up journalism and open a grocery store instead. * Imagined Masculinities: Male Identity and Culture in the Modern Middle East. webTitle: How director Andrzej Wajda inflamed a nation

fields.headline: Patriot games
fields.standfirst: Ten million Poles - including the Pope - have seen Andrzej Wajda's patriotic epic Pan Tadeusz.  Kate Connolly  on how an old master inflamed a nation
fields.trailText: Ten million Poles - including the Pope - have seen Andrzej Wajda's patriotic epic Pan Tadeusz. Kate Connolly on how an old master inflamed a nation
fields.body:
'In a communist country," Andrzej Wajda once said, "a young person has three choices: if he was lucky, he could leave. If he was cunning, he could enter politics. Barring these, he could become a priest or a movie director." Luckily for the cinematic world in general, and for Poland in particular, Wajda opted for film.

At this year's Oscar ceremony, the 75-year-old director, often regarded as the father of modern Polish film, finally got the recognition he deserved for a magnificent career spanning more than four decades and more than 40 films, receiving a special Oscar for lifetime achievement. The award came just a few months after the release of his most recent film, Pan Tadeusz, an elegant 19th century costume drama which has stunned critics and Polish cinema-goers alike. At the latest count, around 10m Poles - including the Pope, who sent Wajda his congratulations - had been to see Pan Tadeusz, a staggering 25% of Poland's population.

Wajda's film is a daring attempt to adapt the most venerated poem in the Polish literary canon. Adam Mickiewcz's Pan Tadeusz is a national epic written in Paris in the mid-19th century, at a time when Poland had been wiped off the political map. Even now it brings tears to the eyes of any Pole asked to recite a stanza from it (a sample: "My homeland /You are like health /Your value is only recognised by he who loses you"). In many ways, Pan Tadeusz is the perfect storyboard for a film, including threads of crime, passion, betrayal, jealousy and war. Its narrative is a complicated mesh of interwoven tales, but the basic plot tells a touching love story involving a young couple (Tadeusz, played in the film by the Brad Pitt of Poland, Michal Zebrowski) and Zosia (Alicja Bachleda-Curus) from two opposing families, set against the rising hopes that Napoleon will invade Russia and thus give back to Poland the independence it lost years earlier.

The poem contains huge digressions during which Mickiewicz waxes lyrical about the countryside, flying ants and mushroom-picking (a national passion to this day). But thankfully Wajda chose to condense his version to two and a half hours by focusing on the individual characters and their quarrels. Differences are more or less put aside when the compatriots realise they must pull together in order to help Napoleon achieve success. On one level it is as if Wajda has simply given Polish history the Merchant Ivory treatment and is presenting nothing more than slushy patriotism. But there's also a strong underlying darkness to it, as Wajda reinforces Mickiewcz's ridicule of the Poles for their fiery patriotism which obscures the long-term vision necessary for them to save their country.

Independence, as history records, was short-lived. "It's a great story that focuses on our national characteristics," Wajda maintains. "The Poles in Pan Tadeusz are the same as we are now: sometimes wise, sometimes stupid. It's basically a picture of how we are now and allows us to look at ourselves and see who we are and where we're going." These are pertinent points for a country which just over a decade ago received back its independence having tossed off the communist yoke, and now faces the uphill battle to assert itself in the new world order (including pushing for entry into the European Union), while at the same time trying not to lose sight of a sense of national identity. "It's a very good time to make it," says journalist Gregorz Mazurowski. "This is a time of transition for Poland, many émigrés are returning, and we have to remember who we are. Pan Tadeusz, you could say, is a little bit like Braveheart for the Scots."

Although likely to set the standards for historical dramas to come, Pan Tadeusz is not the first Polish film to appeal to a sense of national pride. It follows close on the heels of Jerzy Hoffmann's adaptation of Henryk Sienkiewicz's epic Ogniem i Mieczem (With Fire and Sword) which is also on the essential reading list. An estimated 7m Poles - twice as many as saw Titanic - have been to see Poland's answer to Gone with the Wind, and fallen in love with its computer-generated castles. Hoffmann describes the importance of home-grown movies, particularly for a nation that has spent so much of its history in a state of suppression. "No nation can afford to lose sight of its culture and its identity," he says. "Poles are longing to see their own national film made to the standards of the west."

At the entrance to Lodz film school - two hours south of Poland and still considered to be one of Europe's best - a plaque used to hang on the entrance, on which was inscribed Lenin's dictum: "Of all the arts, film is the most important to us." But here, in Lodz, Wajda is a Pole apart. Despite the critics' praise for Pan Tadeusz, the school's professors - contemporaries of Wajda, Polanski and Kieslowski - are sniffy about Wajda's efforts to put Polish history on the silver screen. "Frankly this commercialisation of films is not very Polish," says Professor Piotr Wojciechowski. "Okay, so Pan Tadeusz had to be made into a film, because it represents a stream of national consciousness, but it's not art - it's as if Wajda is repeating what he learnt in his Hollywood lectures." He adds that this unfortunate tendency will be over in "two to four years". Student Eugeniusz Hanemann, 30, agrees: "I think Mr Wajda made a mistake. But then again I'm biased - we don't like him because he tried to move the school to Warsaw."

The fact remains that few film-makers have remained as consistently committed to depicting their own nation's history and culture as Wajda. His personal history no doubt has a lot to do with it. During the second world war, he joined the resistance as a 16-year-old, after his father, a Polish army officer, was shot in the back of the head, along with some 90% of Poland's officer corps, at Katyn, Ukraine, on Stalin's orders. The communists blamed the massacre on the Nazis and many believed the lie for decades. Just two years after graduating, Wajda directed A Generation, his first professional film, but the one that was to herald the arrival of a new era of film-making in Poland and for which he'll be most remembered. Polanski, who worked with him on the film, says: "The whole of Polish cinema can trace its roots to it." With A Generation, Kanal (which won the jury prize at the Cannes film festival in 1957), and Ashes and Diamonds, which clinched the jury prize at Venice in 1958, Wajda put Polish cinema on the map with a trilogy of films about young Poles who are born in the shadow of fascism and fall victim to their nation's call for sacrifice.

Wajda spent much of his subsequent career battling censors, and in 1981 he was forced to move to France, only returning once Solidarity was legalised in 1989. His film legacy, including the Oscar-nominated Promised Land, set in Lodz, the anti-propagandist Man of Marble, and Man of Iron (about the rise of Solidarity, in which Lech Walesa plays himself), indicate that most Poles had lives equally as painful as Wajda's own and that, nevertheless, the nation managed to retain its identity. To his credit, even since the fall of communism, although many have said his talent is ebbing, Wajda has continued to make Poles think. Now that totalitarianism is over, he insists, his compatriots need to be provoked, not consoled. Pan Tadeusz, he admits, was the most difficult project of his career. But the hardest might be to come.

He is currently working on what he says will be his directorial swansong: a recreation of one of the greatest crimes of the 20th century, the Katyn massacre, in which his father died. The alleged perpetrators of the massacre are now battling to clear their names in the Polish courts. Production has not yet begun, but critics are already hailing it as Poland's most cathartic film.

 Pan Tadeusz has its British premiere tonight at the French Institute in London. Details: 020-7838 2144

fields.headline: The best bass player scene
fields.standfirst: This is Spinal Tap
fields.trailText: This is Spinal Tap
fields.body:
As part of his documentary on British legends Spinal Tap, film-maker Marty DiBergi (Rob Reiner) chats with the group about their treatment by the press.

"Let's talk about your reviews a little bit," says Marty, holding up an album by the band. "Regarding Intravenous De Milo: 'This tasteless cover is a good indication of the lack of musical invention within. The musical growth-rate of this band cannot even be charted. They are treading water in a sea of retarded sexuality and bad poetry.'"

The band fume silently. Guitarist Nigel Tufnell (Christopher Guest) shrugs.

"That's... that's just nit-picking, isn't it?"

Marty holds up a second album.

"The Gospel According To Spinal Tap: 'This pretentious, ponderous collection of religious rock psalms is enough to prompt the question - what day did the Lord create Spinal Tap, and couldn't he have rested on that day too?'"

Frontman David St Hubbins (Michael McKean) forces a smile.

"Never heard that one."

"That's a good one," nods bassist Derek Smalls (Harry Shearer). "That's a good one."

Marty picks up a third album.

"The review you had on Shark Sandwich - which was merely a two word review. Just said 'Shit sandwich.' Um..."

"Where'd they print that?" Derek demands.

"Where did that appear?" asks David.

"That's not real, is it?" exclaims Nigel.

Derek looks outraged.

"You can't print that!"

See also: Backbeat, Sid and Nancy, Some Like It Hot

Don't see also: Wayne's World

Pointless trivia: Christopher Guest is the fifth Baron Haden-Guest of Saling.

fields.headline: Big is beautiful
fields.standfirst: It was once hailed as, quite literally, the biggest thing ever to hit cinemas. But Imax never really caught the public imagination. Now, that's all changing - and everybody wants a slice of the action.  Meg Carter reports
fields.trailText: It was once hailed as, quite literally, the biggest thing ever to hit cinemas. But Imax never really caught the public imagination. Now, that's all changing - and everybody wants a slice of the action. Meg Carter reports
fields.body:
Champions of the world's largest film format, Imax, are confident that next week's UK release of CyberWorld, a 3D animation extravaganza with stars from Antz and The Simpsons, will further place the medium on a viable commercial footing. Despite this and the opening of three new British Imax cinemas in coming months, the acceptance of Imax into the movie mainstream still has some way to go.

Imax has been around since 1970, when the company behind it, Imax Corporation, developed a new, giant-screen feature film format. It uses film 10 times larger than a conventional 35mm frame and three times bigger than standard 70mm. This, combined with unique Imax projection technology, delivers images of unsurpassed size, clarity and, aficionados insist, impact.

Accompanied by state-of-the-art multi-speaker sound systems, Imax films are projected onto screens 20 metres high by 26 metres across - the size of five double-decker buses. Due to its particular specifications, however, Imax requires films to be shot and produced in a particular way.

You can't just shoot footage on any old format and transfer it into large format - although this might be possible in the future. For now, large-format films must be shot using large-format equipment and with specially designed giant film stock.

Resembling a fridge on a tripod and as noisy as a vacuum cleaner, an Imax camera needs re-loading after just a few minutes. Yet despite this, hundreds of films have been shot in Imax since the format's launch. And last year more than 75 million people visited an Imax theatre worldwide.

Since the mid-90s, Imax Corporation has invested heavily in international expansion. It's opened hundreds of Imax theatres around the world. And it's developed further innovations with Imax technology such as Imax 3D, and "stereo animation" which allows animators to draw and animate freehand in 3D space.

Without doubt the main appeal of Imax is, quite literally, the spectacle. An Imax film is larger than life - a true movie-going "experience". Which explains the fact that, for many years, the majority of Imax films were factual, made for a specific venue, such as a museum or visitor centre, or for theme park rides.

This has changed, however, with growth in the number of commercial Imax cinemas, says Dennis Laws, technical manager at the BFI London Imax cinema. "Established producers and studios have woken up to the potential of shooting in Imax," he says. "With 280 Imax cinemas now worldwide, it's more appealing - and commercially viable - to make Imax films."

So, Disney produced Fantasia 2000 for Imax. CyberWorld, a potpourri of computer-animated short films, is backed by DreamWorks, 20th Century Fox and Sony Pictures Imageworks. DreamWorks, meanwhile, recently confirmed plans to release an Imax 3D version of its next animated feature, Shrek, in December 2001. Even the BBC is getting in on the act, currently making an Imax film about the human body.

"As a film-maker, Imax is the pinnacle - it's filming the best you can ever get it, on a 90-foot screen, at 70mm resolution and in stereo," says Ian Bird, creative director of London-based Eye Animation Studios which produced the Liberation sequence in CyberWorld.

"Even though it's been around a while, I believe Imax will become the main theatrical experience for film in the future," he adds. "It's more intimate and personal, for some reason. And its potential for stirring narrative is starting to be realised." A case in point is recent Imax production Loch Lomond: Legend of the Loch, made by British company Principal Large Format, which was acclaimed at last month's Giant Screen Theatre Association convention in Frankfurt for demonstrating the true narrative potential of Imax.

A key issue, however, will be at what point Imax films graduate from their standard 45-minute duration to 90 minutes-plus. A key reason for their shorter length is the format's documentary heritage, Laws says. Another is caution over production costs. The economics of making an Imax movie are very different to conventional film-making. They have a far longer shelf life, for a start - which is just as well given that it can take years for investors to see a return.

"Traditionally, the box office split is less favourable to the film-maker than in conventional film-making," explains Lock London producer Phil Streather, director of Principal Large Format. "For Imax, the box office pays for prints and advertising so the return to the distributor/film-maker is far less - perhaps $15m on $100m gross." Typically, just one third of an Imax film's production budget comes from equity funding, with the balance usually comprising scientific grants and sponsorship - AOL, Saab and Yahoo are among companies which have backed the format.

The extent to which the growing interest of big studios will affect what remains, in effect, a cottage industry remains to be seen. As does how far commercial interests push Imax into narrative storytelling. Until both issues are resolved, however, it will be difficult, irrespective of hype, to justify claims that Imax has finally gone mainstream.

 CyberWorld is released on Friday October 20

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Erin Brockovich | Permanent Midnight | In Too Deep
fields.trailText: Erin Brockovich | Permanent Midnight | In Too Deep
fields.body:
Erin Brockovich
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 15
****

A whole new Julia Roberts and unlike some previous whole new Julia Robertses (the dowdy maid in Mary Reilly, say), this is a makeover that works. Her version of the real-life Erin Brockovich is an angry woman on a mission - a stroppy, Wonderbraed, mini-skirted, twice-divorced mother of three.

The hitherto omnipresent smile is entirely absent, the fluffy vulnerability gets nary a look-in. It's undeniably a star vehicle - Roberts is hardly ever offscreen - but it's one where the star is changed to fit the part, not the reverse. With careful direction from Steven Soderbergh, a good line in sassy dialogue from Susannah Grant's sparky script and enjoyable bluff support from Albert Finney, this is both a significant story and a thoroughly entertaining one to watch.

It's a departure too for Soderbergh and for Aaron Eckhart, a loathsome misogynist in Neil LaBute's In the Company of Men, an impossibly sweet-natured biker boyfriend here. The villain is big business, this time PG&E, whose shocking misbehaviour, with the dogged activities of Ms Brockovich, won a $333m award - big bucks before Anna Nicole Smith went to court.

Permanent Midnight
Rental and DVD (£19.99)
Columbia Tristar Cert 18
***

A trawl through the memoirs of a Hollywood junkie, told largely in flashback. It's superior straight-to-video material, enlivened by a highly believable performance by the versatile Ben Stiller.

Anyone with even a tangential knowledge of a serious drug abuser will recognise the endless bouncing between Planet Earth and Planet Junk and the bullshit that goes with a world where the fix trumps everything else in life. Stiller's strung-out rant for a prospective TV puppet show ("I see Mr Choppers as a modern-day Tom Joad") is wonderfully funny and, like much else, rings true.

Subsisting initially on a green-card marriage to Liz Hurley, Stiller's character becomes increasingly unhinged as the $5,000 a week scriptwriter with a $6,000 a week habit. In conclusion, Stiller is replaced by lookalike and real-life autobiographical writer Jerry Stahl, seen telling his story on confessional TV chat shows. Ann Widdecombe won't be renting it, but ultimately, this is a strongly anti-drug film.

In Too Deep
rental
Metrodome Cert 18
**

Once more unto the hood, and drugs are again at the root of a plot which sees undercover cop Omar Epps in dangerous pursuit of the local Cincinnati Mr Big known as "God" (LL Cool J). "You've got to find a street character or invent one to hide behind," Epps is told by his police connection, Stanley Tucci. The plot is about how far you can immerse yourself in an invented personality without becoming it. It was done more inventively in Deep Cover, but it's played with conviction here.

webTitle: Focus on Michael Reeves, the short-lived genius

fields.headline: How Michael Reeves made it to Hollywood on the back of his mother's tea trolley
fields.standfirst: At the age of 11, he shot his first movie. At the age of 23, he filmed his masterpiece. At the age of 24, he was dead.  Will Hodgkinson  on the British prodigy with a genius for the low-budget, make-do movie
fields.trailText: At the age of 11, he shot his first movie. At the age of 23, he filmed his masterpiece. At the age of 24, he was dead. Will Hodgkinson on the British prodigy with a genius for the low-budget, make-do movie
fields.body:
Great directors don't always have great careers. The British film-maker Michael Reeves made only three films, between 1966 and 1968: The She-Beast, The Sorcerers, and Witchfinder General, his masterpiece. A year after making Witch-finder General, he died aged just 24, but left the world with three imaginative, low-budget movies, which - in their own modestly ambitious way - are superb examples of a very British type of cinema.

Reeves's love of film started young. At the age of eight, he announced to his mother that he wanted to be a film director; three years later, he made his first film, Carrion, which starred his friend Ian Ogilvy as a psychotic who attacks a girl in a wheelchair. Another regular Reeves collaborator, the writer Tom Baker, worked on the film, too. "He didn't just want to make films, he wanted to make Hollywood movies," Baker recalls now. "So we had to learn how to track. For this we used his mother's tea trolley with an 8mm Bolex on top."

Reeves and his mother were the poor relations of a rich family, and inherited money when Reeves was 15. He used the opportunity to take himself off to Hollywood at 17, and meet his hero, the action director Don Siegel. Somehow Reeves discovered where Siegel lived, and turned up on his doorstep, where the bewildered director appeared in a string vest and underpants. "I've come all the way from England to meet you because you are the greatest director that ever lived," Reeves told him, and promptly found work in town.

A year later he had convinced the producer Paul Maslansky to work with him on his own film, The She-Beast, to be shot in Rome and starring Ogilvy in his first major role. Reeves's goal was to make a scary movie, but cheap sets and corny lines made it obvious that nobody was going to be too scared by this tale of young holidaymakers terrorised by a monstrously deformed witch who comes back from the dead. So they camped it up instead. Made for £15,000, The She-Beast remains notable for making a leading lady of the already legendary horror film icon Barbara Steele, although she was booked for only a single day. "I managed to get her for $1,000 for one day's work," Maslansky recalls, "but I didn't say how long that day was. I made her work for 18 hours. She didn't speak to me for 20 years."

Having cut his horror teeth on The She-Beast, Reeves returned to England to make The Sorcerers, a brilliant forerunner of Being John Malkovich in which an old couple, Boris Karloff and Catherine Lacey, invent a machine that allows them to live vicariously through a dissolute young man (Ian Ogilvy, naturally). In an allegory for the vicarious thrills of cinema itself, the old couple's fun starts off innocently enough, with Ogilvy hanging out with groovy chicks and imbibing soft drinks at various swinging nightclubs, but slowly the old woman gets carried away and makes the young hipster carry out a series of increasingly gruesome acts.

A moral forewarning of the dangers of a thrill-seeking lifestyle, The Sorcerers depicts an innocent time and makes it seem very sinister indeed, with nightclub scenes inevitably ending in bloodshed and various dolly birds - Susan George among them - coming to a grisly end.

The Sorcerers was made quickly, efficiently, and on next to nothing. "We blew up a Jaguar in Notting Hill without permission," Ian Ogilvy remembers. "The blast shattered windows for blocks around, then we ran like hell. We knew that if we didn't get the right shot within minutes, we'd be in jail for sure." Reeves had no problem with endangering the lives of his cast, either. He and Ogilvy filmed a motorbike scene on the M4 at 100mph. Ogilvy wore no helmet, Reeves was in the boot of a car with his camera, and he demanded that his leading man come closer and closer until he was within a metre of him.

Then came Witchfinder General. In essence an English western, it is a tale of violent revenge based on the life of Matthew Hopkins, one of Oliver Cromwell's witch-hunters, who is alleged to have ordered the death of 200 people between 1645 and 1646. Hopkins, played with great relish and twisted moral arrogance by Vincent Price, travels through the Suffolk countryside with his thuggish henchman John Stearne and murders the innocent, ostensibly to cleanse the land of evil - but in reality for profit, sexual favours, and the sheer hell of it. When he turns his wicked attentions on an old priest and his daughter, he incurs the wrath of the daughter's husband, a Cromwellian soldier played (naturally) by Ian Ogilvy, who rises up against the witchfinder's dark power. It is a brutal, shockingly violent film, yet beautifully shot, capturing - with panoramic tracking shots - the rolling English landscape under a Turneresque sky. It is an example of something hardly seen today: a uniquely British film that portrays the country's elegance as well as its oppressiveness.

As usual, it had limited financial resources. Extra funding came from American International Pictures, and with that came Vincent Price. Used to the comfort of Hollywood, this revered, veteran actor was sent by his studio to the wilds of cold, damp and misty Suffolk, and into the hands of an extremely wilful and very resourceful 23-year-old director. The story goes that a short-tempered Reeves told Price to "stop over-acting, please, please, please, stop rolling your eyes, and try and look natural for once." An offended Price replied: "Young man, I've been in 84 films. How many have you made?" "Two good ones." At which Price burst into laughter and did exactly what the young man told him from then on. Price didn't even complain about the uncomfortable job of acting the final sequence, in which Ogilvy beats Hopkins to death with a hammer - rubber, but still rather painful for the ageing actor.

The film was shot over five weeks in Suffolk, using a single Arriflex camera, by cinematographer John Coquillon. The few sets used were built locally, and a disused second world war aircraft hangar (rented for £50 a week) was the production base.

Lighting came courtesy of Lee Electric, who provided a noisy generator free of charge. According to Coquillon: "Michael was 25 years ahead of his time, with the eye and the imagination of a veteran. I still wonder whether we ever worried our producers about our way of shooting Witchfinder. We were determined to make it our way and not in the conventional, accepted, boring (to us) ways of those times." According to Ogilvy, such conditions helped create great cinema: "[Reeves's] ability to make do is what makes his films so interesting. How to get over a bad situation."

Upon release, Witchfinder General was a critical and commercial success, despite cuts by censors concerned by its violence. Reeves was quickly swamped with scripts, but rejected most of them outright, and fell into depression. Always secretly prone to the condition, he began drinking heavily and taking anti-depressants. "He would shut right down, maybe three to four months before he died," Witchfinder's writer, Tom Baker, remembers. After a couple of abandoned projects, Reeves came home one night after a skinful and had insomnia. The coroner's report states that he took a handful of anti-depressants and was found dead in the morning.

What Reeves might have gone on to achieve is hinted at by a letter from his old cinematographer Coquillon to the American director Jeff Burr, written in 1983. Coquillon recalls a telephone conversation with Reeves when he was in Los Angeles, shortly before he died. "One day he called me full of excitement. He'd found the story. We were going to ride around the US, shoot in 16mm and shoot every which way, into the sun and out of the sun - on motorcycles. The actor was to be a long-time LA buddy - a completely unknown son of an actor - name of Peter Fonda. The film was to be called Easy Rider. It was while planning this movie that Michael Reeves died. I still mourn the man and miss him. Always will. One doesn't get to meet many people like him."

 Witchfinder General and Blood Beast: The Films of Michael Reeves will be screened at the Cornerhouse, Manchester on October 21 as part of the Britain in Darkness season. Details: 0161-200 1500

fields.headline: Sex, lies and certificates
fields.standfirst: Hubert Selby Jr gets into trouble with the censors and  Paula Jones joins parade of stripping female celebrities
fields.trailText: Hubert Selby Jr gets into trouble with the censors and Paula Jones joins parade of stripping female celebrities
fields.body:
What is it about the famously meek and mild Hubert Selby Jr that turns civic bluenoses green at the gills? In the mid-60s his first novel, Last Exit to Brooklyn, was the subject of a famous British obscenity trial that fell midway between Lady Chatterley and the Oz "Schoolkids issue". Despite the fact that the cream of the British literary aristocracy trooped through the courtroom to defend Selby's merits, the book was first banned, then unbanned on appeal a year later - all this notoriety guaranteeing its publishers a runaway bestseller.

There was no such equivalent palaver when Last Exit was filmed in the late 80s - with Jennifer Jason Leigh in the, um, "difficult" role of Tralala, a hooker who is multiply, horribly raped outside a bar - and was released without incident. But 35 years later, we seem to have moved no further into the future. The US ratings system seems as ossified as the 60s obscenity laws. Requiem for a Dream, Selby's 1978 junkie novel, has been filmed by Darren Aronofsky, who debuted with Pi a couple of years ago.

Requiem has intentionally been released without a ratings certificate in the US, a strategy aimed at avoiding the Motion Picture Association of America's NC-17 rating. The NC-17 appellation was developed as an alternative to the old X rating - which was indelibly associated with hardcore porn - to distinguish non-pornographic adult movies from mere masturbation fodder. Most non-metropolitan American newspapers refused to carry advertising for X ratings and, far from drawing distinctions between X and NC-17, they have merely assumed that one means exactly the same as the other. In short, the NC-17 rating is now rightly seen as a stigma that kills movies at the box office.

The distributors, Artisan Entertainment, claim they've been the victim of the recent clashes between Washington politicians and Hollywood studio heads over sex and violence in movies. Exhibitors at two cinema chains in New York have demanded that Artisan's ads and posters specify that no one under the age of 17 will be admitted - even though underage moviegoers aren't usually barred from unrated films. "We agree with the request being made of us," says Artisan chief Amir Malin, "but we are very concerned about the precedent this sets."

"I think this decision by our exhibitors is a dark harbinger of a cold climate of censorship that's blanketing this nation," added Requiem's producer Eric Watt this week. "The really disturbing aspect of this decision is that morally bankrupt studio films will continue to be released unscathed due to their financial and political muscle, while independent films dealing with powerful themes are going to be scapegoated."

The MPAA has officially rated Requiem as NC-17 - but Artisan in effect repudiated the verdict by risking an unrated release, partly because the rating was based not on any violent content, but on "explicit sexual content", in particular a scene in which a pimp forces a woman to have sex with a hooker before a roomful of men. At a time when even hidebound British movie censors have declared that sex on screen - even hardcore sex - is no great threat to public morals, their American equivalents are still obsessed with drawing metaphorical figleaves over the naughty bits, even as they pass violent studio movies uncut. MPAA head Jack Valenti - who used to defend the Vietnam war as LBJ's press spokesman - is equally anxious to defend the now thoroughly discredited NC-17 rating despite, or perhaps even directly because of, debacles like last year's battle over South Park: Bigger, Longer and Uncut. Directors Trey Parker and Matt Stone used the ratings process and the resulting movie as a stick with which to beat Valenti's organisation. "Every time they asked us to cut something," said Stone, "we'd take it out and put in 10 things that were much worse - and they'd pass them without blinking."

Until the wildly unfair inconsistencies of the MPAA system are ironed out, we will continue to live in an upside-down moral universe in which nipples and pubic hair are deemed more threatening to the public good than machine-gun massacres and skipfuls of severed heads. "Mommy! That lady's pointing her fully loaded boobs at me! Wah!"

Pin-up Paula

You can understand why Pamela Anderson and Dr Laura Schlessinger might object when nudie pictures of themselves turn up on the internet for the titillation of one and all, but one really has to wonder at the willingness of many women stars and celebrities to disrobe for money in the pages of America's skin mags. The parade of stars who seek empowerment by taking control of their own bimbo-isation has been endless and now presidential accuser Paula Corbin Jones plans to appear nude in Penthouse.

You have to ask yourself if Jones - whose rhinoplasty operation will soon celebrate its second birthday - has even seen a copy of Penthouse recently. Chances are she thinks it's still a couple of degrees naughtier than Playboy's chaste and airbrushed sexual romper-room aesthetic. Wrong. Penthouse's Bob Guccione has - since the bitter "Pubic Wars" of the early 70s - always positioned himself beyond the Playboy pale. Opening a copy of US Penthouse today is like opening a hardcore magazine in 1975: photo layouts feature oral sex, penetration and ejaculations. This is all part of a little-remarked change in the men's sophisticate magazine market spearheaded by Larry Flynt in the early 90s, when he told his employees he wanted "more penetration!" (I used to toil for Flynt and this was one of many company meetings I attended with eyes popping, my chin on my chest). Now everyone's doing it - except Playboy.

So if Paula is expecting the hazy dreamworld that enfolded Gennifer Flowers when she stripped for Hef, she needs to think again, given the relentlessly gynaecological focus of the Penthouse lens. No doubt we can also expect a retelling of her tawdry dealings with Bubba Clinton (if indeed there were any), and further discussion of the presidential member. The dividing line between "empowerment" and voluntary degradation seems to have disappeared completely.

Is it only a matter of time before Hillary gets 'em off?

Pin-up Paula You can understand why Pamela Anderson and Dr Laura Schlessinger might object when nudie pictures of themselves turn up on the internet for the titillation of one and all, but one really has to wonder at the willingness of many women stars and celebrities to disrobe for money in the pages of America's skin mags. The parade of stars who seek empowerment by taking control of their own bimbo-isation has been endless and now presidential accuser Paula Corbin Jones plans to appear nude in Penthouse. You have to ask yourself if Jones - whose rhinoplasty operation will soon celebrate its second birthday - has even seen a copy of Penthouse recently. Chances are she thinks it's still a couple of degrees naughtier than Playboy's chaste and airbrushed sexual romper-room aesthetic. Wrong. Penthouse's Bob Guccione has - since the bitter "Pubic Wars" of the early 70s - always positioned himself beyond the Playboy pale. Opening a copy of US Penthouse today is like opening a hardcore magazine in 1975: photo layouts feature oral sex, penetration and ejaculations. This is all part of a little-remarked change in the men's sophisticate magazine market spearheaded by Larry Flynt in the early 90s, when he told his employees he wanted "more penetration!" (I used to toil for Flynt and this was one of many company meetings I attended with eyes popping, my chin on my chest). Now everyone's doing it - except Playboy. So if Paula is expecting the hazy dreamworld that enfolded Gennifer Flowers when she stripped for Hef, she needs to think again, given the relentlessly gynaecological focus of the Penthouse lens. No doubt we can also expect a retelling of her tawdry dealings with Bubba Clinton (if indeed there were any), and further discussion of the presidential member. The dividing line between "empowerment" and voluntary degradation seems to have disappeared completely. Is it only a matter of time before Hillary gets 'em off?

webTitle: Polly Toynbee on the Tories' pension policy

fields.headline: Tory shufflers
fields.standfirst:
The Conservatives are manipulating their pension figures and the elderly are getting wise to the tricks

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Conservatives are manipulating their pension figures and the elderly are getting wise to the tricks
fields.body:
The Conservative's pension policy is just about to be blown out of the water - from a most surprising quarter. Indeed, Labour sounds almost as surprised themselves. Saga magazine is about to publish the results of an opinion poll of its readers asking which party's pension policy is best. Saga magazine has more than a million pensioner readers, most of them likely to be natural conservatives since their readership is largely more affluent ABC1s. After the policy of each party was explained carefully, 5,000 Saga readers resoundingly rejected the Tory plan, by 72% against to 28% in favour.

This is the Tory plan: William Hague says he will match whatever Labour promises and add an "extra" £3.50 too. This "extra" comes from taking the £150 winter fuel payment, the £10 Christmas bonus and the £104 television licence for over-75s, and spreading it all out over the year instead. There would also be a real 42p a week more, raised by taking money from the social fund for the destitute and axing the new deal for lone parents. Adding in the £2.25 inflation uprating the government will pay out automatically next April, Hague claims a total of £5.75 more.

When it was revealed to be only 42p new money, the Tories replied sententiously that it was a question of dignity: the old wanted to save or spend their money themselves and not have it paid in lump sum "gimmicks". Tories say that wherever they go pensioners say they want their money paid by the week: Labour says pensioners tell them they like their lump sums. All the same, until today Labour was worrying that pensioners might be fooled by this Tory sleight of hand - giving them back their own money.

But in this poll overwhelmingly more pensioners wanted to keep their bonuses. The Tory's 42p is even more of an insult than the government's ill-fated 75p uprating this year. "Mr Hague will have to think of something better than this," said a reader from Reading who is a Conservative party member. "The fuel allowance and TV licence saves us a lot of worry," said a widow from Birmingham.

What's more, many had immediately understood the devilish complexity of the apparently simple Tory plan. Currently these lump sums are not taxed, but they would be for better-off pensioners once it was all rolled into the pension. The Tories hastened to say they would make sure tax thresholds were raised so that no one would be worse off.

But the number of losers keeps on growing. One and half million men aged 60 to 64 will have their winter fuel payments taken away altogether under the Tory plan. So will a number of women who never paid enough NI contributions to qualify for the full pension. On top of that, the Saga poll unearthed all kinds of new anomalies and anxieties. One man whose pension contributions only qualify him for 69% of the basic pension complains that he would only get 69% of his winter fuel allowance returned to him under the Tories. A Mrs H from Hampshire is in the council tax trap many others would face: "If my pension was increased by £3.50 a week the council would take back £2.98, leaving me 52p." Again as each new problem arises, the Tories hasten to say they'll sort it all out. But many Saga pensioners didn't trust the Tories not to claw it back: "Better money in the hand from Labour than promises in the bush from the Tories," said a pensioner from Chippenham.

Most of these 5,000 pensioners polled are unlikely to be natural Labour supporters. Not only are they mostly the more affluent, but Mori's last poll showed how although Labour had pulled ahead by two points among all voters, among pensioners they were still trailing three points behind. In general, pensioners are not inclining towards Labour and yet, however much they dislike Labour policy, this poll suggests they think the Tories' even worse.

Labour remains wisely cautious. Its own focus groups suggest pensioners are fickle. This time of year, with their £150 just about to be paid, they are all for it. But come March they tend to have forgotten about it and want the money paid out weekly. What should the government do? The chancellor is out and about listening this week - to groups of hauliers, farmers, pensioners and single mothers, gauging their mood before his crucial pre-budget statement in three weeks' time.

After stormy scenes at the Labour party conference, Gordon Brown rushed to promise £90 for next April's minimum income guarantee (MIG), a great £12 jump for the poorest to the level recommended by Age Concern and the Commons Select Committee. He also let it be known that the basic pension will rise. "Transitional" arrangements until 2003's new pension credit provides an excuse for upping the universal pension. It could be as much as £5 more a week for rich and poor alike, plus the automatic inflation uprating of £2.25 - £7.25 for a single pensioner. Will that do the trick?

If the chancellor really wants to shoot the Tory fox, this is what he should do. In listening mode, he should ask pensioners which way they want their money paid. After comprehensive polling and consultation he should do whatever they want. If, as in the Saga poll, they really like things as they are, then the Tories are dead in the water. If, on the other hand, they say they do indeed want it paid weekly, then why not? Either way, the Tories are left without a policy. Considering this "listening" and "responsive" option, some worry it looks as though it is following not leading. But since its only a matter of distributing money already allocated, why not let them choose?

Apart from old Labourites in the unions who swung the conference vote for restoring the earnings link, the serious objection to Labour's policy is the half million who fail to claim the MIG: DSS research finds it's ignorance not pride. If they were found, opposition to targeting would fade away. Age Concern and Help the Aged were annoyed their help was not sought in the new Thora Hird-led campaign to find non-claimers. Why didn't the government give money to this huge network of volunteers? They could set up desks in every post office on pension day, approaching pensioners as friends where the Benefits Agency would look threatening. Alistair Darling is now scrambling to make it happen.

This Tory pension policy is just the first casualty of their impossibilist "more-spending-less-taxing" agenda. Now, unless they up their bid for the grey vote, that 42p will be hung round their necks. So at last grey power has arrived - each party obliged to outbid the other for the mighty 25% of votes cast by pensioners - and so an end is in sight to pensioner poverty. How far the ground has shifted in politics since 1997. Now each party has to promise more, and woe betide talk of cuts. On policy after policy, the Tories will be trounced by this healthy new mood.
