webTitle: Vauxhall aims for net gain in fresh car wars campaign

fields.headline: Vauxhall aims for net gain in fresh car wars campaign
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Vauxhall yesterday claimed to be the world's first car manufacturer to offer the entire range of its models for sale on the internet.
fields.body:
Vauxhall yesterday claimed to be the world's first car manufacturer to offer the entire range of its models for sale on the internet.

The initiative, to be launched on November 9, will offer even cheaper prices than those now available in showrooms as manufacturers slash prices to stimulate demand.

Vauxhall, the second biggest car seller in Britain with 13.5% of the new car market, yesterday followed the lead of Ford, the No 1, by cutting its list prices by between 4% and 12%.

The price of an Astra, Vauxhall's most popular model, will fall by an aver age 9%, while a Tigra 1.4i 16v will cost £11,900 compared with £13,400.

Nick Reilly, chairman and managing director, claimed to have outbid Ford by offering free AA breakdown assistance for all three years of its 60,000 mile warranty. Vauxhall said it will also give a free loan car if an owner's vehicle is off the road for more than 24 hours for warranty repairs.

Last week Ford cut list prices by between 5% and 13% and offered a free, three-year warranty in place of the current 12 months.

Its move triggered a price war among manufacturers, with struggling MG Rover following suit.

Vauxhall sold 1,200 units via its website, www.vauxhall.co.uk in the first 12 months out of annual sales of 300,000 but Mr Reilly said it planned a huge expansion, offering all models in all colours and specifications.

fields.headline: Urbanfetch pulls out of Britain
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: E-delivery service Urbanfetch dealt a fresh blow to the fragile business-to-consumer internet sector yesterday by announcing the closure of its UK operation, with the loss of 100 jobs.
fields.body:
E-delivery service Urbanfetch dealt a fresh blow to the fragile business-to-consumer internet sector yesterday by announcing the closure of its UK operation, with the loss of 100 jobs.

The US firm said it had not been able to make a profit from a service which guaranteed to deliver goods worth £5 or more to customers in the London area within an hour and free of charge. It said it would concentrate on its profitable business-to-business focused courier service, UrbanFetch Express, operating in New York.

Urbanfetch's retrenchment came a day after online CD retailer Boxman said it planned to file for liquidation. Boo.com and Clickmango lead a growing list of other online retailers that have struggled to develop viable business models.

"We stepped back and looked at our revenues and, market conditions being what they are, we regretfully decided to end the service in London," an Urbanfetch spokeswoman said. "This is not a question of a company going bust or staff not being paid, it was simply a rational attempt to move towards profitability. We would not rule out the possibility of re-entering the B2C market if conditions change."

Urbanfetch offers a range of foods, videos and consumer electronic goods, claiming 99% are delivered within an hour of being ordered.

Analysts have long questioned how the service would make money while heavy overheads included a large staff and fleet of delivery vans. Profit margins were thought to have been minimal and average spend around £25.

The website urbanfetch.co.uk will remain open for business until the end of next week to clear stock. Last night it was advertising reductions of 40%.

Urbanfetch raised $70m from US venture capital groups. Merger talks with New York competitor Kozmo recently collapsed after the two firms failed to agree on a business-to-consumer strategy for the enlarged group.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Amazon bandits seize foreigners
fields.body:
Amazon bandits seize foreigners

Armed bandits in Ecuador yesterday seized a helicopter with 10 foreigners aboard, from an oilfield in the Amazon jungle.

Ecuador's vice-president, Pedro Pinto, said six Americans, a Chilean, two Frenchmen and an Argentine were taken.
AP, Quito

Car bomb kills 15 in Chechnya

A car bomb outside a police station in the Chechen capital, Grozny, killed 15 people yesterday, reports said. More than a dozen people were hurt, and the death toll could rise.

The station was said to be where Russian passports were issued to Chechens.
Reuters, Moscow

Sharif wife held in Pakistan

The wife of Nawaz Sharif, the Pakistani prime minister overthrown by the army, was said by her spokesman to be under house arrest as part of a crackdown on people protesting at the first anniversary of army rule.

Rashid Latif said Kulsoom Sharif had been confined since Wednesday at the home of a party official in Rawalpindi. Scores of other activists were also rounded up.
AP, Islamabad

webTitle: India's ex-leader gets jail term for bribing MPs

fields.headline: India's ex-leader gets jail term for bribing MPs
fields.trailText: A sentence of three years in jail for bribery was passed yesterday against India's former prime minister, PV Narasimha Rao.
fields.body:
A sentence of three years in jail for bribery was passed yesterday against India's former prime minister, PV Narasimha Rao.

Rao's lawyer said he would be appealing in the high court in Delhi next month against the sentence and the earlier conviction - the first time an Indian prime minister has been found guilty in a criminal case.

Bail was granted to Rao, 79, who was caught out bribing MPs to support his Congress party government in a crucial vote of no confidence seven years ago. A former cabinet colleague, Buta Singh, was also given a three-year sentence for his part in the vote-buying scandal, but he was unrepentant. "If I got the chance I would do it again," he said.

Rao was driven away from court without comment but a former associate said last night: "You must remember, Rao was not the first Indian prime minister to be guilty of corruption, merely the first one to be caught."

The Congress party tried last night to dissociate itself from the affair, saying the sentence was not a verdict on the party but only on Rao.

A packed courtroom heard how Rao had paid $800,000 (£545,000) to four MPs belonging to a small regional party in return for their sup port before the knife-edge vote in July 1993. The MPs hid the money in personal and party bank accounts, and Congress held on to power until 1996.

A case was lodged against Rao four years ago when one of the MPs decided to give evidence in return for immunity from prosecution. Rao was eventually convicted last month.

Rao's lawyers argued on Wednesday, before sentence was passed, that because of their client's age, failing health and long contribution to public life he should be treated leniently.

But prosecutors demanded an exemplary punishment and pointed out that "deceptively respectable members of society" had committed the crime. In the end, the sentence - for criminal conspiracy, corruption and bribery - was a compromise. Rao could have received up to seven years.

The judge, Ajit Bharihoke, also fined Rao and Singh 100,000 rupees (£1,500) yesterday and called for India's Central Bureau of Investigation to examine the role played by the three MPs who made no immunity deal.

The jail sentence means the end of Rao's political career. A classic backroom politician, he was propelled into the prime minister's job after Rajiv Gandhi was assassinated in 1991. One of his successes was the liberalisation of the economy.

fields.headline: Missing children haunt Salvador
fields.standfirst: Campaigners are pressing for army units to be brought to justice for their civil war atrocities against the very young
fields.trailText: Each morning Jose Serrano greets the children in the poster that he has stuck on the bare brick wall of his now empty hut.
fields.byline: Tom Gibb  in Chalatenango, El Salvador
fields.body:
Each morning Jose Serrano greets the children in the poster that he has stuck on the bare brick wall of his now empty hut.

"To my mind," says the 65-year-old man, pointing at one of the girls, "she is my girl, Norberta. She was 10, with a little round face and a small nose. And this one behind? I'm sure he's my boy."

Ever since he was forced to abandon his children 18 years ago, Mr Serrano has been surrounded by their ghosts. The faces in the poster are not his children's, but he imagines they are. He hears their voices on the paths of El Salvador's northern hills.

"Sometimes I hear them shouting," he says. "It makes me long to see them; they are always in my mind."

Before the civil war, Mr Serrano was a father of six. Today, he is alone, sustained only by a growing hope that some of his children might still be alive.

His family was one of thousands destroyed by a policy of the US-backed Salvadoran army to murder and abduct the children of potential guerrilla supporters - the full horror of which is only now emerging.

Ideological cleansing on a large scale, it was a policy designed to prevent the time bomb of a new generation growing up "indoctrinated with communism". As a result, thousands of children were murdered, put in orphanages, given away or sold for adoption abroad.

Today, a growing campaign has traced missing Salvadoran children as far away as Europe, the US and Canada.

Jose's story is typical of those who lost their loved ones. In May 1982, he and his four youngest children were caught in the closing net of a scorched-earth operation by 10,000 government troops.

His pregnant wife and two eldest sons had already been killed. Jose knew that the soldiers would murder all adults but he had also heard that small children found alone were sometimes spared and taken away in helicopters. So, when the soldiers caught them at the bottom of a steep creek, he took a decision which he has agonised over ever since: he ducked and ran from the bullets, leaving his children behind.

A week later, villagers found the corpse of his eldest daughter, 12, by the creek. But there was no sign of the others, giving Jose hope that they might still be alive.

Jose Serrano is not the only person haunted by the ghosts of children. Rodolfo, who asked for his identity to he hidden, is a former soldier who was trained at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, and fought throughout the 12-year war.

Rodolfo took part in the dragnet in which Mr Serrano lost his children and was among the first former Salvadoran soldiers to break the army's code of silence. Testimony like his, unheard of in El Salvador, is potentially explosive in a state which has tried to bury its past.

At the start of the war, in 1980 and 1981, Rodolfo says, orders came from the high command that, in rebel areas, "not even the fleas on a dog should remain alive".

"The children would have their throats slit, strangled or shot," says Rodolfo. "Most did not like killing children. But a few volunteered: they enjoyed it."

The rationale was to stop the children growing up to become guerrillas. But the killing started to play on the soldiers' minds. "At the massacre sites we would hear the cries and laments of children," Rodolfo says. "But when we looked, there was nothing there. It was their ghosts."

Worried about troop morale some commanders started to spare the youngest. Some were put in orphanages or given away. But others would be sold for adoption. Troops had the right to take one or two each - a type of war booty. "They could fetch $10,000 [£6,800] each," Rodolfo says.

Mr Serrano's hopes that his children are alive are sustained by continual stories in the local newspapers of children found alive - and their emotional reunions with their real parents.

A Jesuit priest, Father Jon Cortina, first started the search for missing children when the war ended in 1992. He founded a group called Pro Busqueda ("in favour of searching") after hearing stories such as Mr Serrano's in the mountains where he worked with peasant communities.

"At the start we thought it would be a few dozen cases," says father Cortina, "but even now it's only the tip of the iceberg."

Forgive and forget?

The group now has almost 600 cases on its books. It has located more than 70 children in El Salvador and abroad, some of whom were being raised by the army officers who killed their families.

Father Cortina and his group also wage a successful publicity campaign against the tacit deal at the end of the war to forget the past - convenient for the guerrilla chiefs, the army and its US backers, he says.

"Forgive and Forget," he says. "That's nonsense. How can you ask a mother to forget that her child was robbed. And forgive? Who are we supposed to forgive? Who has asked for it?"

Mr Serrano agrees with that. "The officers who ordered those things should be punished," he says. "They cannot just be pardoned and forgotten."

Father Cortina complains that, until now, the Salvadoran army has withheld records and not allowed officers to give testimony. But moves for a government inquiry could change all that.

Ex-soldiers such as Rodolfo, many of whom have vital information, say they would share it, and although he is afraid of reprisals, he is bitter that many of the top command who issued the orders have now been made US citizens.

Since the war, he has been tormented by nightmares and flashbacks. While he first tried to bury the past, he now believes it should be brought into the open.

"In my dreams," Rodolfo says, "I see dead people, I walk over their corpses. I believe it's a form of mental torture that I inflict upon myself, as if I am now passing judgment against myself."

For that, he says, former soldiers such as he should cooperate in the search for the missing children: "It would help the internal peace of all concerned."

webTitle: Plotting thickens in Mexico's living soap

fields.headline: Plotting thickens in Mexico's living soap
fields.trailText: Mexico is in the grip of a new chapter in the Salinas saga - a tale of power, corruption and family feuds, with characters Mexicans love to hate.
fields.body:
Mexico is in the grip of a new chapter in the Salinas saga - a tale of power, corruption and family feuds, with characters Mexicans love to hate.

The latest installment began last week when the former president Carlos Salinas, visited his homeland from self-imposed exile in Dublin. He used the visit to break his silence on the outgoing president, Ernesto Zedillo, who replaced him in 1994 just weeks before the climax of an economic crisis in the country.

Mr Salinas, a figure of hate in Mexico, is widely blamed for the crisis and the corruption in his administration - but his new memoirs claim all the fault lies with Mr Zedillo, whom he holds responsible for the recession and for guiding the Institutional Revolutionary party (the PRI) to defeat in elections in July this year after 71 years in power.

Mr Salinas also accuses his successor of waging a vicious campaign against the Salinas family. But many believe his book is motivated by bitter ness against Mr Zedillo for the imprisonment of his brother.

Raul Salinas is serving 27 years for murdering a leading PRI figure who had been married to a Salinas sister, Adriana. He is also under investigation on suspicion of stashing $90m (£62m) abroad while his brother was in power.

Carlos Salinas left Mexico at the weekend, but nobody believed the chapter was closed and, sure enough, the plot thickened on Tuesday when a taped argument between Raul and Adriana was broadcast on primetime news.

The initially friendly conversation degenerated as they discussed a TV interview in which Carlos Salinas denied knowing about the $90m.

"It was cowardice of Carlos not to defend me," said the voice identified as Raul. "It was the betrayal of a brother. I am going to tell everything ... when the moment comes."

Raul has since said he has no complaints about his brother's handling of the case, but the tape is causing a furore. Mr Zedillo, the main suspect for leaking it, is saying nothing.

webTitle: Families of dead nuns sue leaders

fields.headline: Families of dead nuns sue leaders
fields.trailText: Two former leading figures in the Salvadoran military appeared in court in Florida this week accused of being responsible for the murders of three American nuns and a social worker in El Salvador 20 years ago.
fields.body:
Two former leading figures in the Salvadoran military appeared in court in Florida this week accused of being responsible for the murders of three American nuns and a social worker in El Salvador 20 years ago.

The civil action is the latest attempt to bring to book US-based members of the Latin American military responsible for atrocities in Central and South America.

Jose Guillermo Garcia and Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova are accused of having ultimate responsibility for the murders of the four women in 1980. At the time, the two men held the positions of Salvadoran defence minister and director-general of the Salvadoran national guard, respectively. Both claim they did not give orders to have the women killed.

The women were stopped at a roadblock, abducted, raped and executed; their bullet-ridden bodies were found later.

After an international outcry, five soldiers were charged with the killings and jailed for 30 years in 1984. Some of them have since claimed they were acting under orders and that they had been told by a superior they could carry out the killings with impunity.

The women, Sister Maura Clarke, 51, Sister Ita Ford, 40, Sister Dorothy Kazel, 42, and social worker, Jean Donovan, 32, had been helping at a refugee centre. At the time, the military regarded sections of the church with deep hostility because religious leaders drew attention to the atrocities being carried out against civilians.

In an opening statement for the families on Wednesday, lawyer Bob Montgomery said the military had targeted the women because they were sympathetic to the peasants.

Bill Ford, the brother of Ita Ford and a New York lawyer, said he was convinced that the soldiers did not carry out the killings on their own initiative.

"There were clearly higher orders," he said.

webTitle: Ford moves to head off strike threat

fields.headline: Ford moves to head off strike threat
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: Ford yesterday moved to head off a threatened strike at its main Dagenham car plant by announcing a new diesel engine facility and around 300 more jobs at the Essex factory.
fields.body:
Ford yesterday moved to head off a threatened strike at its main Dagenham car plant by announcing a new diesel engine facility and around 300 more jobs at the Essex factory.

Its surprise initiative came at a meeting with union leaders who had called a series of mass meetings and a strike ballot over the US group's plans to end car production at Dagenham in early 2002.

It led some union sources to argue that the planned mass meetings and strike ballot had been put on ice, with talks with the company due to reconvene on November 2. "There's no way a strike can take place on the basis of this new company offer," they said.

The suorces said up to 150 more staff had applied for voluntary redundancy than the 1900 initially sought by the company, which is offering a minimum severance of £20,000 and up to £60,000 to leave.

But Tony Woodley, chief union negotiator, denied that the strike plans had been put on ice. "Far from it. The only thing that will make us cancel our plans is if our members say they are happy with Ford's measures and I don't think that will happen."

He added: "Yes, there were about 120 more volunteers this year when the first 1,500 left. But the fact remains that, with the 1,300 redundancies the company is now seeking, around 3,000 will have left the site within two years."

Ford's shrewd move was effectively to split workers at the engine facility from other production staff by offering them work at a brand new, hi-tech, dust-free,"clean room" to be built by 2002. It will build 900,000 diesel engines a year by 2004 compared with the current 650,000.

This and a series of other measures to relocate staff, Ford said, would reduce the planned job losses from 1900 to 1300 and Dagenham would still employ more than 5,000 when the assembly-line closes.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Bud Light ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Bud Light ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad:
A cool American bloke is lying on his sofa in a funky US-style apartment, watching a game of baseball on the TV. His phone goes. "Wassup?" he says nonchalantly. "What are you doing?" Other mates begin to intercept the call, either via his flat's intercom or call-waiting on his phone, until they're all trading their gormless catchphrase across the room and down the line. The ad reaches a ridiculously laddy "Wassup" crescendo, then comes back down to earth with the first guy who just coolly says "Watchin' the game, havin' a Bud..."

The jargon:
This commercial, based on an original short film, debuted in America in December 1999 and even won the top prize at the Cannes International Advertising Festival in June. Rather than positioning Bud against rival beers or talking specifically about the brand, it's simply trying to connect with its target audience, providing them with a blokey piece of tribal code or catchphrase they can adopt.

Personality:
You're an 18-24-year-old male. You work hard so you can play with your mates, drink beer (Bud), play footie and talk (if not have) sex.

You're into looking good and having something funny to say.

Financial status:
Bud spans all social categories, but is primarily targeted at BC1C2s. However, you could possibly be on the A-list or only earning around £90 per week.

Telling lifestyle detail:

You don't take life too seriously yet, so your role models are more likely to be cool young Americans than the chiselled, square-jawed Greek gods in traditional male-oriented ads.

Other relevant data:
Having stormed America, "Wassup" has truly entered the UK vernacular since the ad launched here in September. TV presenters have used it, Budweiser brewer Anheuser-Busch's switchboard has been jammed with jokers screaming "Wassup", while Arsenal footballer Thierry Henri even screamed "Wassup" into the crowd when he scored against Man United on Saturday.

fields.headline: No: 1740
fields.standfirst: Radiohead
fields.trailText: Radiohead
fields.body:
Age:
Nearly 10.

Appearance:
Gaunt, haunted, moist-eyed, fragile, red-haired. Actually, that's just vocalist Thom Yorke, but nobody really notices the other three. Sorry, four.

They've been around for a while. Done anything good?
Only made the Greatest Album in the History of Music, according to a recent industry poll. That was OK Computer, their 1997 despair-ridden, guitar-laden, pop cliche-busting, seminal record, and the best thing since 1995's "not quite the best album ever, but certainly in the top five", The Bends.

Blimey. How do you top that?
By releasing a bizarre collection of electronic "tunes", with a miserly scraping of guitars, a whispering of incomprehensible lyrics, and a refusal to allow any of the tracks to be put out as singles. And by calling it Kid A, thus exciting your fans with the prospect of an alphabetic anthology of 26 similar albums. And then launching it straight to the top of the US album charts this week, the first British artists to do so since the Prodigy back in 1997.

Ah, the twisted firestarters. You know where you are with those lyrics.
I'll let you into a secret: prise away the plastic bed that holds your Kid A CD (bought at midnight on the day of release, naturally) and you'll find a bonus booklet crammed with disturbing doodles and randomly assembled words. These are the lyrics. But keep it quiet.

Some cynics have claimed that the lyrics are directed with venom towards the curator of Cool Britannia himself.

You mean: "He says he wants to be our friend, he says he's always been on our side. Tough choices with difficult decisions that you really wouldn't understand"?
Well, there is that. And the cartoon of a Blair-like creature with a fanged smile and red eyes. And the support for Ann Widdecombe's cannabis policy.

Really?
No.

Least likely to:
Air-kiss at No 10.

Most likely to:
Cry.

fields.headline: American psychos
fields.trailText: The Sopranos | Fat Friends
fields.body:
Why can't this family just get along?"

- Meadow Soprano.

There was a floral tribute at the Kray funeral from The Boys In New York. Uh-huh. None was recorded from The Boys In New Jersey, who were unavoidably engaged at the time, bleeding over the scenery.

At the end of the first series, all the senior Sopranos had tried and failed to kill each other. You could not fault their energy or ingenuity. It was sheer bad luck. Livia ("Mommy Dearest") Soprano was in intensive care with a stroke brought on by pure rage at the failure of her labyrinthine plot to kill her son. Junior ("Mr Magoo") Soprano, the older-than-god godfather, was in jail. Only Tony ("I'm not fucking insane") Soprano was left standing.

I may have misheard a word or two. Listening to The Sopranos is like your first encounter with Rab C Nesbitt. You think you've gone deaf. After a while you can pick up the tune of it, even if you still miss some of the lyrics.

Uncles can come out of jail and mothers can come out punching. Which brings us, via the most spine-tingling opening titles on TV, to the second series of The Sopranos (C4). James Gandolfini got a well deserved, if overdue, Emmy for playing Tony Soprano in this series, and deserved a suitcase of used notes. It is an object lesson in acting to watch his eyes suddenly start to slide.

Tony's saving grace is his humour, or what "Big Pussy" Bompensiero calls his jokey shit. Pussy, whom we all feared was down a well, wisely went to Puerto Rico for his health and has returned looking, said Tony, like a tanned ghost. The Sopranos is ferociously funny and, of course, vice versa. Excessive ferocity is itself funny.

I have sometimes wondered what happened to the Romans. One day there they were, running the world, and the next they were making tutti frutti. So where did the Romans go? On this showing, New Jersey.

Livia, played by the irreplaceable Nancy Marchand who died in June, has the same name as the Empress Livia, matriarch of the more obviously insane Caesars. It is a name derived from the Latin word for malignity. Livia is probably the world's most trying mother-in-law. Tony's wife says, tolerantly, that she is a peculiar duck and the reason Tony needs extensive therapy. Unfortunately shrinks take to the hills when approached for a consultation, and even the deliciously cool Dr Jennifer Melfi is downright icy. Sometimes Tony's world seems to slow down like an old gramophone and close friends look treacherous...

"Cunnilingus and psychiatry brought us to this!" says Tony memorably. I would really like to explain this but I don't think I will.

With Livia defanged or deranged ("Let me die! I saw a light! Voices calling out to me!"), a new Soprano has joined the snake pit. Tony's sister, Janice, is a hippy who prefers to be known as Parvarti, a Hindu goddess. "Hey Parvarti, take it easy," says Tony as she smacks a passing fly. "According to you, that could have been Robert Mitchum." As goddesses go, Parvarti is not someone you would care to share a table with in an all-night cafe. She is associated with ferocity, destruction and strings of skulls. And don't act like you are amazed. You know you are not.

WARNING: Do not accept any social invitation immediately after watching an episode of The Sopranos. It is best to allow a full eight hours for the effects to disperse. Otherwise you will find yourself greeting quite old and valued friends with a fond "Come here you fat fuck!"

Which brings me smoothly to Fat Friends (ITV) by Kay Mellor - a short series about people in a slimming club. There is a quite distinctive feel about it. It is cosy, domestic, acutely observed, touching and looks dead easy. In the first episode (and the powerful company of Alison Steadman and Barrie Rutter), Ruth Jones was strikingly delightful as the overflowingly fat and sassy Kelly. We meet her failing to force herself into a flouncy wedding dress. It is, you feel, entirely the fault of the wedding dress for failing to get into the fun of things. Kelly's ebullience recalls Two Ton Tessie O'Shea, who used to sing bouncily to a disconcertingly small banjo: "There a little bit here and a little bit there and it all belongs to me."

There is a series of celebrity cameos during the series. One is Judy Finnigan.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: BSkyB has been instructed by the government to give undertakings to remedy competition concerns after its takeover of programme distributor British Interactive Broadcasting.
fields.body:
BSkyB taken to task

BSkyB has been instructed by the government to give undertakings to remedy competition concerns after its takeover of programme distributor British Interactive Broadcasting.

BSkyB must promise that its feeds of premium TV channels to rival distributors will be stripped of interactive elements to ensure that they work on other platforms, Kim Howells, the minister for consumer and corporate affairs, said.

Fiat pulls back over Daewoo

Fiat chairman Paolo Fresco said yesterday that the Italian group is interested in negotiating over only part of the assets of South Korea's troubled Daewoo motor company.

General Motors, the world's leading car manufacturer, confirmed on Monday that it, and its partner Fiat, were in talks to buy Daewoo's passenger vehicle assets and related business. GM has renewed its interest in Daewoo since Ford pulled out of negotiations last month.

Duke enters UK power market

American company Duke Energy is preparing to enter the British domestic market as a supplier of electricity. It is also considering buying generators and supplying energy to industrial customers.

Duke wants to be operating as a trader before the start of new electricity trading arrangements (Neta) scheduled to start next year.

"We want to be up and running for the start of Neta but we may start trading in the over-the-counter market before then," David Shipway, vice president of trading at Duke Energy International (Europe),said.

Duke, which has European offices in London and the Netherlands, started trading natural gas in Britain in August.

Vivendi looks at merger boost

Vivendi yesterday detailed anticipated cost savings and profit goals from its planned merger with Canada's Seagram, despite uncertainty that the deal will gain EC regulatory clearance today, as had been expected.

The French telecommunications, media and utilities group put out a set of figures for Vivendi Universal, the media and entertainment organisation it plans to form with Seagram and its own pay TV unit Canal Plus.

It said synergies would generate savings to add €420m (£252m) to its 2002 earnings before tax. Revenues would benefit from synergies to the tune of €200m in 2002 and over €400m in 2003.

US officials in 'e-trade' row

Some American economists believe the US government may be sliding into improper competition with private business in its use of electronic commerce.

In a study of a number of government activities commissioned by the Computer & Communications Industry Association - including online auctions of Defence Department surplus equipment - they found the activities could have an "anti-competitive effect".

webTitle: Body Shop plans assault on US

fields.headline: Body Shop plans assault on US
fields.trailText: Body Shop's French chief executive Patrick Gournay is targeting the US for expansion. The green cosmetics company, which yesterday announced flat first-half profits of £6.8m, is planning party-plan home sales, internet sales and an ambitious store opening programme.
fields.body:
Body Shop's French chief executive Patrick Gournay is targeting the US for expansion. The green cosmetics company, which yesterday announced flat first-half profits of £6.8m, is planning party-plan home sales, internet sales and an ambitious store opening programme.

Body Shop Direct - the party-plan arm of the company - has been thriving in the UK. Its sales leaped by 35% in the first half and it now accounts for 10% of turnover.

Next spring the company will also start selling on the web to American consumers through Body Shop Digital. "There are 60m online shoppers in the US, compared to 3m here," said Mr Gournay, "so it makes sense to start there".

He is also focusing on the 290-strong American store chain. Body Shop's main US rival Bath & Bodyworks has more than 2,000 US outlets and Mr Gourlay said: "We should have 1,000 stores in the US. The potential is huge".

Body Shop, founded by green campaigner Anita Roddick, had serious problems in the US, but Mr Gourlay says they are now back on track. "It is our biggest success story. We have now had nine consecutive periods of positive like-for-like sales growth and are in profit." In the first half of the year operating profits there leaped to £2.2m, compared to £600,000 a year ago.

But at the same time the strong pound has caused problems in Europe. Body Shop has been forced to support prices on the Continent to stop them getting out of line with rivals and that translated into a dip in profits equal to the gains made in the US. In the UK, profits were flat. The group, which operates from 1,700 stores worldwide, now generates more than 60% of its profits outside Britain.

The company said sales growth in the year to date was 6% with like-for-like sales, which exclude increases due to new space, up 2%.

Mr Gourlay said retail sales were being driven by new products. "We want 40% of our business from new products each year. Currently it is 37%, twice the level of two years ago." The shares added 1p to 99p.

webTitle: Go-Ahead ousts Connex for misery line franchise

fields.headline: Go-Ahead ousts Connex for misery line franchise
fields.trailText: One of the companies at the heart of the Paddington rail crash is to be awarded a 20- year franchise to operate services on the most crowded commuter network in Britain later this month.
fields.body:
One of the companies at the heart of the Paddington rail crash is to be awarded a 20- year franchise to operate services on the most crowded commuter network in Britain later this month.

The bus and rail group, Go-Ahead, has beaten the French-owned company Connex to secure the south central franchise for London suburban services from Sussex and Surrey.

Go-Ahead's award will be criticised, but it will produce nothing like the outcry if franchise holder Connex was reinstated against mounting public opposition about its service.

The franchise is to be awarded by the shadow Strategic Rail Authority, charged by the government to redraw Britain's rail map with a series of deals with rail companies in which the passenger is put first.

Go-Ahead runs several franchises, including Thameslink and Thames Trains, the company whose train collided head on with an inter-city express outside Paddington last year, killing 31 people and injuring more than 400. Thames has been criticised for poor driver training methods during the lengthy public inquiry.

The SSRA has been under scrutiny for allowing itself to get into a position where the final two bidders for the franchise, Go-Ahead and Connex, were both flawed. Connex, has one of the worst records on Britain's railways.

 The 25 train operating companies yesterday announced plans to equip guards with computers containing all timetables and fares.

fields.headline: At this price?  RJB Mining
fields.trailText: RJB Mining, Britain's biggest coal producer, hit an intractable wall of resistance on Wednesday when it called off takeover talks with Renco, the US conglomerate: its shares lost 27% of their value, ending the day at 46.5p, making the group run by Richard Budge worth just £67m.
fields.body:
RJB Mining, Britain's biggest coal producer, hit an intractable wall of resistance on Wednesday when it called off takeover talks with Renco, the US conglomerate: its shares lost 27% of their value, ending the day at 46.5p, making the group run by Richard Budge worth just £67m.

Just four years ago they hit a peak of 625p, valuing RJB at just under £900m, after the government initiated a series of measures, including a ban on new gas-fired power stations, to preserve coal's role in the nation's energy mix.

Ministers are now waiting for European Commission approval of a new £100m aid package for the coal industry designed to keep pits open. RJB stands to benefit by £70m after waving the stick of closures and job losses among its 8,000-strong mining workforce.

So, is the group worth backing as it goes it alone? Yesterday the shares staged a sort of comeback, gaining at various stages 10% before closing up 4p at 51p. That came on the back of a note from brokers Williams de Broe uprating the stock from hold to buy and a series of analysts' comments that the shares are cheap.

But there are no obvious alternative suitors to Renco which had been examining RJB for six months and failed to come up with an offer expected to be worth between £110m and £130m. RJB, on the other hand, has some cogent reasons of its own for encouraging support as an independent group.

It points to plans to sell off parts of its extensive property portfolio or land bank, worth up to £75m, and return cash to shareholders. More importantly, it is selling more coal than it produces: 12m tonnes in the first half when it made a £10.2m pre-tax loss. And prices have risen some 20%.

Pat Carrogher, leader of the colliery managers' union, says there is more upside in the form of hardening oil prices and, since the petrol crisis, a continuing role for coal in the national fuel mix. His hunches are right and investors should back them.

webTitle: Tomkins chief quits as firm starts review

fields.headline: Tomkins chief quits as firm starts review
fields.trailText: Greg Hutchings yesterday resigned as chief executive of the Tomkins industrial group he built up over 17 years after confirmation of "corporate excess".
fields.body:
Greg Hutchings yesterday resigned as chief executive of the Tomkins industrial group he built up over 17 years after confirmation of "corporate excess".

Chairman David Newlands said the board had lost confidence in Mr Hutchings and was now putting in place a wide-ranging review of all the company's activities. Disposal has not been ruled out.

Shares in Tomkins, which earlier this week fell close to a nine-year low, rose 3.5p to 168.5p and major shareholders expressed relief that a new era for the company was to start.

Mr Hutchings, 53, declined to comment on his own departure but made it be known through friends that he admitted he had made some mistakes.

The company had brought in accountants Arthur Andersen to investigate allegations following criticism from shareholders that Mr Hutchings had effectively used four jets and two London residences as his own. His wife Caroline and their housekeeper had been put on the Tomkins payroll while £40,000 a year was being given to a charity run by a close friend of Mr Hutchings.

Mr Newlands, brought in earlier this year, has switched from non-executive to executive chairman and said the inquiry into all these allegations was still under way. But he could confirm already there was "clear evidence of corporate excess in the past".

Mr Newlands said he had not realised until this week that flats in Eaton Square and Peninsula Heights used by Mr Hutchings were owned by the company. Nor did he realise that four jets allegedly used on occasions by Mr Hutchings for flying him to his holiday home in Portugal were controlled by the company.

Having Mrs Hutchings and a housekeeper on the payroll was also new to him as were the donations to United Response. He said: "It is still to be established to what extent Greg used these different assets but the board had lost confidence in him."

He said some of the practices unearthed at Tomkins were unusual and might be technically acceptable but still not right. Mr Hutchings resignation had been accepted without prejudice to either side and no severance terms had yet been agreed.

Mr Newlands would concentrate on finishing the investigation but also start to look at ways of taking the company forward. "Tomkins is in good shape with excellent management teams around the world. It has an exciting future and I look forward to working with management to deliver value for shareholders," a statement said.

This was particularly important to investors such as Hermes Pensions Management which holds a 5% stake. Hermes director Peter Butler said: "We welcome this strategic review and its emphasis on shareholder value." Tomkins had been built from a tiny engineering company worth £6m into a conglomerate worth £4.4bn in the 1980s but fell out of favour in the 1990s selling off many of its businesses.

Having Mrs Hutchings and a housekeeper on the payroll was also new to him as were the donations to United Response. He said: "It is still to be established to what extent Greg used these different assets but the board had lost confidence in him." He said some of the practices unearthed at Tomkins were unusual and might be technically acceptable but still not right. Mr Hutchings resignation had been accepted without prejudice to either side and no severance terms had yet been agreed. Mr Newlands would concentrate on finishing the investigation but also start to look at ways of taking the company forward. "Tomkins is in good shape with excellent management teams around the world. It has an exciting future and I look forward to working with management to deliver value for shareholders," a statement said. This was particularly important to investors such as Hermes Pensions Management which holds a 5% stake. Hermes director Peter Butler said: "We welcome this strategic review and its emphasis on shareholder value." Tomkins had been built from a tiny engineering company worth £6m into a conglomerate worth £4.4bn in the 1980s but fell out of favour in the 1990s selling off many of its businesses.

fields.headline: Keep an eye on these
fields.trailText: New Capital Invest shares return from suspension today with the company renamed Eagle Eye Telematics, and dealers are expecting brisk business.
fields.body:
New Capital Invest shares return from suspension today with the company renamed Eagle Eye Telematics, and dealers are expecting brisk business.

NCI was an investment vehicle set up by former Kingfisher director Nigel Whittaker and Monaco financier Stephen Tucker to bring a hot technology company on to the AIM market. The shares were suspended at 70p in July after it agreed to a reverse takeover from in-car technology specialists Eagle Eye Telematics. It uses a global satellite positioning system and mobile phone networks to monitor fleet vehicles. Trafficmaster offers similar products.

Beeson Gregory has just completed a £3m fund raising at 152p per share that values the company at £40m. Mr Tucker's Command Fund will retain a stake of about 10%.

The issue was three times oversubscribed suggesting the stock could surge to a significant premium.

fields.headline: Bookham feels the heat
fields.trailText: The first cracks are starting to appear in the Bookham Technology fairy tale. Not only is the company's share price £30 below its high but market professionals are starting to ask if there is money to be made from selling the stock short.
fields.body:
The first cracks are starting to appear in the Bookham Technology fairy tale. Not only is the company's share price £30 below its high but market professionals are starting to ask if there is money to be made from selling the stock short.

From its flotation in April, the performance of Bookham has been almost too good to believe.

On its first day of trading back in April, Bookham shares surged 146%. Three months later the company was a FTSE 100 constituent and by July its share price had breached £54, valuing the Oxfordshire-based group at almost £7bn.

That performance was based on the belief that Bookham could deliver on one integrated silicon chip all the components needed to route light signals in fibre-optic telecom networks. According to those who know, this the holy grail of the industry. Yet, along the way, there has been a marked lack of research on the group's prospects.

But, according to traders, things are changing. Schroder Salomon Smith Barney has just published a cautious note on the company.

Oddly, Schroder is the first big broker to start coverage of the stock and it appears to have done so with a distinctly lukewarm "neutral" rating a target price of £22.00. In the note, Schroder is said to have highlighted a number of execution risks in the Bookham business model.

Chief among these is the fact that Bookham's products have no track record. Shipments of its main product have only just started and high volume manufacture is not yet under way.

Moreover, Schroder is said to be pointing out that average selling prices for such kit is declining and competition is hotting up. Bookham may be the only player using silicon to design an integrated chip but others are using silica and polymers.

All in all, Schroder is said to be telling clients that investors in Bookham are paying a call option premium (the right to buy) for a fully integrated optical chip that might not be available for five years. Bookham shares ended down 89p at £23.71.

Other leading shares, meanwhile, endured a roller-coaster session that brought little comfort to jittery traders.

The FTSE 100 closed 14.3 points higher at 6,131.9, a disappointing performance given that fact that the blue chip index had been up nearly 100 points in early afternoon trading.

That gain was quickly wiped out after events in the Middle East took a turn for the worse, sending the oil price to a10-year high. With the Dow Jones industrial average down over 300 points, London displayed its usual lemming-like tendency and the blue chip index fell to its lowest level since May 24.

But with the heavyweight banking sector mounting a recovery and oil stocks in demand for obvious reasons, the FTSE 100 dragged itself off the floor. Nevertheless, few were cheering. "The corpse is twitching," was how one dealer summed it up.

Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 eased 9.1 points to 6,452.4 and the TechMark slipped 38.52 to 3,401.58.

Advertising group WPP topped the blue chip performance chart rising 37p to 730p on the back of ABN Amro upgrade.

Tobacco group BAT , up 16.5p to 464p, was in demand for its defensive qualities while Allied Zurich added 13.5p to 747p. Investors on share register last night were entitled to 40p special dividend.

On the downside, British Airways fell 21.75p to 275p unsettled by the strong oil price and a curious rumour that it had opened merger talks with Alitalia.

Kingfisher dropped 27p to 368p as the prospects of a takeover diminished after potential predator Home Depot issued a shock profit warning.

Outside of the leading index, Navan Mining was driven up 8.5p to 71p on continued bid speculation.

fields.headline: Homeless charities get cash warning
fields.standfirst:
Groups must back anti-begging drive or lose funds
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government's homelessness tsar has threatened to withdraw funding from charities which refuse to back its controversial anti-begging campaign.
fields.body:
The government's homelessness tsar has threatened to withdraw funding from charities which refuse to back its controversial anti-begging campaign.

The planned £240,000 advertising blitz urging people not to give on the streets has provoked criticism that drug users will turn instead to theft or prostitution to finance their habits.

At a private meeting chaired by a Home Office minister, the head of the government's rough sleepers unit, Louise Casey, warned charities: "Anybody who is touched by my funding, and doesn't sign up, has got to come up and see me later - if you want out."

The strategy to which charities were required to "sign up" involves setting up an "alternative giving fund" with collection points in shops and pubs where the public will be invited to donate rather than give directly to beggars, a source at the meeting said.

The meeting last Friday in Brighton, which has one of the highest concentrations of rough sleepers, was chaired by Lord Bassam, himself a former squatter.

Lord Bassam reiterated the government's stern line on beggars when he told a local newspaper afterwards: "I would like to see a more positive street culture in Brighton and less harassment of people by beggars and Big Issue sell ers." The claim of aggressive begging was yesterday dismissed by Jenny Backwell, director of Brighton Housing Trust, who was at the meeting.

She attacked the anti-begging campaign, which will be launched with adverts in national newspapers and magazines four weeks before Christmas, as "extremely simplistic.

"Without help, people are not just going to stop [taking drugs] because you hit them on the money front," she said. "I am not in favour of begging because it is unpleasant for everybody - it's unpleasant for the people that do it.

"But I would rather people sit by a cash machine and ask for spare change, than stand by a cash machine and bang me on the head when I get money out."

A study published by the charity Crisis today lends weight to the government's analysis that money given to beggars is spent on drugs and alcohol.

Crisis researchers questioned 202 beggars and street drinkers in eight locations across the UK and found that 42% said they had started begging "to get money for drink or drugs". Only 4% said "for food."

Crisis chief executive, Shaks Ghosh, said: "If you tackle begging, you don't have to tackle giving. The thing you really want to remove is begging."

Beggars and street drinkers needed to be given an alternative which is better than the street, Ms Ghosh said, point ing out that some hostels, particularly with large numbers of drug users, can be frightening places, or offer nothing for people to do. She also called for more investment in drug detoxification projects.

Ms Ghosh, whose charity was not represented at the Brighton meeting, added that it was wrong for the government to suppress dissent by threatening funding. "Charities in a sense are the conscience of the nation and we must be allowed to follow our consciences. We should get funding on the basis of whether our projects make a difference. Money should not be contingent on agreeing with government policies."

Ms Casey yesterday insisted her comments to charities were about getting good value for "the taxpayer's money. If you are taking money from the rough sleepers' unit you have got to buy in to the prime minister's strategy - otherwise why are you taking the taxpayer's money?"

Stephen Sharpe, chief executive of Brighton charity St Patrick's Trust, stressed that the discouragement of alms giving was being combined with investment. His trust runs a hostel where 12 new emergency beds will open next week with government backing.

"We wouldn't be supporting this if it was just a case of 'don't give to beggars', without a package of support and care," he said.

webTitle: Medical results that you must disclose

fields.headline: Medical results that you must disclose
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: British insurance companies have for several years been demanding that applicants for life insurance reveal the results of a number of genetic tests.
fields.body:
British insurance companies have for several years been demanding that applicants for life insurance reveal the results of a number of genetic tests.

They do not compel applicants to take the tests - simply to say what the results were if they have taken them.

Tests are only likely to be taken by people who believe they are at risk of contracting the disease concerned, usually because of family history.

In each case, certain patterns of mutations in single genes, or pairs of identical genes, are known to give an extremely high risk of the patient getting the disease.

Genetic tests of this kind are still relatively rare. Most common diseases, such as cancer, are thought to be the result of a combination of environmental and genetic factors. In a genetic test, a sample of DNA - the chemical in which genes are encoded - is extracted from a patient's body, often from blood cells. This is then analysed to check for mutations in the suspect gene.

Equipment to carry out these tests is becoming faster, making it likely that genetic testing will become more common for diagnosis in future.

The seven genetic tests where the Association of British Insurers demands disclosure are for:

 Huntington's disease

 Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

 Myotonic dystrophy

 A form of Alzheimer's

 Multiple endocrine neoplasia

 Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy type I

 Hereditary breast cancer, where a single gene is involved.

webTitle: Comment: Amos Oz on Yasser Arafat

fields.headline: Why Arafat must take the blame
fields.standfirst:
Middle East conflict

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Madeleine Albright's office
Yasser Arafat's office
Ehud Barak's office
Israeli government
Palestinian National Authority
fields.trailText: The new Israeli-Palestinian war is unnecessary and in vain. Everyone both in Israel and in Palestine knows that when it is over there will be a two-state solution. Even people who hate this solution know that it is the only one, the unavoidable one.
fields.body:
The new Israeli-Palestinian war is unnecessary and in vain. Everyone both in Israel and in Palestine knows that when it is over there will be a two-state solution. Even people who hate this solution know that it is the only one, the unavoidable one.

For a lifetime peace-activist like myself, this war is a personal calamity. I have been involved in a struggle to persuade the Israelis to recognise a Palestinian right of nationhood and sovereignty, next to Israel and in peace with it. Since July 1967, immediately after the six-day war in which Israel survived an all-Arab attempt to liquidate it, I and my colleagues in the Israeli peace movement have been involved in an effort to build a bridge between the reluctant Israelis and the desperate Palestinians. At times, most of my fellow countrymen regarded me as a traitor and the two-state solution as a knife in the back of the Jewish faith.

In 1994 in Oslo, Israel and the PLO finally recognised each other and agreed on a pattern of an evolutionary solution. Through ups and downs, progress had been made. We were almost there.

In the past two years there has been a major change of heart inside Israel. For the first time the majority of Israelis were willing to accept an independent Palestinian state in the West Bank and Gaza. Ehud Barak stretched this volatile new tide in Israel to its limits when he offered, in Camp David, to give the Palestinians more than 90% of the West Bank and to recognise a Palestinian state with East Jerusalem as its capital city. He even agreed, with clenched teeth, that the disputed holy places in Jerusalem would go under Muslim custody.

To no avail. Yasser Arafat returned from Camp David back in August calling himself the new Saladin. Palestinian press and media immediately began to beat the drums of a holy war against the Jews, "for the redemption of the holy places".

Mr Arafat is a colossal tragedy for both peoples. He has allowed the newly created Palestinian authority to sink in corruption, and he has incited his people against Israel and against the Jews. Finally, he has initiated this recent burst of hateful violence, in an attempt to inspire a raging fury all over the Arab and Islamic world to start a jihad, a holy war, against the Jews.

As I listen to the rhetoric of the Palestinian official state and media, and of the Arafatesque intellectuals, I am hardly surprised by the lynching committed in Ramallah. The Palestinian people are suffocated and poisoned by blind hate.

It will end. It will end with a compromise, and the compromise is going to take the shape of a two-state solution. Neither the Jews nor the Palestinians are going anywhere. They cannot live together like one happy family, because they are not one, because they are not happy and because they are hardly a family. The only thing to do is to mark a partition somewhere across the country roughly in accordance with demographic realities, and become neighbours. Not brothers or sisters, just civilised neighbours.

This is going to materialise, perhaps even sooner than most people can imagine at this horrible moment. When it does, the dead on both sides will be forever staring at all of us asking why, and what for? At this moment only Mr Arafat seems to have the answer.

© Amos Oz 2000.

 Amos Oz is one of Israel's leading novelists and a founder of the Peace Now movement.

fields.headline: Farm income down 90% in 5 years
fields.standfirst: Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Farmers' incomes are continuing to spiral downwards bringing the fall over the past five years to 90%, the accountants Deloitte and Touche said yesterday.
fields.body:
Farmers' incomes are continuing to spiral downwards bringing the fall over the past five years to 90%, the accountants Deloitte and Touche said yesterday.

An average-sized farm of 202 hectares (500 acres) which earned £80,000 in the mid-1990s is now bringing in just £8,000 and might be running up losses of £4,000 next year, according to a survey of the company's agricultural clients, mainly in England and in the arable sector.

They are the worst financial results in the survey's 11-year history with an average 28% drop in income during 1999-2000.

The figures came as no surprise to farmers' leaders who predicted more unemployment in the industry which shed 22,000 jobs in the year to last June.

The industry blames the strength of the pound, high fuel prices and red tape.

The continuing reduction in the number of small, local abattoirs and the high cost of hygiene charges are also adding to the problems of livestock farmers.

Deloitte and Touche said that income per hectare (2.5 acres) had fallen from £57 to £41 last year and that profit would turn into a loss of £22 during this financial year.

The figures might not even indicate the full extent of the problems since the survey represents few clients in the livestock sector.

Mark Hill,of Deloitte and Touche, said: " The increase in non-farming income shows that farmers are looking to use their skills and resources more widely."

Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers' Union, said: "The public has witnessed the devastation of trade and businesses in this country's pig sector and the pressures facing dairy farmers. These figures demonstrate that our arable farmers are also on the rocks."

The government, which is expected to reveal that hard-up hill farmers are making only £1,200 a year from their businesses, said it was "well aware" of the problems and had provided £750m in aid to farmers since 1997, on top of £4.5bn a year EU help in subsidies and price support.

Ministers, however, point out that income had doubled in the five years before the slump started in 1995.

Tim Yeo, the Conservative agriculture spokesman, said: "The Labour party is rapidly being exposed as the scourge of our countryside."

fields.headline: Dewar to have cathedral funeral
fields.standfirst:
Special report: devolution in Scotland
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The funeral of Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, will take place next Wednesday in Glasgow, the city of his birth.
fields.body:
The funeral of Scotland's first minister, Donald Dewar, will take place next Wednesday in Glasgow, the city of his birth.

Mr Dewar's family had hoped for a private ceremony but were said to have been moved by the outpouring of grief at his death and had acknowledged the need for a public farewell. The setting will be Glasgow Cathedral. It is likely to be one of the largest funerals Scotland has ever seen.

Tributes have continued to flood in for Mr Dewar who died in hospital on Wednesday from a brain haemorrhage at the age of 63.

Flags across Scotland are at half-mast and condolence books have been filled with messages of warmth and sorrow.

The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, was among the first to sign a condolence book in the Scottish parliament building yesterday. He left a simple statement: "In affection, respect and gratitude."

Bouquets have also been left outside Bute House, Mr Dewar's official residence in Edinburgh, where he took the tumble on Tuesday that led to his death.

President Clinton sent a message of support to Mr Dewar's family, and in London, ministers held a minute's silence in memory of Mr Dewar when they gathered for the cabinet meeting. The prime minister told them that while there would be other occasions to mark Mr Dewar's life, they should stand in silence in memory of his "contribution to the country, parliament, the cabinet, the Labour party and the people of Scotland".

Later today the Scottish parliament will reconvene from the autumn recess for a special sitting to remember Mr Dewar. Tributes will be led by the leaders of the opposition parties and the public has been invited to take part.

webTitle: Insurers insist on wider gene tests

fields.headline: Insurers insist on wider gene tests
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Insurance companies will continue to demand information about seven genetic tests from potential customers, even if the government, as expected, only approves one of them, the industry's lobby group has said.
fields.body:
Insurance companies will continue to demand information about seven genetic tests from potential customers, even if the government, as expected, only approves one of them, the industry's lobby group has said.

A government watchdog body is set to give insurers the nod today to use the results of a single genetic test, for Huntington's disease, when it considers applications for life insurance.

A spokeswoman for the Association of British Insurers (ABI) said yesterday that they saw no reason to wait for the government to approve use of the other six tests, and would carry on using them unless they were told to stop. "There is no agreement or legislation to say we can't use these test results," she said. "In our discussions with the government, that wasn't on the agenda."

The ABI says that if the watchdog, the genetics and insurance committee, does eventually give any of the tests the thumbs down, it will compensate customers who have been made to pay higher premiums.

People with a family history of Huntington's disease can choose to have their DNA analysed for mutations in a particular gene which, if present, mean they are certain to contract the fatal brain condition, even if they appear to be perfectly well.

Insurance companies say they will not try to force anyone to take the test. But if a potential customer has been tested, they insist on knowing. A positive test for the Huntington's gene would result in increased premiums.

Reaction to the committee's likely endorsement of the test has been muted, partly because Huntington affected families have long faced genetic discrimination. Even without a genetic test, insurers require applicants to report any history of Huntington's in the family.

"The people likely to be affected by these proposals are the people who already know they have a family history, and if they try to get insurance they will already have come up against a family history clause in life insurance applications," said John Gillott of the Genetic Interest Group, which lobbies on behalf of charities for sufferers of genetic diseases.

Another of the illnesses where insurers already use genetic information is a rare form of Alzheimer's disease, affecting several hundred people in Britain. Like Huntington's, there appears to be a genetic test capable of predicting accurately whether someone is likely to get the disease or not.

More controversial is the test for an inherited form of breast cancer. Here, the presence of mutations only gives a healthy person an increased chance of getting the disease, not a certainty. This genetic test is not endorsed by the genetics and insurance committee but factored in by insurance companies.

The National Consumer Council criticised the insurance companies yesterday, saying people would choose not to have medically important genetic tests for fear of it being used against them.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Dando accused sent for trial
fields.body:
Dando accused sent for trial

Barry Bulsara, 40, the man accused of the murder of TV presenter Jill Dando at her home in Fulham, south-west London in April last year, was yesterday committed for trial at the Old Bailey on November 9.

District judge Graham Parkinson, sitting at Bow Street magistrates court, granted Bulsara legal aid and remanded him in custody.

More city academies

The school standards minister, Estelle Morris, yesterday announced two further city academies, designed to boost standards in two of the country's most deprived inner-city areas - Middlesbrough and Haringey, north London.

Doctors 'spurn basic hygiene'

Doctors are not washing their hands after treating patients, despite evidence that basic hygiene could dramatically reduce hospital infection rates, according to the Lancet today. Researchers found significant improvements among nurses, but not among more than two-thirds of doctors.

Action on death in custody

A police officer is to face four disciplinary charges after Patrick Jean-Louis, 57, died in custody at Plumstead police station, south-east London, the police complaints authority said yesterday.

Spitfires may fetch £4m

Three restored second world war Spitfire fighter planes went on sale yesterday and are expected to fetch more than £4m.

webTitle: Hindley could be freed by new act

fields.headline: Hindley could be freed by new act
fields.standfirst: Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The home secretary, Jack Straw, may be forced to release Myra Hindley and other murderers against his will under the new Human Rights Act, the lord chief justice said yesterday.
fields.body:
The home secretary, Jack Straw, may be forced to release Myra Hindley and other murderers against his will under the new Human Rights Act, the lord chief justice said yesterday.

Judges may well remove the home secretary's power to decide the "tariff" or earliest date of release for murderers, Lord Woolf predicted in an interview in the New Statesman.

Asked if Mr Straw was legally right to insist on keeping the power to decide when murderers are set free, he replied: "I would be very surprised if he proves to be correct."

Hindley's case could be one of the first challenging the home secretary's role to come before the judges under the new act, which came into force in October. Her lawyers have already filed a claim on her behalf at the European court of human rights in Strasbourg.

They argue that allowing the home secretary to set the "tariff" breaches the right to a fair trial guaranteed by article 6 of the European convention on human rights, because in effect a politician rather than a judge fixes the sentence.

Last December in a case brought by the murderers of two-year-old James Bulger, the Strasbourg court removed the home secretary's right to set a tariff for underage killers sentenced to detention at her majesty's pleasure - the juvenile equivalent of a life sentence for murder.

Hindley's lawyers also plan to bring her case back before the English courts now that the Human Rights Act has come into force. She lost her challenge to her "whole life" tariff in the House of Lords last year, but the court could not rule on whether the home secretary's role in setting the tariff breached her right to a fair trial because the European convention on human rights was not yet part of English law.

Hindley is among 23 prisoners serving life for brutal murders - who also include her accomplice Ian Brady - for whom the home secretary has set a whole life tariff, insisting "life should mean life." For murders with no aggravating or mitigating features the standard tariff is 14 years. For Hindley's part in the sadistic murders of four children, the then lord chief justice, Lord Lane, recommended a tariff of 25 years in 1988, but she has now served 34.

Lord Woolf, who sat in the court of appeal on Hindley's previous case, said Mr Straw had been wrong to take the view that life should mean life and had not dealt with the matter correctly.

However, "one has to accept the constraints of the law as it is," he said and told Hindley that Mr Straw was entitled to say at that stage that he would not release her, as long as he kept the case under review.

"I see no possible objection to sentencing someone to life as long as there is in place a proper, objective machinery for review. We do not have that at present in cases like Myra Hindley's."

The lord chancellor said last month that the government might in rare cases refuse to comply with judges' human rights rulings, in what was taken as a reference to cases like Hindley's.

But Lord Woolf said he expected Mr Straw to give way to the judiciary, whether he liked it or not. "I do not see any home secretary, except in the most exceptional circumstances, being prepared to go to parliament and say: 'We want to pass legislation that is inconsistent with the Human Rights Act'."

"Jack Straw says that the ruling [of the Strasbourg court on James Bulger's killers] does not apply to adults. If he's wrong about that, I would expect him to do what he did in regard to juveniles. He may not like it, but that is what he would do."

He signalled that government proposals to lock up dangerous people with severe personality disorders who had committed no crime were likely to be shot down by the judges if they went ahead. He would be "very unhappy if the courts were drawn in to compulsorily sentence someone who has not committed an offence."

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: Northumberland
fields.body:
A heart-stopping moment when I walked into our bedroom last week and there, in the gathering dusk, sat a small feathered football on my windowsill. Aware of an alien presence, the bird's head swivelled. I saw the V of the face, the tiny erect ear-tufts, the large blinking eyes, deep yellow irises about the small dark pupils. We both stared in astonishment.

It was an owl from our Norman church tower, only 100 yards away. I often hear them hooting. After at least a full minute, the owl began to mantle - she knew she was being watched, widening the big organ eyes and ruffling the feathers on her back. Then her wings went into an arch above her head. This threat had no effect. She simmered down and silently slipped off the windowsill, flying low on silent wings.

Was this a barn owl, or a tawny? It was so dark, I could not identify it. There are only 30 pairs of barn owls left in this county, and around 10,000 pairs in the whole of Britain. Factors include loss of nest-sites in traditional farm buildings and a decline in lowland rough grassland which supports field voles, their main food source.

Although wild barn habitat may be increasingly under threat, it is appalling that thousands are being kept in captivity. A spokesman at the Kielder Bird of Prey Centre reports ads offering barn owl chicks for sale as pets. These will grow into large birds destined to spend their lives in cramped cages.

The term "owling" was given to the 18th-century practice of smuggling wool out of England to France. The men (owlers), carrying the wool on their back, had an owlish outline in the dusk.

webTitle: Tobacco giant admits cigarettes are addictive

fields.headline: Tobacco giant admits cigarettes are addictive
fields.standfirst: Special report: smoking
fields.trailText: The world's largest tobacco company, Philip Morris, admitted for the first time yesterday that cigarettes are addictive and harmful, during public hearings in Geneva in the run-up to a global treaty on tobacco control.
fields.byline: Peter Capella  in Geneva and  Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
The world's largest tobacco company, Philip Morris, admitted for the first time yesterday that cigarettes are addictive and harmful, during public hearings in Geneva in the run-up to a global treaty on tobacco control.

Until yesterday, despite scientific evidence and internal industry documents that have been revealed in litigation in the United States, tobacco companies have refused to acknowledge that vast numbers of people are hooked on nicotine. The companies always claimed that people smoke out of choice.

"We agree that smoking is addictive and causes disease in smokers," announced David Davies, Philip Morris Europe's vice president for corporate affairs, at a news conference. "Today I affirm we are in step with public health authorities."

His historic admission was dismissed by anti-tobacco compaigners as a clever piece of footwork by the industry, which is trying to win inclusion in the World Health Organisation's negotiations on a global tobacco treaty which begin on Monday. Campaigners believe the tobacco industry would attempt to water down the treaty and would drag out negotiations if its representatives are included in the discussions.

Mr Davies' position yesterday was that, however addictive and damaging cigarettes are, the public have a right to smoke if they want to. Public health campaigners will argue that this stance is illogical and that someone who is addicted is stripped of choice in the matter.

Philip Morris supported "sensible" regulation of tobacco products and their sales, marketing and advertising, said Mr Davies, but opposed "any proposal which would constitute a prohibition on the ability of companies like ours to make cigarettes and the ability of informed adults to choose to use cigarettes".

It opposed uniform global tax rates and called for countries to outlaw the sales and marketing of cigarettes to under 18s - a measure which health campaigners say is totally ineffective in preventing children from starting to smoke.

Mr Davies promised the company would share its own research with WHO scientists and take steps to combat smuggling. There was laughter from the audience when Mr Davies said Philip Morris regretted a decision last week by the European court to throw out legislation that would have banned almost all tobacco advertising and sponsorship in the EU by 2006.

Matthew Myers, president of the US-based non-governmental organisation Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, dismissed the remarks as "an insidious effort by Philip Morris to prevent strong government regulation".

Tobacco companies and public health groups have come face to face for two days of public hearings on tobacco control, which was the WHO's answer to the demands of the industry to be included in negotiations on the framework convention on tobacco control. Over 500 submissions came in from all over the world and have been posted on a dedicated website.

In spite of enthusiasm for the treaty from the public health community, it will not be easy to get agreement on specifics. Tobacco growing employs many people in the developing world and cigarettes are a big source of tax revenue for governments. The WHO wants its 191 member states to agree on international duties on cigarettes, a clampdown on smuggling, a total ban on advertising, the outlawing of public smoking worldwide and support for farmers who stop tobacco farming.

British American Tobacco, the other tobacco giant, backed national action to stop minors from smoking. But it did not support the proposed international convention and asked the health agency to concentrate on policy advice and research.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Alan Jay Lerner: The Street Where I Live | I Have A Right To...
fields.body:
Actor Henry Goodman provides a sparkling reading of Alan Jay Lerner: The Street Where I Live (7.0pm, Radio 2), the lyricist's hilarious memoirs. In the first of six instalments, Lerner reveals how My Fair Lady was chiselled from Shaw's Pygmalion. The Hungarian film producer George Pascal (for whom the concept of chutzpah was surely invented) had acquired the rights, but Shaw's text couldn't be bent to the musical conventions of the period. Oscar Hammerstein struggled for two years, then Pascal invited Lerner to try.

With Britain's legal incorporation of the Human Rights convention, BBC World Service launches its largest worldwide education project. I Have A Right To... (8.30pm, World Service, Essential Guide) will eventually be transmitted to an audience of 125 million in 12 languages. The opening programme considers when military force is justified to secure human rights. Rageh Omaar wonders why NATO intervened in Yugoslavia but not in Chechnya. (Overnight domestic repeat: 2.30am, R4).
