fields.headline: Private Lives
fields.standfirst: Invitations have dried up since I became single. What can I do about it?
fields.trailText: Invitations have dried up since I became single. What can I do about it?
fields.body:
A year ago my boyfriend and I ended our four-year relationship. Although I decided to call it a day, we continue to be on good terms. On the whole I feel positive about being single. Since my relationship ended I have developed a new network of friends and I have joined several societies.

My dilemma is that many of my friends are married with children. I have found that if I wish to see them at the weekend, I have to make the arrangements. I appreciate that they are busy, but I wonder if it is worth inviting people round who then never invite me back. Recently some friends were invited to a wedding at which my ex-boyfriend was the best man. I had known the groom from university and seen him frequently over the last four years, yet I did not receive an invitation. I was upset that some people who were happy to meet up with me when I was part of a couple no longer want to include me in their activities.

I would like to meet more people of my own age (early 30s) who are single. My job involves working with people in their 40s and 50s, so I am unlikely to make friends through work. Have other readers had similar experiences, and if so, what would they recommend?

Enjoy the single life

Ignore all television advertising showing young couples having fun, making tea or doing DIY. I have been single since I split up with my fiancée five years ago; I am 31, and enjoy life enormously. I lead a very full life, and I really appreciate the flexibility that singleness brings, in terms of deciding what I do, when, and with whom. If I feel like going away for the weekend at the last minute, I just go, and don't need to ask anyone's permission.

While it is true to say that I am not so close as I used to be to my married friends, many of whom have children, I have many more friends now than I ever did while I was part of a couple, encompassing people from a far wider cross-section of ages and backgrounds. My life is filled with variety, I have an interesting job and feel like I'm able to be "me". How? By making the most of the advantages of the flexibility that singleness brings, like being able to change jobs quickly, take part in a wide range of different social activities, and generally building up more and more of the confidence I need to lead the life I want.

Find out what you enjoy doing, find some new friends who like doing these things, and have fun. It takes perseverance, though, and can feel like you're on a rollercoaster ride some of the time, but it's worth taking the longest possible view.

Steve Mitchell, Brighton

It's time to move on

Like you, after years of trying to keep up relationships with friends who have had children, I've given up, although it's a cause of great sadness in my life. It's not through want of trying on my part - I make a real effort to keep in touch, am happy to visit them and play with their offspring, and try and suggest social activities that fit in with their children's lives. But eventually the return calls dry up and then even the Christmas cards stop coming.

But you have to move on, and there are people out there who would be happy to have you as a friend, it just takes time. I moved to a new area this year and for several months thought I would never have any friends again, but eventually things start to fall into place. It is hard, but you say you have a new network of friends and have joined several societies so it sounds like you're doing all the right things.

And by the way, don't automatically write off your work colleagues just because they're older. They can still be great fun, and through them you could meet more people your own age.

Name and address withheld

Hang on in there

I also broke up with a boyfriend after four years about two years ago. I experienced the same kind of feelings about my friends who had relationships and children. Initially I felt hurt that they did not seem to have time for me, but I realise now that their lives were taken up so much with offspring, partners and work that I expect their intentions to phone me were often sidetracked. I recognised that they were always pleased to hear from me or to suggest a better time to ring, so I kept phoning. As the children got older the pressure eased off a bit and they began to be able to give others more attention, so hang on in there.

As someone once said to me, if you need the people, you need to keep in touch. I appreciate that this will not solve your immediate social problem. I suggest that you try indulging in some of your own personal interests. Have you never wanted to learn to do something, go somewhere, try something? Well now's your chance, there's no one to stop you. You will have the satisfaction of doing something you want to, and although there are no guarantees, you will be amongst people that you have something in common with and so have more of a chance of hitting it off.

I have no suggestions about your social exclusions. I think this kind of thing has to be put down to experience, as it often happens with groups of friends when someone splits up.

Name and address withheld

Seek out old friends

Friends are people who share common interests and your current ones do not include being part of a couple. It is inevitable over time, as people and their situations change, that friends will change as well. With this in mind it may be more worth your while to concentrate your attentions on other single people. Look up old friends and acquaintances - do you know any that are single? One email here and a phone call there will help you find other people in the same boat. If there are any single people in the societies that you have joined, get to know them better as well. You will be surprised how many people are in the same situation but you must actively look for them and make the effort to get to know them.

Of course, do not dismiss your other friends even though it is upsetting when you feel left out or forgotten about by all the couples around you. Many couples feel awkward around single people. They don't know how to act and may think that you would feel left out surrounded by couples. They probably feel as bad for not asking you as you feel about not being asked. Eventually you will rejoin the clan and it will be as though you have never left. It's just one of those social oddities.

Jane Buckley, Manchester

Next week

I am a happily married family man in my late 40s. I was gay at school and remember having a secret admiration for muscular boys (shades of Charles Atlas). Gradually I turned straight and over many years have been aware of admiring muscular women. There is nothing sexual here, just admiration of the strong female physique.

As (bad?) luck would have it, I have discovered on the internet that some women body builders offer "muscle worship" sessions and I am seriously tempted to indulge what seems to have been a life-long fantasy. Inevitably I feel ashamed and embarrassed. Should I go? Should I tell my family? Or should I just repress my feelings and get on with living? How on earth do I broach the subject? Being naturally shy, I don't know who to consult: are these thoughts innocuous, a waste of time, or even worse, decidedly unhealthy?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020- 7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
The tawdry world of television love burst forth from behind the screen this week with revelations that the BBC's Peter Salmon has left his wife for the new love of his life, actress and former Coronation Street star Sarah Lancashire.

The "exclusive" story - written up by The Sun, Mirror, Times, Telegraph, Express and Daily Mail - emerged, it seems, at Tuesday's National TV Awards (broadcast not by the BBC but by ITV).

Suffice to say the pressures on TV execs are huge (honest) and Salmon's is not the first marriage to crumble while working in the frenetic world of meeja. But readers can rest assured of one thing: there is no likely conflict of interest in this new televisual love match. Salmon, controller of BBC1 and ultimately responsible for commissioning Lancashire's hugely successful drama Clocking Off, is changing jobs. He's set to become head of sport at the BBC.

 Staying with the BBC, we were interested to read the embittered tone of a BBC2 statement from controller Jane Root, ushered out on Wednesday afternoon to explain the imminent move of the channel's Friday night comedy zone.

 From January the "zone" will move to another night of the week, although BBC2 is as yet unable to tell us which night. The move has nothing, the BBC says, to do with the fact that Have I Got News For You has been pillaged by BBC1 to bolster its new evening schedule around the news at 10pm. In fact BBC2 would like to use this opportunity to trumpet the fact that "in the past programmes like Absolutely Fabulous and The Royle Family have all used the freedom of BBC2 to first develop and reveal the comic potential of everyday characters and cultures before seeing them become firmly embedded in wider national psyche care (sic) of BBC1." So absolutely no sour grapes there, then.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

webTitle: US keeps Sudan off UN top table

fields.headline: US keeps Sudan off UN top table
fields.standfirst: Africa split on regime's bid for security council seat
fields.trailText: The United States was celebrating yesterday after preventing Sudan - which it regards as a haven for practictioners of terrorism - from getting a place on the UN security council.
fields.body:
The United States was celebrating yesterday after preventing Sudan - which it regards as a haven for practictioners of terrorism - from getting a place on the UN security council.

Sudan had the backing of the Organisation of African Unity, though not of all the OAU's members. But the US threw its weight behind Mauritius, and the Indian ocean state got Africa's council place after four voting rounds.

In 1998, the US bombed a building in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, claiming that it had been making chemical weapons for the Afghanistan-based terrorist, Osama bin Laden. The US also blamed it for sponsoring a 1995 assassination attempt on Egypt's president, Hosni Mubarak.

The US representative at the UN, Richard Holbrooke, said: "This was a big, big win for the United States and for the Un ited Nations and for Mau ritius. I think this is a tremendous victory for reason in the UN, and a total repudiation of Sudan."

He claimed that Sudan was a double loser: before the vote, he offered Khartoum a deal in which UN sanctions would be lifted if Sudan pulled out of the running for the security council seat; but the offer was turned down.

The US had been lobbying against Sudan for months.

Britain almost certainly voted against Sudan, but the Foreign Office does not reveal such information.

Christian groups had also campaigned against Sudan, accusing the Islamic government of brutally suppressing Christians and followers of traditional religions.

Mauritius gained strong support from several dozen other small island nations, as well as southern African countries which refused to abide by the OAU recommendation.

Most European countries backed Mauritius as did Latin American nations and India. It finally emerged with 113 votes, while Sudan got 55.

The other big winners were Ireland and Norway, which defeated Italy for the two council seats allocated for Europe. Colombia and Singapore ran unopposed and scored easy victories for the Latin American and Asian seats.

The five winners will replace Argentina, Canada, Malaysia, Namibia and the Netherlands, whose two-year rotating stints come to a close at the end of the year. Five countries with vetoes on council decisions - the US, Russia, Britain, France and China - have permanent seats.

Sudan's representative at the UN in New York, Elfatih Erwa, said: "We were not running against Mauritius. We were running against a superpower."

Mr Holbrooke said: "If he enjoyed to be knocked out in the fourth round when he could have avoided the fight, that's his business."

fields.headline: The final cut
fields.standfirst: What drives healthy men to have themselves castrated?  Marina Cantacuzino  delves into the bizarre world of cutters, eunuchs and men who hate their testicles
fields.trailText: What drives healthy men to have themselves castrated?  Marina Cantacuzino  delves into the bizarre world of cutters, eunuchs and men who hate their testicles
fields.body:
Some people can identify a defining moment in their childhood - an incident that brings an idea to mind which is then indelibly fixed in the psyche. For Gelding - an adopted alias for the American internet guru to all wanna-be eunuchs - that moment came when he was 12 years old and thrown against an older boy in a packed bus. "Do that again and I'll crush 'em," said the older boy, grabbing his genitals. The pain was as piercing as the pleasure. And so began a lifetime's quest to be castrated.

In the UK, self-motivated castration mainly exists only in the most extreme S&M scene, while in America those aspiring to be castrated comprise a burgeoning and divergent tribe made up of both gay and straight men. Men who want to be castrated fit no stereotype, have no common neuroses or childhood experience. Some are androgynous types (thin and underdeveloped) who want to remain in a prepubescent, asexual phase, others are eroto-phobes who don't like to feel driven by their libidos and want to become surgically tranquillised. Some want to be feminised, a few - known as nullos or smoothies - want to become nullified by having their penis removed along with their testicles.

In Gelding's experience a quarter of those who get castrated continue to regulate their libidos with testosterone, which allows them to have full sex. But what compulsion drives grown men to be castrated in the first place? According to Gelding, for most men the desire to be castrated stems from puberty but does not develop into a fixation for at least 10 years.

This was certainly his experience. Now in his early 50s, he has been without his testicles for six years and is keen to point out that he has no desire to be feminised. Growing up in rural New York State, he knew he was gay from childhood, but it was only in his mid-20s, while working for the military in a top security position, that he discovered the gay S&M scene and a world where castration was honoured rather than abhorred.

One of his first boyfriends was a cutter - a man who worked in the netherworld of the gay S&M scene, cutting off men's testicles, consensually and safely. By 1991 Gelding's testicles had become an unbearable affront to him. The idea of cutting aroused him sexually, but more than that, there was an aching need to be rid of something that had begun to take a stranglehold of his life.

At first he tried to cut off the offending items himself by using rubber bands as a tourniquet and drenching his balls in ice water. But after an hour he ran out of adrenaline and went into clinical shock. In hospital a horrified A&E surgeon castigated him for trying to remove healthy tissue. Three years later he went to a cutter in California and got rid of them safely and efficiently. "I've never felt more myself, more complete or happy," he says, unemotionally.

In order to receive the testosterone that he requires to keep him functioning as a man (he has occasional erectile problems but can still ejaculate) he has devised a cover story which makes him eligible for medical treatment. The story is posted up on the web and tells how he lost his balls against his will in a gay S&M episode which went horribly wrong. "My cover story also means that if someone finds out I'm castrated they view me as a victim, or a brave stalwart rather than a deviant or psychotic person," he explains. As well as resurrecting the libido, testosterone prevents osteoporosis and reduces the flab that castration causes to the hips and breasts. (On the down side, it also increases the risk of prostate cancer.)

A self-confessed mother hen, Gelding has for four years been dispensing advice on his website to men who want, or think they want, to be castrated. In that time he's had 5,000 enquiries from both gay and straight men, all believing that their obsession is unique. Consultant psychiatrist Dr Russell Reid, of Hillingdon Hospital in west London, identifies castration fixation as "highly disturbed behaviour, in mainly gay men, whose self-hatred is directed towards their genitals".

Gelding's response to this interpretation is equivocal. "Yes, it's true that no normal person would do that, but then given that homosexuality has always been called a sickness, what's normal?" Reid's experience of this tender topic is predominantly with transsexuals (some of whom even castrate themselves) as well as with men who are hypersexed. "These men are led by their erect penises and some are driven to offend. Being castrated can be a huge release because they become pre-pubital, and sex is no longer an overwhelming preoccupation."

He finds the origins of the fixation perplexing but speculates that it might be a case of the fear of castration turned on its head to become a uncontrollable craving.

But eunuchs are nothing new. For 4,000 years they have represented some of the most marginalised and most honoured in society. In ancient India, eunuchs advised princes and guarded their harems, and the Biblical Daniel was a eunuch who rose to become prime minister of Babylon and later Persia. More recently there have been the Italian castrati of the 19th century - boys who sacrificed their manhood for the sake of singing careers in the opera houses of Europe. Today there are the cross-dressing Hijras in India and religious extremists such as members of the Russian Skoptsy sect who see the testicles as an organ of weakness. The medical profession understands this "syndrome" only in relation to transgender reassignment surgery or as part of body dysmorphia (a syndrome in which people become fixated with having a limb amputated). But Gelding disregards the connection with the body modification scene, believing the desire to be castrated is far more complex.

Nor can he relate to the transgendered, "some of whom get castrated just to get on to a gender reassignment programme". He is also reluctant to help those whose desire to be castrated hinges on the ritual of cutting: "Because if that's the overriding issue then most of these people are into fantasy and role play and don't have a true fixation." When castration is a true fixation, Gelding believes it is vital that surgeons treat the problem in a much more educated fashion. "There isn't a doctor in the world informed in this area, because nothing will justify to a physician the removal of healthy tissue."

There are several doctors in the US who will surgically remove testicles, but seldom before getting their patients to sign a consent form saying it is for gender reassignment. Dr Felix Spector, who advertises castration on his business card, has become something of a celebrity in the murky world of eunochdom, having performed his first castration in 1957. But the vast majority are amateur cutters, subject to prosecution for practising medicine without a licence, and desperately sought after on the net by men in urgent need.

Although these cutters offer a necessary service (reducing the instance of self-castration), for the most part they too find the act of cutting erotic. Talking about doing a DIY castration, one cutter described the "lovely crunching sound" a Burdizzo (a castration device) makes "like biting into fresh celery". Burdizzos, elastators and other animal castration devices can all be purchased on the net. The internet has become a sanctuary to these would-be eunuchs. There are numerous websites providing information, and chat lines link men from all over the world who share this compulsion.

When Gelding was delivering himself into the hands of the cutter there were no such support services and perhaps that's why it wasn't until he was in his 40s that he finally did what he had always wanted to do. Since then, he says, he has found some kind of inner peace, but at a price. He would have preferred to have been one of those who rationalised their way out of it, something he encourages all his correspondents to do. He considers those who manage it to be the lucky ones.

The others must join him among one of the most disenfranchised of groups. Men who are ridiculed, despised and misunderstood by a society which will never be able to make any sense of why they feel incomplete with their testicles and yet complete without them.

 Hidden Love: Modern Day Eunuchs is on Channel 4 next Tuesday at 10pm

Growing up in rural New York State, he knew he was gay from childhood, but it was only in his mid-20s, while working for the military in a top security position, that he discovered the gay S&M scene and a world where castration was honoured rather than abhorred. One of his first boyfriends was a cutter - a man who worked in the netherworld of the gay S&M scene, cutting off men's testicles, consensually and safely. By 1991 Gelding's testicles had become an unbearable affront to him. The idea of cutting aroused him sexually, but more than that, there was an aching need to be rid of something that had begun to take a stranglehold of his life. At first he tried to cut off the offending items himself by using rubber bands as a tourniquet and drenching his balls in ice water. But after an hour he ran out of adrenaline and went into clinical shock. In hospital a horrified A&E surgeon castigated him for trying to remove healthy tissue. Three years later he went to a cutter in California and got rid of them safely and efficiently. "I've never felt more myself, more complete or happy," he says, unemotionally. In order to receive the testosterone that he requires to keep him functioning as a man (he has occasional erectile problems but can still ejaculate) he has devised a cover story which makes him eligible for medical treatment. The story is posted up on the web and tells how he lost his balls against his will in a gay S&M episode which went horribly wrong. "My cover story also means that if someone finds out I'm castrated they view me as a victim, or a brave stalwart rather than a deviant or psychotic person," he explains. As well as resurrecting the libido, testosterone prevents osteoporosis and reduces the flab that castration causes to the hips and breasts. (On the down side, it also increases the risk of prostate cancer.) A self-confessed mother hen, Gelding has for four years been dispensing advice on his website to men who want, or think they want, to be castrated. In that time he's had 5,000 enquiries from both gay and straight men, all believing that their obsession is unique. Consultant psychiatrist Dr Russell Reid, of Hillingdon Hospital in west London, identifies castration fixation as "highly disturbed behaviour, in mainly gay men, whose self-hatred is directed towards their genitals". Gelding's response to this interpretation is equivocal. "Yes, it's true that no normal person would do that, but then given that homosexuality has always been called a sickness, what's normal?" Reid's experience of this tender topic is predominantly with transsexuals (some of whom even castrate themselves) as well as with men who are hypersexed. "These men are led by their erect penises and some are driven to offend. Being castrated can be a huge release because they become pre-pubital, and sex is no longer an overwhelming preoccupation." He finds the origins of the fixation perplexing but speculates that it might be a case of the fear of castration turned on its head to become a uncontrollable craving. But eunuchs are nothing new. For 4,000 years they have represented some of the most marginalised and most honoured in society. In ancient India, eunuchs advised princes and guarded their harems, and the Biblical Daniel was a eunuch who rose to become prime minister of Babylon and later Persia. More recently there have been the Italian castrati of the 19th century - boys who sacrificed their manhood for the sake of singing careers in the opera houses of Europe. Today there are the cross-dressing Hijras in India and religious extremists such as members of the Russian Skoptsy sect who see the testicles as an organ of weakness. The medical profession understands this "syndrome" only in relation to transgender reassignment surgery or as part of body dysmorphia (a syndrome in which people become fixated with having a limb amputated). But Gelding disregards the connection with the body modification scene, believing the desire to be castrated is far more complex. Nor can he relate to the transgendered, "some of whom get castrated just to get on to a gender reassignment programme". He is also reluctant to help those whose desire to be castrated hinges on the ritual of cutting: "Because if that's the overriding issue then most of these people are into fantasy and role play and don't have a true fixation." When castration is a true fixation, Gelding believes it is vital that surgeons treat the problem in a much more educated fashion. "There isn't a doctor in the world informed in this area, because nothing will justify to a physician the removal of healthy tissue." There are several doctors in the US who will surgically remove testicles, but seldom before getting their patients to sign a consent form saying it is for gender reassignment. Dr Felix Spector, who advertises castration on his business card, has become something of a celebrity in the murky world of eunochdom, having performed his first castration in 1957. But the vast majority are amateur cutters, subject to prosecution for practising medicine without a licence, and desperately sought after on the net by men in urgent need. Although these cutters offer a necessary service (reducing the instance of self-castration), for the most part they too find the act of cutting erotic. Talking about doing a DIY castration, one cutter described the "lovely crunching sound" a Burdizzo (a castration device) makes "like biting into fresh celery". Burdizzos, elastators and other animal castration devices can all be purchased on the net. The internet has become a sanctuary to these would-be eunuchs. There are numerous websites providing information, and chat lines link men from all over the world who share this compulsion. When Gelding was delivering himself into the hands of the cutter there were no such support services and perhaps that's why it wasn't until he was in his 40s that he finally did what he had always wanted to do. Since then, he says, he has found some kind of inner peace, but at a price. He would have preferred to have been one of those who rationalised their way out of it, something he encourages all his correspondents to do. He considers those who manage it to be the lucky ones. The others must join him among one of the most disenfranchised of groups. Men who are ridiculed, despised and misunderstood by a society which will never be able to make any sense of why they feel incomplete with their testicles and yet complete without them.  Hidden Love: Modern Day Eunuchs is on Channel 4 next Tuesday at 10pm

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | On the menu | Just out |  Food on the net
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Jamfish, 28-32 Greenwood Street, Altrincham, Cheshire, WA14 1RZ, 0161-928 6677.

The open-plan kitchen delivers dainties through to full meals (£2.95 - £11.95), from salads and sandwiches to dishes with style and substance. Try lamb carpaccio with Swiss chard; smoked haddock and oyster mushroom risotto; or calves' liver and kidney with pancetta. A North African edge catches the eye: look out for Tunisian fish soup with harissa butter and tabouna bread and Moroccan tagine with dried figs and preserved lemons. Kids' menu includes sweetcorn and feta cheese omelette with sautéed potatoes and penne with tomato and basil. Conveniently split into bar, lounge and restaurant areas.

Quick bites...where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Peak Art Cyber Cafe, 30 Market Street, New Mills, High Peak, Derbyshire SK22 4AE, 01663 747770.

The north's original cybercaff. View exhibitions by local artists, shuffle around the wholefood shop, order herbs and spices online and scoff the grub, too. Superior sandwiches and toasties (£1.70 - £2.50), salads and jacket potatoes (£1.40 - £3), full English/veggie breakfasts and oatcakes (£2.50 - £4.50), cafe snacks and ploughman's lunches (60p - £3.50) and vegetarian, filled Mexican tortillas with salsa (£3.50). Kids' stuff offers all of the above in manageable portions. Teas, coffees, juices and milkshakes also available. A great space to rediscover the charms of a mug of Horlick's after trekking over the Peak District.

On the menu... chutney

Or chatni, as we like to call it.

Oh, do we? Why?
Because that's what the Indians call it, and they invented it.

What is chutney or chatni, then?
Strictly speaking, it is a relish designed to bring a little glamour to boring lentils or rice. You should make it fresh each day by grinding spices and herbs and mixing them with a paste of, say, garlic, tamarind, ginger and lime. You can add coconut or mango or walnuts or tomatoes if you want. Your real chatni can be almost liquid, but it should always taste fresh and slightly sour.

Are you telling me Aunty Mary's Fabulous Apple and Raisin Chutney isn't?
More of a pickle, I'd say, than a chatni.

Just out: Dubble

Form:
Smooth chocolate crispy crunch bar (their words, not mine).

Flavour:
Sweet; faint taste of low-class chocolate; indubitably crunchy.

Verdict:
Taste aside, the USP of this particular addition to the armoury of children's sweets is the triple-decker feelgood factor. The chocolate is produced by 35,000 small-scale cocoa farmers in Ghana via the fair trade Day Chocolate Company, and is part of Comic Relief's charitable enterprises. And it'll send blood sugar levels soaring. Kids will love it. So will dentists. While applauding the sentiments, I can't help wishing that Dubble was a better product.

Price:
35p per 40g bar.

Food on the net

www.martinisonline.com

Everything you ever need to know about martinis in one elegant site. There's news, merchandise links and fabulous tips for the perfect martini. And if you're wondering what you can make with that bottle of gin and those leftover cocktail onions, then martinisonline will provide the answer.

Pros:
411 martini recipes. Including the All Bleu (gin, dry vermouth, blue cheese, stuffed olives) and the High Times martini (six parts gin, one part dry vermouth, one part marijuana). All recipes are listed alphabetically and have star ratings. Or you can browse by style: Classic, Trendy, Fruit, Spice & Cajun...

webTitle: Boots and Granada in media link-up

fields.headline: Boots and Granada in media link-up
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Boots, the high street chemist, yesterday announced a joint venture with Granada Media for a television channel and website aimed at the health and beauty market.
fields.body:
Boots, the high street chemist, yesterday announced a joint venture with Granada Media for a television channel and website aimed at the health and beauty market.

The channel and website will initially do little more than cross promote but the aim is to provide a fully integrated service when broadband becomes widespread.

The two companies will invest £18m in the business in the first 12 months rising to £50m during the peak funding year and with a view to break even by 2005.

Programmes on specific areas of health such as asthma will redirect to the internet site where Boots products can be bought. The website will also offer expert advice and forums online as well as having 10,000 products available from day one. The two opera tions are due to go live in February. Boots' chief executive, Steve Russell, said: "This is a further example of how we can create value by capitalising on the enormous value of the Boots brand."

He said he expected that within a few years revenues would be equivalent to 2% of Boots current UK sales. Steve Morrison, Granada Media chief executive, said the brands of the two companies would be used to promote the business but said that the channel would be editorially independent. "The key is broadband. Over time the two services will become more integrated," Mr Morrison said.

The business will have its own management team and will be 60% owned by Boots and 40% by Granada.

"Our broadband strategy is based on the formation of alliances with strong partners which have certain key characteristics," Mr Morrison said.

webTitle: 'I cannot recognise the picture you paint'

fields.headline: 'I cannot recognise the picture you paint'
fields.standfirst: Earlier this week in G2, Christopher Hope argued that the new South Africa was becoming as thin-skinned and repressive as it was under apartheid.  Graeme Bloch, who was himself banned by the old regime, says the novelist is badly mistaken
fields.trailText: Earlier this week in G2, Christopher Hope argued that the new South Africa was becoming as thin-skinned and repressive as it was under apartheid.  Graeme Bloch, who was himself banned by the old regime, says the novelist is badly mistaken
fields.body:
Christopher Hope is wrong. South Africa is not getting like it used to be. The new South Africa is nothing like the old one. I shall avoid Hope's more simple and crude devices, such as dismissing other views as "tosh". I shall disagree, even though he sets up his critics as thin-skinned lackeys of a punitively repressive government ("the search is on for enemies of the people").

Let me speak also as a white South African. Like Hope, I have experience of banning, except it was me and not my work - more than two people was an illegal gathering; no publishing; restricted to Cape Town. I was detained without charge (four times), and on the run for three years.

Now I have the satisfaction of knowing that no one can (ever) do these things to anyone again - not even the president has these powers. A progressive constitution and active constitutional court would stop him in his tracks if he tried. I certainly didn't fight in order to see our new rights eaten away.

South Africa is an immensely better place than it used to be. We no longer hear the midnight knock on the door. People are not murdered for their views. No matter how he looks at it, Hope would have to admit that even his critiques now have wider distribution than ever.

South Africa is better too because I can look my fellow citizens in the eye. Because I stood and voted in a second election last year, and the queue was black and brown and white, there were the thin and the fat, the good, the bad and the ugly. It's quite tangible, this equality in our new democracy.

Our skills base is at last drawing on the entire gene pool. The child of our domestic worker walks hand in hand with her schoolfriends at the formerly white school down the road. The TV announcers reflect the country as a whole. They are young, smart and energetic, and they all wear the Aids ribbon as a sign of their commitment to the crucial issues they face. Ordinary people, the rock-solid residents of townships and villages, at last have a public voice.

Of course race is still an issue. Hope is right that there is scope for a simplistic playing of the racial card. Racism is indeed a charge that is sometimes used to silence critics. There is plenty of space for opportunists and for greedy elites. These morbid symptoms do appear. It is good, as Hope tells us, that intellectuals like Njabulo Ndebele remind us thoughtfully of the whole.

Yet, in Mahwelereng, near Potgietersrus, in the last few days, white commandos accused a 17-year-old boy of housebreaking. They beat him up, forced him to eat his own faeces and smeared it on his body. Cleophas Mphela of Moletji, accused of stealing, was forced to eat dogshit, and the white alleged culprit got free bail; two domestic workers in Gravellotte were stripped naked by a farmer and his son for allegedly stealing a purse.

Very few whites have ever said sorry. We certainly haven't recognised the extraordinary act of generosity that has been reconciliation in South Africa, and the many sacrifices and dreams deferred for ordinary black people in our land.

Now, Hope accepts that racism lives. Yet he skips over racism as an issue not worth much discussion. He trivialises racism by focusing on commissions, who in his eyes seek "subliminal" racism as a way to brand enemies. But the question of subliminal racism - like "institutional racism" - is complex and real, does express a range of connections and processes that still help to shut black people out and ensure an unequalled standard of life and wealth for whites in South Africa. There are a whole host of aspects of our lives and institutions that we still must change. It's not all about witch-hunts, which is what Hope claims.

Hope claims figures are simply manipulated for political purposes: "Rape is widespread. Well then, let us declare it unpatriotic to talk about it. Road fatalities are shockingly high - let us no longer give them out," he cites as evidence.

Well, I did a cursory web search. On September 5 the minister of transport told parliament there were 9,068 people killed in 511,605 road accidents in the last year. Jackie Loffell of Johannesburg Child Welfare Society gave shocking statistics on child rape and crime against children, using police statistics, to her annual conference on September 6. At a seminar in Pretoria on August 14, Statistics SA released its study on rape, commissioned by the president, where the annual figure of 68 rapes per 100,000 of population was discussed. The Medical Research Council said it could be 10 times higher, Dr Chris de Kock of the police's crime information analysis centre delivered a paper and another police official gave details of court referrals. Even the British Home Office was represented there.

Was Hope's work suppressed on the (new) South African Broadcasting Corporation? It is possible. The SABC's newly appointed chief Vincent Maphai has himself called for steps to right the wrongs of recent excess, and heads have rolled. But the SABC is not the government.

In fact, in his bid to prove his point, Hope uses two other examples of authoritarian views. Both sound ominous, but they are actually letters by ordinary citizens to newspapers. Hope may not like what they say, but there's room to contest! He simply had to write a reply and send it in to the newspapers. The debate is robust: no more wild applause just because you once opposed apartheid; just arguments that anyone and everyone can propose.

This is not a sign of a government gone mad but of a country learning to talk to itself. One of the great things about South Africa is precisely that everything is up for discussion, everyone has views. Debate is intense and hard, and nothing like the fear-inspired, apparatchik-dominated silence that Hope seems to face.

Hope thinks the government sees a secret cabal leading a racist conspiracy. The problem is in a way the reverse: Hope thinks every criticism of ideas must be a conspiracy by government. When the government replies to Cosatu (the union federation), it must be repressing debate - yet surely Cosatu's attacks on macroeconomic policy (recently backed up by the Sangoco coalition of non-governmental organisations working in the development field) are precisely a sign that there is not the "deeply unhealthy respect for authority" that Hope fears. In an odd way, even the trouble President Mbeki has got into over HIV/Aids is partly through a stubborn defence of the right of the so-called Aids dissidents to sit on a panel and be heard.

When Hope couldn't get on to SABC radio, there were a host of other radio stations to try. He could even do what I did, which was to debate the London correspondent RW Johnson's rightwing views on the popular Tim Modise talk show; earlier a London paper had continually refused to publish my replies.

Yes, Christopher, much has changed. I, who was called a terrorist yesterday, represent my country today. But I have a burning desire never to let the same old things happen. In my position, I also have the privilege of meeting the best young people my land has to offer. They see no contradiction between being patriotic and being critical.

So, Christopher, continue to speak out at what you think is wrong. I'll join you on that. But I cannot recognise the picture you paint. Please don't call me repressive for saying you're wrong.

 Graeme Bloch is a former chief of social development in South Africa's department of welfare and the husband of the South African high commissioner in Britain

fields.headline: Awash with warnings
fields.standfirst:
We need our flood plains back
Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The reports made it sound like a disaster from the developing world: a man trying to open his shop carried away by a fast flowing flood, fortunately found clinging for his life several hundred yards downstream, by a helicopter; inflatable lifeboats, overturned by the weight of water; stranded people climbing on to roofs of vehicles to escape the rising flood.
fields.body:
The reports made it sound like a disaster from the developing world: a man trying to open his shop carried away by a fast flowing flood, fortunately found clinging for his life several hundred yards downstream, by a helicopter; inflatable lifeboats, overturned by the weight of water; stranded people climbing on to roofs of vehicles to escape the rising flood. Yet this was not Bangladesh, but genteel counties of south-east England: Kent, Sussex and Hampshire. Some 60 flood warnings and four severe flood warnings (the Environment Agency's most serious category) had been issued for the south-east by midday, with further rain still to fall. The Met Office reported four inches of rain falling in the region - about a month's average supply - within 24 hours. Six main roads and two motorways were impassable in several sections. Central Uckfield, in East Sussex, was under four feet of water. West Sussex towns such as Haywards Heath, Arundel and Steyning were badly affected. Lewes residents were evacuated when the Ouse threatened to break its bank. Local fire service officers declared the flooding as the worst since 1972.

What can be drawn from these dramatic events? Most of the floods were not an accident. They are closely linked to building developments on traditional flood plains along with "canalised" rivers, where bends are straightened out and banks reinforced, to make them drain faster. Mechanistic modifications are no match for extreme weather conditions. Whatever the cause of this week's weather, geographers have warned policy-makers that climate change and global warming are going to create many more extreme conditions in the future. Planners will need to recreate the environment that nature provided to meet the unexpected: flood plains that can act as sumps for surplus water. Just another reason why out-of-town developments and supermarkets on greenfield sites need to be curbed.

fields.headline: A day of horror
fields.standfirst:
Who can halt the slide towards war?
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli army said they were unarmed reservists who had taken a wrong turning near Ramallah. The Palestinians said they were undercover members of Israeli death squads. The Palestinian police claimed they had tried to protect the two men when a mob attacked the police station where they were being held.
fields.body:
The Israeli army said they were unarmed reservists who had taken a wrong turning near Ramallah. The Palestinians said they were undercover members of Israeli death squads. The Palestinian police claimed they had tried to protect the two men when a mob attacked the police station where they were being held. Israelis believe the two were sacrificed by Palestinian security forces already deeply complicit in the violence of the past two weeks. The young men who beat and stabbed the Israelis' mutilated bodies in the street seemed to think they had struck a blow for freedom. But many Israelis will find in this horrific act a confirmation of their belief that there can be no peace with such an enemy.

The retaliatory Israeli helicopter and naval attacks that ensued were, in the defence force's menacing view, a "token signal" of their country's wrath. But Palestinians, and the Arab world, saw the assault on Yasser Arafat's Gaza compound as a declaration of war. Thus in the space of a few, terrible hours, the enormous gulf of misunderstanding, distrust, and violence that has in recent weeks rapidly opened up between these erstwhile "partners for peace" is shockingly dramatised. "There is no peace process today. The peace process is dead," said Israeli minister Binyamin Ben-Eliezer. Perhaps he is wrong. Perhaps dialogue can eventually be revived with less ambitious, incremental goals. But perhaps he (and many leading Palestinians) are right. Perhaps October 12 will indeed come to be remembered as the moment when the hopes raised after Mr Arafat shook hands with Yitzhak Rabin at the White House in 1993 finally died in a maelstrom of missiles, knives and bullets.

If so, the Middle East may yet reap an awful harvest. For, in the absence of peace, what does war mean? For the Israelis, it will undoubtedly mean a closing of ranks, the return of a siege mentality, and in all probability, an even greater military ruthlessness in the unquestioned, unquestionable cause of national self-defence. For hapless prime minister Ehud Barak, it means the utter failure of the peace platform upon which he was elected last year. It means, in all likelihood, the formation of a national unity government with Ariel Sharon, the rightwing leader of Likud, and the withdrawal of all previous Israeli offers and suggested compromises on the return of occupied territory, recognition of a Palestinian state, and the shared administration of Jerusalem. It brings the prospect of renewed terror, settlement killings, suicide bombs and daily, paralysing fear.

For the Palestinians, the triumph of violence, an end to dialogue, would be equally horrendous. For all the Arab world's bombast and threats, the Palestinians are always left to fight their battles alone. Yet they have no army to send against Israel; in military terms, it is a war they cannot win. It means, prospectively, the ascendancy of the extremists as, perhaps, the discredited Mr Arafat and his corrupt Palestinian Authority are pushed aside. It may bring an end to much western aid and support contingent on the peace process. It may even mean the loss of that land which has, through negotiation, been wrested from Israeli control. Without a shadow of a doubt, it means that Palestine's people will continue to die, but in ever greater numbers; and that tears and blood, and yet more tears and blood, will ultimately be all they share with the state of Israel.

This is a disaster that can still be avoided. But who can bridge this divide, this calamitous, widening gulf of hate and fear? Who can work the miracle? For it is a miracle the Middle East needs now.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 A voice from the past calls concerning an alleged hoax. It is Rocky Ryan, the celebrated Fleet Street hoaxer, who furiously insists that Ian Edmonson's Sunday People "exclusive" about Reggie Kray being homosexual relied on a faked letter from that late diamond geezer. "I have 30 letters from Reggie in prison," says Rocky, "and he was barely literate. In the People story Kray asks the reader to 'understand my predicament'. He wouldn't know what predicament meant, let alone how to spell it." Mr Edmonson admits the letter, written in 1994, was so illegible that the paper transcribed the words. "If you say the letter is a fake," he tells us, "there will be legal action." Quick, matron, the smelling salts ... It was the high-minded People which recently ran a front-page picture of "Michelle", a woman wronged by bonking England footballers, so it claimed, swiftly uncovered as a staff reporter called Lucy. As for Rocky, the last we heard from him he was threatening to grass us up to Private Eye for not using his story. Definitely one of those days.

 Who is Anji Hunter, Mr Tony's adorable Marcia Falkender figure, and what are her dreams? Did she write a thesis entitled Whither Marxism - or even Wither, Marxism - at Oxford Poly (now Oxford Brookes University)? Does Cherie really hate her ... and if so is it because Mr Tony and Anji have been close friends since they were around 17 ? And was it in fact Anji, and not Alastair Campbell, who described weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown as "psychologically flawed"? We don't have any of the answers, and we almost certainly never will. Still, we will be making a tentative crack at finding them.

 Stirred by a rebuke to the cabinet for its phobia over surveys (the reason always given for failing to answer cannabis enquiries), a reader relates how doing one's bit can be not only socially responsible but profitable as well. Among rewards for contributing to the National Shoppers Census was a free trip to the Millennium Dome at any time between September 30 and October 8. The voucher arrived yesterday, he tells us, on October 11. Cracking form, as ever.

 Other beneficiaries of a lucky near miss at the dome were a party of Japanese tourists whose coach driver became lost on Wednesday night (and it is a small building) and took them instead to the nearby Billy Smart's Circus. Reuters reports that the visitors only cottoned on when a giant inflatable clown took the stage. "As they came out of the circus, they said: 'Where is the big body we were told we could walk through?' " says circus spokesman Robin Cook. Attempts to interview the clown failed yesterday (is this one too obvious? Probably, but I haven't the heart to weed it out), when a spokesman said Monsieur P-Y Gerbeau was too busy to come to the phone.

 I am sad to learn that, even in the inclusive Tory party (in which MP Christopher Chope calls for the disabled to be paid below the minimum wage), poor manners persist. Mr Hague's adviser George Osborne has failed, for two days, to return our call concerning his name. Friends say that this is in fact Gideon, which he dropped while seeking a parliamentary seat, fearing it might sound not quite right. Then again, the vanished Gideon may be a middle name. Either way, the ruse worked splendidly and Mr Osborne will fight Tatton, now represented by Martin Bell, but last held for the Tories by the fabled Neil Hamilton.

The California Office of Transportation has issued a notice warning motorists to drive "defensively" when faced with certain hazards: whenever they see other motorists "shaving, flossing, blow-drying, lap-top faxes and computers or doing their laundry in portable washing machines" that plug into dashboard cigarette lighters.

 diary@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Female doctors' key role
fields.trailText: Your headline Anger at slur on women doctors (October 5) was not an accurate reflection of the statement made by Phillip Hammond MP at a private meeting during the Tory party conference.
fields.body:
 Your headline Anger at slur on women doctors (October 5) was not an accurate reflection of the statement made by Phillip Hammond MP at a private meeting during the Tory party conference. Mr Hammond made the point that over a lifetime female doctors work fewer hours than their male colleagues. This is a statement of fact which in no way reflects the quality of these women.

Without committed women doctors, who now account for over 50% of medical school graduates, the NHS would grind to a halt. The need for women to have maternity leave and flexible working practices is not unique to the NHS. A shift needs to be seen in the context of a reduction in junior doctors' hours and the the call for increased accountability of doctors to the public to ensure safe and high standards of medical care. Hence replacing our stressed and overworked NHS staff with men and women working more sensible hours and living more balanced lifestyles may improve the standard of medical practice. Politicians need to be aware that a substantial increase in the number of doctors will be needed.

The Royal College of Physicians is reviewing the data on women in medicine to ensure that female doctors have equal opportunities in all branches of medicine and that the working environment is flexible enough that excellent and highly skilled women are maintained in the NHS.

Prof Carol Black,
Dr Rebecca Fitzgerald
Royal College of Physicians

fields.headline: Acting local
fields.trailText: I agree with Bob Holman (Society, October 4) that to make a real difference, the money from the new children's fund needs to be administered locally and targeted to meet local needs.
fields.body:
 I agree with Bob Holman (Society, October 4) that to make a real difference, the money from the new children's fund needs to be administered locally and targeted to meet local needs. The fund, worth £450m over three years, will help vulnerable children and young people break through the chronic cycle of poverty and underachievement. Most of this new money will be for preventive work, primarily with children aged 5-13 and their families, helping them before they hit a crisis. The voluntary sector, with its strong experience in delivering services to children and young people, will be recipients of much of this funding. I am determined that the sector will be central to delivering these new resources.

Paul Boateng MP
Minister for young people

webTitle: Letters: Where the blame lies in South Africa

fields.headline: Where the blame lies in South Africa
fields.trailText: Certain South African institutions, and the SABC in particular, are legitimate targets for liberal protest, but Christopher Hope (Just like old times, G2, October 11) is unfair.
fields.body:
 Certain South African institutions, and the SABC in particular, are legitimate targets for liberal protest, but Christopher Hope (Just like old times, G2, October 11) is unfair.

White racism is not a bogeyman; South Africa is saturated and dripping with it. Subliminal racism is also alive and well, as is institutional racism.

"Jewish money circulating 10 times" is about the problem of township economics and the difficulty of keeping black money in the black community; the suggestion that this reference is "a choice bit of rant" is typical of Johannesburg dinner tables.

South African tourism, the industry on which this desperately poor economy most depends, is plagued by a negative image originating with the gossip of its white citizens. "One settler, one Prozac", might please Mr Hope, but perhaps those in charge of the advertising budget would like, for a change, jokes that recognise the existence of the other 92% of the population.

Put Mr Hope's main proposition to any black South African and he or she will laugh. So for whom is the new South Africa "a lot like the old one"? For the settlers. Their privileges are much the same and they are the only South Africans that can afford Prozac.

Anita Van de Vliet
Gil Elliot
London

 Like much recent controversy on the issue, your report (Mbeki is accused of Aids hypocrisy, October 10) lets those most to blame for denying poor South Africans access to HIV/Aids drugs off the hook.

Millions cannot afford the drugs because of the prices charged by the companies that control the patents. When the South African government sought to pass a law that would allow them to import or make cheaper generic copies (as other countries do) the drug companies took them to court. The companies have lobbied to try to use global trade rules to protect their monopoly profits. Leon Brittan wrote to President Mbeki claiming that the act "might conflict with the objectives of the trade, development and cooperation agreement [between the EU and South Africa]... and its implementation would negatively affect the interests of the European pharmaceutical industry".

Ben Jackson
Director,
ACTSA
actsa@actsa.org
fields.bodyText:  Certain South African institutions, and the SABC in particular, are legitimate targets for liberal protest, but Christopher Hope (Just like old times, G2, October 11) is unfair. White racism is not a bogeyman; South Africa is saturated and dripping with it. Subliminal racism is also alive and well, as is institutional racism. "Jewish money circulating 10 times" is about the problem of township economics and the difficulty of keeping black money in the black community; the suggestion that this reference is "a choice bit of rant" is typical of Johannesburg dinner tables. South African tourism, the industry on which this desperately poor economy most depends, is plagued by a negative image originating with the gossip of its white citizens. "One settler, one Prozac", might please Mr Hope, but perhaps those in charge of the advertising budget would like, for a change, jokes that recognise the existence of the other 92% of the population. Put Mr Hope's main proposition to any black South African and he or she will laugh. So for whom is the new South Africa "a lot like the old one"? For the settlers. Their privileges are much the same and they are the only South Africans that can afford Prozac. Anita Van de Vliet Gil Elliot London  Like much recent controversy on the issue, your report (Mbeki is accused of Aids hypocrisy, October 10) lets those most to blame for denying poor South Africans access to HIV/Aids drugs off the hook. Millions cannot afford the drugs because of the prices charged by the companies that control the patents. When the South African government sought to pass a law that would allow them to import or make cheaper generic copies (as other countries do) the drug companies took them to court. The companies have lobbied to try to use global trade rules to protect their monopoly profits. Leon Brittan wrote to President Mbeki claiming that the act "might conflict with the objectives of the trade, development and cooperation agreement [between the EU and South Africa]... and its implementation would negatively affect the interests of the European pharmaceutical industry". Ben Jackson Director, ACTSA actsa@actsa.org

fields.headline: Theatre loses the plot
fields.trailText: In his review of Somerset Maugham's The Circle, Michael Billington hit back at mine and Mike Bradwell's suggestion that we ban classics from subsidised theatre  by saying he can think of "a few dramatists who might learn how to harmonise plot and character" from studying Maugham's play.
fields.body:
 In his review of Somerset Maugham's The Circle (Reviews, October 12), Michael Billington hit back at mine and Mike Bradwell's suggestion that we ban classics from subsidised theatre (Bite back, G2, October 11) by saying he can think of "a few dramatists who might learn how to harmonise plot and character" from studying Maugham's play. I agree. Only a fool would suggest that today's writers do not read their Shakespeare and their Ibsen.

Our plea to leave off the classics for a while was not aimed at writers but at producers and critics. It was an attempt to open up debate about theatre's reliance on revivals and the audience's fears about new work. When Mr Billington says we should "overcome our prejudices and widen the area of choice", I couldn't agree more. But Michael, we cannot do this by maintaining a status quo which has allowed the word theatre to develop deeply negative and old-fashioned connotations in the eyes of young people who nightly pack the cinemas to see new films. I want the next generation to love plays as much as I do and not think of them simply as something that their parents went to.

Tim Fountain
Literary manager,
Bush Theatre

 Is Brian Watkins (Letters, October 12) suggesting that one needs to write a play before one can pass comment on a writer? What a bizarre thought. No non-chefs to write critiques of restaurants, no sportswriters who have not won more medals than the players they assess, no Film 2000 presenters who haven't directed an Oscarwinning film? We don't teach playwriting here ... Sorry.

John Freeman
De Montfort University

fields.headline: Peace hits the rocks
fields.trailText: As an Israeli who campaigns for human rights together with Palestinians, I disagree with Jonathan Freedland's description of the crisis as "a religious war" (Doves must be hawks, October 11).
fields.body:
 As an Israeli who campaigns for human rights together with Palestinians, I disagree with Jonathan Freedland's description of the crisis as "a religious war" (Doves must be hawks, October 11). This week in Nazareth, armed Israeli civilians and police carried out what can only be described as a pogrom, indiscriminately clubbing and shooting both Christian and Muslim Palestinians. Three Palestinians were shot dead and dozens were injured.

A close friend from Galilee is devastated after losing her 17-year-old son, Asil Asleh. Armed Israeli police beat him and then shot him through the neck at close range. He was a well-known peace activist and at the time of his execution, as reported by you, he was wearing a T-shirt emblazoned with "Seeds of Peace" (Israeli Arabs enraged by underclass life, October 6). He was executed because he campaigned for peace and Israel prefers to have fundamentalists as enemies.

Yael Kahn
Kenilworth,
Warks
yaelkahn@femail.com

 Edward Said proves that the Arab-Israeli quarrel is not about Jerusalem but about turning the clock back to 1947, sabotaging Israel's right to self-determination (Double standards, October 12).

All the Arab parties involved in 1948 rejected the UN partition resolution. They then all voted against resolution 194 about refugees "willing to live in peace with their neighbours". This reduces the present riot to a dust-in-the-eyes exercise. The proof is that Arafat refused this summer's offers on Jerusalem because the price was the indifferently reported requirement to end the conflict and its claims altogether. The Palestinian Authority will have to accept that while Israel can be pushed about small items of territory, it can no more be pushed off self-determination than the Arabs.

Meanwhile if Belfast erupted in a shower of bricks, would it be a "peaceful" demonstration? In 1929, British bullets killed over a hundred Arabs in two days, let alone two weeks.

Frank Adam
Manchester

 Ehud Barak claims that the Arab world is facing a moment of truth. The truth is that it is Israel that faces its moment of truth. Israel's strategy has for many years been based on the idea that it can take by force what it wants and compel the Palestinians and the Arabs to accept it; the idea that Palestinians and Arabs can be forced to "lower their expectations". But with the conflict becoming much more political and popular, rather than elite and military, Israel's options have become much more restricted.

Is Israel seriously going to reoccupy the towns and villages of the West Bank? Even if Israel does not itself care about the massive losses of Palestinian life that will be involved, its reputation will take a further nosedive. Is Israel really going to re- occupy the south of Lebanon and build another security zone, at a time when Hizbullah is much better organised and equipped than it was in the early 1980s and when Israel no longer has any "local" agents willing to do its bidding? Or is it just going to bomb Beirut and Damascus?There is no alternative to peace.

David Cobham
St Andrews,
Fife

 In June I stood overlooking the Jewish settlement of Ma'ale Adumin, looking at the document that approves the expansion of this settlement from Jerusalem to the Jordan river, creating a city larger than Tel Aviv or Jerusalem itself; the approval for this extension was agreed under Barak. I felt then that Israel could not be serious about wanting peace at Camp David.

Oslo is dead. Let us go back to Madrid and 242; it is the only way forward.

Rev Garth Hewitt
London

fields.headline: Barclaycard plans online mega-mall
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Barclaycard yesterday set a goal of attracting 500,000 on-line shoppers to a new portal housing 350 retailers which it is establishing through a £30m joint venture with the Japanese investment bank Nomura.
fields.body:
Barclaycard yesterday set a goal of attracting 500,000 on-line shoppers to a new portal housing 350 retailers which it is establishing through a £30m joint venture with the Japanese investment bank Nomura.

The subsidiary of Barclays was unperturbed by a survey from the Trading Standards Institute, which discovered that shopping online can be slow and problematic.

Bob Potts, chief executive of Barclaycard, insisted he expected further growth in on-line shopping and that high standards demanded from retailers by Barclaycard would tackle some of the problems.

"People are just lacking confidence," he said.

In addition to Barclaycard's own anti-fraud promise to users of its credit card for on-line purchases, the new portal will require retailers on the site to confirm orders and make it possible for customers to contact them easily. This would address two of the problems revealed by trading standards investigators who found 25% of sites vulnerable to hackers.

Analysis of 102 UK-based sites found 38% of orders failed to arrive on time while 17% did not turn up at their destinations at all.

The trading standards officials also found there were problems with 36% of all attempted purchases, including one firm which vanished after taking credit card details.

This new venture will be Barclaycard's second foray into online shopping. It also runs Barclay Square, which Mr Potts said would remain operational and continue testing for digital services, such as downloading music.

He refused to reveal the name of the new portal, other than to admit it would be related to the Barclays brand.

He said it would offer more than 5m products eventually. At launch later this year it intended to have 50 retailers on-line selling more than 1m products ranging from computers to clothing.

The service is unlikely to make money for two years. However, Mr Potts said he regarded the internet as an important way for Barclaycard to expand its business in the years ahead.

"Building our credentials as a major player in interet-related commerce will be a significant factor in the growth of Barclaycard over the next five to 10 years."

In a separate announcement, the catalogue retailer N Brown Group said its e-commerce arm, Zendor.com, was in negotiations for 10 new contracts. However, it admitted Zendor would not make a profit until next year.

The company said the e-commerce offshoot, in which it has a 75% stake, made a £400,000 loss for the first half of the year and predicted a similar figure for the second six months.

Zendor, which offers services from warehousing to delivery, already has contracts with New Look and River Island but refused to comment on speculation it is signing a deal with Marks & Spencer.

Analysts expect it to be floated within five years.

N Brown, which reported pre-tax profits up 7.9% from £21.4m to £24.7m on a £185.9m turnover, benefited from improved mail order sales.

It said there had been increased emphasis on household and electrical products while it has reduced reliance on the clothing market.

fields.headline: Michael Whitelaw
fields.standfirst: Medical champion of the elderly
fields.trailText: Michael Whitelaw, who has taken his own life aged 46, was a champion of geriatric medicine. For the past two years, he was medical director of the Riverside community healthcare trust, in London, and, in 1999, was seconded to the Department of Health to assist with the development of a national service framework for older people.
fields.byline: Finbarr Martin, Peta Berman and Linda Goldsmith
fields.body:
Michael Whitelaw, who has taken his own life aged 46, was a champion of geriatric medicine. For the past two years, he was medical director of the Riverside community healthcare trust, in London, and, in 1999, was seconded to the Department of Health to assist with the development of a national service framework for older people.

In 1985, he had become consultant and senior lecturer in geriatric medicine at St George's hospital and medical school, south London. His passion was clinical medicine for the elderly. Intelligence, empathy and fairness endeared him to his patients.

Michael played a major part in the development of the medical school's first undergraduate clinical course in geriatric medicine. He researched the relationship between the declining strength and functional ability of older people, and developed a forum for the identification and clinical management of those at risk of losing their independence. An educational programme was initiated - with the participation of older people themselves.

Michael was educated at Malvern College. He graduated from University College hospital medical school, London, in 1976, after which he trained in general, internal and geriatric medicine. Then came St George's.

Serious depressive illness cost him both his marriage and his consultancy, although after his recovery he pursued, throughout the 1990s, a wide variety of activities with enormous energy and enthusiasm, flourishing as an independent health consultant, and advising on the development of community care for older people. In 1993, he obtained a master's degree in health promotion from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. Six years later, he took a health executive master's degree from Keele University.

Michael's commitment to the contribution of lay people and carers to health services led him to the League of Friends movement, and he became chairman of its constituency and members' forum in 1996. He was clinical adviser to the national diet and nutrition survey of older people, and to the Health Education Authority and Age Concern's seminal Agewell project. In 1994 he co-founded - and later chaired - the health promotion and preventive care group of the British Geriatrics Society.

Between 1996 and 1999, he advised an EC-funded Palestinian group working with isolated older people in the West Bank. He also worked on older people's health services in South Africa.

Ever forthright, Whitelaw's missions into political and religious community activity stretched his friendships, but his honesty and commitment brought more admirers. A particularly happy period was as a member of a village community in Chiddingfold, Surrey.

Back in London, with the Redbridge healthcare trust - and then at Riverside - he led the strategy for a health improvement programme for older people in west London. Locally and nationally, during his last few months, he saw his aspirations move from the margin to the mainstream.

Passionately fond of music, literature, sport and the arts, Michael had charisma, humanity, charm and wit that touched many lives. He remained devoted to his children and, even in his lowest moments, was always a loyal and loving father. He leaves his daughter, Amelia, and his son, George, their mother, Lindsey, his parents and his sister.

Michael Newton Whitelaw, medical director, born October 20 1953; died September 13 2000

fields.headline: John Worsley
fields.standfirst: Energetic artist who drew a debonair police hero for the Eagle comic, and created Albert RN, the dummy hero of a famed wartime escape
fields.trailText: It was as the artist for the Eagle comic's Adventures Of PC 49 in the 1950s that John Worsley, who has died aged 81, really reached an audience. From his first episode, published in August 1951, he drew the tales of 49 - Archibald Berkeley-Willoughby - until March 1957. Some 290 episodes, involving more than 3,000 drawings, appeared in Eagle comic alone, with further tales in the Eagle Annual and various spin-off books. Three-quarters of a million schoolboys relished every brushstroke each week.
fields.body:
It was as the artist for the Eagle comic's Adventures Of PC 49 in the 1950s that John Worsley, who has died aged 81, really reached an audience. From his first episode, published in August 1951, he drew the tales of 49 - Archibald Berkeley-Willoughby - until March 1957. Some 290 episodes, involving more than 3,000 drawings, appeared in Eagle comic alone, with further tales in the Eagle Annual and various spin-off books. Three-quarters of a million schoolboys relished every brushstroke each week.

Worsley also worked for the Eagle's companion paper, Girl, drawing Belle Of The Ballet, and, beyond that, turned his talent to an extraordinary range of work.

This included Albert RN, the dummy sailor at the centre of a daring wartime escape plan from Marlag O prisoner-of-war camp, near Bremen. Worsley, himself a sailor PoW at the camp, created the life-sized figure out of wire and papier-mache, after which it was held between two soldiers during roll call, fooling the camp guards into thinking they had a full complement of prisoners while a British escaper made his getaway.

For four days, Albert, with his ping-pong ball eyes and no hands (his sleeves were stuffed into his jacket pockets), stayed on parade; unfortunately, the escaper was recaptured on the northern coast of Germany. Two months later, Albert was finally rumbled when a second escape attempt was foiled, and the camp guards realised they had one too many prisoners.

Back in England, Guy Morgan, a former fellow PoW, immortalised Albert RN in a play, which, in 1953, became a film starring Anthony Steel as a fictionalised version of Worsley. The artist himself recreated Albert for the movie, and the dummy is now kept at the Royal Naval Museum, Portsmouth.

Born in Liverpool, Worsley was the son of a naval officer who settled on the family coffee farm at Kabuka, north of the Kenyan capital, Nairobi. It was here, amid spectacular scenery and at an altitude of 6000ft, that Worsley grew up, shooting and messing around in the family model-T Ford when not attending school.

This idyllic life ended in 1928, as coffee prices collapsed. John was sent to St Winifred's boarding school, his fees subsidised by the Royal Navy Trust. He won a scholarship to Brighton College, and spent three years at Goldsmiths College school of art. In his final year, he purchased a second-hand Fiat for £4, and, after leaving college, travelled the south coast, making sketches to sell to magazines.

Worsley's naval experiences began in 1939, with a three-week crash course in seamanship. His ability to accurately report through his work helped him to become the youngest official war artist in the Mediterranean. He had already survived the sinking of HMS Laurentic, by a German U-boat in 1940, and now found himself taking part in the landings at Sicily, Reggio and Salermo.

In 1943, he was among the rescue party sent to establish a base on Lussin Piccola, in the north Adriatic, only to find it overrun by Germans. Worsley was taken to Germany for interrogation, and spent almost two months in solitary confinement before being sent to Marlag O. It was there that he met the journalist Guy Morgan, who was about to be repatriated with serious war wounds, and who smuggled out a number of Worsley's drawings in the plaster cast on his arm. Then came the Albert RN escapade.

As allied troops advanced in early 1945, Worsley and other PoWs were forced to march the 80 miles to Lübeck, arriving a few days before the war ended. Returning to Britain, he settled in a small studio in Barons Court, west London. He was asked by the Admiralty to paint portraits of high ranking officers, and found illustration work on the Eagle soon after its launch, painting a full-page advertising/ adventure strip for Walls ice cream, starring Tommy Walls, a lad whose heroics were always accomplished by the Lucky Walls Sign, and whose reward was, inevitably, lashings of ice cream. PC49 followed.

In later years, Worsley produced for Esso a series of paintings showing life on oilfields in Iraq and America. He made hundreds of colour illustrations for television readings of children's stories; many of them later found their way into books. Even in his late 70s, he could still be found busy, always working on a marine painting, sculpture or glass engraving.

H e was a gracious guest of honour at dinners organised by PC49 fans, and impressed a new generation with his collection of wartime sketches, John Worsley's War. Many of his paintings and portraits - including those of Montgomery and Admiral Sir John Cunningham - can be seen at the Imperial War Museum and the National Maritime Museum. He also worked as a police sketch artist, his facility for capturing a likeness being responsible for many arrests.

A recent article about his work by one of his enthusiasts was entitled The Complete Artist; nobody earned that title more than John Worsley.

John Godfrey Bernard Worsley, artist, born February 16 1919; died October 3 2000

It was there that he met the journalist Guy Morgan, who was about to be repatriated with serious war wounds, and who smuggled out a number of Worsley's drawings in the plaster cast on his arm. Then came the Albert RN escapade. As allied troops advanced in early 1945, Worsley and other PoWs were forced to march the 80 miles to Lübeck, arriving a few days before the war ended. Returning to Britain, he settled in a small studio in Barons Court, west London. He was asked by the Admiralty to paint portraits of high ranking officers, and found illustration work on the Eagle soon after its launch, painting a full-page advertising/ adventure strip for Walls ice cream, starring Tommy Walls, a lad whose heroics were always accomplished by the Lucky Walls Sign, and whose reward was, inevitably, lashings of ice cream. PC49 followed. In later years, Worsley produced for Esso a series of paintings showing life on oilfields in Iraq and America. He made hundreds of colour illustrations for television readings of children's stories; many of them later found their way into books. Even in his late 70s, he could still be found busy, always working on a marine painting, sculpture or glass engraving. H e was a gracious guest of honour at dinners organised by PC49 fans, and impressed a new generation with his collection of wartime sketches, John Worsley's War. Many of his paintings and portraits - including those of Montgomery and Admiral Sir John Cunningham - can be seen at the Imperial War Museum and the National Maritime Museum. He also worked as a police sketch artist, his facility for capturing a likeness being responsible for many arrests. A recent article about his work by one of his enthusiasts was entitled The Complete Artist; nobody earned that title more than John Worsley.
