fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: It was very much of a piece with the somewhat stoical values of William Bundy (Obituary, October 9) that he never publicly criticised the Vietnam war. I believe he felt that his own role in initiating it had been so significant that it did not lie in his mouth to say publicly that it was wrong, though he came to have the gravest doubts about its wisdom and morality.
fields.body:
Godfrey Hodgson writes: It was very much of a piece with the somewhat stoical values of William Bundy (Obituary, October 9) that he never publicly criticised the Vietnam war. I believe he felt that his own role in initiating it had been so significant that it did not lie in his mouth to say publicly that it was wrong, though he came to have the gravest doubts about its wisdom and morality.

He did, however, devote many years at the end of his life to his book, A Tangled Web, which was a measured and - because it was so fair - devastating demolition of many facets of the Nixon/ Kissinger foreign policy era, including their prolonging of the Vietnam war.

Bundy's book reflected his values, those of the traditional American gentleman and patriot who found himself advocating policies that came to shock him. With care and clarity, he accumulated the evidence against the president and Dr Kissinger.

On the last page, he delivers his verdict. "If there is any single lesson from the Nixon era that stands out above all others, it is that a pattern of deception, of Congress and the American people, is, in the end, doomed to failure."

fields.headline: Bashir Barghouti
fields.standfirst: Militant conciliator in Palestine's struggle
fields.trailText: A lifelong communist, Bashir Barghouti, who has died aged 69, was both a linchpin of the Palestinian intifada of the late 1980s, and an advocate of his people's accommodation with the state of Israel. He thus always cut a paradoxical figure in Palestinian politics.
fields.body:
A lifelong communist, Bashir Barghouti, who has died aged 69, was both a linchpin of the Palestinian intifada of the late 1980s, and an advocate of his people's accommodation with the state of Israel. He thus always cut a paradoxical figure in Palestinian politics.

His organisational prowess made him indispensable to the Palestine Liberation Organisation. In 1987, he joined its executive council, as representative for East Jerusalem, and, in 1996, became minister of industry in Yasser Arafat's first, post-election cabinet.

The PLO, however, always envied the communists' efficiency and intimate local knowledge of the occupied territories. From 1973, Barghouti led the indigenous opposition to Israeli occupation - through the Palestinian National Front - until, in 1977, the formally banned PLO engineered its demise.

A conciliator par excellence, Barghouti repaired the schism between Arafat's Fatah and George Habash's radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) in 1987. A year later, the PLO adopted his once treacherous idea of supporting a smaller Palestine living alongside Israel, rather than a larger Palestine displacing the Jewish state.

Barghouti paid dearly for his beliefs. He spent eight years in a Jordanian detention camp at Jaffar, and later suffered Israeli imprisonment. Nor did his sharp pen endear him to the Tunis-based PLO, when he edited two Jerusalem-based newspapers, Al-Fajr (Dawn), and Al-Taliyat (Vanguard).

Barghouti was also a master of reinvention. The Palestine Communist party (PCP) began in 1919 as a joint Jewish-Arab working-class movement. It was the only Arab faction that, in 1947, accepted the UN partition plan for Palestine - albeit reluctantly. Barghouti never wavered from this tenet, but always realised the need for change. In 1982, the PCP broke free from its Jordanian parent party, and, in 1991, Barghouti transformed it into the Hizb a-Sha'ab, or Palestine People's party, audaciously embracing internal democracy, and the mixed economy.

Barghouti was born near the West Bank town of Ramallah. He graduated in 1956 with a degree in political science and economics from the American University of Cairo, and became a founding member of the radical General Union of Palestinian Students, alongside Arafat. The following year, he fell victim to the Jordanian ban on communists, and official attempts to stifle his early publishing ventures.

In 1973, Israel permitted Barghouti to return to Ramallah, by then part of the occupied territories. Some saw this as a reward for moderation, although he soon spent a year in prison for "incitement", and, in 1980, was restricted for 10 years to Ramallah.

In December 1987, the intifada caught both Israel and the PLO by surprise. Desperate to recover lost ground, Arafat ordered the creation of a grassroots unified national command. Barghouti initially rejected this initiative, but soon realised that the communists had a role to play. Working with his trusted lieutenant, Taysir Aruri, he began printing command handbills and created the first West Bank "popular committees".

Barghouti favoured building an autonomous civil society, and the communist-run village of Salfit became a model of disciplined economic self-sufficiency. The intifada spawned many communist organisations, unions and welfare bodies, which now serve as a de facto opposition to Arafat's Palestine Authority.

Throughout the revolt, Barghouti communicated with Israeli communists, although their influence was increasingly undermined by the Islamic resurgence and the collapse of the Soviet Union. Yet virtually everyone respected the balding, chain-smoking Barghouti. He was a leading light in the influential Arab Thought Forum and Council for World Peace.

He became a minister in June 1996, enthusiastically favouring private banks, tax liberalisation, incentives for investors - especially Palestinians in the diaspora - and industrial parks straddling the Israeli border. He none the less continued to criticise encroachments by Israeli settlers, and draconian tendencies within the Palestinian Authority.

In 1997, a stroke deprived him of speech, and he resigned his industry posting. Although named a minister without portfolio in 1998, his political days were over. Arafat personally shouldered Barghouti's coffin at his funeral - a tribute to the affection he commanded. He leaves a widow and three children.

Bashir Abdelkarim Barghouti, politician, born 1931; died September 9 2000

webTitle: Gore and Bush tiptoe through nice-guy debate

fields.headline: Gore and Bush tiptoe through nice-guy debate
fields.standfirst:
Presidential hopefuls avoid any risk to images

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore and George W Bush acted as the image-conscious modern politicians they are and made risk avoidance their priority in Wednesday's second debate by US presidential contenders.
fields.body:
Al Gore and George W Bush acted as the image-conscious modern politicians they are and made risk avoidance their priority in Wednesday's second debate by US presidential contenders.

In an encounter notable for its civil tone, both men opted for the low-key, conversational style that television viewers prefer, and which is likely to leave Mr Bush holding on to a narrow lead in the polls as the race for the White House enters the home stretch.

Most political commentators scored the second of this year's three debates, which took place in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, as a draw: Mr Gore concentrated on avoiding the hectoring tone of last week's first debate; Mr Bush focused on appearing in command of the issues.

A series of instant surveys of the viewing audience suggested that Mr Bush made the better impression, but if reactions to the first debate in Boston are any guide, it will be some days before the overall impact is clear.

Mr Gore went into the debate after having his worst week on the campaign trail since the phase before the party conventions in August. He adopted a cautious and contrite approach - excessively so, some commentators thought after the debate.

He apologised for getting "some of the details wrong" in the first debate. "I can't promise that I will never get another detail wrong," Mr Gore said. "But I will promise you this ... that I will do my best if I'm elected president. I'll work my heart out to get the big things right for the American people."

Mr Bush, while cautious, appeared less chastened. "My case to the American people is if you're happy with inactivity, stay with the horse, the horse that's up there now," he said in some characteristically folksy closing remarks.

With foreign policy issues currently dominating the news agenda, even in the US, the Republican candidate had been intensively tutored for a series of international questions, with which he seemed markedly more at ease than on earlier occasions.

In fact, most of the first half of the debate was marked by polite agreement on a succession of issues, in particular foreign policy. Their responses mostly converged on issues such as the Middle East, the Balkans and international trade, although they sparred after Mr Bush insisted that "nation building" should not be a US foreign-policy objective.

Things got more confrontational, however, when domestic issues took the stage, especially when Mr Gore challenged Mr Bush for his record as the governor of Texas. He appeared to be carefully laying the foundation for a more aggressive onslaught in the coming days by accusing Mr Bush of neglecting issues such as healthcare and the environment.

"I know we have some disagreements on this, and I'm sorry to tell you that, you know, there is a record here, and Texas ranks 49th out of the 50 states in healthcare - in children with healthcare, in women with healthcare - and 50th for families with healthcare," Mr Gore said.

"If he's trying to allege that I'm a hard-hearted person and I don't care about children, he's absolutely wrong," Mr Bush responded. "The facts are that we're reducing the number of uninsured as a percentage of our population."

The last of this year's three presidential debates takes place next Tuesday in Missouri, one of the most hard-fought battleground states in this year's election.

Voters go to the polls on November 7.

webTitle: Officer to face Rwanda war charges

fields.headline: Officer to face Rwanda war charges
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A former lieutenant colonel in the Rwandan army, living in Britain as a temporary refugee, is to be extradited to face charges of genocide before the United Nations international criminal tribunal for Rwanda.
fields.body:
A former lieutenant colonel in the Rwandan army, living in Britain as a temporary refugee, is to be extradited to face charges of genocide before the United Nations international criminal tribunal for Rwanda.

Tharcisse Muvunyi, held on remand in Belmarsh prison since his arrest in February, is alleged to have carried out the murders of more than 100,000 Tutsis during the 1994 massacres in Rwanda.

In the high court yesterday his lawyers withdrew an application for habeus corpus after assurances from the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the registrar for the tribunal, which sits in Tanzania.

They agreed that if Mr Muvunyi is acquitted or discharged he will be escorted to the airport and flown to Britain, where his refugee status will be reviewed. But Mr Straw made it clear that he reserved the right to revoke Mr Muvunyi's present status of being allowed to remain in Britain until 2002 and to retain his discretion on any new application for refugee status.

Mr Muvunyi will fly to Tanzania in the next few days.

Mike Fisher, his solicitor, said: "My client is confident that he will be able to successfully defend himself against the charges. He feared that even if he was acquitted his life would be in danger."

Mr Muvunyi, 46, came to Britain in 1998 with his wife and three children and settled in Lewisham, south London. But it was not until his presence was exposed in the media and an international warrant for his arrest was issued by the tribunal that he was detained.

Mr Muvunyi was in charge of operations for the Rwandese armed forces in Butare and Gikongoro in April and May 1994 when the Hutu militias, backed by the police, started to slaughter Tutsis.

Among the allegations against him is that he directed the murder of 65,000 people in a Runyinya commune on a single day, April 21.

African Rights, a London-based human rights group, claims that there are more than 100 people, including soldiers and local government officials, who are ready to testify.

A spokesman for Amnesty International said yesterday: "The UK government should be congratulated for its cooperation with the tribunal. A speedy transfer of Mr Muvunyi offers the chance to investigate thoroughly some obscene crimes."

fields.headline: Crash inquiry delays threaten Concorde
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Concorde must be flying again before next summer or it will never fly again, government sources said last night.
fields.body:
Concorde must be flying again before next summer or it will never fly again, government sources said last night.

The view was expressed after the second Anglo-French meeting, in London, to discuss the future of the plane after the Air France Concorde crash in July which killed 113 people.

Government representatives expressed their concern at the French investigation system, which is dominated by a magistrate who must examine the technical evidence before further details can be discussed.

A Department of Transport statement said the meeting "was concerned that impediments to the technical accident investigation be removed".

Air France and British Airways want new certificates of air worthiness issued for their 12 Concordes by the end of the year to be ready for summer. They say any long delay would have a serious effect on profits.

webTitle: Lagerfeld sports elegance mixed with punk

fields.headline: Lagerfeld sports elegance mixed with punk
fields.trailText: If some Joe Bloggs said that a vest, jogging pants and sneakers, worn beneath a see-through lace flapper dress was the latest in fashion, would you believe him?
fields.body:
If some Joe Bloggs said that a vest, jogging pants and sneakers, worn beneath a see-through lace flapper dress was the latest in fashion, would you believe him?

In Paris yesterday, Karl Lagerfeld presented his vision for Chanel, spring/summer 2001 in which he fused funky sportswear with elegant tailoring and evening wear.

A credible look? It was lapped up by the assembled great and good of fashion.

Considering the hype surrounding Chanel's competitors over the past few years, with the hiring of many young designers to the major houses it is commendable that Lagerfeld has managed to retain any pulling power at all.

But with a venue the size of an airport hangar, an enviable selection of models and a fashion media-packed crowd, Lagerfeld proved that wisdom and experience still count for a lot. Even if the clothes did not impress, the sheer scale of the event was enough to take the breath away.

The catwalk was arranged in a series of shallow steps which towered high at one end and gradually tapered to ground level. The models appeared through a concealed trapdoor in small groups. As they set off down the catwalk it became clear that, like many other French designers this season, Lagerfeld was playing with contradiction.

The models looked beautiful but walked aggressively. Sheets of fine net around their eyes, which added a little 1940s modesty, were stamped with a fat black Chanel logo like random graffiti.

Even the music could not make up its mind. The theme from Love Story one minute, Blade Runner the next.

But the collection itself had the most fun. A pair of jeans-style dungarees in cream boucle wool; a pretty, broderie anglais gypsy top with a shiny plastic belt and cut-offs; a denim jacket reworked in black lace and worn with a matching multi-ruffle skirt and all of it criss-crossed with strings of elegant pearls that were slung over shoulders and wrapped around waists.

Occasionally, a more serious note crept in. A stiff gathered skirt fell to the knee in black quilted velvet and was worn with a sweet little cream silk blouse (very Coco) and the omnipresent Chanel suit was remodelled with a shorter jacket and a pleated skirt.

But mainly it was a little romantic and a little punk injected with a lot of confidence. Think early Madonna - somewhere between Like a Virgin and Desperately Seeking Susan.

Lagerfeld has proved that he still has the kudos to pull in an unusual fashion direction. But don't try this at home.

 The British designer Julien Macdonald has found a sponsor in the form of Gruppo Lineapiu, the Italian textile company and one of the largest yarn manufacturers. Lineapiu has bought 50% of the Julien Macdonald company and will produce and distribute Macdonald's autumn/winter 2001 ready-to-wear collection.

"I've been looking for a business partner for a long time," said Macdonald. "After this season's collection, sales just went mad and I needed to find a bigger manufacturer to meet the demand."

webTitle: Tokyo arrest breakthrough in hostess case

fields.headline: Tokyo arrest breakthrough in hostess case
fields.standfirst: Japanese police hold businessman and dig up garden after allegedly tracing last call from missing British woman to his mobile phone
fields.trailText: Japanese detectives investigating the disappearance of the Tokyo nightclub hostess Lucie Blackman arrested an Osaka estate agent yesterday and searched his properties.
fields.body:
Japanese detectives investigating the disappearance of the Tokyo nightclub hostess Lucie Blackman arrested an Osaka estate agent yesterday and searched his properties.

Joji Ohara, 48, who reportedly has a penchant for expensive cars and foreign women, was apprehended at a flat in Akasaka, central Tokyo.

He is believed to have been a customer at the Casablanca hostess bar, where Ms Blackman, a former British Airways stewardess, was working until she went missing on July 1.

Detectives have yet to make a statement, but Japanese media reports said a call made by Ms Blackman on the day she disappeared had been traced to Mr Ohara's mobile phone. The 22-year-old from Sevenoaks, Kent, had called a friend to say a customer was taking her to the seaside.

"I can't believe he would be involved in something like this," said a neighbour, who has known Mr Ohara for 30 years. "He was always very polite - a regular Japanese businessman." Other neighbours, however, said the suspect was a mysterious figure who had not been seen at the property for several months.

Mr Ohara is the son of a wealthy Osaka family. He is a law graduate of the elite Keio University and spent three years studying in the United States. His business and private lives, however, are a con fusion of false names and dummy addresses.

According to Japanese media reports, Mr Ohara was a regular visitor to foreign hostess bars in Roppongi - which include the Casablanca - where he would run up large tabs under false names.

The owner of one bar, interviewed by TV Asahi, said: "He was a quiet type who never joined in with karaoke or dancing. He was a bit odd."

At the Casablanca, which has changed its name to the Green Grass, an employee denied that anyone called Ohara had ever been a customer.

His arrest is the clearest sign of a breakthrough in the three-month investigation, which has until now been focused on the possibility that Ms Blackman may have been abducted by sado-masochists. One suspect interviewed by police later hanged himself in a room full of fetish videos.

Ms Blackman's mother Jane said she was relieved that police appear to be making progress. "I feel a mixture of cautious optimism and terrible fear," she said yesterday.

webTitle: Comment: DJ Taylor on the Nobel laureate for literature

fields.headline: Politics, prose and the prize
fields.standfirst: As usual no one's heard of the Nobel laureate, but that's our problem
fields.trailText: As usual no one's heard of the Nobel laureate, but that's our problem
fields.body:
At first sight Gao Xingjian, winner of this year's $1m cheque from the Swedish Academy, looks a thoroughly respectable Nobel laureate for literature. A 60-year-old Chinese expatriate living in Paris (and therefore presumably representing the cause of "freedom"), a novelist, translator, dramatist, director and critic, Xingjian is apparently the creator of Chinese oral theatre as well the author of a classic novel, Soul Mountain. I have never heard of him and neither - shameful to relate - had anyone else whose opinion I canvassed in the half-hour or so following the announcement, but then neither had many westerners heard of the Egyptian novelist Naguib Mahfouz before his triumph in 1988 or Polish poet Wislawa Symborska in 1996.

Xingjian's emergence as the first literature laureate of the 21st century comes at a bad time for the jury that makes the awards. The members of the Swedish Academy who take these decisions - behind closed doors, often at snail-like speed - have been suffering a bad press recently. One of their number, former secretary Lars Gyllesten, has even produced an exposé of stitch-ups, cronyism and, allegedly, the hounding to death of the 1974 winner Harry Martinson, who eventually committed hara-kiri with a pair of scissors at a Stockholm clinic.

In fact, claims of this sort have been made at many times over the past half-century: throughout the 80s one sometimes imagined that the "Graham Greene excluded again" headlines were kept permanently set in type by British newspapers. But then, it would be surprising, given the nature of the judging panel and the conditions in which it operates, if some odd choices weren't made every now and then. To look back over the winners of the past 60 years or so is to turn up half-a-dozen laureates who won for reasons that had little to do with literary merit. John Galsworthy and Pearl S Buck, quintessential middlebrow talents, received the prize in 1932 and 1938 respectively. Sir Winston Churchill won in 1953, presumably for services to world democracy. Even with writers of the stature of Alexander Solzhenitsyn (1970), there is a suspicion that the prize was rewarding dissidence rather than genius.

In very bad years, the academy's choice has boiled down to a kind of United Nations-inspired gesturing, picking some language or nation not previously represented, or deserving of exposure, and seeing what can be fixed. This year's pre-announcement rumours, for example, insisted that the committee wanted an African, and that the front-runners were the Nigerian-born Ben Okri and the Somali writer Nuruddin Farah.

Similarly, back in 1988 much was made of the fact that Mahfouz was the first Arab laureate. Mahfouz's elevation, made at the height of Arab-Israeli peace manoeuvrings, was a fine example of a literature prize suddenly taking on an unlooked-for political significance. This process wasn't without its ironies. Previously held at arms' length by an Arab establishment suspicious of his western leanings and dubious moral teachings, Mahfouz suddenly found himself being put on postage stamps and having his slightest utterance decoded by vigilant diplomats. Even his presence at a reading given by some Syrian poets at around this time was quickly marked down as a sign of a thaw in Egyptian/Syrian relations.

Gratifyingly, though, this kind of globe-trawling often turns up thoroughly deserving winners, whose works go on to win an appreciative international readership. Mahfouz, whose Cairo trilogy (published to huge acclaim in the UK in the early 90s) has been compared to Dickens, is an obvious example. Equally, no one could argue that Kenzaburo Oe (1994) or José Saramago (1998) weren't enormously significant (though in the UK insufficiently known) figures for whom a Nobel prize provided a final, validating boost.

Inevitably, the public monument status that necessarily accompanies the laureateship seldom does much for a writer's career. However tranquil the breezes that blow around its summit, Mount Olympus rarely produces congenial working conditions, and the later careers of laureates chosen for predominantly political reasons have often been slightly shaky. At best, the process produces a warm feeling of national solidarity, combined with the wondrous sensation of books somehow mattering at last, for however short a season (even the Cairo taxi-drivers have heard of Mahfouz); at worst the thought of Buggins's turn.

To set against this is the tribe of international writers who are never going to win any sort of prize, either because their countries have no wider significance, because the academy has never heard of them, or in the case of certain western writers perhaps because it has heard too much about them. Gao Xingjian, who might just be available in a British bookshop or two (inspection reveals that HarperCollins published Soul Mountain in 1999), may well turn out to be an exemplary winner. All the same, one imagines that a good many critics, confronted by news of this year's choice, will be making their usual baffled visit to the literature-in-translation shelf.

 DJ Taylor is a novelist, critic and biographer. He is currently writing a life of George Orwell.

 comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Manufacturing shows growing signs of recovery

fields.headline: Manufacturing shows growing signs of recovery
fields.trailText: Industry leaders hailed signs yesterday that manufacturing is pulling out of the doldrums but said the sector was still too fragile to withstand higher borrowing costs.
fields.body:
Industry leaders hailed signs yesterday that manufacturing is pulling out of the doldrums but said the sector was still too fragile to withstand higher borrowing costs.

Manufacturing activity improved over the past three months after two quarters of slower growth, according to the British Chambers of Commerce. Sales at home and abroad improved and confidence picked up for the first time in three quarters.

But, while industry is more upbeat about prospects, confidence in the service sector is declining. Firms there reported that orders grew at the slowest pace since the second quarter of 1999, but analysts said activity was still robust.

"Given the strong relationship between BCC survey evidence and official service sector data, these figures will provide ammunition to those hawks on the monetary policy committee who argue that further rate hikes are needed so that the economy can accommodate the chancellor's pre-election spending boom," said James Carrick at ABN-Amro.

But the BCC warned that further rate rises would be damaging. "It is too early to say that UK manufacturing is firmly on the road to recovery, but there are tentative signs that the sector's position is strengthening," said Ian Peters, deputy director general of the BCC.

"The return to growth in export activity justifies the period of interest rate stability, but sterling remains at a level against the euro that is still un competitive for many UK manufacturers."

The BCC said the improvement in the sector looked set to continue over coming months, even though manufacturers face rising charges for fuels and raw materials. Surging crude oil prices and a plunge in the pound's value against the dollar, in which most raw materials are priced, are putting the highest level of pressure on firms since the second quarter of 1997.

It remained difficult for firms in both sectors to raise prices because of competitive pressures and the strength of sterling, the BCC said, meaning there was little immediate inflationary danger from the higher costs.

Industry and service sector firms took on staff at the fastest rate for more than two years over the past quarter, and many reported they were experiencing recruitment difficulties. But, despite a shortage of workers, pay pressures eased over the quarter.

webTitle: Burberry gives GUS a bumper check

fields.headline: Burberry gives GUS a bumper check
fields.standfirst: Transformation of raincoat with plaid lining to high fashion item boosts sales by 30%
fields.trailText: The relaunch of the Burberry label is fast becoming a textbook lesson in how to ramp a brand.
fields.body:
The relaunch of the Burberry label is fast becoming a textbook lesson in how to ramp a brand.

Three years ago, Burberry meant just one thing: outdated raincoats with dull plaid linings that were a firm favourite with middle class Home Counties ladies and middle-aged City gents.

Now that plaid is the hottest of high fashion, adorning everything from spike-heeled boots to bandanas, and a must-have in the wardrobes of rock stars and royalty. Kate Moss, Meg Matthews, Nicole Appleton and even Prince William are all big fans of the Burberry beige.

The label is part of the Great Universal Stores catalogue empire and the jewel in its crown. In a trading update yesterday, GUS reported Burberry sales up 38%.

A large store has just opened in New Bond Street, London, another will open in Tokyo's Ginza in December and the label's New York store is doubling its floorspace.

"It is absolutely storming", said GUS finance director David Tyler. The Burberry brand was always big in Japan, but now, he said, that success is being repeated in other Asian markets, the US and Europe.

When former GUS chief Lord Wolfson hired Saks Fifth Avenue president Rose-Marie Bravo to revive Burberry in 1997, he suggested the business had no long-term future inside GUS but it needed fattening up before it could be sold. Now it would be attractive to luxury brand groups such as LVMH and Gucci. Mr Tyler said: "I can't deny people ring us up". But he insisted there were no plans to cash in on its success.

In the rest of the GUS business - which is focused firmly on the opposite end of the social scale to Burberry - the Argos catalogue shops posted an 11% like-for-like sales increase. The best performers were furniture and mobile phones, and GUS said the new Additions clothing catalogue was also performing well.

But the traditional home shopping catalogues are still having a tough time. Sales dipped 5% in the first half after a 7% slide last year. Mr Tyler said GUS recognised it was in long term decline -"you can't push water uphill" - and that the Argos Additions catalogue, which uses the same stock as the home shopping catalogues, was "an important part of the way forward".

When GUS bought Argos after a bitter takeover battle, many analysts criticised the group for overpaying, but Mr Tyler said the Argos sales figures now proved his firm had been right: "Where would GUS be today without Argos?"

The group's Experian credit information business reported sales up 4%.

The shares, which fell from 850p to 330p last year, closed down 1.5p at 454.5p. Analysts are split on the outlook, with ABN Amro and Williams de Broe rating the shares a buy while SG Warburg repeated its "underperform" view.

LVMH yesterday said sales of its portfolio of top labels, which range from TAG Heuer to Dom Perignon and Hard Candy, climbed 35% to €2.9bn (£1.7bn) in the third quarter of this year. September sales hit an all-time record.

Fashion and leather goods sales increased 46% to €812m, with the highlight being Louis Vuitton. LVMH said Celine, Loewe, Kenzo and Givenchy also performed well and Fendi had been "excellent".

But champagne was still hung over from the pre-millennium buying spree.

fields.headline: Britain 'spying on allies'
fields.trailText: A parliamentary inquiry in France has criticised Britain's role in a US-run global electronic surveillance system it calls "a real threat to public and individual liberties".
fields.body:
A parliamentary inquiry in France has criticised Britain's role in a US-run global electronic surveillance system it calls "a real threat to public and individual liberties".

America and Britain set up Echelon in the cold war to intercept military communications in the eastern bloc. But Arthur Paecht, the inquiry's chairman, said the system was now routinely used to intercept economic and industrial information, including messages between firms in EU member states, and between private individuals that are supposedly protected in law.

"Echelon's mission is to monitor every message in the world," Mr Paecht said. "It is not improbable that the information collected is used for political and economic ends, even against certain Nato members."

webTitle: Jobless total in some areas 'twice official level'

fields.headline: Jobless total in some areas 'twice official level'
fields.trailText: Government claims of a buoyant economy spreading prosperity throughout the country were dealt a blow yesterday when a new survey claimed that official figures underestimated the real level of unemployment in parts of Britain.
fields.body:
Government claims of a buoyant economy spreading prosperity throughout the country were dealt a blow yesterday when a new survey claimed that official figures underestimated the real level of unemployment in parts of Britain.

Despite employment at a 20 year high, a report from the Industrial Society points to large numbers of people in old industrial areas, and parts of inner London, falling outside statistics.

It says unemployment in the poorest areas is 10% higher than official figures suggest - although they still put the jobless level at twice the national average, currently 3.6%.

In these jobless "hot spots", particularly Liverpool, Middlesbrough, Hackney and Lewisham, up to 12 people are chasing every available job.

The report will undermine government attempts to highlight a successful economy under New Labour, with claimant unemployment expected to fall below one million over the next few weeks. More damagingly for Tony Blair, it further highlights the north-south jobs divide. With recent opinion polls showing fragile support for Labour in the party's heartlands, ministers are preparing a series of initiatives to play up the government's determination to bridge a divide they sought to play down until recently.

Yesterday's report argues that current job creation strategies will not deliver Gordon Brown's elusive goal of full employment because welfare-to-work policies are not tackling the "jobs gap." This embraces people, particularly women, who are looking for work but are not covered by the unemployment figures.

The report complements studies undertaken by both the TUC, and the Unemployment Unit, a charity which monitors labour trends.

The unit argues that the real figures, including people trapped in part-time jobs because full-time work is not available, stand at 13.7% - or around 4m workers. But in areas like the north east they rise to around 17%.

While claimant unemployment, based on people drawing benefit, stands at 3.6% - or just over one million - a wider International Labour Organi sation (ILO) figure, introduced when Labour came to power, puts the level at 5.4%, or 1.6 m.

Paul Vivand, senior research officer at the Unemployment Unit, said that the level of "hidden" unemployment in Britain was much higher than in the rest of the European Union. British counting methods were flawed because they were consistently "gender biased," excluding hundreds of thousands of women.

"Women with a partner cannot be officially classed as long-term unemployed because it is stipulated that a partner has to assume responsibility after six months (when jobseeker's allowance ends)."

Yesterday's report urges ministers to adopt a new strategy embracing "attachment partnerships" which keep track of people once they have found new work.

Max Nathan, the report's author, said full employment would not happen without transforming government policy. "We need a richer jobs strategy to take people into employment, support them throughout their working lives, and open up the market opportunities that deprived neighbourhoods represent."

Paul Vivand, senior research officer at the Unemployment Unit, said that the level of "hidden" unemployment in Britain was much higher than in the rest of the European Union. British counting methods were flawed because they were consistently "gender biased," excluding hundreds of thousands of women. "Women with a partner cannot be officially classed as long-term unemployed because it is stipulated that a partner has to assume responsibility after six months (when jobseeker's allowance ends)." Yesterday's report urges ministers to adopt a new strategy embracing "attachment partnerships" which keep track of people once they have found new work. Max Nathan, the report's author, said full employment would not happen without transforming government policy. "We need a richer jobs strategy to take people into employment, support them throughout their working lives, and open up the market opportunities that deprived neighbourhoods represent."

webTitle: Wenger says no to England job

fields.headline: Wenger says no to England job
fields.trailText: The perilously short list of potential replacements for Kevin Keegan as England manager thinned last night when Arsène Wenger emphatically ruled himself out of the running.
fields.body:
The perilously short list of potential replacements for Kevin Keegan as England manager thinned last night when Arsène Wenger emphatically ruled himself out of the running.

The news comes as a major blow, though hardly a surprise, to the FA who may have been prepared to override public concerns about the appointment of a foreign coach in order to secure the Arsenal manager's services.

But Wenger said: "I will respect my contract with Arsenal, which runs until 2002, and it does not matter what proposals I receive from any club or country. The England job is an attractive job but somebody else will be taking it - not me."

Wenger, who has previously expressed distaste for coaching at international level, is expected to hold a press conference today to explain why he is not interested in the England position. The Arsenal chairman Peter Hill-Wood said on Wednesday that the FA could "forget any thoughts about asking him [Wenger] to be the next England manager" after banning the Frenchman from the touchline for 12 games.
